Title: “Saree makes me feel sexy”: Mugdha Godse
Content: - Fashion to me is - Aesthetically comfortable.- Five essentials of a woman’s wardrobe - One white dress, one black/red dress, a well-fitted pair of denim, white shirt and a jacket.- My everyday outfit - Yoga pants, a top and a jacket – all Lulu Lemon.- My shopping strategy - If you need anything buy it... or else don’t waste your money. This, I learnt after burning a lot of money. I am a conscious shopper – nowadays.- A grooming tip for women - No facial hair and keep your body moisturised all the time.- Favourite style hack - A colourful scarf can complete an unfinished look.- A fashion trend I hate - Pointy pencil heels.- A fashion trend I love - Oversized clothes.- Biggest fashion blunder I have committed - Not that I know of – fashion blunders are always noticed by the opposite party!- My style philosophy - Stay comfortable and be confident of what you wear.- My must-have grooming essential - A plucker for eyebrows and tampons.- A fashion advice that I swear by - Waterproof mascara during monsoons and G-strings or seamless undergarments under a tight dress or pants.-A skincare advice that my mom passed on to me - Always clean your face before sleeping and keep wet wipes in your bag.- My take on airport looks | Nonsense! One needs to be comfortable and most of the airport looks are turning into mini red carpets. They should create a new trend of comfortable clothing for airport – sneakers instead of heels, easy sports wear or breathable fabrics for flights, etc.- Paparazzi is… - Visual conduit between celebrities and audience.- My fitness regimen - Ashtanga yoga in the morning and TRX/cardio in evening.- My guilty indulgence | Keeps changing but if I have to pick, it would be mainly clothes, especially sarees.- One word for me - I don’t know but I would like it to be ‘elegant’- What makes you feel sexy - A saree-Ultimate fashion destination - Red carpet-Most stylish person in showbiz - I like Anushka Sharma’s dressing style – very chic and elegant

Title: When power lunches get gourmet
Content: Military hotels are bit of an urban legend among the food lovers of Bengaluru. They are described as places that are spartan, functional and great for eating non-vegetarian food; mutton in particular. The most famous of which is the Shivaji Military Hotel. The most famous dish is the donne biryani, so called because of the areca nut palm leaf in which it is served. This is similar to the Dindigul biryani of Tamil Nadu , and is made with the same short-grained seeraga samba rice.The reason why I call it an ‘urban legend’ is that they are not easy for an itinerant traveller to reach. Most are located in places such as Jayanagar, Malleswaram and Cottonpet, the more traditional areas of the city which are not that ‘buzzy’ today, especially with the city expanding its borders. I had been meaning to try out one for a while, but the logistics never worked out. They were either too far or shut by the time I would finish work.Some open in the morning and people queue up as early as 8 am to get their fill of biryani and other meaty treats! These are Hindu-run places and hence mutton is the meat of choice. Beef and pork are not served. Seafood has made its presence felt and so has chicken; not that the owners are too happy about the latter. I finally made it to a military hotel when I recently went to the Ranganna Military Hotel, which was established in 1964. The owner is a gentleman named Ranganna, and he still supervises the grinding of the spice mixes every day. His wife supervises the cooking. Ranganna’s son, Sunil, helps run the business.I must say that the experience at Ranganna did not turn out to be what I had expected my first military hotel visit to have been like. Ranganna is large, neat and clean. Nothing like the grimy ambiance that I had prepared myself for. Nor was the clientele male dominated. I had read that military hotels had initially sprung up to feed men from the interiors of Karnataka, who had come to work in the city. Other theories say they were established to feed the Maratha soldiers, or those from the British colonial army. Hence the name ‘military’. The crowd at Ranganna on a Sunday evening (when the traffic was less) consisted of both genders, panned across age groups and social classes. Bengaluru local, Somanna Muthanna, of the Soul Company, recommended Ranganna to me, saying its more welcoming of outsiders, apart from the fact that the locals swear by its food. A sentiment echoed by Divya Prabhakar, who runs the Bengaluru Oota Company along with Vishal Shetty. Divya belongs to the local Gowda community as do the owners of Ranganna. Over a lovely meal featuring Gowda and Mangalorean dishes that I had at their restaurant the next day, Divya said that she often goes to Ranganna to eat.I went to Ranganna with two fellow Bengalis, Diganta Chakraborty and Arghya Sanyal, and we were mesmerised by the excellent quality of mutton served and the home cooking-like feel that the food had. Our order that evening was a nose to tail mutton affair that included tender mutton chops, liver and brain fry, roughly minced mutton gojju (a thick curry), mutton biryani (no donne leaf here) and an egg curry from the poultry side. Despite being a no-frills place, the subtlety in the spicing of each and the distinct flavours that they offered explained why this 56- year-old restaurant remains so popular.It reminded me of places such as the Swadhin Bharat Hotel and the pice hotels of Kolkata and Kshirsagar, Sindhudurg Hotel, Chaitanya and the many Malvani restaurants of Mumbai. These restaurants too had come up originally to feed their home cuisines to migrant workers in these cities. Are there more such examples across India? Please write in at www.timeskitchentales and tell us about them.How can you be a part of this? Keep a lookout for this space – where we will introduce fresh topics of discussion every week. Find us at: www.timeskitchentales.com and share your stories. The most inspiring stories from the repository of ‘Times Kitchen Tales’ will be shared in this column.

Title: Mirror, mirror…
Content: For most of us, the bylanes of Janpath in Delhi (or any other street shop in your city) were the first places where one came in contact with mirror work. The sellers, ostensibly from Gujarat, displayed their wares on the road. It was our first introduction to sheesha embroidery and for most it stays that – a roadside buy, a cheap deal, a steal. But from the streets to high fashion, mirror work seems to be changing its image.Leading the pack is, of course, designer duo Abu Jani & Sandeep Khosla who have extensively used mirror work with contemporary colours and cuts in their repertoire. Khosla says that the duo is passionate about Indian crafts legacy and their aim is not just to incorporate it into their design expression but to reinvent a technique to a brand new standard of excellence and beauty. Jani adds, “All of us in India have grown up seeing mirror work whether it is in cholis or torans or textiles. The use of mirror in architecture was also a huge influence and inspiration for us.”For Jani-Khosla, the rooms at City Palace, Jaipur and the spectacular dome at Amber fort were the inspiration behind using this reflective art in their work. Embroideries from Rajasthan and Gujarat are seen on designer Ashish’s spring-summer 2020 on denim, dresses and cotton jersey tracksuits. Designer Arpita Mehta who has been using the craft for some time now says, “My favourite part about mirror work is that it has a natural sheen and there is something extremely traditional about it but at the same time it’s also bohemian. I personally have always loved a bohemian touch to an Indian outfit. I feel that this is something that sets it apart from the many traditional crafts we have in India.”Her own twist to it is to use it with cut work and go for pastel colours. She uses resham threads, tiny kadana beads as well as kasab which automatically makes the embroidery look extremely rich. “The craft can be used in multiple ways, like in bags, shoes, jackets, lehengas, or shararas,” she adds. Agrees designer Ridhima Bhasin who says that mirror work is way more versatile than it gets credit for. A fundamental part of her designs, she uses it in monochromatic ensembles in subtle hues to underplay the effect. She uses smaller pieces for the mirror work to make it more wearable. The key lies in keeping the mirror work minimal yet impactful.According to designers what harms its image is the availability of cheap options that use plastic instead of real mirrors, cheap threads and machine embroidery. Mehta says, “One should never go for the cheaper work, as once you do get into that kind of mirror work it becomes less classy.” Even weaving a small piece of mirror onto a fabric requires a specific type of stitch and co-ordination. Bhasin adds that the pattern and stitch changes according to the shape of the mirror and how it blends into the over-all design.It is not for the faint-hearted as its impact is audacious. But people are now open to experimenting. To wear it for a day look, opt for pastel kurtas or go for a dupatta. Bhasin suggests wearing your basic tee and jeans combination with mirror work earring studs, or mirror work juttis. Handbags and belts are the simplest way to work it in.l Sheesha or mirror embroidery is traced back to 17th century in Iran and was brought to India by travellers during the Mughal eral Mirrors are affixed with cross-stitch embroidery that provides it a casingl Most common mirror shape is circular, but other geometric shapes are used tool Mirror work was patronised by the states of Rajasthan, Gujarat and Haryana. Different communities have differentstyles. Like jats of Banni use mirrors of varying sizes and shapes; while garari jats use tiny mirrors on the yokeSource: utsavpedia.com

Title: This will be a 100% saami padam: RJ Balaji
Content: Following his success as a writer with LKG, RJ Balaji is now giving finishing touches to his directorial debut Mookuthi Amman , which stars Nayanthara in the lead. While there are reports that this film, co-directed by NJ Saravanan, will be a satire on devotional films, just like how LKG was a political satire, the actor-director denies it.“This will be a 100% saami padam,” begins Balaji, and adds, “It’s not a satire on the genre. It will have all the elements that were there in the devotional films that we grew up watching. It will be a nostalgic trip, but there will also be a takeaway that is relevant, especially in this present times.”Nayanthara, he says, plays the Goddess, and will appear for most parts of the film. “It is definitely not an extended cameo,” he assures. Talking about why he picked her for this role, he reveals, “I wanted someone with a larger-than-life presence to play the role of the goddess. I did not write this role particularly for Nayanthara, though I wanted someone of her stature... an actress with that majestic screen presence. I’m very hesitant when it comes to narrating scripts. I do not want it to become a dharmasankatam for me or the person saying no, so I narrate mainly to people who I am close to and those who I think are likely to say yes.”He calls Nayanthara “a good friend” and reveals that it was the actress herself who finally gave him the courage to narrate the story to her. “One day, she randomly called me asking why I haven’t narrated any script for her while I have been discussing my scripts with many others. This was around 5pm. So, by 7pm, I met her for the narration and she gave her OK to this project by 7.30pm, saying she liked her role very much,” he elaborates.The male lead’s role will be played by Balaji himself while Urvashi, Mouli, Smruthi Venkat (of Thadam fame) and Visaaranai actor Ajay Ghosh play crucial roles. “There are also several cameos by popular actors. I don’t want to reveal them all now, though a few of the actors have let the secret out,” he wryly remarks.Girishh Gopalakrishnan of Aval fame is composing the music for this film which has cinematography by Dinesh Krishnan, who has shot films like Soodhu Kavvum and Thaanaa Serndha Koottam. Pariyerum Perumal’s editor RK Selva, stunt choreographer Stunt Silva and lyricist Pa Vijay are also part of the crew. “Natpukkaga Vignesh Shivan has written a song,” adds Balaji.On the title, he says that it was quite a random choice. “I had gone to Nagercoil, and I liked the place, where you stumble into a religious place everywhere you go. I had visited Mookuthi Amman temple there, and I felt I could have that as the backdrop. I then did some research on the temple and the town itself and it fit what was in my script. Plus, when we discussed this with the other titles that I had shortlisted, Mookuthi Amman turned out to be everyone’s favourite,” he says.

Title: Low TRP rating brings Paapa Pandu 2 to an end
Content: Fans of the popular series Paapa Pandu, who keenly followed the escapades of Pandu and Pacho, were thrilled when it was revived for a second installment. Directed by Sihi Kahi Chandru , it brought back Shalini and Chidanand in lead roles, along with Shruthi Ramesh and Sourabh Kulkarni . But only a year-and-a-half later, Paapa Pandu 2 has now come to an abrupt end In its new avatar, the serial followed Pacho, as she attempts to control her husband Pandu, and son Punda . According to channel sources, “The show has been wrapped up owing to low TRP ratings.” Actress Shruti Ramesh , who played Nimmi on the show, took to social media to write about this development. “My inbox is flooded with all ur messages as u all were asking me about Paapa Pandu, yes, the serial has ended. I miss everything about Paapa Pandu, so much of emotions attached. I will miss being Nimmi which has given me memories that will be cherished throughout my life, and, I will always be grateful for this opportunity and thank you all for being with us throughout this beautiful journey. I believe every end has a new beginning very soon I’ll come up with a new project to entertain you people, keep supporting and blessing the way u guys have done till date. thank you (sic).”

Title: After 35 years, Bharathirajaa’s Muthal Mariyathai actor returns to Kollywood
Content: Deepan, the actor who played a young goatherd in love in Bharathirajaa ’s Muthal Mariyathai , will now be seen playing one of the lead characters in C/O Kadhal, the Tamil remake of the acclaimed Telugu film C/O Kancharapalem.“I spotted Deepan at the Chennai airport and felt his look suited the character perfectly. I did not know then that he was once an actor. I approached him and asked if he would act in my film, and he told me that he wasn’t interested. But we exchanged numbers, and I pursued him for a month before getting him on board,” recounts Hemambar Jasthi, who is making his directorial debut with this film.Hemambar says that he has changed Deepan’s look a lot for this film. “He was a little stout and I asked him to lose some weight. We also changed his hair style and moustache,” he informs. The director reveals that he conducted a workshop for Deepan for three months to help the actor get familiarised with the character. “All these years, he was running educational institutions, and wasn’t following cinema. So, I had to explain everything to him and get him up to date in terms of technique. He was quite cooperative. In fact, on location, I made him do precisely what we had done in the workshop,” he says.Deepan’s romantic interest is played by Sonia Giri, a politician from Kerala. “I came across her profile on Facebook. She’s a former corporator and a district president of a political party. She, too, was reluctant and asked me to seek someone in the Malayalam film industry. I went to her place, Irinjalakuda, near Thrissur, told her that the character is that of a Malayalee and she looks exactly as how I imagined this character to be, and ultimately convinced her,” he says.

Title: Don’t feed sickness
Content: When an animal, such as a dog or cat, is sick or unwell, its first natural instinct is to refuse food. Their body automatically cuts down appetite till they recover. They may drink water, but nothing else. This is body’s intelligence taking over to heal and recover.Humans aren’t any different. At least, intuitively. All of us are products of nature and we have been designed the same. When we call in sick, the first thing that happens is that our appetites shut down too. Our taste of mouth changes and our sensitivity to smell and taste is numbed. This is our body’s intelligence and subtle biofeedback trying to tell us that it’s time we give our body some rest.This is fasting in a way and has been practised since the longest time – across all religions. Fasting is inbuilt in us and is considered medicinal if you actually go back and read its history. It is our body’s uncomplicated way of cleaning and healing. Unfortunately, we have moved too far from nature and our natural instincts. We are constantly eating and munching even when sick, thereby compromising our own immunity and masking the inbuilt mechanism to heal.When we take a break from eating, we put our digestive system to rest first. Our digestive system utilises 80% of our body’s energy, leaving only 20% for repair, recycling, eliminating. Now when we slow down our eating, we redirect that huge chunk of energy to healing, repair, immunity boost, which our digestive system would consume otherwise. That’s our immunity working for us. The healing or prevention of a disease revolves around immunity. The stronger the immunity, the faster the recovery process; and fasting helps activate our immunity. Major events that happen when we fast, especially, a dry fasting (abstaining from food and water for certain time):- Stem cell activation and regeneration begins.- Body gets rid of its own toxins.- Body tries to sacrifice its sickest cells through the process of autophagy – a natural process and also one that occurs in cases of fasting. Autophagy also helps prevent/manage cancer and plays a vital role in degrading cells infected by bacteria and viruses.- It’s good to go through symptoms of lack of appetite or aversion to foods when sick because it indicates our body doing the right things at the right time. Unfortunately, we have become so addicted to comfort and constant eating, that it has become a tough job to actually gauge our true physical hunger.Through our practise, we see so many cases where people have fasted their way through sickness – from a common cold, fever to obesity, joint pains, hair fall, skin problems, inflammation, bloating, digestive issues. These people eat only when their bodies ask for nutrition. Of course, in certain cases, fasting has to be monitored by a health expert.by Luke CoutinhoHolistic Lifestyle Coach-Integrative Medicine

Title: It’s destination UP now for Kannada filmmakers
Content: The Kannada film industry seems to have found a new go-to spot as far as shooting locations go. And, no, they are not going globe-trotting. A growing tribe of filmmakers are exploring Uttar Pradesh now. After Roberrt, Banaras, Daali and Madagaja have also set part of their narratives in the state. The ease of securing subsidies and permissions and the prospect of fresh locations are reasons cited by them for heading to north India. Tharun Sudhir , whose Darshan-starrer Roberrt has had a significant part of the film set in Lucknow, explains, “The Uttar Pradesh government promotes film shoots and procuring permissions is easy. They do not have a local film industry, so the people there are always opening up their homes for us. What has helped is that in the past two years, quite a few Bollywood films have had UP backdrops, which has set precedence for us.”Yogesh, who is backing Daali, agrees and adds “Permissions to shoot in Uttar Pradesh can be procured provided one plans the schedules well. A good line producer or agent who has understood the system is what one needs, as getting permission to shoot at heritage sites can be time consuming.”Director Jayathirtha , who shot his film Banaras there, says, “The locations have a lot of heritage and history, which is very inspiring.” Filmmaker Prabhu Srinivas , who shot Daali in Lucknow. “The audience has also got tired of seeing the same old locations in India. Cities like Lucknow and Varanasi offer a change for us and the audience,” he says.Filmmakers who shoot and promote places in Uttar Pradesh get a subsidy of 25%, if over 50% of the film is set there, provided it is approved by the Uttar Pradesh Film Bandhu. Earlier, Kannada filmmakers headed Mumbai for films with a North India connect, as it made logistical sense, considering that it is home to a film industry and has studios. Rajasthan and Gujarat were only options for song shoots.- Roberrt – major portion set in Lucknow- Daali – major part of the film set in Lucknow- Banaras - entire film is set in Varanasi-l Madagaja - a part of the film is set in Varanasi

Title: Poops, I did it again!
Content: The crate should be of right size to accommodate your pet comfortably. Your pet should be able sit, stand and move freely. If the crate size is too big then there is a possibility that the pet would use just one corner to relieve her or himself and sleep at the other.Generally, your pup would let you know s/he has an urge to relieve her/himself by whining, or scratching the floor. It’s important to take your pet out as soon as he calls, else it may lead to mishaps, and eventually, your pup would feel this behaviour is acceptable.Dogs, are by nature, clean animals. They like to keep their living space clean and never soil the place they sleep in.Choose a fixed spot in the house that’s acceptable for the puppy to use; put a paper or puppy pad. This might be useful when the pup is too young and has to pee or poop too often. Or, when you have a busy schedule and can’t take the puppy out often. Important thing to note is to remove the soiled paper/potty pad and clean the area thoroughly so that the pup doesn’t feel it’s his only permanent spot to relieve. You can gradually train your pup to move out of the house as he grows up.Once you establish your pet’s potty schedule, just make a note to take him out for quick walks. Let your pet out as soon as the pup whines and lets you know. Do not wait too long else your pet might be in trouble. Some ground rules to follow while potty training your pup:It requires a lot of patience and time from us to get the pet habitual to all daily routines and get the desired behaviour. The most important aspect is to get your puppy on the right schedule. This could be:l First thing in the morningl After every meal/drinking waterl After naps or play timel Before sleep at nightReward your pet by praising him or give him a treat whenever s/he has done the right thing. This would motivate him and reinforce right behaviour. Never scold your pup if there are any accidents. Keep your calm and clean the spot thoroughly to remove all stains. There are several enzymatic cleaners and sprays available that eliminate the stains and odour. This would prevent your pet from using the same spot next time around.The tummy of the pups (4-6 weeks old) is still immature and cannot handle too much food. It is important to not feed them too much. Also, increase his feeding schedule by 3-5 times a day. Choose a high quality and easily-digestible diet for your pet – one that would be easy on his tummy.— Dr Arun, VeterinarianAre you a proud pet parent? Have a cute cat story to share? Maybe your guinea pig is giving you trouble? Whatever is your creature companion, we are here to listen to you. Send your photos, queries and stories to timeslife@timesgroup.com

Title: A stylish launch for a bar in Bengaluru
Content:
Four Seasons Hotel Bengaluru recently showcased its much awaited bar — Copitas — to the swish set of the city. A select bevy of guests were seen enjoying the glamourous atmosphere of this bar. Copitas is a stylish cocktail bar alongside the Asian restaurant , Far & East on the hotel’s Level 21. Open from 5 pm, it is the perfect place to witness a sunset with a bespoke cocktail or artisanal Copa G&Ts. The who’s who of the city were present at the launch of the bar. Prasad Bidapa , Lakshmi Hande Puri, Kevin Oliver, Deepa Rao Acharya and David Whitbread were among the guests who were present.

Here's a closer look at the people who attended the event:

https://photogallery.indiatimes.com/events/bangalore/a-stylish-launch-for-a-bar-in-bengaluru/articleshow/74459406.cms

Title: A stylish launch for a bar in Bengaluru
Content: A day after her release from Byculla jail, Rhea Chakraborty was snapped at the Bandra police station. According to one of the bail conditions, the actress has been asked by the Hihg court to mark her presence at the nearest Police Station from her residence anytime between 11:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. to show her availability. Rhea will be following this protocol for a period of ten days from her release.

Title: Romance of the jharokha
Content: There’s something romantic about jharokhas. For the uninitiated, it’s the overhanging windows with an enclosed balcony that hails from Rajasthan. The beautifully carved structures are used to deck up windows in the royal palaces – a reason why they evoke images of Rajput women looking out from its carefully constructed structure. Royal, elegant, sophisticated, the appeal of jharokha is its timeless elegance. There’s history, style and aesthetics that can perk up your space.Now, the jharokhas are moving beyond the windows. For instance, small ones are being used as a photo frame, while some are being used in temples or to hold mirrors. Art historian and architectural restorer Sunita Kohli says that there’s an increased fascination for jharokhas from those interested in Indian culture.Kohli adds, “Jharokhas were always viewed favourably and now there’s a growing confidence for not rejecting our own culture. This is the one element that can add depth to your living space.” While designing a five-star property in Bhubaneshwar, she used different types of jharokhas in the dining area.This season, window design is changing how our homes look. In contemporary architecture, windows are featured prominently. Modern homes make extensive use of large and unique window designs to let in plenty of natural light. And a jharokha fits right in with its strong traditional aesthetic.The jharokha is more formal and ornamental than English or French “oriel” and is one of the most distinctive element in medieval Indian architecture until the 19th century. Interior designer Anuradha Aggarwal says, “The jharokhas have seen a transformation in the last few years. The interpretation of a jharokha is beyond décor. Decorating windows has a positive psychology, as they are the eyes of your home, bring in energy and how you view the outside world. Interesting jharokhas pep up the room.” She also adds that now jharokhas are used as decorative pieces and come in different shapes and sizes. Tip: If you have a bright painted wall, then use a wooden jharokha to give a charming look. It’s a trend worth looking out for.

Title: Sudeep-starrer Phantom takes off
Content: Ever since director Anup Bhandari and actor Kichcha Sudeep announced their intention to collaborate, fans and industry experts have been waiting eagerly to see what the two of them will bring to the table. The duo, we hear, are now ready to roll with their first film together, Phantom, shooting for which begins in Hyderabad on Monday. The team is still tight-lipped about other details, including casting, but tells us that pre-production work is on in full swing in Bengaluru and Hyderabad. Manjunath Gowda, popularly known as Jack Manju in film circles, who is backing the project, says, “We have finished shooting for the poster and teaser in Hyderabad. Primary filming will begin on Monday. We have been working extensively on the preparations for the film. In fact, a massive set has already been created in Hyderabad, while another is in the works in Bengaluru. Shivu, our art director, is putting it together to facilitate smooth transition from the Hyderabad schedule to the one in Bengaluru.”Questions about the leading lady, though, remain unanswered and all speculation about whether Samantha Akkineni will come to Kannada cinema will be laid to rest only when the team makes an official statement. What they do tell us is that they are also on the lookout for a young girl to be cast in a pivotal role. Anup’s brother and actor Nirup Bhandari is also reportedly a part of the film.

Title: Manage your 40s
Content: While you harp on metabolism all your life, there is also catabolism that we need to worry about (especially women once they touch 40s). As we age, the lean muscle and bone density in the body starts decreasing – this process is called catabolism. Because of the decreased muscle mass, metabolism goes down too. In your 40s, you cannot get away with eating and working out the same way as you did in your 20s and 30s. The main goal in this decade is to reverse the catabolic process and make it anabolic, wherein you start building bone density and muscle mass instead of losing it.How? Eat right. The biggest misconception people have is that they need to starve or give up sugar to look good in their 40s. Quality is the keyword here. Instead of a commercial chocolate bar, look for high quality sweets like homemade halva, laddoos or kheer. They’re made with whole grains and contain nourishers like ghee and dry fruits that make them a much healthier option than anything store-bought. Don’t be fearful of food, at the same time, exercise portion control and don’t go overboard. Eat till satisfied, but avoid bingeing.- Crash diet plans: While they may make you look slimmer in the short term, they will make you lose muscle mass and bone density, which just increases the problem. - Packaged snacks: They come with hidden sugars, salt and chemical compounds that your body finds difficult to break down. Instead of buying a jar of ghee or a pack of milk from the store, look for a sustainable farm that gives you high-quality products.- Breakfast cereals: We have a culture of eating hot breakfast, which is very satisfying. When we eat Western breakfast of cold cereal and milk, we don’t get satisfaction, because of which we end up looking for a cigarette, coffee, or a muffin when we reach work.- Overeating: I always advise people to eat five spoons less than what they would have. Eat till you are satisfied, not stuffed and full.- Exercise: A combination of strength training and yoga is good as it will help to increase lean muscle mass and also accelerate fat loss.- Stop dividing food into groups like fat, protein, carbs. Eat wholesome, home-cooked meals instead.- To reverse the process of catabolism, you need calcium as it is important for bone density, along with iron, protein and vitamin D.- Ghee, seasonal greens, whole grains like millets and single polished rice, sesame seeds, fresh vegetables and farm fresh dairy are all important.— Munmun Ganeriwal, nutritionist and lifestyle consultant

Title: Times of India
Content: There are winter veggies and then there are ‘receding winter’ veggies. Purple radish pods, called mogri/moongre in India, is one of them. While the green radish pods are readily available through winter, purple are hard to come by and are highly undervalued. One of the main ingredients in salads and even pickles, they make for a nutritious treat. Radish pods are rich in ascorbic acid, folic acid, and potassium. They are a good source of vitamin B6, riboflavin, magnesium, copper, and calcium. Known by different names across India, their scientific name is Raphanus sativus. They are members of the mustard family along with arugula, broccoli and kale. The pods carry one or two seeds with a peppery flavour.You can eat moongre raw or cooked. Chop them and put into salads. You could also make a chutney by pounding these with some green chillies, and mixing in salt and yoghurt. Radish pods are also great in Asian stir fries.

Title: Elsa‘ing’is the new ‘ghosting
Content: Dating is hard. One only has to ask the singles. And now that online dating has made it as simple as a swipe, it’s getting more twisted; a reason why modern-day love lexicographers are working overtime to update the dating dictionary. The terms are spinning out so fast that ‘ghosting’ that came two years ago, feels almost ancient. It turned to ‘dial-toning’ last year, and for 2020, ‘Elsa’ing’ is the new ‘ghosting’.Here’s how it goes. So, last year, you were ‘slow fading’, but this year you are probably ‘flatlining’. In 2018, people were ‘orbiting’ – cutting you out but looking at your social media updates, and now they are ‘causeplaying’ – basically, when a casual relationship fizzles out, but the other person keeps popping back into your life to ask for favours. Even as the edits proclaim these as the “cool” new terms, Mumbai-based dating coach Pratik Jain believes otherwise. After all, all the terms describe what is purportedly bad dating behaviour. “To call ‘ghosting’ cool would be wrong. It is common and we have a term for it. But when it happens to someone, it is not cool,” he days.Jain, who has been coaching people to land dates, calls it the new lingo to define certain behaviours. His analysis is simple: the dating world starts young these days – say with 17-18 year olds, where the youngsters are consuming a lot of the pop culture through OTT platforms. “Dating is what defines their culture and these new terms help put a name to what is going on in their lives,” he notes. Matchmaking app Happn revealed a new dating vocabulary for 2020. In a report Didier Rappaport, CEO and founder of Happn, said: “If you’ve encountered dating disappointments or disasters, the way you describe the experience can sometimes help to make light of the situation. Cultural references and puns feature heavily in the terms we predict will break through in 2020 to describe some of the dramas of finding love.” Dating coach Kshitij Sehrawat likes to take his subjects to live locations for dating demos and coaching. He says that trying out for dates in the real world, in real time, with realtalk, gives you more benefits and dividends than swiping online. “The gratification is instant, the markers real and you get a chance to know where you stand,” he adds. Sehrawat’s favourite dating term is his own creation: ‘flirt and roast ratio’ – a ploy to build interest and sexual tension. “It’s a mix of playful (not hurtful) banter that gets the person hooked to your word,” he explains.Australian dating and relationships expert Debbie Rivers had said in an article on new terminology: “New words come about when something becomes so common that we need a way to describe it. However, the problem is these new terms are normalising poor dating behaviour.” So much so, ‘ghosting’ has become a defining millennial act. Making up dating terms started as a way to help us define the confusing, maddening experiences we had while online dating. But in her Mashable article writer AnnaIovine tch-tches the trend and feels it has gone too far. Sehrawat would blame the online dating culture for bolstering these bad behaviours and fostering new ones. He explains why. “On a dating app, you are competing with so many people and are at the mercy of other people. It’s not as fulfilling as taking control, going up to a girl and getting that number.” Online dating makes it easier for people to ‘ghost’ or ‘dialtone’ someone.Editor and single guy Hari Govind Nair calls these dating terminologies “the millennial lingo” but welcomes it. “Earlier, when you were meeting someone, you were probably dating within a circle. Now, you meet absolute strangers. When someone shows a certain trait, and you put a name to that behaviour, it helps you understand them better. That really helps if you are looking for something serious,” he adds. It may have something to do with our natural human tendency to assign names to things. In an article in brit.co, lexicographer Jane Solomon says that cutesy modern dating vocabulary has evolved for a very specific reason: “Dating can be harsh, but these terms give us a relatively lighthearted way to discuss very real disappointment and trauma.”Desi dating terms to look out forFrom Karan Johar, the eternal Bollywood love guru. Basically, an enthusiastic Indian uncle who’s always matchmaking because he loves ‘love’The colony boyfriend who is the stand-in date till an NRI rishta comes alongA clueless friend who gets thrown under the bus because his friend messed upThe forever coming-of-age boy who has Sufi tendencies and a hippie soulThe moment a relationship sours you get dragged in a very public washing of dirty linenTwo people are having a rip-roaring affair but their families are cluelessWhen you get together with someone new and the match surprises people.When someone seems nice when they first approach you but once they have been rejected, even if politely, they turn nasty.Thanks to Ross Geller of Friends and his infamous ‘we are on a break’ episode. This basically refers to the confusion that ensues when you have defined the relationship (DTR).A date with this kind of a person would feel like an ‘interrogation’. These people ask you personal questions on first date.The new ghosting. When someone suddenly freezes you out without explanation. It comes from Elsa’s character in Frozen.When you lure people in with cute snaps of you and your pet, and they’re really only hanging out to spend time with your dog.When you are neglecting the person you are seeing and don’t give them the attention for the relationship to grow.Remember Clippy, the irritating assistant that popped up on Microsoft Word? He’s back as the commitment-phobe guy with a smart phone. Basically, the one who pops up when you least expect him to remind that he exists, despite not wanting to date you.An advanced state of dating limbo, where you hang out all the time, almost live at each other’s places, meet each other’s friends and family. You are very couple-y! But you haven’t ever defined the relationship.This happens when your date is only interested in talking about him/herself.When someone chooses who to date based solely on personality types.When you immediately adopt all of your significant others’ hobbies and interests.Similar to ghosting but involves ignoring the other person before the relationship ever even begins.Getting all dolled up, only to be cancelled at the last minute.When a casual relationship fizzles out, but the other person keeps popping back into your life to ask for favours.

Title: 'Miss Gulab Jaan' enthralled Bareillywallahs!
Content:
'

Miss Gulab Jaan

'

Preeti Singh

One of the most awaited events of the year—Windermere Theater Festival 2020 was held in the city recently and concluded with a popular celebrity-based play. It was 8-day 13th Windermere Theater Fest 2020 conducted in the city based on the theme 'music' and hence they were presented with panoply of musical adaptations of real life characters and legends.The theater fest kicked off with the playpresented by Rang Vinayak Rangmandal theater repertory, Bareilly , which was directed by Randhir Kumar and playwright by Asif from Chhapra Bihar, a NSD Alumni and recipient of Ustad Bismillah Khan Yuva award by Sangeet Natak Academy for his writings. Based on the autobiography of Gulab Bai, the famous and first female artist in Nautanki that made her living legend, the play ‘Miss Gulab Jaan’ showcased the personal, professional and social conflicts in her life as an artist, a dalit woman, lover, wife, mother; a single woman in a profession dominated by men.The play deals with personal, professional and social conflicts in her life, and makes everyone, especially an artist, realize how and what an artist goes through life., one of the theater buffs, said, "Miss Gulab Jaan was quite a touching performance, and has a soulful feel to each and every character played by artists. It wonderfully portrayed the challenges of personal, professional and social life all together and maintaining a perfect balance at the end."

Title: Peace needs a chance: Afghans greet US-Taliban deal with unease & hope
Content:
KABUL: For millions of war-scarred Afghans, the US-Taliban

deal

represents some hope for an end to years of bloodshed. “Peace is extremely simple and my

country

deserves it. Today is the day when maybe we will see a positive change,” said Javed Hassan, 38, a teacher living on the outskirts of Kabul.

Some people in the country were seen celebrating the end of an 18-year-old war. “We and are impatiently waiting for the foreign invaders to leave Afghanistan,” said

Arefullah Saad

, a resident of eastern

Khost province

, where the Taliban boast a strong presence. “I do not know if peace will be achieved, but it is enough to just end the war,” Zarmina, 27, from Ghazni

province

said.

But there were others who said they feared what comes next. Kabul

Immediately after the deal was signed, Taliban political spokesman

Suhail Shaheen

said Afghan women “should not worry about their rights”.

But activist

Zahra Hussaini

said she had no faith in such claims. “I don’t trust the Taliban, and remember how they suppressed women when they were ruling,” the 28-year-old said in Kabul. “Today is a dark day, and as I was watching the deal being signed, I had this bad feeling that it would result in their return to power rather than in peace,” she said.

Hassan’s children were killed in a bomb blast carried out by the Taliban in 2018. Since then, he has been writing letters to world leaders urging them to end the Afghan war . And today his prayers have been answered.The agreement inked in Doha sets out a timetable to end America’s longest war, which has cost tens of thousands of lives, in return for a commitment by the Taliban to refuse sanctuary to jihadist groups such as al-Qaida and hold negotiations with the Kabul government.shopkeeper Husain Ahmad said that while Afghans were “hungry for peace”, the agreement represented a victory for the insurgents whose stint in power from 1996 to 2001 saw the imposition of strict sharia law and confined women to their homes.

Title: Coronavirus Death in US Latest News: Washington state reports first coronavirus death in United States
Content: Washington state health officials reported the first patient death from coronavirus in the United States on Saturday, according to a news release.State health officials were due to provide more information at a news conference on Saturday at 1:00 p.m. Pacific Time (2100 GMT), according to the statement. No other details were immediately available.Coronavirus is a kind of virus like any other common cold virus that causes an infection in your throat, nose or sinuses. They are termed as zoonotic, meaning they are transmitted between animals and humans. It’s spread is mainly in the same way as other cold-causing viruses i.e. through infected people sneezing and coughing (droplet infection), physical contact with an infected person, or by touching the belongings of the infected people.According to the WHO, the signs of infection include fever, cough, and difficulty in breathing. In more severe cases, the virus can lead to pneumonia, kidney failure, severe acute respiratory syndrome and even death. The incubation period of the coronavirus remains unknown. It could be up to 10 days.• Wash your hands properly with sanitizers or warm water and soap• Cover your mouth and nose when someone is sneezing or coughing• Avoid close contact with anyone who is suffering from a fever or cough• Avoid direct contact with live animals and surfaces in contact with animals when visiting live markets in affected areas• Make sure you avoid eating raw or undercooked animal productsIf you are mildly sick, you should• drink plenty of liquids• stay home and rest• Avoid self-medicationIf you are concerned about your symptoms, you should consult with a medical expert.Inputs by Amol Naikawadi, Preventive Healthcare Specialist, Indus Health PlusNews Inputs: Reuters

Title: South Africa vs Australia: 1st ODI: Klaasen ton leads South Africa's big win over Australia
Content:
SCORECARD

PAARL (South Africa): A maiden international century by Heinrich Klaasen set up a 74-run win for South Africa in the first one-day international against Australia at Boland Park on Saturday.Klaasen hit 123 not out in a South African total of 291 for seven. Australia were on target midway through their reply but lost their last seven wickets for 43 runs to be bowled out for 217.Steve Smith and Marnus Labuschagne put on 84 for Australia's third wicket after the early loss of opening batsman Aaron Finch and David Warner, both dismissed by Lungi Ngidi, who finished with three for 30.Smith (76) and Labuschagne (41) hit only three boundaries between them as scoring proved difficult on a slow pitch and a big outfield.When they tried to accelerate Labuschagne was caught at long-on off left-arm spinner Keshav Maharaj.Mitchell Marsh helped Smith add 41 for the fourth wicket but Marsh was bowled by Ngidi and three balls later Smith was trapped leg before wicket by Anrich Nortje.It was always going to be difficult for new batsmen to get established and the innings subsided.By contrast Klaasen and David Miller (64) put on 149 for South Africa's fifth wicket and were not parted until Miller was out in the 49th over."That was the difference between the teams," said Australian captain Finch. "Klaasen and Miller batted really well. When you have a couple of batters going deep - they scored something like 81 runs in the last ten overs." It was actually 82 but it proved crucial.Klaasen said he felt "pure emotion" when he reached his century after a difficult recent period when he lost his place in the team and had to fight his way back. He gave credit to Miller and new cap Kyle Verreynne, who made 48 and helped Klaasen add 78 for the fourth wicket after South Africa had been 48 for three after winning the toss.Verreynne, 22, made an impressive debut which included three catches in the outfield by a player who keeps wicket in domestic cricket . Two of Verreynne's catches were spectacular, one to dismiss Warner when he dived forward from point and late in the innings when he ran in from long-on and dived to take a steepling catch from Pat Cummins.South African captain Quinton de Kock was phlegmatic after a topsy-turvy few weeks when South Africa have had good wins interspersed by heavy defeats. "It's a matter of being consistent in what we do and then we will be alright going forward," he said.The three-match series continues in Bloemfontein on Wednesday.Use your cricket knowledge to play CricPlay, India’s first free fantasy cricket app

Title: UK top official at the centre of Priti Patel bullying row quits
Content:
Priti Patel has been accused of shouting and swearing, belittling people and making unreasonable demands. The ... Read More

LONDON: The top civil servant in the UK Home Office at the centre of a row over a strained relationship with Indian-origin Home Secretary Priti Patel resigned from his post on Saturday and said he plans to sue the government over his "constructive and unfair" exit.

Philip Rutnam, Permanent Secretary in the department led by 47-year-old Patel, said there had been a “vicious and orchestrated campaign” against him over the last 10 days and pointed the finger of blame at the minister .

“The Home Secretary (Patel) categorically denied any involvement in this campaign to the Cabinet Office. I regret I do not believe her,” he said in a statement.

“Even despite this campaign, I was willing to effect a reconciliation with the Home Secretary, as requested by the Cabinet Secretary on behalf of the Prime Minister. But despite my efforts to engage with her, Priti Patel has made no effort to engage with me to discuss this,” the statement said.

Rutnam said his experience formed part of a wider pattern in government and that he plans to take legal action on the grounds of constructive dismissal.

“I believe that these events give me very strong grounds to claim constructive, unfair dismissal, and I will be pursuing that claim in the courts. My experience has been extreme, but I consider there is evidence that it was part of a wider pattern of behaviour,” his statement adds.

The resignation comes just days after he and Patel had issued a joint statement in an effort to quell media reports of discord within the Home Office.

“The Home Secretary and Permanent Secretary are deeply concerned about the number of false allegations appearing in the media,” a UK Home Office spokesperson said on Monday, when the government took the rare step to issue a formal statement to quash rumours circulating around the frosty relationship between the minister and her top civil servant.

Patel has been at the centre of a controversy over an alleged bullying atmosphere within her department, an allegation that has been denied and also led to Downing Street confirming that the minister has the “full confidence” of Prime Minister Boris Johnson .

These allegations will be revived again as Rutnam makes reference to it in his detailed resignation statement published in a blog for ‘ The Spectator ' magazine.

He said: “One of my duties as Permanent Secretary was to protect the health, safety and well-being of our 35,000 people. This created tension with the Home Secretary, and I have encouraged her to change her behaviours.

“I have received allegations that her conduct has included shouting and swearing, belittling people, making unreasonable and repeated demands, behaviour that created fear and needed some bravery to call out.”

The bureaucrat with a 33-year career in the UK civil service said he expects his resignation could have very serious personal implications but he had chosen to turn down an offered financial settlement from the Cabinet Office to take a stand.

The UK Home Office is yet to comment on the news of Rutnam's resignation.

Title: Chloe Dygert: Cycling: American Chloe Dygert wins pursuit title with new world record
Content:
Chloe Dygert (AFP Photo)

BERLIN: American cycling star Chloe Dygert won the women's pursuit title at the track world championships in a new world record time on Saturday.

The 23-year-old cross-discipline champion trimmed more than three seconds off the old 3km time set in 2018, winning the world title in 3min 16.937sec.

The American pulverised German rival Lisa Brennauer, who came in over six seconds adrift.

The women's 3km pursuit is not on the Olympic roster but Dygert aims to race the team pursuit in Tokyo as well as the road race individual time-trial.

Dygert, 23, who is coached by three-time Olympic gold medallist Kristin Armstrong, stunned the road race circuit by beating Dutch duo Anna van der Breggen and Annemiek van Vleuten to take gold in the world time-trial in Yorkshire last September.

Earlier Saturday Germany's Lea Sophie Friedrich was given a standing ovation on her victory lap at the Berlin Velodrome after she won the women's 500m time trial.

It was the 20-year-old's second gold of the championships after she also helped Germany win the women's team event on the opening day.

"I tried so, so hard and in the end it was a very fast time," said Friedrich.

The Netherlands won a fifth gold of the championships in the women's 30km relay event, the Madison, a race which featured a spectacular crash where Poland's Daria Pikulik was accidentally run over by a Chinese racer after a fall.

Dutch pair veteran Kirsten Wild and Amy Pieters clinched the marathon event, named after the Madison Square Garden venue in New York, where the convoluted touch-and-go tag-relay, further complicated by points being allocated every ten laps, debuted.

Frenchman Benjamin Thomas emerged as the winner of the men's multi-discipline Omnium event beating Dutch star Jan Willem van Schip and Britain's Matthew Walls.

Title: Boris Johnson, girl friend engaged, expecting first child
Content:
Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson walks with his partner Carrie Symonds. (Picture credits AFP)

LONDON: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his girlfriend Carrie Symonds are expecting their first child together and are engaged to be married, the couple announced on Saturday.

"The prime minister and Miss Symonds are very pleased to announce their engagement and that they are expecting a baby in the early summer," the couple said in a statement.

The 55-year-old Johnson took office in July and led his Conservative Party to a decisive election victory in December.

The announcement means he will become the first British prime minister to marry in office for 250 years.

The Sun newspaper quoted a Downing Street source as saying " Boris and Carrie are both delighted at this news. They have both known for a while but have kept it under wraps until the pregnancy progressed."

"It partly explains why he has been lying low recently - although he works flat out and that won’t change. Carrie is thrilled and she will also continue to work on her environmental projects," the paper quoted the source as saying.

Johnson was previously married to Marina Wheeler.

"I wouldn't normally post this kind of thing on here but I wanted my friends to find out from me," Symonds, 31, said on Instagram , according to British media.

"Many of you already know but for my friends that still don't, we got engaged at the end of last year... and we've got a baby hatching early summer," adding: "Feel incredibly blessed".

Recent British prime ministers' wives have had babies while their husbands were in office

Former Conservative Prime Minister David Cameron 's wife Samantha had a baby daughter, Florence, in 2010.

Labour Prime Minister Tony Blair's wife Cherie had a son, Leo, in 2000

Title: Delhi communal violence will only push more people into ghettos, says political scientist Laurent Gayer
Content:
Delhi is one of the most religiously segregated cities in your rankings. What has led to this situation? Are these ghettoes or enclaves?

What is the relationship between spatial segregation and communal violence?

The context for this violence was Muslims defending their right to protest, to claim public space. These very sit-ins and the traffic delays were held as provocation. Is this a new threshold in their marginalisation?

Is there a gap between Islamophobic propaganda and lived experience in mingled neighbourhoods?

Northeast Delhi is where working-class Muslims and Hindus live in mixed neighbourhoods. But fear and anger are driving a wedge between the communities. Laurent Gayer, a political scientist who has worked on urban spaces and social integration in both India and Pakistan , and co-author of the book Muslims in Indian Cities, speaks to Amulya Gopalakrishnan about violence and coexistence. Urban sociology classically established a distinction between enclaves, whose residents are supposed to congregate by choice with their kith and kin, and ghettos, where stigmatised populations are thought to be confined against their will. The growing sense of insecurity among Indian Muslims has collapsed these two categories into a single experience of marginalisation. In Delhi, as in other highly segregated Indian cities, middle-class Muslims currently live side by side with working-class Muslims in dilapidated localities. They have traded the comforts of middle-class urban living for security. Obviously, the recent pogrom will lead to new displacements and new attempts to search for safety in numbers.There is no mechanical relationship between segregation and communal violence. Among Indian Muslims, feelings of insecurity are key to processes of enclosing and are deeply subjective. Delhi is a case in point: while, historically, this has not been a communally sensitive city, with ‘only’ 50 deaths in incidents of Hindu-Muslim violence between 1950 and 1995, its population has been increasingly segregated on religious lines since the 1990s. The city’s Muslim population has been responding to incidents of communal violence elsewhere in India and anticipated that such incidents could someday spread to the capital. Sadly, the events of the past few days have vindicated these predictions, and will certainly reinforce existing patterns of segregation.The anti-CAA protests are part of a global wave of urban uprisings, for which the city is not merely a background setting but a major stakeholder in the conflict between insurgents and incumbents. These are all struggles for the city, for its territories and flows, for the control of place and pace. The global enthusiasm of protesters for occupations and blockades is not merely a matter of protest tactics, though. It also carries a desire for new forms of collective life, brandished against the forces of parochialism, the disruptive power of capital and the violence of state repression. Anti-CAA activists in Shaheen Bagh and Jaffrabad did not only craft a new style of protests: night after night, they reclaimed the city as a place for pluralistic living and political solidarities across denominational divides. This sort of constituent imagination is a matter of concern for the authoritarian neo-liberal states that are becoming the norm worldwide. In India, this concern overlaps with what many Muslims and secular non-Muslims see as a systematic process of disenfranchisement of the Muslim population. In this perspective, reclaiming the streets is not only about restoring law and order or resetting the pace of circulatory flows essential to the economy: it is part of a political program aiming to replace the old citizenship by right with a citizenship by permit, which will be granted at the discretion of the rulers. The idea of the street as an arena for universalistic public claims, firmly rooted into the language of rights, is anathema to this new conception of citizenship. The ‘new India’ should brace itself for some street-fighting years.The events of the past few days have shown that many Indians were not ready to fall for the sirens of communalism. In Seelampur, for instance, Muslims and Dalits stood together against the storm threatening to be unleashed in their localities. There is no such thing as traditions of peaceful coexistence: coexistence is always hard labour. Sometimes, this everyday labour of coexistence pays. Communal forces are well aware of this, which is why they need to spread rumours and bring assailants from outside to disrupt long established patterns of conviviality. Without downplaying the recent destructions and dislocations, we should give their due to those Hindus who put their life at stake to save their Muslim neighbours and friends, or those Muslims who defended Hindu temples in the midst of chaos. This reminded me of a verse common to the Quran and the Talmud: “whoever saves one life, it is as if he had saved mankind entirely”.

Title: Victories, rivalries and grunts: The 28-year legacy of Maria Sharapova
Content:
The on court racket

Giving it back to the sexists

A career-long feud with Serena Williams

A sartorial star on the court

Sharapova mostly wore her personalised tennis shoes. Along with her initials/name/signature, the shoes also featured 5 Xs, which represented her five Grand Slam titles

While defending her title at Wimbledon in 2005, the sports star was seen wearing gold-speckled shoes that estimated over US $500

On February 26, Maria Sharapova , former No 1, five-time Grand Slam winner and a global sports star, announced that she was saying goodbye to tennis. The ‘ice queen’ retired after a 28-year-long career that included many titles, losses and even a ban from the sport for drug abuse. Not just an ace tennis player, Sharapova was the highest-paid female athlete till 2016 and was also a model and a businesswoman. Sharapova, who put the racket down at the age of 32 when she was ranked No 373, started playing tennis when she was only four. It was in 2004 when she beat Serena Williams and won Wimbledon at the age of 17 and shot to global fame. But her downfall began in 2016 when she was suspended for using a performance-enhancing, banned drug. The suspension ended in 15 months but Sharapova could not bring back her original form to the court. Citing recurring problems with her right shoulder, the tennis star in her retirement letter said that her body had “become a distraction”. Since returning to the WTA Tour in the spring of 2017, Sharapova played a total of 73 matches. She had 45 wins. One title and one major quarterfinal. However, her form wasn’t the only talking point in her glorious career.Sharapova was famously one of the loudest grunters in the game. While some didn’t see a problem with it, others, including her rivals, claimed that it was just a tactic to throw the opponent off their game. One of her rivals even said that Sharapova was “just too loud and annoying”. Over the course of her career, her shrieks have reached up to 101 decibels. A news website said she “crescendos an A6 note as a 27-year-old, which is an octave above a soprano singer”. However, criticism from her rivals hardly ever mattered to Sharapova.“I’ve been the same over the course of my career. No one important enough has told me to change or do something different,” she hit back after being called out for her grunts.Throughout her career – whether it was while talking to the press or calling out authorities – Sharapova didn’t turn a blind eye to the rampant sexism in the tennis world. In January this year, she slammed Brisbane International chiefs after the women players, including Sharapova, were forced off the main court to make room for the men’s inaugural ATP Cup. Sharapova said the women’s Brisbane International tournament felt “second hand”. “There’s a lot of girls that are deserving of that centre-court spot. You definitely recognise it and notice it. It feels like a little bit of a second-hand event,” she said. In 2012, when France’s Gilles Simon said that women in tennis didn’t deserve to be paid as much as men because the men’s game is more “attractive”, Sharapova hit back with a simple, “I’m sure there are a few more people that watch my matches than his, so...” And this time, even Serena was on her side.The claws (from both ends) have been out since Sharapova defeated Williams in 2004. Both ladies, on several occasions, have taken digs at each other’s personal and professional lives. In her autobiography, Sharapova wrote that it all started in 2004 when a distraught Williams, after her Wimbledon loss, told a friend (who then told Sharapova) that she would “never lose to that little b**** again”. She even wrote about how Serena hated her for “being the skinny kid who beat her, against all odds, at Wimbledon. I think she hated me for taking something that she believed belonged to her.” As for their off the court rivalry, in 2013, when a reporter assumed that Williams was talking about Sharapova when she called someone boring while referring to their personal life during an interview, Maria told the press, “If she wants to talk about something personal, maybe she should talk about her relationship and her boyfriend that was married and is getting a divorce and has kids.” She was referring to Patrick Mouratoglou, who was at the time coaching Serena. However, the rivalry wasn’t just with Serena. Sharapova was known for isolating herself from the rest of the tennis world. In an interview in 2013, she had said, “I’m not really close to many players. I think just because you’re in the same sport it doesn’t mean that you have to be friends with everyone.”

Title: Visiting Rajasthan for Angrezi Medium was like a homecoming for Irrfan
Content: Key portions of the upcoming film, Angrezi Medium , starring Irrfan, Kareena Kapoor Khan and Radhika Madan, were shot in Rajasthan. Visiting the state was a homecoming of sorts for Irrfan, who hails from there. The actor was born and raised in Jaipur before he moved from the Pink City to pursue a career in acting. Instead of staying at a five-star hotel in Udaipur (where parts of the movie were shot), Irrfan chose to stay at a comfortable homestay. For him, shooting for this film and interacting with the locals was like going back to his roots. He would spend his free time resting on a charpai and enjoying the company of the people around him. The film captures the heart-warming relationship between a single father, Irrfan, and his daughter, Radhika.Post the shoot, director Homi Adajania and co-actors Deepak Dobriyal and Radhika, too, would often end up spending more time with Irrfan at his homestay, rather than at their own hotel. The actor’s relatives, who stay in various parts of the state, would frequently drop in to visit him and bring him homemade delicacies. In fact, the rest of the crew would eagerly wait for lunch and dinner breaks to gorge on these delicacies.

Title: Dance, music and masti at Bennett University’s Uphoria
Content:
A groovy start: BU’s western dance society, Verve, inaugurated the fest with entertaining performances

A grand start

Dance and drama: Students putting on an energetic performance

Bennett dances to

Millind Gaba

’s tunes

nukkad natak

Curtains down

Students of Sri Guru Gobind Singh College of Commerce performing their nukkad natak

Bennett University,

Greater Noida

offers undergraduate and post graduate programs in

Engineering

,

Management Law

and Media. For details, visit

www.bennett.edu.in

— Vinayak Joshi, BTech, first year and Riti Ghai, BA-JMC, first year

From rap competitions, dance and comic acts to quiz shows and celebrity performances, the recently concluded Uphoria 4.0, the annual cultural fest of Bennett University , saw a wide variety of events, which were a perfect mix of entertainment and learning.The fest kicked off with three performances by Advaita, the music society of the university, followed by energetic dance performances put up by Verve, the dance society of the university. There was also the much-awaited masquerade party and the prom. The student DJs kept the crowd grooving and popular Bollywood films like 'Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara' and 'Dil Chahta Hai' were also screened.Raising the temperature, quite literally, Millind Gaba gave a smashing performance on the second day of the fest. Apart from cultural events, the day also saw a fashion show, the staging of a, a debate competition, a pottery workshop and a traditional group dance competition. The food stalls were another attraction at the fest. A student, Vartika Madan, shared, “This is my first college fest and it has been an amazing experience. Milind Gaba’s act ensured that the student had an amazing night.”On the third and final day, stand-up comic Aakash Gupta took to the stage. A student, Abhilasha Rawat, said that his jokes had them laughing so hard, that they couldn’t breathe. “I can’t wait for the fest to happen again next year,” she added. A laser maze course by the astronomy club, painting competition by the club Silhouette, virtual reality experience provided by the robotics club, pop quiz conducted by the club Cerebrums, and a competition organised by Isac, the photography club of BU – these were some of the other highlights of the events. While the organisers had a busy and hectic schedule, as Akshita Chaplot, a member of the artist management team, pointed out, “The smiles you see on people’s faces makes you realise your hard work has paid off, and then, everything feels worth it.”

Title: Decoding Trump’s handwriting and what it says about his personality
Content:
He uses all capital letters, which is unusual. It indicates that he needs his space at all times, has his own independent opinion to which he sticks to, uninfluenced by biases of others.

The unconnected letters shows a person who likes neatness and is very particular about his personal appearance. This is apparent when he is posing for pictures – always looking down to straighten his jacket or tie to ensure that his dress is in order.

The straight handwriting shows a practical and business-like approach in life.

His handwriting reveals that he uses great pressure while writing, which shows his physical fitness levels, aggression and also his approach in life. He will always push his way through to get his work done – that is his personality.

The dots on the I are exactly in the centre, neither to the left or right, indicating that he is particular about being on time for appointments and expects the same from others.

The exclamation mark and underlining of the word ‘India’ means special emphasis and shows that he shares a special relationship with India.

Trump’s signature is sharp with dagger formations, ending abruptly with no end strokes. It shows readiness to use force and power to get things done.

Donald Trump’s message that he wrote in the visitors’ book at Raj Ghat (above) and Sabarmati AshramOn his recent two-day visit to India, US President Donald Trump made quick stops at Sabarmati Ashram in Ahmedabad first and then at Mahatma Gandhi’s memorial at Raj Ghat. In both places, he wrote messages on the visitors’ books that have since been shared and commented upon widely. Astro-numerologist Anupam V Kapil analysed his handwriting and according to him, here’s what it reveals about Trump’s personality:

Title: The JLo Challenge makes a case for body positivity
Content: It was actress and singer Dolly Parton whose challenge went viral on Instagram a few weeks ago. And now, Jennifer Lopez is taking up from where she left off. The mum-of-two has been getting a bunch of social media users to shares pictures of themselves with the hashtag #JLoChallenge. And yes, they’re as cool as it can get. It all started on February 17, when the singer and actress posted a mirror selfie of herself in a white bikini looking as fit as ever. She captioned the photo, “Relaxed and recharged.” It garnered a staggering eight million likes and reactions such as ‘Wowza’, ‘Insane’ and ‘Hot’.JLo’s post got women of all sizes to share similar photos of themselves, inspired by the singer. They also shared stories of their own journey to fitness and what made them take the step to post their bikini pictures on Instagram. One user from a moms’ fitness community added, “Own your story. Create your own accountability. Don’t make excuses for your inaction. If she can do it, if I can do it, if thousands of working moms who come in all sizes, shapes and ages can do it, then you can do it!!!?” Another wrote: “If Jlo can do it at 50, I can do it at 61!”The Hustlers actress’ post brought out how body positivity may not always be about a taut tummy and toned arms, but about acceptance.Tennis star Serena Williams also showed how fit she was in her latest post on Instagram. The mother-of-one wore a black jumpsuit and propped herself on one arm as she stretched out on the floor.

Title: First death, unexplained virus cases in 3 states raise US fear
Content: Troubling new signs that the coronavirus is spreading in the US emerged on Friday, as cases not explained by overseas travel or contact with a person known to be infected were reported in California , Oregon and Washington state.Officials from the three states announced that their testing had found new cases: a high school student from north of Seattle; an employee of an elementary school in Oregon, near Portland; and a woman in California, in the heart of Silicon Valley.Sixty-five cases of the virus have been reported in the US, but until this week, all of the cases could be explained by overseas travel or contact with someone who had been ill. The three new cases on Friday, and a case earlier in the week, in California, were the first in the US where the cause was mysterious and unknown — a sign, experts warned, that the virus, which has killed more than 2,800 people worldwide and sickened tens of thousands of others, might now be spreading in the US.Despite anxieties, Trump has defended measures taken by his administration and lashed out at Democrats who have questioned his handling of the threat. Trump asserted that Democratic complaints about his handling of the virus threat are “their new hoax” intended to undermine his presidency.Meanwhile, Iran is preparing for the possibility of “tens of thousands” of people getting tested for the new coronavirus as the number of confirmed cases spiked again on Saturday, an official said. Covid-19 has killed 43 people out of 593 confirmed cases in Iran, health ministry spokesman Kianoush Jahanpour said. The new toll represents a jump of 205 cases — a 150% rise from the 388 reported the day before.South Korea, the second hardest hit country, reported 813 new cases on Saturday — the highest daily jump since confirming its first patient in January and — raising its total to 3,150. In Italy, four more people died from coronavirus, bringing the total to 21, while the number of those testing positive jumped to 889 from 650 the day before. Pakistan confirmed two more cases of coronavirus, bringing the number of positive cases to fourSaudi Arabia said it would bar citizens of the Gulf Cooperation Council from Islam’s holiest sites in Mecca and Medina over concerns about the virus’ spread. The GCC is a six-nation group including Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and UAE. On Thursday, the country closed off the holy sites to foreign pilgrims.Officials in Ecuador on Saturday confirmed the first case of the virus in the nation.Health minister Catalina Andramuno Zeballos said the patient was a 70-year-old Ecuadoran woman who lives in Spain. It was the second case in South America, following a Brazilian case reported on Wednesday. Meanwhile, officials confirmed a third case of the new coronavirus in Mexico.

Title: Mahathir Mohamad battles hard, but Malaysia picks Muhyiddin Yassin
Content:
Malaysia's Interim Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. ( Picture credits: Reuters)

KUALA LUMPUR : Malaysia’s Mahathir Mohamad on Saturday lost the battle to return as prime minister once again as the king invited Muhyiddin Yassin to be the country’s eighth PM after exhausting political manouevrings witnessed by Malaysians for the past week since the popular Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition government was toppled.

Muhyiddin, a former home minister in Najib Razak’s government and most recently in Mahathir Mohamad’s, a soft-spoken man widely perceived as a moderate face of Malay politics, was invited by the king to be PM after it was clear the current interim PM, Mahathir, propped up by the PH coalition, did not have the numbers for a majority.

The announcement from the palace ( Istana Negara ) said Muhyiddin has been chosen as he is “the MP who likely commands the confidence of the majority MPs in the Dewan Rakyat”. Over the past couple of days, the king has reportedly met all the 222 MPs and sought their written declaration of support.

Muhyiddin is president of the Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (PPBM); the party, which is in the eye of this political storm, was formed and led by Mahathir in 2016. The latter, however, relinquished his post as chairman after some PPBM MPs colluded to bring down the PH government in late-night intrigue last Sunday.

Interestingly, the all-Malay force headed by Muhyiddin that is set to take power in a swearing-in ceremony on Sunday has at its core the Barisan Nasional, which still considers Najib as a key leader. Currently, it sits in opposition with UMNO and PAS, two pro-Malay parties, as its mainstay. It was convincingly overthrown by the electorate in 2018 against the backdrop of a billion-dollar corruption scandal involving 1MDB.

Questioning Najib on the embezzlement and joining ranks with his once-staunchest adversary Anwar Ibrahim , Mahathir rode to power in May 2018 and raised hopes of a new, clean Malaysia, with his PPBM party joining Anwar’s PKR party, even promising to pass on the baton to Anwar.

But the reluctance of keeping that promise, together with ambitions of Anwar’s own deputy Azmin Ali , brought out the ugly cracks into the open.

Anwar, backed by the PH coalition, continues to support Mahathir as the PM candidate. In a meeting on Saturday, PH leaders disputed the figures quoted by the Muhyiddin-led coalition and claimed the majority of PPBM members are still rooting for Mahathir as PM.

Muhyiddin is expected to head a new coalition comprising the breakaway faction of PPBM, UMNO, PAS, and other small parties.

Meanwhile, sources in political circles here who keep a close watch on India-Malaysia relations called Muhyiddin an inclusive leader, respectful of all religions and races, and widely supported by the royalty of Malaysia. In fact, his name surfaced after the Council of Rulers, including the current Sultan of Johor, met the king on Friday to bring about a credible resolution of a situation that has angered Malaysians across the race divide.

Experts warn this may still not be the end and on March 9, when parliament meets for a vote of confidence, the saga could unfold another surprise.

Title: liverpool: Liverpool's 44-match unbeaten run in Premier League ends in a thrashing at Watford
Content:
Reuters Photo

LONDON: Liverpool 's unbeaten run of success in this season's Premier League was ended in unfathomable fashion on Saturday as struggling Watford hammered the European champions 3-0 at their ecstatic Vicarage Road stadium.

Ismaila Sarr inspired the extraordinary upset, stunning Liverpool with two goals in six second-half minutes before he set up captain Troy Deeney with a third for the team who had started the day one from bottom, 55 points behind the runaway leaders.

Liverpool's first league defeat of the season meant the end of their hopes of going the whole league campaign as unbeaten as the new 'Invincibles' after 44 league matches without a defeat.

It also came on the evening when they were expected to surpass champions Manchester City by creating a new English top-flight record of 19 successive league victories.

The setback will doubtless not stop Juergen Klopp's men going on to lift their first English title for 30 years as they still remain 22 points ahead of their nearest pursuers, yet their season's aura of domestic invincibility has now been demolished.

Liverpool had previously dropped only two points in the league this season -- their draw at Manchester United in October -- but from the start, Watford attacked them with unexpected vigour.

Watford had looked the more likely to break the deadlock in the first half with Gerard Deulofeu proving Liverpool's main tormentor before he was taken off by stretcher with a knee injury.

Yet it was only when Sarr struck twice just before the hour mark and then turned provider for Deeney to shoot home a third that the 'mission impossible' became a reality.

Title: April onwards, Indians will pay $50,000 more for US investor visa
Content:

, a media

programme, the

daily said in the report on Friday

In 2019, the EB-5 investor visa programme, for the first time since the 1990’s, increased the minimum investment amount to $900,000. With this increase, the new 5% additional tax would mean that applicants would have to pay the extra $50,000, when they move

money

to an escrow account in the US to fulfil their application criterion
