They sit on dharna from afternoon till evening on a daily basis. Meanwhile, police have asked them to discontinue the protest and also denied permission when locals sought necessary police permission to hold a dharna.

The group of representatives went to meet CP R B Brahmbhatt, but as the latter was on leave, they submitted the application in office for submission of applications. Later, as they were leaving the office, a cop from Patel's office approached the group in the parking area on the campus and told them that Patel wanted to meet them.

The group of around seven persons went to meet Patel, whose regular posting in city is of joint commissioner of police sector II.

Parikshit Rathod, state general secretary of Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) who was among the group, said: “Patel started asking us why scheduled caste people were getting involved in it (anti-CAA protest). He indirectly told the representatives that they are Pakistani and Bangladeshi and refused to give us permission to continue dharna. He also denied to give the refusal in writing," Rathod alleged.

The group members claimed that they left their mobile phones outside Patel's office as they were instructed by staff to do so.

Title: Bihar: PACS chief, three others held for boozing
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: Police on Saturday raided a flat at Pranjal Apartment on West Boring Canal Road under the Sri Krishnapuri police station area here and arrested Balwant Kumar Singh, president of a primary agriculture cooperative society (PACS), and three others while they were enjoying a liquor party.

Singh is the president of Bikramganj PACS in Rohtas district. The three other arrested people were identified as Sanjay Upadhyay, Dilip Kumar Mishra and Deepak Prakash, all residents of Bikramganj.

Acting on a tip-off, police raided flat number 106 of the apartment around 1pm. Singh was staying at the flat as tenant.

SHO of Sri Krishnapuri police station Neeraj Kumar Singh said an empty liquor bottle was seized from spot. “The four were in an inebriated condition. Breathalyzer tests also confirmed that they were drunk,” he said.

Title: Airfares skyrocket as Holi approaches
Content:
PATNA: With Holi around the corner, the one-way fare of flights from Delhi, Kolkata and Mumbai to Patna has witnessed a steep surge.

If the data available on online travel websites are anything to go by, a trip from Delhi to Patna between March 1 and 9 can cost at least Rs 7,000 per person. The average airfare on the Delhi-Patna route is usually Rs 2,500-Rs 4,500, but the price of a ticket for a flight on March 8, two days before Holi, has gone up to Rs 11,216. Similarly, the airfare on the Mumbai-Patna route, which is priced around Rs 4,022 on normal days, has increased to Rs 15,704.

Aviation analysts attributed the rise in demand for tickets of Patna-bound flights as the main reason for the surge in fares. An executive of GoAir in Patna told this newspaper, “The Delhi-Patna and Mumbai-Patna routes witness the maximum rush of passengers. Hence, the fares go up during the festive season.”

An IndiGo executive claimed that there had been a significant surge in last-minute bookings for Patna-bound flights.

“Hundreds of people return to Patna from cities like New Delhi, Mumbai, Pune and Kolkata before Holi. However, most of them book their tickets a week or a fortnight before the festival,” he said.

The price of a return ticket from Patna to Delhi two days after Holi is in the range of Rs 5,500 to Rs 10,000. The price of the same ticket has dropped to Rs 3,890 on March 16.

According to travel agents in the city, getting a confirmed railway ticket is almost impossible during festivals like Holi. As a result, people prefer flights, whose tickets are expensive.

“Most people living outside the state come home to celebrate festivals with their families. Since trains witness heavy passenger rush, a number of them choose flights,” said Mritunjay Kumar, the employee of a city-based travel agency.

Prakash Singh, the owner of another agency, claimed that people booking tickets almost three months before Holi had to pay a high amount. “Usually, those, who book tickets one or two months prior to the date of their travel, pay lower fares than those, who do last-minute bookings. However, during festivals like Holi, most passengers have to pay a high amount,” he said.

Meanwhile, flyers are of the view that the exorbitant airfares charged by different airlines create a lot of pressure on their budgets.

“I do not think I will be able to celebrate Holi at home this time. The flight ticket is overpriced and I cannot afford it right now. Besides, there are no confirmed tickets in trains,” Shristy Sonal, the student of a private college, told this reporter over phone from Noida.

Title: Sugar factory workers call off their stir, blame local officials
Content:
The sugarcane workers want a hike in wages from Rs250 per tonne to Rs400 per tonne to cut sugarcane

Surat: Sugar factory workers , who were on strike since Friday to demand higher wages from their employers in south Gujarat, called off their agitation after local administration revoked the permission of a rally in front of Bardoli sugar factory.

“We planned to hold a meeting and a rally in front of Bardoli sugar factory on Saturday. We were granted permission by the executive sub magistrate of Bardoli on 27 February. However, the local administration revoked the permission under pressure from owners of sugar factories. Thus, we decided to call off our agitation in protest,” a sugarcane worker said.

“The sugarcane workers want a hike in wages from Rs250 per tonne to Rs400 per tonne to cut sugarcane. It takes 14 hours for two labourers to cut one tonne of sugarcane. It is a hard job,” the sugarcane worker added. About 30 per cent of workers, mostly tribals, did not go to factories on Friday. There are about 13 sugar factories in south Gujarat, which produces 85 lakh tonnes of sugarcane per annum.

“Block administration cancelled its permission for a public meeting due to enormous pressure brought on them by managements of sugar factories. There is a fear among them that the stir could spread throughout the state,” said Jayesh Gamit, secretary of Majur Adhikar Manch.

Union leaders claimed that they were also threatened of dire consequences by some anti-social elements and asked to leave the area. “Given the prevailing atmosphere of terror, the manch has decided to withdraw its call for strike to ensure safety of workers,” a MAM press statement said. The MAM on Saturday submitted a memorandum to chief minister on the demand of workers through local administration. The memorandum has said that the workers were being exploited by sugar factories and that the working conditions continue to remain poor for them.

It is estimated that almost two lakh tribal workers migrate from tribal-dominated districts of Gujarat and Maharashtra to harvest sugarcane crop in the region during the season. Dang accounts for almost 40% of total workforce in sugar factories.

Title: Get treated by tribal ‘healers’ in your city
Content:
Annual Garden fair by association of people with disability APD, sale and exhibition of exotic ornamental plan... Read More

Surat: Are you suffering from any chronic illness and tired of allopathic drugs? If yes, this may be a good news for you. Seek remedial measures with traditional tribal methods of healing now at your doorstep.

For the first time in Surat, a six-day fair is being organised where traditional tribal ‘healers’ or ‘Vaidu Bhagats’ will give important health tips, medicines for various ailments and diseases which are based on traditional practices. These practitioners will be available for six days at a party plot on Athwalines in the city.

State forest and environment minister Ganpatsinh Vasava will inaugurate the fair, organised by by Shree Pachhat Mahila Vikas Mandal (Bhavnagar), on Sunday.

According to officials, over 130 traditional healers from villages of Dang and Valsad will take part in the unique fair and offer services to heal joint pains, skin diseases, and paralysis among many other chronic ailments.

A fair on ayurvedic plants will also be opened for the general public and where visitors can get chance to see how ayurveda and traditional healing methods are used to treat illnesses.

Moreover, visitors can have a chance to taste a range of tribal food reciepes made from organic food and grains. The unique fair will be opened on March 1 (Sunday) and it will last on March 6. People can visit this fair from 10 am to 9 pm.

The fair will also have a ‘Nahri Kendra’ where visitors will be able to buy food and grain items prepared by tribal women. These items include biscuits made from Nagli, Papad, Makai na Vada, Medicinal tea, green team among many other items. All the food items will be served only on clay vessels.

Besides this, Pithora paintings too will exhibited at the fair. Surtis will also get chance to see Junagadh’s ‘Siddi Dhamal’ during the cultural event that will be held every evening in the fair.

Title: BRTS bus catches fire at Sarthana, passengers unhurt
Content:
The bus was engulfed in fire near Sarthana on Saturday

Surat: Passengers had a narrow escape when the BRTS bus they were travelling in suddenly caught fire near Sarthana on Saturday afternoon.

Bus (GJ-05-BH-2218) was going from Varachha to Kamrej when the driver Kiran Desai detected smoke coming out from the front portion of the bus when it was nearing the Surat Municipal Corporation’s (SMC) nature park and zoo and immediately stopped the bus at the BRTS station at Sarthana.

He tried to control the smoke with the fire extinguisher in the bus, but in vain. Fire spread rapidly from the engine side and all passengers were asked to de-board the bus immediately.

Fire officials from SMC’s fire and emergency department stated that the incident occurred at about 2.50 pm and when fire tenders reached the spot, the bus was engulfed in fire.

Chief Fire Officer, Basant Pareek said, “The passengers had a narrow escape thanks to the alertness of the driver. After he detected smoke coming out from the engine section, he immediately asked people to vacate the bus. Our teams managed to douse the fire within half an hour.”

Talking with TOI, assistant municipal commissioner (BRTS Cell), Kamlesh Naik said, “This is the second incident of fire in BRTS bus in the last two years.”

Naik added that the earlier BRTS bus caught fire in 2018 due to some technical problem in the alternator of the engine. “We had asked the company to change all the alternators. After Saturday’s incident, we will now ask the bus company to check all the buses thoroughly to curb any such fire incidents.”

Official sources said that there are about 165 BRTS buses and 575 city buses plying in the city on 102 km BRTS corridor, the largest dedicated corridor in the country. About 1.35 lakh commuters travel daily on BRTS buses. Apart from BRTS, on average, 1.40 lakh commuters travel on city buses daily in the city.

Title: CM promises Rs 5L aid to kin of Delhi riots victim
Content:
Dehradun: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Saturday promised Rs 5 lakh as financial assistance to the family of Dilbar Singh who died in Delhi violence on February 24. The markets of Pauri, the native place of the deceased, remained closed on Saturday as a mark of respect to the youth who was charred to death after a mob set the shop, where he was sleeping, on fire. The locals also took out a condolence march for him.

Manbeer Singh, head of Paithani Vyapar Mandal, said, “The market remained closed for the day in memory of Dilbar Singh. He had shifted to Delhi barely a year ago and was expected to come home on Holi. The bandh was our way of registering our grief.”

Meanwhile, police informed the grieving family members that though Singh died on Monday, his body could be retrieved only on Wednesday. He was later cremated in Delhi on Friday.

Title: ‘Namaste India Festival’ to be held today
Content:
Surat: Artists from across the country are taking part in ‘Namaste India Festival-2020’ (season-11), which will be held in the city on Sunday. There will be dance, music , mono act , comedy and poetry at the festival being organized by city-based Gujarat International Film Festival Society. Renowned sportsperson Pankaj Kapadia will inaugurate the festival.

“First, second and third prizes will be given to winners in different categories. The programmes will start from 3pm on Sunday,’’ said Abhishek Galshar, one of the festival directors.

“Rajiv Gaursingh, Santosh Singh, Pankaj Pathakji (theatre personality) and Bhumika Barot (assistant professor, department of journalism and mass communication, Ahmedabad) will be jury members at the festival, he added.

Title: Sharon Stone shares ‘samosa packet’ pic, part of protest featuring city photographer’s work
Content:
Kolkata: Days after Pink Floyd co-founder Roger Waters read an English translation of Aamir Aziz’s ‘Sab yaad rakha jayega’, Hollywood actor Sharon Stone has shared an image of a samosa packet that is part of “a joint artists’ protest in solidarity with mass protests in India”. Titled #turbinebagh, this “samosa packet movement” will happen in London.

The Instagram story of the ‘Basic Instinct’ star has an image of a samosa packet shared by London-based architect and artist Sofia Karim that has a poem titled ‘The Price of Gratitude’ penned by her uncle, the Bangladeshi photojournalist Shahidul Alam. The movement, which “speaks out on the rise of fascism, racism and far-right nationalism across the globe”, will host an exhibition in March, which will include a samosa packet made out of a photograph taken at an anti-CAA/NRC/NPR rally in Kolkata.

In 2019, Alam shared the poem as a reaction to the death of a student who had criticized Bangladesh’s agreement to allow India to draw water from the Feni. Along with this poem, a photograph by Alam was printed on the back of a throwaway paper, which was then used to make a samosa packet. Stone posted one of the five images of this packet that was shared on Instagram five days ago.

A screenshot of Stone’s post was shared on the Instagram handle of this movement along with a post that asked people to share artwork that stands in solidarity with the resistance in India. “Email us something to print on a samosa packet. Even a screenshot of old work will do... People are dying in India as far-right mobs descend on the streets and raise their flags. What we see in Delhi is fascism unchecked,” the post read, adding that the packets will be displayed at the “peaceful protest” at the Turbine Hall in London’s Tate Modern on March 28. Some packets will also be sent to protest sites, including Shaheen Bagh.

One of the contributors to this movement is Kolkata’s photographer-turned-director Ronny Sen. A samosa packet has already been made of Sen’s photograph of rapper Kat Jr from the rally on College Street last December. On his chest is written, “Jaat na bhat de (Don’t give me religion, give me food)”.

Speaking about the movement, Sen said, “On Thursday, Roger Waters read lines of my very dear friend and poet Aamir Aziz. On Friday, John Cusack shared a photograph of Narendra Modi where his hands are soaked in blood along with the words ‘Gujarat 2002, Delhi 2020’. And on Saturday, Sharon Stone has shared about Turbine Bagh. It is wonderful that those outside the country are taking note of the people’s movements across India and South Asia at large.”

Title: Crowdfunding plea for Delhi riot relief material
Content:
Kolkata: A group of good Samaritans in the city — comprising doctors, teachers, students and human rights activists — are leaving for the riot-affected zones in north east Delhi next week with relief material, money and necessary medicines. This is the first such initiative from Kolkata since violence erupted between pro-CAA and anti-CAA groups in the Capital last week, killing 39 people so far and damaging several neighbourhoods.

The group has started a crowdfunding campaign from Thursday to raise the money and are planning to leave for Delhi sometime between Tuesday and Wednesday. In Delhi, the group is supposed to work with a team of doctors and students to distribute the relief material in the riot-affected areas.

“This is the least we can do. Seeing the situation in Delhi, we can’t sit back in the comfort of our homes and do nothing. We have started pulling funds from our own accounts and have also appealed to our friends and well-wishers over social media and text messages, asking them to contribute whatever they can to our effort,” said Raya Debnath, one of the main organizers of the activity.

Debnath, a regular face at the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protest site at Park Circus, said she and the other members in the group were moved by the shocking videos and news from their friends in Delhi about the situation in the violence hit-areas and saw how hundreds of people have been rendered homeless.

“We are willing to accept whatever people are willing to donate and while the fund-raising exercise is limited to online transactions, our volunteers will be on the roads on the last two days to accumulate as much as possible. We are also working in close co-ordination with citizens’ groups and NGOs in Delhi to ensure that the relief material is aptly distributed,” said Satabdi Das, a school teacher.

The group is working closely with members of Shramajibi Swasthya Udyog — an organization of doctors and health workers — who will accompany them on the visit and are part of the crowdfunding programme.

“A team of doctors from our organization will be part of the group that will visit the riot-affected areas in Delhi next week. This is our form of protest against the forces that try to create division among our own citizens on the basis of religion and also against the role of the police and the central government in failing to tackle the situation,” said Punyabrata Gun, secretary of Shramajibi Swasthya Udyog.

Title: Malegaon: Pvt firm to handle power supply
Content:
Nashik: From the midnight of March 1, the Calcutta Electric Corporation (CESC) has taken over as the distribution franchisee of the power supplied by the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited (MSEDCL) in the Malegaon town.

“Malegaon’s 1.40 lakh power consumers will have all their supply-related issues serviced by the CESC from March 1,” said B K Janvir, the chief engineer of MSEDCL’s Nashik zone.

Janvir was camping at Malegaon at the time of MSEDCL’s handover to the CSEC on Saturday night. “We have everything in place. All the power supply meters across 16 of 33 KV power sub-stations and three extra-high voltage sub-stations will be read for the units consumed at the transition time.”

“Thereafter, the MSEDCL will be duty-bound to supply power until these sub-stations. All the power going to the consumers, thereafter, will be managed and serviced by the CESC that, in turn, will provide the revenue as per the terms and conditions,” the officer added. He said there will be no change in the rate of power supply and users will continue to be MSEDCL consumers.

Taking over the power distribution, CESC general manager Anirban Raha said that the priority of his company would be to ensure quality and uninterrupted power.

“We are here to serve the people what they deserve. We will first start with a centre for registration of complaints and attend to them at the earliest,” Raha said.

“A round-the-clock call centre, complaint redressal and night patrolling of the power supply establishments are priorities. We fully understand that the network is weak, but our priority would be to connect with people,” he said.

Raha said that the company would pump in money for the transformation of the entire network with quality equipment to increase the reliability of the power supply in the second phase.

Initially, MSEDCL personnel will be posted along with CESC personnel in a parallel arrangement. These employees and the officers will be slowly withdrawn from the system.

Malegaon town consumes about 100 million units of power every month and the MSEDCL could generate a demand of Rs 23 crore from the consumers for that duration. The recovery is just above 50%, another senior officer from the state-run power utility said.

Title: West Bengal plans drive to dispel rumours about chickens spreading coronavirus
Content: KOLKATA/ARAMBAGH: Novel coronavirus cannot spread through consumption of chicken and eggs, said doctors, microbiologists and experts in veterinary sciences on Saturday, attempting to clear the air on the possibility of nCoV infecting poultry and then spreading to humans consuming it. Pradip Majumdar, the agricultural advisor to the chief minister, said the state government will launch an awareness drive o from Monday to assure consumers that there is no link between the virus and chicken.The West Bengal Poultry Federation (WBPF), which is reeling under the impact of rumours about nCoV in poultry products, involved experts on Saturday to counter the fake social media messages on contamination that had spread like wildfire, triggering a 50% slump in chicken and egg consumption and causing losses amounting to Rs 300 crore to the industry over the fortnight. In Kolkata, price of dressed chicken has come down by 20% following the crisis triggered by the rumours.Pointing out that the virus host was mammals, not birds, the experts ruled out the possibility of birds being infected. The nCoV is believed to have spread from bats in an animal market in Wuhan. Thereafter, the contagion had spread among humans, doctors said.“There are 60 variants of coronavirus. Of them, three — MERS-CoV, SARS CoV and nCoV — lead to fatalities. All three have their origin in bats. Though it is now getting transmitted from humans to humans, there is no possibility of it infecting poultry and then spreading to humans through consumption of chicken or eggs,” said RG Kar Medical College professor Jyotirmoy Pal.Barun Roy, a professor in the department of animal nutrition at the West Bengal University of Animal & Fishery Science, felt that the rumour has not only affected the poultry industry, but had an impact on the common man as well since chicken and eggs are a source of good and affordable protein essential to develop immunity to fight against virus.The crisis in the industry has the potential to affect the lives of 15 lakh workers who are directly or indirectly associated with the poultry industry in the state. “The situation is grave. We need to stamp out the rumour,” said WBPF general secretary Madan Mohon Maity.Poultry farm owners in the districts are reeling under severe losses since the beginning of February. In districts like Bankura and Hooghly, price of whole chicken has plunged to Rs 65 a kg to spur demand. But it hasn’t helped yet.Even a major hatchery like Arambagh Hatcheries is witnessing a slide in business. Its city manager Gopal Ray said, “Our farm in Arambagh was closed for a few days in November after hens showed signs of a viral disease. We found they were shivering too much. We closed the farm for a few days and followed all necessary procedures, like removing the ailing birds, before reopening the farm the same month. Since then, chicken was regularly supplied from the Arambagh farm. But in February, when we had healthy livestock, we noticed that demand was declining. It is only recently that we realised that this slump has been sparked by rumours on social media that chicken in the state has been affected by the coronavirus.”

Title: Nagpur: Youth killed, 6 injured in road accident after enjoying party
Content:
NAGPUR: Attending birthday party of a friend turned tragic for a youth after he was killed while six others, including two women, sustained injuries in an accident in the wee hours of Saturday near Gavsi Manapur village on Nagpur-Wardha Highway.

According to police, the group of friends was returning to the city after partaking in a liquor party at Mississippi dhaba near Parsodi. Sources said most of the dhabas on Wardha road allow liquor consumption.

The deceased have been identified as Yash Rahate, a 23-year-old BCCA graduate. Yash’s father Rajendra is an executive engineer in Nagpur Municipal Corporation .

The injured have been identified as Avinash Iyer, Anand Gaidhane, Ankit Tupkar, Harshal Thavre, Mohini Mahurkar and Shivani Giripunje.

Police said around 12 friends attended the party. At around 10pm, five of them left the dhaba while others stayed back. Later, all seven sat in a four-wheeler owned by Tupkar. Thavre was driving the vehicle.

Sources said that most of the people in the vehicle, including Thavre, were drunk. After leaving the dhaba, they took a U-turn on the outer ring road at a nearby toll booth and travelled towards Wardha road.

The accident occured after Thavre lost control of the speeding vehicle at a turning. Many of the passengers were thrown out of the vehicle having a removable top.

In November 2018, a man was killed while two others were injured in an accident after they were coming to the city drunk after a birthday party at one such dhaba.

Yash and Shivani sustained major injuries. One of the injured informed police control room. Hingna police, led by senior PI Sarin Durge, sent the injured to a private hospital where Yash died during treatment.

Hingna police have registered a case of rash driving and death due to negligence against Thavre.

“On Saturday morning, Shivani’s family shifted her to another hospital,” said PI Durge.

Title: Districts asked not to use PVC flex board in government offices
Content:
PATNA: State environment , forests and climate change department has sent an advisory to all district magistrates asking them to stop use of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) flex board in government institutions, banners and posters to prevent environmental degradation.

Principal secretary of the department Dipak Kumar Singh said an advisory in this regard was issued by the Union ministry of environment and forests a few days ago.

“The state governments were asked not to use flex in government establishments as well as in posters and banners to prevent environmental degradation. We have, therefore, asked the district magistrates to ensure compliance of the advisory,” Dipak told TOI.

The Centre’s advisory was in pursuance of PM Narendra Modi’s vision to implement blanket ban on use of single-use plastic by 2022.

Experts said use of flex was highly hazardous to environment and its ban in government establishments is a welcome step. “Flex is almost like plastic and it takes hundreds of years to degrade. Thus, restriction on its use by the government is a welcome step. There are several other environment-friendly alternatives which can be used instead of PVC flex,” Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB) chairman Ashok Kumar Ghosh said.

The state government had banned use, manufacture, sale and storage of plastic bags of all sizes in the urban areas of Bihar in December 2018 and in rural areas in February last year.

The BSPCB and Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) conducted raids at several shops and factories and seized the plastic bags. The ban was implemented effectively in the beginning as the district authorities formed multiple task forces for penalizing the offenders, following which most shopkeepers started using paper bags or cloth bags.

However, the plastic ban gradually became less effective. “It is true that ban on single-use plastic has become less effective and one of the primary reasons for the same is poor recycling facility in the state. However, the use of plastic bags has almost stopped in big retail outlets and malls,” Ghosh said.

He added, “Raids are still conducted regularly to curb use of plastic. We will launch a fresh awareness drive to induce behavioural change among people in this regard.”

Title: Colleges should modernise science laboratories: Experts
Content:
PATNA: A two-day state-level ‘Science Innovators’ Meet’, which was organized by Munger University at the Raj Bhavan, concluded with a call to set up Bihar Academy of Science and Technology for promoting research among the youths of the state.

The meet recommended that sufficient grants should be provided to the colleges and universities for modernizing their science laboratories and boosting up genuine research activities.

“Science teaching should be made more attractive through the application of information and communication technology, artificial intelligence, simulations and scientoons. Collaborative studies should also be conducted with national laboratories and research centres,” said Munger University vice-chancellor Ranjit Kumar Verma.

Verma told this newspaper on Saturday that a large number of youths and students from different colleges and universities displayed well-designed models at an exhibition-cum-competition at the Raj Bhavan. Those, who were awarded prizes, included Ramanuj Kumar (developing land tiller from motorbike scrap), Vineet Kumar (manufacturing petrol from plastic), Sonali Kirishna and Utkarsha Raj (smart stick), Shailendra Kumar, Md Gulam Rasool and Ankit Kumar (conversion of wealth from waste).

The meet was inaugurated by governor-cum-chancellor Phagu Chauhan. State education minister Krishna Nandan Prasad Verma, science and technology minister Jai Kumar Singh, agricultural minister Prem Kumar, PDM University VC A K Bakshi, Patna University VC Rash Bihari Prasad Singh and scientist A K Saxena also attended the programme.

Title: Three-day ‘Vikramshila Mahotsav’ begins
Content:
BHAGALPUR: Curtains were lifted on the three-day ‘ Vikramshila Mahotsav ’ in Bhagalpur on Saturday.

The event, which aims at promoting tourism and creating awareness about the ancient Vikramshila Mahavihara, was jointly inaugurated by Congress Legislature Party (CLP) leader Sadanand Singh, JD (U) MP Ajay Kumar Mandal, zila parishad chairman Anant Kumar alias Tuntun Sah, Bhagalpur SSP Ashish Bharti, DDC Sunil Kumar and former BJP MLA Aman Paswan, among others.

Speaking on the occasion, the CLP leader said, “Efforts are needed to link the excavation site of the ancient Vikramshila Mahavihara at Antichak village in Kahalgaon sub-division of Bhagalpur district with the Buddhist circuit.”

He added, “Development of the site and provision of proper infrastructure in and around the area are required to promote tourism because of the large number of foreign tourists visiting the place in recent years.”

According to historical texts, the Vikramshila Mahavihara was one of the important centres of Buddhist learning in India during the Pala period (8th to 12th century AD). It was established by King Dharmapala (783 to 820 AD) and is located at 50km east of Bhagalpur, at present.

JD (U) MP Mandal claimed that all-round development was taking place in the state under the leadership of chief minister Nitish Kumar. “We hope that a central university will come up near the excavation site soon,” he said.

Title: ‘More signature buildings on the anvil’
Content:
PATNA: Signature buildings like Samrat Ashok International Convention Centre, Niyojan Bhawan, Bihar Museum and Sardar Patel Bhawan, constructed by the state building construction department (BCD), have changed the skyline of state capital. BCD minister Ashok Choudhary talks to TOI’s Sheezan Nezami about several other upcoming ambitious projects. Excerpts:

What are the upcoming projects of your department in Patna?

We are working on the construction of Bapu Tower on seven acres of plot at Gardanibagh. It will document the life of Mahatma Gandhi. Contract for construction work has already been awarded. Some legal issue is required to be resolved before commencement of construction. The project is targeted to be completed in 21 months.

Is your department working on constructing buildings in other towns as well?

Construction of a convention centre at Bodh Gaya with the capacity to accommodate 2,000 people is underway. It is being built with an expenditure of Rs145 crore and nearly half of the work has been completed. The department is also building a Shanti Stupa at Vaishali, which will be 131 feet in diameter and 128 feet tall, spread over an area of 72 acres. It will be made of Dholpur sandstone from Rajastahan. The campus will also have a ‘Buddh Smayak Darshan Sanghralaya’, library, amphitheatre, guesthouse and meditation centre.

Construction of duplex bungalows for MLAs and MLCs in Patna is also going on. When will the bungalows be handed over to the legislators?

Altogether 75 duplex bungalows for MLCs have been built near R-Block and keys for 55 such bungalows have been handed over to the legislators. The remaining 20 bungalows will be handed over by June. We will hand over the duplex to MLAs which is being built near Beer Chand Patel Path by next year.

What is the status of upcoming sports academy-cum-international cricket stadium at Rajgir?

The sports complex at Rajgir with an international cricket stadium will also have indoor game facilities and construction work has already begun. We have targeted to complete the work by June next year. In fact, our team of engineers had gone to Australia and New Zealand two months ago to inspect the stadium there. Similar features will be incorporated in our stadium.

The state government is presently focusing on Jal Jivan Hariyali campaign. Is your department contributing to this ambitious scheme?

We have introduced rainwater harvesting facilities at 11,000 government buildings.

Title: Mahto cremated with full state honours
Content:
PATNA: JD(U)’s Valmikinagar MP Baidyanath Mahto (73), who had passed away at All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) in New Delhi on Friday after a prolonged illness, was cremated with full state honours at his native village at Pakadia in Nautan block of West Champaran district on Saturday.

Earlier in the day, Mahto’s body was brought to JD(U)’s state headquarters where CM Nitish Kumar and others paid floral tributes to him. Mahto was admitted to AIIMS a fortnight ago after he complained of breathing problem. A first-time MP, he was elected to Lok Sabha last year.

Besides CM and other JD(U) leaders, former CM Rabri Devi, leader of opposition in state assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav, former minister Tej Pratap Yadav and Rajya Sabha member Misa Bharti recalled Mahto’s leadership and contributions to society.

State BJP president Dr Sanjay Kumar Jaiswal, who is the party’s MP from Paschimi Champaran constituency, left Patna for Bettiah on Saturday to pay his respect to Mahto. “He was very popular among people in the district,” Dr Jaiswal said.

The CM said Mahto had remained his friend for more than two-and-a-half decades, right from the days Samata Party was formed.

“I made him rural development minister in 2005. Last year, he became an MP. It is sad that he has passed away so early,” the CM said.

JD(U) MPs R C P Singh, Rajiv Ranjan Singh alias Lalan Singh and Ramnath Thakur also paid floral tributes to Mahto at the party’s state headquarters. Ministers Ashok Choudhary, Shyam Rajak, Shrawan Kumar, Khursheed alias Firoz Ahmad, Krishnanandan Prasad Verma, MLC Ranbir Nandan and several other legislators paid floral tributes to Mahto at the JD(U) office.

Title: Corona scare: 2 Koreans asked to work from home
Content:
An elderly woman wearing a protective facemask sits with other patients coming to the outdoor patient departme... Read More

Varanasi: In the wake of the expanding reach of Coronavirus (COVID-19) which has claimed several patients in Asian countries, two South Korean nationals staying in Sonbhadra for a professional project have been asked to work from home as a precautionary measure.

No Coronavirus cases have been reported in Sonbhadra so far. The foreign nationals are among the 50 Korean citizens living in Sonbhadra and are employed by the South Korean conglomerate Doosan Group, which is constructing two power generation units of 660 MW each at Obra in the district.

Talking to TOI on Saturday, manager (human resources) of Doosan Group’s India office Lal Babu Jha said, “Three South Korean employees working in the district are on leave. Of them, Don Kim and Denam Kim returned to Obra after a vacation in South Korea on February 25 and 26 respectively. The two were screened at airports in New Delhi and Varanasi airports and were not found to be infected by COVID-19.”

“The company has asked the two to work remotely for a fortnight as a precaution. A team of district health department also examined them,” said Jha.

Jha said that Doosan Group has roped in around 4,000 employees for the power generation projects in Obra. Of these, 50 are South Korean nationals.

The projects have been commissioned by Uttar Pradesh Power Production Corporation.

Title: Demand for stoppage of important trains at Navsari for Dandi memorial
Content:
Surat: Navsari MP C R Paatil has demanded stoppage of important trains between Ahmedabad and Mumbai at Navsari station to facilitate tourists coming from different parts of the country to visit National Salt Satyagrah Memorial (NSSM) at Dandi.

Paatil strongly represented train stoppage issue at Navsari station during the visit of divisional railway manager (DRM) of Mumbai central division, G.V.L. Satya Kumar on Saturday. He said Navsari has been facing neglect when it came to stoppage of superfast and other important trains.

Paatil told TOI, “The footfalls at Dandi memorial have increased phenomenally in the last one year after it was inaugurated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi on January 30, 2019. If the Western Railway allows stoppage of important trains at Navsari station, tourist flow could be stupendous. We have demanded stoppage of Janata Express, Bhilad Express and Saurashtra Express.”

Title: Silchar prof’s arrest creates uproar; family, friends call it an attack on free speech
Content:
Kolkata: The arrest of Souradeep Sengupta , guest lecturer at a Silchar College, apparently for his Facebook post on Delhi violence have raised a hue and cry on social media, with his family, friends, professors and students’ union at his alma mater, Presidency University, castigating the act and demanding his immediate release.

Booked under at least two non-bailable charges, Sengupta has been remanded in judicial custody till Monday, something about which his cousin, Ananya Duttaroy, is worried about and fear it would take a toll on his mental and physical health. “Souradeep’s parents are panic-stricken about what is going to happen to him. They themselves were humiliated by RSS, ABVP members. Souradeep was also told to kneel down and apologize on Facebook Live,” she said. “We fear about the family’s safety and also worried this arrest might adversely affect his career.”

Sengupta did his graduation in physics from Presidency University in 2012-15 and was the assistant general secretary of Presidency University Students’ Union as an Independent candidate in 2014-15. His batchmate, Aritra Ghosh, is shocked at the arrest. “Souradeep was one of the brightest and the best among us. Unlike many of us, he took a conscious decision not to go abroad for his PhD. While preparing to apply for PhD programmes, he decided to return to his hometown, Silchar, and teach at a local college to give back to his community. It pains me to think Souradeep is in jail.” said Ghosh, who studies at Yale. He added that this incident strongly reflected how the concept of free speech had eroded in India.

Sumallya Mukhopadhyay, who was the Presidency union president during Sengupta’s stint, said, “Unlike some leaders of recognized political parties, Souradeep isn’t someone who wants to instigate riots. While no action is being taken against those leaders’ hate speech, scholars and students are being targeted.” The research scholar at IIT Delhi said if the reason for the arrest was the online post, Sengupta had deleted it and even publicly apologized in another post. “It only projects the intolerance of the party in power and its students’ wing. They do not want people to protest or disagree,” he said. Echoing him, a Silchar University professor said the current scene was extremely depressing. “Freedom of speech is being curtailed and there is no space for dissent,” he said.

Condemning the arrest, Presidency dean of students Pradip Basu said, “The Delhi violence is a result of RSS-BJP’s divisive politics. As a political science professor, I feel our Constitution gives us the freedom to voice our views. This type of incident is an attack on democracy and is creating an atmosphere of fear.”

Title: ‘Govt offering ‘fake’ solutions to tackle climate change’
Content:
Chennai: “Planting trees is not a solution to protect Chennai’s environment, planting trees all over is harmful and planting around riverbeds will destroy the rivers,” said Leo Saldanha, coordinator of Environment Support Group. The environmentalist was addressing a gathering on the final day of their ‘ climate action’ month at Music Academy on Saturday.

Over the past one month, the organisation along with others has held around 70 events, including talks and walkathon involving school and college students and communities.

The day-long event featured talks by environmental activists who criticised the government for offering ‘ fake ’ solutions to tackle climate change . “Solar parks would destroy grasslands and farmlands. Also, the first thing the government is doing is destroying wetlands by setting up industries over them. Later, it complains the city has no water. This has to stop,” said Leo. The talk was followed by a musical tribute to Indian tribes by Paul Jakob and Blaaze. TNN

Title: Coronavirus: 108 kept under observation in Bihar
Content: PATNA: At least 108 people in the state have been kept under observation at their homes owing to possible exposure to the novel coronavirus . Of the 108 people, samples of 48 were sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV), state health department officials said. Altogether 26 people have completed the 14 days of quarantine.Soon after the WHO declared coronavirus as Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), the state health department strengthened the surveillance and control measures against the disease.The state health department has taken several steps to prevent spread of the deadly virus that has gripped China and several other countries. From revising health plans to preparing for emergency healthcare facilities, initiatives have been taken to fight coronavirus . Several teams have been working at hospitals, schools, villages, airports and border areas.State surveillance officer Dr Ragini Mishra said altogether 16,035 and 93,190 people have so far been screened at Gaya and Patna airports, respectively. “We have enhanced the surveillance in bordering districts of Nepal, including Jogbani, Forbesganj and Raxaul. The district magistrates are also spreading awareness about the virus along with panchayats and anganwadi and healthcare workers. As many as 3,036 gram sabha meetings have been held till now,” she said.Meanwhile, hotels and monasteries across the state, especially those in Gaya, Vaishali, Nalanda and Araria, have been asked to report any symptomatic case to the health authorities.The state health department has also appealed to people not to panic or get driven by any rumour. “People should strictly follow the cough etiquettes by covering the nose and mouth using handkerchief and towel while sneezing or coughing. They should frequently wash their hands with soap and water. Those who have arrived from Corona-affected countries should stay at their homes and not go out in public gatherings, irrespective of their status of being symptomatic or asymptomatic. Besides, people with symptoms should immediately call 104 or visit nearest healthcare centre,” the advisory stated.

Title: Rs 2.87 lakh looted from office of financial firm in Patna
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: A group of six armed criminals looted Rs 2.87 lakh from one of the branches of a financial firm near Zero Mile under the Agamkuan police station area in Patna City on Saturday.

More than 12 employees of the firm, Shriram Transport Finance Company Limited, and several customers were present when the criminals barged into the branch and committed the crime between 10.30am and 11am.

The criminals also fired targeting a person inside the office during the loot attempt. However, the pistol misfired and bullet fell down, according to an eyewitness.

The criminals hit branch team leader Ganesh Kumar in the head with a pistol. Firm’s junior executive Sonika Kumari, told media persons that the criminals looked for the keys of the cash box after entering the office. However, the criminals failed to lay hand on bulk cash as it was remitted from the branch last evening. They then looted the money from the customers and fled.

Patna City SDPO Manish Kumar said the criminals were inside the office of the firm for 10 to 12 minutes. “We have gathered CCTV footages from the office and efforts are on to arrest the criminals. A similar incident had taken place at the branch in the past too,” he added.

SHO of Agamkuan police station Abhijeet Kumar said branch manager Rajan Kumar Singh has lodged an FIR in connection with the incident.

Title: Gadhiroli official in state edu think tank
Content:
Nagpur: Probably for the first time, an education official working in remote Bhamragarh taluka of Gadchiroli district has been appointed to be part of a state-level think tank to improve academic quality in school students. Ashwini Sonawane who hails from Pune had earlier become the first in the state department to take a transfer to Gadchiroli where now she works as a block education officer.

As she completes three years in Gadchiroli, Sonawane finds herself entrusted with an important responsibility. At Bhamragarh, Sonawane has been able to mobilize all staff members and initiate new schemes for the district.

Under her guidance the first ever tehsil-level school parliament was organized in which actual elections were held, giving a taste of democracy to students. Sonawane has been consistently working with stakeholders to ensure maximum exposure for her ZP school students.

The 32-member think-tank consists of people from not only education department but retired government officials, who have worked in education related fields, and various NGOs.

As per the government order issued on Thursday, the ‘chintan gat’ (think tank) will focus on providing equal and quality education to all schoolchildren in state. Also, it will work on regularly suggesting changes and improvement to the system.

Education minister Varsha Gaikwad decided to include experts from various fields like science, arts, vocation skills etc and bring them on a common platform for the benefit of students.

The first meeting of this think tank is scheduled for Saturday and till the time of going to press no information had come.

Title: Satyarthi launches ‘child-friendly transport’ initiative in city
Content:
Dehradun: Child rights activist and Nobel Prize winner Kailash Satyarthi along with chief minister TS Rawat launched the Dehradun Smart City Limited’s ‘Child Friendly Dehradun’ project here on Saturday.

Addressing school students and other guests at the event, the CM said that ‘Child Friendly Dehradun’ is an attempt to provide a safe, clean and healthy environment for children in the city.

Satyarthi said, “Dehradun has become the first city to launch an initiative that allows ease of access and mobility for children. It also places children first in a commuter-centric and sustainable mobility plan.” “If our society is not child-friendly, then we need to re-evaluate and rethink our stance on evolution of cities. By launching this project, the state has made a place for itself in history and will set an example for the others to follow,” he added.

On the occasion, DSCL and IIT Roorkee also signed a memorandum of understanding aimed at improving knowledge management on technical issues. Some of the potential areas of collaboration include electric mobility plan, public transport system, traffic plan, drainage systems, and integrated and sustainable development plan.

DSCL CEO Ashish Kumar Srivastava said, “The collaboration between IIT Roorkee and DSCL will open up new possibilities and opportunities.”

Title: DVAC seizes Rs 78 lakh cash from spl deputy collector’s premises
Content:
Vellore: Directorate of vigilance and anti-corruption ( DVAC ) officials in Vellore on Saturday caught a special deputy collector (stamps department) and his driver red-handed while they were receiving Rs 50,000 bribe from a complainant. The official had allegedly demanded the bribe for approving stamp duty valuation for land registered at the Kannamangalam sub-registrar office in Tiruvannamalai district.

Subsequently, the sleuths conducted a search in special deputy collector S Dhinakaran’s office cabin in the Vellore collector office complex and his rented house at Brammapuram, Katpadi, and seized Rs 78.59 lakh cash .

S Vijay, DVAC inspector and one of the officers involved in the search operation, said S Ranjith Kumar, 25, of Irumbuli near Polur in Tiruvannamalai district had recently registered 1.47 acres of land in his name at the Kannamangalam sub-registrar office. However, the staff at the sub-registrar office had said that incorrect stamp duty was paid for the registration and that it should be cleared by S Dhinakaran, special deputy collector (stamps department), Tiruvannamalai and Vellore districts. Following this, when Ranjith Kumar approached Dhinakaran, the latter had allegedly demanded a bribe of Rs 50,000 to clear the stamp duty matter.

Based on a complaint by Ranjith Kumar, a team of DVAC sleuths headed by DSP N Devanathan caught Dhinakaran red-handed when he received the bribe amount from the complainant.

M Rajini Kanth, another inspector of the Vellore DVAC, said that Dhinakaran, to avoid risk, had asked Ranjith Kumar to wait with the money near an ATM kiosk near the collector’s office. Around 9.30 pm on Friday, Dhinakaran and his driver B Ramesh Kumar, 45, who picked up Ranjith in his personal car, collected the bribe in the car and later asked him to alight. “Based on the alert by Ranjith, we chased the car and intercepted it near Sathuvachari Aavin,” said Rajini Kanth.

Dhinakaran was then taken to his office on the first floor of A-block in the collector’s office complex and searches were conducted in his cabin and house at Brammapuram.

Speaking to TOI, Devanathan said, “In the search at his rented house and office cabin, Rs 78,59,270, apart from the Rs 50,000 confiscated from his car, was seized.” As Dhinakaran confessed that the cash was his and he had amassed it collecting bribes while working in various departments, he along with his driver were booked under Section 7 of the Prevention of Corruption Act and remanded in Vellore central prison. Since a search was on at Dhinakaran’s hometown, the exact amount seized could be ascertained only after it’s completed, Devanathan said.

A police team led by Tiruvannamalai DVAC inspector Arul Prasad were conducting a search at the deputy collector’s house in Polur.

Title: Health services affected at BHU as doctors go on strike
Content:
Varanasi: Patients and attendants at elective outdoor patient department (OPD) of trauma centre at Banaras Hindu University had a harrowing time on Saturday when resident doctors went on a strike against alleged misbehaviour by some people on Friday.

Operation theatres also remained partially affected due to the strike. Inspector, Lanka, Bharat Bhushan said the main accused in the case Vishal was arrested after lodging an FIR while the professor in-charge of trauma centre ( BHU ) Dr Sanjeev Kumar Gupta appealed to resident doctors to call off their strike in the interest of patients.

“On Friday, Badri Vishal of Sonbhadra had gone to visit a relative at trauma centre. He reached the OPD and allegedly started forcing resident doctors to attend to his relative on priority. When doctors asked him to wait, he indulged in a heated argument with them,” Dr Gupta said.

“Vishal returned with two accomplices and thrashed the resident doctor. Other doctors and staff reached there and nabbed Vishal,” he added.

Title: Expedite probe to trace 35 missing Akola girls: HC to cops
Content:
Nagpur: Expressing serious concern over growing number of missing girls from Akola, the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court directed the police to expedite the probe to trace them out. Over 35 young girls have allegedly gone missing from the district in two months, and parents of two approached the HC.

Father of one of the missing girls, Kiran Thakre, contended that the police were not taking his missing complaint seriously and prayed for expediting the probe to find his daughter.

Alleging that a boy and his mother had lured her away, the petitioners submitted data of 35 girls in the age group of 15-25 years who went untraceable between August 15 to October 14, 2019. Taking cognisance of the petitioners’ data, the court summoned the Akola SP for explanation in last hearing.

“This information speaks volumes about police machinery’s efficiency and their control over law and order situation in Akola. In spite of such an alarming situation and pathetic failure on their part, it appears to us that the files entrusted to police to undertake investigation into such serious offences and bring the offenders to book, haven’t been opened. This state of affair would impel us to summon a higher officer to the court,” a division bench led by justice Sunil Shukre had tersely said.

After being summoned, the investigating officer informed that additional clues were received by them and a team had been dispatched to search for the missing girls. He also assured to place progress record in the case.

The judges then granted additional time to the police for investigations. “We hope that investigating officer does his best and leaves no stone unturned in detecting missing girls as soon as possible. He should act upon whatever information or clues are given to him by the petitioners, including their suspicion that the mother of a boy allegedly took away their daughters without their consent,” the bench said, before adjourning the hearing till March 12.

(With inputs fronmSanjana Girhe)

Title: Retailers up in arms against wholesalers for med supply
Content:
Nashik: Members of the Retail Chemist and Druggist Association, Nashik district, led by Dhananjay Khandgir, presented a memorandum to district collector Suraj Mandhare, expressing their opposition to wholesalers selling drugs directly to the medical practitioners.

Members of the association said that they had met commissioner of police Vishwas Nangre-Patil and assistant commissioner of the Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) Dushyant Bhamre demanding action against the wholesalers.

“We met the FDA and presented names of the wholesalers who sell drugs to the doctors illegally. We have asked the FDA to take action. Since our demand has failed to evoke any action, we met the commissioner of police and also presented our memorandum to the district collector,” said office-bearers of the association.

The doctors buy the medicines from the wholesalers and give it to the patients. “If doctors start selling medicines, what are the pharmacists for? What is the future of these medicos, who after completing their formal education, are now eating into the business of pharmacists,” asked one of the office-bearers.

The association claimed that the correspondence with the FDA had failed to move authorities to action. “If the administration fails to take action, we will be forced to go on a chain hunger strike from March 4,” the association stated in its presentation to the collector.

The wholesaler druggists and chemists denied such allegations. “The wholesaler can sell the drugs to a registered medical practitioner (RMP) as there is no such ban. Schedule K of the FDA clearly states that the RMP can buy the drugs. The problem could be with the quantum of medicine stored at the RMP’s place. This can be disputed but the FDA has no objection to this,” said Sudesh Aager, an office-bearer from the wholesalers association.

Title: Ahmedabad records a rise in minimum temperature
Content:
Bitumen melting on Maninagar road

AHMEDABAD: The city on Saturday recorded 3 degree rise in minimum temperature - from 19C on Friday to 22C - with effects of western disturbance wearing off. In absolute terms, the temperature of 22C was 5.6 degrees higher than the average, mentioned India Meteorological Department (IMD) website. The maximum temperature of 34.4C was 1.5 degrees higher than the average.

On Sunday, the minimum temperature is likely to remain around 20C.

‘No large change in minimum temperature is likely over the region during next 24 hours. Thereafter, fall in minimum temperature by 2-3 degrees celsius very likely in subsequent 48 hours,’ mentioned the IMD website.

Amreli was the hottest with maximum temperature of 34.6C on Saturday, followed by Bhuj (34.5C), Ahmedabad (34.4C), Deesa (34.2C), Gandhinagar and Vadodara (34C). In coastal regions, the maximum temperature remained in the rage of 27-30C. The state traditionally experiences onset of summer from March, said IMD officials.

Title: ‘Shilanyas’ of temple at Umiya Dham done
Content:
Ahmedabad: Gujarat chief minister Vijay Rupani and deputy chief minister Nitin Patel released a souvenir on Vishwa Umiya Dham at the Shilanyas Samaroh here on Saturday.

Speaking at the function Rupani said the world’s tallest temple being built at Umiya Dham by Vishwa Umiya Foundation in the state will make Gujarat proud. The construction of this temple will contribute to building a New India, working for the development of society. The Patidar samaj has emerged as a community working for every sections in the state, the CM said. People of every section should come forward and donate for social equanimity, he added.

Rupani said the majestic Umiya Mandir, when built, will add to the list of new centres of pilgrimage. The world’s largest cricket stadium at Motera, the Statue of Unity and religious places like Umiya Dham will also help tourism activity in the state in the coming days.

Title: Over 20k state RTE admissions under threat as schools go ahead with boycott
Content:
Nagpur: Over 20,000 school students may lose out on RTE admissions as schools who have not been reimbursed by the state government have decided to boycott the admission process.

Office bearers of Independent English Schools Association (IESA) were in Nagpur on Saturday to meet school owners and rally them for putting up a united stand in their inevitable fight against the education department.

Rajendra Dayma, president of IESA, said, “Over Rs400 crores is still pending as part of RTE payments to schools. There are thousands of schools that have not received more than 50% of their bills. For last couple of years, we have been patient but it seems the government is just not interested in education sector and that’s why it is not responding to our queries.”

IESA refutes charges of using pressure tactics. “We are determined to follow through with our resolution and we do not care whether they cancel our school’s recognition. If they (education department) want to close us down then let them do so, but we will not budge till our demands are fulfilled,” said Dayma.

Gangadhar Nakade, president of IESA-Nagpur, said, “There are no options available for school owners now because we have been pushed to financial brink by the government. There is no logical reason for denying us the payments because the admissions were given the education department itself.”

Abha Meghe, senior member of IESA and director of a well-known group of schools, said, “We are in fact saying that the government should not give us money and rather spend it on making their schools better. This will benefit the masses and ensure quality education for all without dependence on private schools.”

Dayma insisted that IESA does not hold a grudge against RTE Act. “We believe that RTE is wonderful and a much needed thing. But the government has to do the right thing and follow up on their promise of reimbursing schools. Had the state government done its part, then we would have not found ourselves in such a situation,” said Dayma.

Title: Using seat belt on back seat saves woman’s life, leaves her injured
Content:
Nagpur: Safety measures like seat belts can substantially reduce the risk of serious injuries in case of accidents. However, these features can also lead to injury, especially in a high-speed accident. A 55-year-old woman was involved in one such incident recently.

The organs from this woman’s belly moved into her chest cavity near the lungs due to seat belt pressure when her car met with an accident two weeks ago. She was treated laparoscopically at Orange City Hospital and Research Institute (OCHRI) and was discharged on Saturday.

Dr Mukund Thakur, who performed minimal invasive surgery on this woman, said that she was sitting in the back seat with belts fixed when her car hit a stationary truck on Tiosa-Talegaon road on February 12.

“No doubt the woman was saved from fatal injury due to seat belt, but it is rare to see such herniation of abdominal contents inside chest cavity due to seat belt compression,” he said.

Road safety expert Vinay Kunte said that air bags in the back seat may have saved her from injury. “In this incident, other occupants sitting in the front were saved due to air bags. But, a very few cars do have airbags for back seats in India. We must note that the woman was saved from life threatening injuries as she was wearing seat belt,” he said.

The patient’s husband, who hails from Gadarwada in Madhya Pradesh, said that she was brought to Nagpur in a cardiac ambulance on ventilator support. “I was with my wife in the same car. Her injuries were not visible externally, but she was facing problem in breathing. We were lucky to reach OCHRI where all her injuries were treated laparoscopically without opening the abdomen,” he said.

OCHRI director Dr Anup Marar said that seat belt is the simplest way to protect yourself from permanent disabling or fatal injuries. “Such seat belt injuries occur very rarely. But, they are pale in comparison with possible consequences of not buckling up,” he said.

Injured but saved

Woman was travelling in back seat with belt fixed when car met with an accident

Seat belt successfully kept her attached to seat

It was such a high impact collision that seat belt bruised internal organs in her abdominal area

She was not bleeding or had visible wounds

Later, it became difficult for her to breathe properly

She was treated in Nagpur for almost two weeks and is now safe

Doctors said this case is an exceptional and not wearing a seat belt has much more disastrous consequences

Title: Govt primary school students to get fortified milk at midday meals
Content:
Dehradun: Higher education minister Dhan Singh Rawat on Saturday announced that students from class 1 to 8 studying at government primary and upper primary schools of the state will get fortified milk during midday meals from March 12. Rawat was speaking at the first convocation ceremony of Uttaranchal University in Dehradun.

“We are already serving 100 ml milk four days a week to 1.82 lakh kids at anganwadi centers across Uttarakhand. Under the new Mukhyamantri Amrit Anchal Yojana, we aim to provide milk to 8 lakh students of primary schools too. The scheme will be launched on March 12,” Rawat said.

The state cabinet had approved the provision of milk at midday meals in a meeting held on October 23 last year in Almora. Unlike regular milk, fortified milk contains vitamin D and A, folic acid, zinc and iron. The milk will be supplied by Uttarakhand Cooperative Dairy Federation. Rawat also said that every college in the hill state will celebrate International Women’s Day on March 8.

Commending the state government’s decision to announce a holiday on “harela festival” on July 16, the higher education minister said that school and college students across the state, along with their teachers, will plant a sapling on the occasion.

“We aim to make a record of planting trees this year. Therefore, every kid and teacher of primary, secondary and degree colleges will participate in the planting drive (on July 16),” Rawat announced.

The minister also announced that shortlisted candidates for the super 30 scheme will receive free coaching for civil service exams, apart from medical and engineering entrance exams.

At the event, vice chancellor Uttaranchal University NK Joshi presented a report regarding the progress and achievements of the university. He said that a total of 2,688 degrees were to be distributed, including 16 doctorate degrees and 59 gold medals.

“The faculty members of the university have published 571 high-quality research papers and out of 26 registered patents, 19 have already been published. Nine companies have been registered by our students under the guidance of the Centre for Innovation and Entrepreneurship. Producing more than 50 judicial officers in such a short period of time is a special achievement,” Joshi added.

Title: Woman kills 10-yr-old son for property
Content:
Varanasi: A woman was arrested along with her paramour for allegedly killing her 10-year-old son to usurp the property her deceased husband left the minor, under Bhelupur police station, in Varanasi on Saturday.

According to police, the accused were identified as Shanti Devi and Vikas Modanwal. Police also recovered the knife and bricks used in the murder. The murder weapons were covered in blood.

SP (city) Dinesh Kumar Singh said, “A 10-year-old boy’s body was found in a roadside ditch in Amra Akhri area, under Rohania police station, on February 19. Police were trying to ascertain his identity, when they got to know that one Shanti Devi, (35), had lodged a complaint alleging that her son Gaurav Bind was missing.”

Later, police were able to identify the deceased as Gaurav. “During the investigation, we got a little suspicious about Shanti’s intentions. Meanwhile, Shanti panicked and tried to run away with her lover Vikas Modanwal. However, they were arrested by Bhelupur police near Manduadih railway station before they could run away,” said the SP.

The two confessed to killing Gaurav. “Vikas said that he lived in Shanti’s house as a Shanti and the two fell in love over time. Shanti told Vikas that her husband had registered all his propery in Gaurav’s name before his death a few years ago,” said police. She also told him that she could get the property only after Gaurav’s death.

“As she wanted to spend marry Vikas, the two hatched a plan to kill Gaurav,” said police.

On February 19, Shanti reached Amra Akhri area and asked Vikas to reach there with Gaurav. “When they reached the spot, Shanti attacked her son with a knife and then she and Vikas hacked Gaurav to death. They dumped his body in a roadside ditch and fled,” said the SP.

Title: Muslim outfit calls for action against people spewing hatred
Content:
Nashik: The Muslim Arakshan Sangharsh Samiti has appealed for peace in the country and called for strict action against those spewing hate content in the society or on the social media.

The samiti, led by Aziz Pathan, met resident deputy district collector Bhagwat Doifode and presented him a memorandum addressed to the President of India which stated that some political parties and individuals were dividing people on communal lines.

“The riots in Delhi are being attributed to the protests against the CAA, NPR and NRC. But that is not the case. There is peace across the country where agitations are being carried out,” said members of the samiti.

“People are peacefully demonstrating against the government in a democratic manner. We are sure that none of us are taking law in our hand. This seems to be the handiwork of some anti-social elements, who are trying to defame the peaceful agitation of the people,” said the samiti members.

The samiti has appealed to the President of India to ask Central and state governments to ensure zero tolerance against people inciting communal hatred and treat them as anti-nationals.

“We appeal to the President of India to take action against people who are inciting communal hatred between sections of society. These people should be treated as anti-nationals and tried accordingly. When few such people are booked, none of the others would dare to follow them,” said the samiti.

Title: Maharashtra: Burglars uproot, flee with ATM containing Rs 14L cash
Content:
Representative image.

NASHIK: In a theft that lasted just five minutes, unidentified burglars were able to uproot an entire automatic teller machine ( ATM ) unit that contained Rs 14 lakh early on Thursday in the Shirud village of Dhule district .

Authorities said by the time the police responded to an automated alert that was sent to the control room in Dhule — and relayed to the Dhule taluka police station — the burglars had escaped with both the machine and the cash.

Officials said the CCTV footage from the scene showed that at least four people were involved in the theft.

“The incident took place between 2.20 am and 2.25 am,” said inspector Dilip Gangurde of the Dhule taluka police station.

“The criminals arrived in a pick-up van and parked it opposite the kiosk. They then used a cable to uproot the machine. The cable was used to tie the ATM to the van. Within five minutes, they were able to remove the ATM, drag the machine till the veranda in front of the kiosk, load it into the van and flee the scene.”

Gangurde said the entire operation was caught on CCTV installed inside the ATM kiosk. Police said an automatic alert system, indicating something was wrong with the ATM in Shirud village, was sent to the control room. The message was then relayed to the Dhule taluka police station.

Senior police officials then rushed to the spot, but the unidentified suspects had already fled.

Gangurde said three police teams have been formed to track down the van seen in the CCTV footpath. The teams have fanned out in different directions and will focus on toll nakas and other important junctions.

The ATM kiosk is located inside a small shopping complex in Shirud village, 25 km from the Dhule taluka police station. The bank the ATM belongs to is also located nearby.

The police team that had responded to the automated alert was able to reach the spot at around 2.40 am.

Title: Rs 300 crore expressway to be built to decongest traffic in Puducherry: CM V Narayanasamy
Content:
Chief Minister of Puducherry V. Narayanasamy

PUDUCHERRY: The Union road transport and highways ministry has acceded to the Puducherry government’s request to construct an expressway stretching 9 km at a cost of Rs 300 crore to decongest traffic in the town, said chief minister V Narayanasamy .

Speaking to media representatives on Saturday, Narayanasamy said the Puducherry government had earlier submitted four highway-related proposals to the ministry and road transport and highways minister Nitin Gadkari , who visited Puducherry on Friday, reviewed the projects and assured that they would be executed. He said the projects include the construction of an expressway connecting Sivaji statue on East Coast Road with Murungapakkam at a cost of Rs 300 crore. The ministry will construct flyovers wherever required and widen the existing road in the 9km stretch. He expressed optimism that the project will decongest traffic in the town. He said the ministry has also come forward to widen the existing road connecting Villupuram with Nagapattinam into a four-lane road at a cost of Rs 926 crore. He said the previous Congress-led UPA government gave in-principle approval for the project. Presently, the ministry has commenced the process of acquiring land in Puducherry, Karaikal and Tamil Nadu for the project, he said.

He said the ministry has approved a proposal to upgrade and widen the road connecting Mahabalipuram with Puducherry into a four-lane project at a cost of Rs 800 crore. He said the project will be implemented without disturbing the thickly populated town areas and the proposed four-lane road will join the Villupuram NH via Ousteri, Villianur and Ariyapalayam.

Similarly, the existing road between Madagadipet and Puducherry will be made four-lane at a cost of Rs 130 crore. The project includes the construction of a bridge over the Sangarapani river. Narayanasamy said he submitted a memorandum to Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu, also the chancellor of Pondicherry University, to provide 25% reservation for students from Puducherry in all courses offered by the university. Presently, the university extends 25% reservation for Puducherry students only for a few courses, while denying quota for the majority of the most sought-after courses, including job-oriented courses.

Title: T-108 makes fields near R’bore its hub, raises security concern
Content:
Jaipur: The forest administration at Ranthambore has once again rung an alarm bell after tigers are venturing out from inhabiting area of the reserve and becoming a threat not just for humans but for themselves as well.

Ranthambore forest officials on Thursday wrote to the state chief wildlife warden (CWLW) Arindam Tomar to take action regarding tiger T-108 which has made its base in the fields close to the reserve. The tiger, which had previously killed a boy, has been out of the reserve for around four months and is creating major problem for the farmers in Sawai Madhopur, who are unable to go to their fields. T-108 has found a conducive environment as it has also found a mate in T-114 because of which it is not returning to the reserve, claimed officials.

Manoj Parashar, field director, Ranthambore Tiger Project told TOI, “T-108, sub-adult tiger named Jai (T-108), which killed the 10-year-old boy has ventured out of the reserve few months back and has made its base on the on the boundary in some fields. This has become a very serious issue for the villagers who are unable to go to the fields due to fear of the tiger. The worst part is that there is a tigress also along with T-108. So essentially, it is getting food, a mate and its own territory because of which the tiger does not want to come back to the reserve. Some action has to be taken to resolve this issue because of which I have written to the chief wildlife warden to look into the matter.”

According to sources, the tiger is also at the risk of being killed by the villagers. The officials further stressed on the fact that the department should consider relocation of few of the tigers from Ranthambore to other reserves. The Ranthambore reserve has a core area of 392 square kilometre, with a buffer zone of 1,342 square kilometre. Of the total area of little over 1,700 square kilometre in RTR, only 600 square kilometre can be used by tigers. According to the data available there are 51 adult tigers in the reserve out of which 25 are female and 26 males. Apart from this there are 13-14 young ones though the exact number is not available.

The number of tigers in Ranthambore is the highest in the state which also means that the tigers keep venturing out of the reserve to look for territory. “The letter to the Warden is essentially centered on the issue of T-108, there is also a suggestion that in it regarding possible relocation of the tigers as they are venturing out of the reserve too often,” added Parashar. The number of tigers in Ranthambore Tiger Reserve (RTR) has increased to the point that the reserve can no longer sustain the big cats that are currently inhabiting the area.

Title: HC slams police over pending probe
Content:
Allahabad: Observing that even in cases of serious crime, senior police officials have failed to intervene in long-pending investigations, Allahabad High Court on Saturday directed the state’s director general of police and superintendent of police, Kannauj to appear before the court on March 5.

The court directed them to file a chart showing pendency in probe in cases registered across the state over one year. Further, “they will explain whether they have taken appropriate action against lax investigating officers, and if not, cite reasons”, the court added. Hearing a petition filed by one Dharmpal Singh of Kannauj, a division bench comprising Justice Sudhir Agarwal and Justice Rajeev Mishra directed that both DGP and SP, Kannauj, will file their personal affidavits by the next hearing. In the present case, the petitioner said, police investigation was not being done fairly and the accused had not been arrested so far, though the case was registered on July 22, 2018 under section 302 (murder), 307 (attempt to murder) and other sections of IPC at Vishnugarh police station in Kannauj district.

After reading the supplementary counter affidavit (reply) filed on behalf of the state government, the court came down heavily on the police administration, observing, “A perusal shows that, in fact, nothing has been done in the matter though FIR was registered on July 22, 2018. It is surprising that in such a serious matter involving offence under section 302 (murder) of IPC, investigation has not proceeded at all and senior officers have also not taken care to ensure proper investigation. In our view, all officers, including superintendent of police, Kannauj as also director general of police, UP, Lucknow are responsible for inaction since they are supposed to supervise and ensure that subordinate officers are working properly.”
