According to Preksha’s complaint, Upadhyay took money to settle his criminal cases, make purchases of sound mixer and portable storage hard drives for his ashram among other things.

Until recently when the couple’s issues were not resolved, Preksha started demanding her money back. Upadhyay then started to threat her of dire consequences including of registering false police complaint against her.

Lately, on learning about Upadhyay’s misdeeds and registration of police complaints against him, Preksha approached Gotri police to register her plaint too. Cops have lodged an FIR for cheating and criminal intimidation against the priest.

Police said that Kinjal was an ardent follower of Upadhyay since 2009 and after his marriage to Preksha, the latter too started visiting the temple in Warasia and Upadhyay’s ashram and residence in Gotri. Preksha has alleged that Upadhyay has call recordings of several other women as they were trapped by the priest.

“We have registered the FIR and the accused will be arrested on Saturday late night,” said inspector A B Gohil of Gotri police station.

Title: College student, 19, arrested for sexually abusing 10-year-old girl
Content:
Representative Image

MADURAI: The Melur All Women Police have arrested a 19-year-old college student for sexually assaulting a 10-year-old girl from his village. Although he has been abusing the girl for a long time, it came to the knowledge of her parents only a few days ago when the girl narrated her ordeal.

The accused was identified as B Shanmugabala, a third year BCom student. Police said he was the girl’s neighbour and used to frequent her house.

He used to show pornographic materials to her on his phone and sexually abuse her. The girl did not inform her parents initially since he had threatened her with dire consequences.

Based on a complaint from the girl’s mother on Friday, AWPS police registered a case and arrested the accused. Inspector Nirmala conducted an inquiry with the accused and the victim.

Apart from a couple of sections of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act (Pocso), the accused was also booked under IPC sections 323- voluntarily causing hurt and 452 – house trespass after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault )

Title: Man held for impregnating minor girl
Content:
Coimbatore: The Thudiyalur all women police on Friday arrested a 31-year-old Kavundamapalayam resident for ‘marrying’ and impregnating a minor girl with her parent's permission in 2018.

The incident came to light after the victim delivered a baby boy at the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH) a few days ago. Doctors alerted police who arrested the man and remanded him in judicial custody on Saturday.

The man, a labourer, had ‘married’ the 16-year-old girl on February 16, 2018 with the consent of her parents, police said. He was booked under sections 5 (l) read with 6 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 and Section 9 of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006, and remanded in judicial custody.

Title: Over 30% samples in adulteration crackdown found to be substandard
Content:
Bhopal: It is official now. Almost one-third of food samples collected in the city July 19, 2019 -when the drive against unadulterated foods was started - and February 25, 2020, and whose reports have been received, have failed the quality test. Either they are adulterated or are sub-standard.

On an average, one sample was taken every four hours in the city during these past seven months. Overall, between July 19, 2019, and February 25, 2020—740 samples have been taken across eateries of the state capital by food safety officers. Of these, reports of 210 have been received so far, said official sources. And of the 210 reports received, more than 30% or 78 samples have been found to be of sub-standard quality. Four of them contain unsafe ingredients, added sources.

Based on the reports, a total of 46 cases have been registered against the adulterators in the court of additional district magistrate and a total Rs 28.30 lakh penalty has been imposed by the court.

Besides registering cases in courts, 11 FIRs have also been registered against different accused in police stations and action under National Security Act (NSA) has been taken by the district collector against five persons, said official sources, requesting anonymity.

It is noteworthy that since the busting of a chemical milk gang in the state by the Special Task Force on July 19, 2019, a statewide campaign against adulteration was launched by the state government.

On August 3, 2019, Bhopal district administration announced a reward of Rs 11,000 on information regarding adulteration. As per the orders, any citizen who provides information regarding adulteration in food products will get a cash reward of Rs 11,000 and his/her identity will be kept confidential. A list of the contact numbers of officials concerned has also been published by the district administration where people can give information about adulteration at any of the places.

In July last year, the Madhya Pradesh special task force (STF) busted three factories in two Chambal districts that was supplying highly toxic synthetic milk to branded packed milk units in five states in connivance with quality control officers and agents.

As many as 57 people were arrested from Morena and Bhind districts and 20 tankers, 11 pickup vans and 2,275 kg of maltodextrin were retrieved. Bhopal and Delhi are among the main supply regions of the products.

Title: 10th plastic bank inaugurated in Doon
Content: D ehradun-based advocacy group SDC Foundation in collaboration with CSIR- Indian Institute of Petroleum has inaugurated its 10th plastic bank at Mount Fort Academy in Vasant Vihar. The plastic bank, officials of SDC Foundation said, aims to promote decentralised source segregation, collection and recycling of single-use plastics generated at homes, offices and other institutions.

Title: 6 held for trying to lay siege to min’s house
Content:
Madurai: The Sellur police on Saturday arrested six members of the Palani Baba Students Federation after they tried to lay siege to cooperation minister Sellur K Raju’s house. They were taken to the police station, where a case was registered against them. They were later released in the evening.

The six members, led by the outfit’s state organiser A K Shahul Hameed gathered at Minnal Mahal in Sellur. Hameed said they carried out a protest to urge the state government to pass a resolution in the assembly against CAA in order to protect the Muslim community. He said that Muslims voted for former chief minister J Jayalalithaa in 2016 assembly election since she opposed the BJP. But it is unfortunate that the AIADMK joined hands with the BJP and supported the bill in Parliament, he said. tnn

Title: Eight dwellings re-erected in Sanjaynagar razed again
Content:
VMC officials said that eight dwellings were constructed recently

Vadodara: Encroachment squads of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) razed eight dwellings that were erected by families that were earlier ousted from Sanjaynagar in Warasiya where a housing scheme in coming up on a public-private partnership (PPP) mode under the Pradhan Mantri Aavas Yojana (PMAY).

While the civic body razed 1,841 dwellings in the slum in July 2017, work has not commenced at the site yet due to a series of complications regarding land as well as controversies regarding the change of stakes of partners of the firm that had taken up the contract. As many as, 2,637 houses are to be constructed at the site for the urban poor and the remaining portion of the land will be developed and monetised by the realtor.

VMC officials said that eight dwellings were constructed recently in the land cleared earlier using tin shades. The VMC sent its razing teams along with police personnel to oust those who had started living at the site again amidst claims by the residents that they had been granted a stay order by a court.

The eight dwellings were razed by the civic body after ousting those who were staying there with the help of police.

Title: Custodial death: Kin of Barmer youth demand CBI probe
Content:
Jaisalmer: Three days after the custodial death of a Dalit youth Jitendra Khatik in Barmer rural police station, his family members did not allow to conduct the post-mortem and refused to lift the body till their demands are met. Now, the family is demanding for a CBI investigation in the case and this has created a new problem for the government.

On Saturday, Barmer MLA Mevaram Jain, on behalf of the government, spoke to the youth’s family members but talks failed as the family members were adamant for CBI investigation and a compensation of Rs 1 crore. The kin of the deceased youth were still outside the mortuary and did not allow the body to be taken for the postmortem.

Former MLA of Barmer Jalam on Friday late night met the family members and supported their demands. On Saturday, Union minister Arjun Ram Meghwal’s son Ravi Meghwal also met the family members and told them that he will get the matter raised in Lok Sabha through his father. BJP is preparing to raise the issue in the Rajya Sabha and Lok Sabha to corner the Gehlot government on the matter.

Ravi Meghwal, accusing the Gehlot government, said that lately, Dalits are not safe in Rajasthan and in this case, total carelessness of the police has come to light, but no police personnel has been arrested so far. Despite three days passing, there has been no response from the government and he would send a factual report to the PM, party president and Union minister Meghwal.

RLP leaders also expressed grief over the matter and supported their demands. RLP vice president Udaram Meghwal said that the government accepted in the assembly that if the person was kept at the police station for so many hours, then the police would have certainly beaten him up. BJP leaders and the members of the community have said that till the accused policemen are not arrested, the persons sitting on dharna won’t budge from their place and have asked to write to Centre demanding a CBI probe . After Ravi Meghwal met the family members along with the people of the community, the family decided to call for a CBI probe.

Additional DGP Ravi Prakash Meharda has been continuously persuading the family, but they are adamant and have added a new demand for a CBI probe in the matter.

Title: Rajkot: PUBG-addicted 12-year-old steals Rs 3 lakh from home
Content:
Representative Image

RAJKOT: When the parents of a 12-year-old boy in Adesar village of Rapar taluka in Kutch district found that cash, in small amount , was vanishing from their cupboard they grew suspicious. But when the figure of the stolen cash crossed Rs 3 lakh, they were stunned, also because it was their son who had been stealing the money.

“When the parents kept a watch, one night they noticed their 12-year-old boy sneaking into the room and stealing cash from the cupboard. When questioned, the boy said he needed the cash which he had lost in PUBG mobile gaming he used to play with his friends,” said an official from Adesar police station.

The worried parents, who own a grocery store in Adesar, approached the police. The police found that a group of teenage boys of their son’s age group had got him addicted to mobile gaming.

“When we traced the boys, we found that from the cash they had received from the victim, the accused had purchased expensive cellphones, about which their parents had not questioned them,” added the official.

Though the police have taken an complaint in this case, action will be taken as per law as all the accused are minors.

Title: 3 killed as car collides with load vehicle
Content:
Virudhunagar: Three farm labourers, including two women, were killed and 10 other injured when a car hit a load vehicle near Aruppukkottai in Virudhunagar district on Saturday morning. Police said that 23 farm labourers from a village near Kariapatti were travelling in the load vehicle. The incident took place near the Palayampatti railway overbridge.

The load vehicle toppled in the impact, injuring 17 people. The car fell into a dry channel in the opposite side on the road. While the passengers of the car fled the spot, the Aruppukkottai police later arrested the driver identified as Poovalingam, 34, from Koppu Sithampatti village.

The deceased were identified as M Vijayalakshmi, 22, S Palaniammal, 28, and Mari, 55, from Kandianendal village. At least 10 of the injured including Pechiammal, Alagu, Chinnammal, Munianadi, Kathammal and Saravanan were referred to the Government Rajaji Hospital in Madurai. The remaining were treated at the Aruppukkottai government hospital.

Based on a complaint a case was registered with the Aruppukkottai Town police station and an inquiry was carried out.

Title: Textile workshop at MSU
Content:
Participants at the workshop

Vadodara: The Department of Museology of M S University’s Faculty of Fine Arts organised a two-day national seminar and workshop titled, ‘Museum textiles: Meanings and care’. Addressing the workshop as the keynote speaker, Prof Anjali Karolia, dean of Faculty of Family and Community Sciences, discussed the historic textiles of the country in great details at the national seminar and workshop that ended on Saturday.

Around 36 participants including three international students from museology, textile and clothing, and archaeology departments participated in the workshop. Dr Simmi Bhagat, associate professor of Lady Irwin College of Delhi University discussed about the documentation, storage and stabilization of textiles, while PhD scholar Siddha Shah presented the use of Jain ‘pattachitras’ as source of architectural studies.

“The workshop was aimed to develop skill and confidence among students for correct identification of textiles, their proper documentation, proper storage and meaningful displays through interdisciplinary approach and practice,” said HoD Dr Ambika Patel.

The seminar comprised sessions on historic textiles of India, documentation, preventive conservation of textiles materials, stabilisation of textiles, textiles as source of inferences for architectural studies, as inspiration for commercial designs in the field of applied arts.

Title: Cut-off date for solar rooftop extended
Content:
Vadodara: The Gujarat Urja Vikas Nigam Limited (GUVNL) has revised and extended the cut-off date fixed for applying for ‘Surya Gujarat’ (Surya Urja Rooftop Yojana) – solar rooftop scheme that was launched by the state government.

Earlier, the state government had fixed February 28 as the last date for the residential category consumers to get their applications registered under the scheme for financial year 2019-20.

The cut-off date has now been extended up to March 15. Only those applicants whose applications are registered on the Surya Gujarat portal with the required documentation up to March 15 will qualify to get subsidy benefit in financial year 2019-20.

The state government had launched the scheme on August 5, 2019 with an aim to let the electricity consumers of residential category generate energy at their homes and sell surplus amount of energy, if any, to get relief in the electricity bill and earn extra income.

Title: Telangana: Snake dance lands 6 cops in soup
Content:
Screenshot of the video of cops dancing

HYDERABAD: A few days after an inspector was attached to the Cyberabad commissionerate after he was caught on camera performing snake dance , another video surfaced on Saturday of six policemen of Kothur police station, doing a similar act and some consuming beer at an open area.

The policemen in the video were not on duty and had gone to attend the wedding of a constable. Later in the day, Cyberabad police commissioner VC Sajjanar attached the six officers— assistant sub-inspector Balaswamy, constables Ashok Reddy, Amarnath, Chandra Mohan, Venkatesh Goud, Rama Krishna Reddy — to the commissionerate.

As per the video, the cops were partying near the constable’s marriage hall, by playing songs from their personal cars.

Two of them were seen consuming liquor and dancing. Soon, the others joined them in the dance steps. Though the incident reportedly took place over 10 days ago, the video went viral on Saturday. A few days ago, Shadnagar inspector Sreedhar Kumar was also attached to the commissionerate after his video of dancing at an event, went viral.

The ACP was directed to inquire and submit report. In both incidents, the senior officers treated it as misconduct.



In Video: On cam: Cops consume liquor, perform snake dance in the open, lands in soup

Title: Case registered against Manuu
Content: Hyderabad: An assistant prof. of MANUU registered a criminal complaint against the top brass of administration accusing them of discrimination based on caste. Raiduram Inspector S Ravinder said that a case was registered under Prevention of Atrocities Act based on the complaint by the recently suspended K Bonthu. TNN

Title: Pharma student, engg graduate end their lives
Content:
Hyderabad: A second year pharmacy student committed suicide in Chaitanyapuri on Saturday. B Tejaswini had hanged herself in her hostel room in Alkapuri. “She is suspected to have taken the step due to health problems. She left a suicide note saying no one is responsible for her death,” said Chaitanyapuri inspector Janaki Reddy. A suspicious death case was registered.

Devaraya Sridhar, a BTech graduate, hanged himself at his LB Nagar home . Cops said Sridhar was involved with a married woman. Her husband found out about the duo. Sridhar, in his suicide note, blamed the husband for his death. A case of abettment to suicide was filed. TNN

Title: Take steps to promote Tamil, protesters tell government
Content:
Coimbatore: Tamil scholars, aficionados and students staged a hunger strike at Sivananda Colony in the city on Saturday urging the state government to take steps to safeguard and promote the language in all places from educational institutions to places of worship. They said Tamil has been pushed to the backseat in all the walks of life today.

Santhalinga Marudachala Adigalar, of Perur Adheenam, said they have floated a movement to safeguard Tamil. “Tamil medium education has to be implemented in elementary schools, higher secondary schools and colleges. The state should implement the Tamil Nadu Official Language Act strictly in all the departments,” he said.

One of their demands was to use Tamil for consecration ceremonies in all the temple in the state that were under the control of Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments department.

They said commercial establishments should be made to use Tamil in their name boards predominantly. “The state should also have 80% reservation in government jobs for the people who have studied in Tamil medium schools. Like the Karnataka government, the state should also set up a ‘state official language commission’ to promote Tamil. Also, steps should be taken to teach Tamil in schools that don’t teach the subject today,” they said.

They also called on all the parents in the state to name their children only in Tamil.

Title: Trains to hit 110km/hour on Jaipur-Delhi route
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: After the completion of double track on Jaipur-Delhi rail route , the average speed of trains is going to increase from existing 90km/hour to 110km/hour.

Once the electrification work would be over, the trains can attain a speed above 110 kms/hour on the route and will bring down the travel time from existing 4 hours 30 minutes to 4 hours 15 minutes.

As the doubling between Bandikui-Dhigawara was over recently, the authorities of NWR are geared up to facilitate various trains on the Jaipur-Delhi rail route with the benefits of doubling.

“This will also bring punctuality as trains like Pooja Express, Aashram Express, Bhuj-Bareilly, Jaipur-Delhi double decker which used to face crossings between Bandikui-Dhigawara will get through with the double line. This will of course cut down the travel time of the passengers,” said a senior officer involved in the traffic of the NWR on Saturday.

Senior officials added that trains like Shatabadi Express and Rajdhani Express between Jaipur-Delhi were already touching 100km/hour but the doubling followed by electrification will benefit the passengers.

“This will also increase the goods train movement and frequency of the trains. Also, the trains which used to get crossings would be benefited. The electrification is on its final stages and hopefully from July onwards many trains will attain speed up to 120km/hour,” said an officer.

When contacted, Abhay Sharma, chief public relations officer, said, “Trains would be through and this will help us to maintain a good speed between Jaipur-Delhi and Delhi-Jaipur.”

Presently trains on the route are maintaining a speed of 80 kms/hour to 90 kms/hour on the Jaipur-Delhi and Delhi-Jaipur sections. “This will also help in bringing more goods trains and also there might be introduction of new trains on this route,” said an officer.

Title: Arms supplier among 2 held, 5 weapons seized in Jodhpur
Content:
Representative image

JODHPUR: The police in Jodhpur continue to crack whip on the illegal and country-made weapons. In yet another breakthrough, police arrested two persons and seized five weapons from them. One of those has been identified as supplier of the weapons to city youths and had arrived here for this purpose.

It may be noted that in past 20 days, 25 persons have been arrested and 44 weapons have been seized from them which is an indication of Jodhpur emerging as a hub for both weapon suppliers and buyers.

DCP (East) Dharmendra Singh Yadav said that the police have been keeping an eye on the suppliers and buyers of these weapons in Jodhpur and constantly gathering inputs from those arrested so far and from the informers.

“On Saturday morning, we got information that one weapon supplier Ramesh Jangu was in city to sell the weapons. Our team swung into action and arrested him in Saran Nagar area with four pistols. On the information given by him, another person identified as Mukesh was arrested with one pistol from other location,” said Yadav.

These weapons have increasingly been finding charm with those engaged in drug smuggling, sand mining and recovery gangs. Many such incidents have taken the city under panic where the criminals have fearlessly engaged into gang-wars using weapons fearlessly.

“But shockingly, these weapons have also found charm with the youth just for the shake of showing off. They have no criminal records but out fear was that with the weapons in their hands, it would not be surprising if they are tempted into using them and committing crime,” said an officer.

The biggest seizure had been reported in Jodhpur February 14 when the police had seized 18 pistols with ammunition and arrested eight persons including a juvenile.

The probe so far has revealed that these weapons have been making their way to Jodhpur from MP and groups on social media have been acting as bridge between the suppliers and buyers.

Two personas arrested so far as suppliers of these weapons have been found to be belonging to MP and said to have been supplying the illegal and country-made weapons in Jodhpur for past many months.

Title: Act against MPHRC ‘namesakes’, SPs told
Content:
Bhopal: Over two years after the Madhya Pradesh Human Rights Commission (MPHRC) complained to it regarding the misuse of the former’s name by namesakes, the state government has finally acted on the issue.

Last month, the police headquarter informed MPHRC that all the superintendents of police (SP) in the state have been asked to initiate action against those using names similar to that of the rights commission.

Misuse of the name and emblem is a punishable act under Emblems and Names (Prevention of Improper Use) Act, 1950, the MPHRC had informed the state government.

In one such case, an organisation Rashtriya Manav Adhikar Sangathan was floated in Delhi. The Sangathan also appointed office-bearers in Madhya Pradesh, the commission told the government. Such organisations were registered in Delhi but have nothing to do with national or state human rights commission, the MPHRC stated in its complaints. MPHRC chairman Justice Narendra Kumar Jain said, “There were number of complaints related to such namesakes. We wanted the government to take action against such people who used names similar to that of the MPHRC.”

He said that such names were even used for “blackmailing”.

Incidentally, a similar complaint was also filed in 2010 by National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) to the then chief secretary Avni Vaish.

In October 2017, the MP Human Rights Commission filed a complaint with the then chief secretary. When no action was taken, it again sent a reminder to the Congress government last year.

In one instance, it was found that in 2015, permission was taken from the RTO by an organisation ‘Manav Adhikar Association’ to use hooter on a four-wheeler.

Without any investigation, the permission was also granted, the state human rights commission told the state government citing media clippings.

In January this year, the new government issued orders to all the superintendents of police. Referring to the two complaints, the one filed by the NHRC in 2010 and another by the state commission in 2017, a deputy superintendent of police (complaints) said that SPs across state have been instructed to act against those misusing the MPHRC’s name under Emblems and Names (Prevention of Improper Use) Act.

Title: Telangana governor’s relative commits suicide in Coimbatore
Content:
Coimbatore: The Telangana Governor Tamilisai Soundararajan's relative committed suicide by hanging from a ceiling by a saree at his residence in Subramaniyampalayam near Thudiyalur here on Friday night.

The deceased was identified as S Shanmuganathan, 25, from Teachers Colony at Subramaniyampalayam. He owned a medical shop at Seventh Street in Gandhipuram.

Tamilisai Sounderarajan's son Suganthan had married Divya of Teachers Colony near Subramaniyampalayam. The deceased Shanmuganathan was younger brother of Divya.

His mother Gokila found him hanging from ceiling on Friday around 10 pm and rushed him to a private hospital at Thudiyalur where doctors declared him brought dead. The dead body was sent to the Coimbatore medical college and hospital for postmortem. After the postmortem, the dead body was handed over to the family members on Saturday afternoon. Thudiyalur police registered a case under section 174 of CrPC. The reason for the suicide is yet to be known. tnn

Title: Now, parents can get birth certificate from govt hosps
Content:
Jaipur: No more you have to queue up to get birth certificates at the Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) office as now government hospitals can provide that to the parents.

In a meeting held at JMC on Friday, the government has given powers of digital signatures to the hospital authorities and now birth certificates will be issued by them. Representative of around 95 private and government hospitals were present at the meeting on Friday in which government hospitals have been bestowed with this power.

At present, the name of the parents and child is mentioned in the certificate in the hospitals but the signature of JMC authorities is necessary to make it valid. Parents have to run pillar to post if any minute spelling mistake is committed in the certificate by the hospitals. So, to done away with this inconvenience, birth certificates will be granted by the hospitals.

Deputy registrar at JMC Pradeep Pareek said that this will give comfort to the parents who have face difficulties if any mistake is committed. “From now onwards, JMC will not have play any role in issuing birth certificates. There were lot of confusion earlier as hospitals used to write wrong names and parents have to run to hospitals if a minute mistake is committed. However, on a later stage of life if a person wants to make any amendments in his/her name or date of birth that will be done in JMC office,” said Pareek.

With the power lies at the hospitals, any mistake made in the certificates will be corrected on the spot by the hospital authorities. At present this facility is available only at Kanwatia Hospital, Jaipur where it has been fairly successful. However, most of the children are born in other hospitals in the city. The hospital authorities have been directed to install internet facility in their premises to put digital signatures on the certificates.

Title: Pass resolution against CAA, MJK tells govt
Content:
Coimbatore: Manithaneya Jananayaga Katchi ( MJK) on Saturday requested the State government to pass a resolution against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 in the assembly. MJK passed 17 resolutions in a conference conducted at Codissia Ground at Peelamedu on Saturday.

National general secretary of Communist Party of India D Raja, who addressed MJK cadres, said that citizenship should not be linked with any religion. “India belongs to all and not for only one religion. The Constitution of India should be saved. During the riots of 2002 in Gujarat, BJP and RSS planned a mass massacre in New Delhi. India, its democracy and the Constitution should be saved from fascism,” he said.

CAA is not only against Muslims, but against all poor people, Raja said. “BJP threatened to register cases of sedition against Communist leaders. During the British rule, we sacrificed our lives for freedom. We faced many cases. Now, we are ready to face more cases and ready to face BJP.”

MJK leader Thamimun Ansari said there are no employment opportunities in the country. “Industrial sectors have been crippled and the entire economy is affected. The Union government implemented CAA to divert people’s attention,” he said.

One of the resolutions passed by MJK condemned the Union government for implementing CAA. The Act will segregate people based on religion and is against the Constitution, the resolution said. The government should not implement the National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC), another resolution said.

Another resolution condemned the miscreants, who opened fire at the people, who protested against CAA. “Students were also attacked by right-wing people in New Delhi. Members of Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) were involved in violence in Delhi with the support of police. Union home minister Amit Shah, who failed to control the atrocities and violence against Muslims, should resign,” the resolution said.

The state government should take stringent action against the people, who posted controversial messages on social media to spur violence in Tamil Nadu, a resolution said. The conference also condemned AIADMK for supporting CAA in the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha.

Title: Karnataka: Customs unit seizes 1.35kg gold
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

MANGALURU: The customs preventive unit, led by assistant commissioner Rajesh Pujari, on Wednesday booked offence cases against four persons at Kundapur and one at Byndoor after they were found in possession of foreign-origin gold .

Joannes George, joint commissioner of customs, Mangaluru , on Saturday said the unit recovered 1.35kg gold valued Rs 56.99 lakh after purification.

Acting on tip-off that some persons were transporting gold from Kozhikode to Bhatkal, Udupi district police intercepted some people at Kundapur and Byndoor and informed the customs preventive unit here, George said.

The unit rushed to the spot, and seized the gold from the persons after an inquiry. Further investigation is on at the customs headquarters office here, he said.

Title: Delhi riots: Bodies continue to arrive west Uttar Pradesh, toll at 9
Content:
The bodies of both the men are being brought to their native place in Bijnor

BIJNOR: Bodies of North East Delhi’s horrific riots continue to arrive in Uttar Pradesh. In addition to the seven reported deaths of UP residents, two more deceased have been identified. They belonged to Bijnor district . The bodies of the two youngsters are expected to arrive by Sunday.

Native of Bijnor’s Sahaspur, Salman, a 22-year-old youth, who was a tailor by profession, was killed in the violence. Another deceased was identified as 35-year-old Ayyub, a rickshaw puller. The bodies of both the men are being brought to their native place in Bijnor. Heavy police and paramilitary have been deployed in these areas as a precautionary measure.

Ayyub was a resident of Khari village – around 10 km away from the district headquarters. He was staying in Delhi for some time now. His wife and four children lived with him. His brother, Riyajuddin, lived at his native village in Bijnor.

Talking to TOI on Saturday, Ayyub’s brother Riyajuddin said, “My brother Ayyub was residing at a place near Mustafabad in Delhi. He was there for the past 15 years. He was a rickshaw puller.”

“I had received a call from Delhi around 7pm on Friday. My relative informed me that Ayyub was shot dead and his bullet ridden body was found. On Saturday morning, I came to know that he was killed by crowd. My son headed for Delhi. Ayyub’s body is being brought from there and is expected to arrive any moment now. He will be buried in his native village. Strict action should be taken against those who killed my brother,” Riyajuddin added.

Salman, a resident of Sahaspur under Seohara police station, was working as a tailor in Delhi for past four years. According to villagers, his father, Sabir Ahmed, had settled down at Loni 10 years ago. Salman lived with his family members, including parents and five brothers. He was the eldest and worked in Mustafabad. On December 24, he was on his way to a house when he was attacked by a mob. With severe injuries, police admitted him to a hospital where he was declared dead. Now, his body is being brought to Sahaspur.

Police are on high alert. According to official sources, three of the dead were from Bulandshahr and two each from Hapur and Muzaffarnagar.

City’s superintendent of police Lakshmi Nivas Mishra said, “Bodies of the deceased will arrive by Saturday night. Police have been deployed in their native places as a precautionary measure. The situation is normal though. We are maintaining a strict vigil on all local mischief-makers. We are appealing to everyone to maintain peace and ensure law and order.”

Title: Woman, paramour held for murder
Content:
Salem:Jalakandapuram police in Salem district arrested a woman and her paramour in connection with a murder case on Friday night.

The victim was identified as sugarcane cutter V Padavetti, 40, of Avadathur village. He was found dead with his head smashed with grinding stone on Thursday.

Jalakandapuram police retrieved the body and sent it to the government hospital in Salem city for post-mortem.

The accused have been identified as P Nala, 37 of Avadathur village near Jalakandapuram and her paramour S Rangasamy, 28 of the same village.

During inquiry, Padavettis’ elder daughter,15, claimed to the police that she had murdered her father when he attempted to rape her in an inebriated condition.

“Her mother Nala also confirmed her daughter’s statement,” a police official said. However, the police officials were not get convinced and intensified their inquiry.

Finally, Nala confessed to her crime of murdering her husband Padavetti after he noticed her illicit relationship with her cousin Rangasamy.

Padavetti and Nala had got married about 16 years ago and they had two daughters and a son.

Five years ago, Padavetti and Nala separated over a family feud. Nala started living with her daughters and son in the same village.

“Meanwhile, she developed an extramarital affair with Rangasamy over these years,” the official said, adding that, on February 2, Padavetti had returned to his house and joined his family.

Nala and Rangasamy did not like it and planned to murder him.

Nala smashsed his head with the grinding stone and killed him with the support of Rangasamy.

Later, she requested her daughter to give false testimony to the police.

“Nala thought the police will release her daughter after realising that she had murdered her father in self-defence,” the official added.Based on their confession, the Jalakandapuram police lodged them at Salem central prison under judicial custody.

Title: NMR fares to go up threefold today
Content:
Udhagamandalam: Taking a ride on the Nilgiri Mountain Railway (NMR) is sure to pinch your pocket hereafter as the Salem division of Southern Railway has increased the prices by nearly threefold.

While a reserved first-class ticket from Mettupalayam to Ooty will cost you Rs 600, up from Rs 175 earlier, the price for reserved second-class ticket has gone up to Rs 295 from Rs 75. The revised prices would come into effect on Sunday (March 1).

While unreserved tickets were not available earlier, the railway has introduced the same now. In this category, first-class ticket is priced at Rs 520 and the second-class ticket at Rs 175.

The Salem division has also introduced reservation facility for the passenger train between Ooty and Coonoor.

While 40 first class and 112 second class seats will be brought under the reservation category, 40 seats in both the classes will remain unreserved, a communication said.

The railway said the revised fares won’t be applicable for the tickets that were already booked. “We won’t charge them the difference in fare. The charges will apply to only those who reserve tickets on and after March 1,” it said. tnn

Title: Vadodara Municipal Corporation to send senior officials on study tour to Japan
Content:
Representative Image

VADODARA: Senior officials of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation ( VMC ) will be travelling to Japan to study state-of-the-art technology to treat waste water in the city. The civic body is looking to upgrade its 8.5 million litres per day (MLD) capacity sewage treatment plant (STP) located at Kamatibaug that uses Polyvinyl Alcohol (PVA) gel beads.

The VMC now wants to upgrade it to 16MLD capacity, work for which has been taken up as a Smart City project.

The Japanese company that has manufactured the beads has offered an all-expenses paid trip for the VMC officials to visit its plant as well as a STP in Japan. A proposal to send municipal commissioner Nalin Upadhyay as well additional city engineer Dhiren Talpada to Japan in April was cleared by the VMC standing committee recently.

What has raised eyebrows is that the visit has been cleared at a time when Japan is exercising extreme precaution in wake of the spread of coronavirus outbreak in China. It has even shut down schools as a precautionary measure.

Title: Starting out early: Hyd’s band of student entrepreneurs
Content:
Hyderabad: The novel Coronovirus (COVID-19) outbreak that crippled China earlier this year, didn’t spare Hyderabad-boy Anurag Reddy either. Miles away in his hostel room at Lovely Professional University, Punjab, he felt the ripples of the crisis as orders on his e-commerce portal started to pile up. Revenues dropped, and customers became jittery.

Fortunately for the student-cum-entrepreneur, the phase lasted only a few weeks. Now, his start-up – Penguinkart – is up again and racing towards hitting the $2,00,000 revenue mark. “I used to dabble in bitcoins during my second year of engineering, when this idea of floating an online shopping portal, struck me. It’s different from others as we promote innovative products for daily use – most of it sourced from Shenzhen, China,” said the 22-year-old now in his final year.

Anurag strongly believes in starting out early, as it allows for more time to take risks. “These are the defining years of our life. So, if we want to start something of our own, this is the right time,” he said.

Driven by the same ideology are many others from the city, collectively fuelling student entrepreneurship. All aged between 20 and 25 years and still pursuing professional courses, this band of young men and women, have registered companies on their names, offering a range of services – training job aspirants, using robotics in construction, providing retail customers, among others.

“It is often very difficult for students from lesser known colleges to land jobs. That’s also because they are not industry-ready. Our firm bridges this gap,” said Saksham Garg, one of the two founders of Work Minar Pvt Ltd that conducts talks by industry experts/trainers and skilling workshops for these students. So far, they have conducted over 10 seminars across Hyderabad and Vijayawada. The group is currently looking for funding to scale up their reach.

Academics encourage this trend. “It is an extremely rich experience and must be supported by colleges and parents. Start-ups must be viewed as part of education. If this shift in perspective happens and we become less obsessed with jobs, our country will have more successful entrepreneurs,” said Ramesh Loganathan, professor, Co-Innovation at IIIT-Hyderabad.

Gokaraju Rangaraju Institute of Engineering and Technology (GRIET) is among those making the effort. Supported by the college, a team of five 21-year-olds have set up an enterprise – Standard Programmed Instruments – that uses automation to offer solutions. “To begin with, we have developed a kiosk that allows for self-issuing and self-depositing of books at a library. We are setting up one in our college and are in talks with another in Pune,” said Bhanu Prakash Kandula. The plan is to use the same technology to offer medical services in remote villages, going forward.

Sai Kiran Gaddam’s long-term plan is equally exciting: promoting sustainable fashion while simultaneously telling stories about risk-takers. “The Jobless Street (online portal) is a platform that applauds free-thinking and combines it with fashion that complements it. Every piece of garment must have a story behind it. Right now, I am promoting Ikat,” said the ASCI student, scouting for funds.

Claiming that dedication is the only must-have for this job, Rohit Chelta, founder of Warranty Me said: “Even while being a full-time student, I worked tirelessly on my product. I often woke up in the middle of the night to write down some random strategic idea. I single-handedly built the business plan, pricing, managed sales, followed up with technical partners and raised funding.” His is a mobile app that allows customers to keep track of their purchases (electronic products) and avail of warranty services. With nine small retail outlets under his belt, the Guru Nanak Institute of Technology is gunning for the big brands now. He recently received a funding of Rs 4 lakh from the state government.

Title: Cos ride a new wave to make ops water positive
Content:
Jaipur: Running large factories in water-starved geographies like Rajasthan brings its own risks. But for some companies, the advantages that the state offers outweigh the challenges water throws up. Rather they have converted the difficulties to opportunities, building on their sustainability initiatives.

Ambuja Cement runs a 2.60 million-tonne plant in Pali district and construction is currently underway for another plant in Nagaur. Pearl Tiwari, CSR head of Ambuja Cement, said if you want to bring prosperity to parched regions, water needs to be taken care of.

“In Rajasthan, Ambuja is 17 times water positive . We are working not only to reduce consumption of water, but improving its harvest. Ambuja started with 2 villages in Pali district in 2004. Now our initiatives have spread to 125 villages, benefitting 1.8 lakh people and as many cattle,” said Tiwari.

She said in these years, Ambuja has built roof rainwater harvesting facilities in 5,500 households, revived 400 ponds, created 43 check dams and made 40 bunds with the help of the local communities. “Now, we are present in 4 blocks but would be soon adding Ajmer and Bhilwara soon for the water conservation and harvesting initiative,” added Tiwari.

Ambuja is not alone. Kaushlesh Maheshwari, president (marketing) of Mangalam Cement, said they have ensured that their products consume less water. “Our campaign, Jal Kam Jalan Kam, reflects our thrust on saving water,” added Maheshwari.

Recently, at a corporate event at its research and development centre in Jaipur, Hero MotoCorp chairman and managing director Pawan Munjal said they have started a programme to make their operations in the country water positive by 2024.

Hero MotoCorp has a manufacturing facility in Neemrana which the company calls its ‘Garden Factory.’ Vijay Sethi, head of CSR of the two-wheeler major said, “Our facilities in Neemrana have jointly gone through water footprint assurance-cum-verification and achieved ‘Water Positivity Index - 21.14 which effectively means we are giving back water to mother nature by 21 times more than our actual consumption.”

He said the major water conservation measures the company undertakes include large-scale rainwater harvesting projects that ensure water recovery and recycling and recharge of ground water.

Similarly, Udaipur-based Hindustan Zinc has stopped using ground water and using 90% of recycled water at its Rajpura Dariba Complex mine operations. A senior official of the company said that there are dams the company has constructed to meet its demand. “While we have not applied for any water positive certification, our operations are water-positive given the diverse range of activities we have undertaken,” said the official.

Title: Gujarat’s Tasnim shocks Benyapa
Content: Ahmedabad: Gujarat’s promising shuttler Tasnim Mir created a flutter toppling top-seed Benyapa Aimsaard of Thailand 21-9, 17-21, 21-15 to breeze into the quarterfinals of the Dutch Junior International tournament at Haarlem near Amsterdam (Netherlands) on Saturday.The talented 14-year-old, a class IX student of Vardhman English Medium School in Mehsana, who won gold medal at the Asia Junior Badminton Championships and Dubai International last year, put up a stupendous performance to outclass Aimsaard in a thrilling match which lasted 44 minutes.Interestingly Aimsaard came into this match without losing a single game in the ongoing tournament.After winning the first game with comparative ease (21-9), Tasnim faced some resistance from Aimsaard and went down 17-21 in the second game. However, Aimsaard could not deter the young Gujarati girl who held her nerves to pull off a stunning victory after winning the final game 21-15.“This was Tasnim’s second outing with Benyapa as the Thai had outwitted her in straight games last year at the Thailand Junior Open,’’ said Irfan Mir, father and coach of Tasnim.“I remember Tasnim being very keen to avenge her last year’s defeat to Benyapa before the tournament and today she did exactly that,’’ Irfan added.Mayur Parikh, secretary of Gujarat Badminton Association, too was all praise for Tasnim.“She is one of the most talented shuttlers and I am sure she will emerge as one of the finest badminton players in the days to come,’’ opined Parikh.

Title: Haryana man confesses to Tirupur bank robbery
Content:
Coimbatore: A police team from Tirupur that landed in Haryana on Saturday is interrogating a local man suspected to have stolen 241 sovereigns of gold ornaments and Rs 18 lakh from the State Bank of India (SBI) branch at Kallipalayam near Palladam on February 24.

The Haryana police identified the suspect as Anil, a history-sheeter wanted in several bank robbery cases. “He was involved in a SBI branch burglary in Haryana a few years ago. But we could not locate his whereabouts and had issued a lookout notice against him in all domestic and international airports,” a police officer told TOI.

Anil was detained from the Delhi domestic airport on February 26 and was handed over to the Haryana police. “He revealed his involvement in the Tirupur bank heist during interrogation. He said he had burgled the bank along with accomplices who hailed from three states and had handed over the valuables to them,” the officer said.

Senior Haryana police officers informed their Tirupur counterparts about the arrest on the same day and a police team led by inspector Arul from the Kamanaickenpalayam police station left for Haryana on Friday. They are interrogating Anil.

“We plan to obtain a prisoner transit warrant to bring Anil to Tirupur to conduct inquiry,” the officer said. “Anil’s gang was involved in a series of burglaries that targeted SBI bank branches in Andhra Pradesh and Haryana apart from Tamil Nadu.”

Title: 5-year-old girl falls into open septic tank, kin protest
Content:
Salem: A five-year-old girl fell into an open septic tank when she went to the public toilet in Pudur Kallankuthu area in the city on Friday night. While the girl was rescued immediately and her health condition was said to be stable, she has been admitted to the Salem government Mohan Kumaramangalam Medical College and Hospital, where doctors said she had to be in their observation as she had drunk fluids in the tank.

The Hasthampatty police identified the victim as M Srimathi, a kinder garden student in a primary school in Pudur Kallankuthu area.

A police officer said, “The incident took place at 8pm on Friday when she went to the public toilet that’s run by the Salem Municipal Corporation (SMC). The entire area was under the blanket of darkness as there was no streetlight on the toilet premises. So, she did not notice the septic tank, which was open, and fell into it.”

People in the vicinity immediately pulled her out and took her to the Salem Government Mohan Kumaramangalam Medical College and Hospital, where she is undergoing treatment. Doctors said her condition was stable. “However, she needs to be under our care as she has drunk fluids in the tank,” a doctor said.

Meanwhile, the girl’s relatives and local residents staged a road roko at Pudur Kallankuthu area near Peramanur, demanding the SMC to close the open septic tank. Traffic came to a standstill for an hour. They said the SMC wasn’t bothered about endangering people’s lives.

When alerted, the Hasthampatty police held peace talks with the protesters, who dispersed as the former took them into confidence that the septic tank would be closed at the earliest.

Title: CM to lay foundation stone for medical colleges
Content:
Madurai: Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami will lay foundation stone for government medical college hospitals in Virudhunagar and Ramanathapuram on Sunday. Director of medical education (DME) Dr R Narayanababu arrived in Madurai on Saturday to oversee the preparations.

The Ramanathapuram medical college will have a six-storeyed building with 750 beds at a cost of Rs 325 crore on the integrated district collectorate campus. In Virudhunagar, the college is planned with 700 beds at a cost of Rs 380 crore on the district collectorate campus. Deputy director of medical education T Sabeetha also arrived early in Madurai to oversee the preparations ahead of the foundation stone laying functions.tnn

Title: Now, QR code to book rail tickets
Content:
Secunderabad: South Central Railway (SCR) has introduced QR (Quick Response) code ticketing, to cater to passengers purchasing unreserved tickets on a daily basis.

“QR codes have been supplied to all railway stations. This will help passengers book tickets through unreserved ticketing system at the station and also at one kilometre radius from the station by scanning the QR code ,” reads an official release from SCR.

Another feature has also been added to the Automatic Ticket Vending Machine (ATVM), where top 30 destination stations have been defined for each ATVM, based on the frequent transactions. TNN

Title: Two murders reported in 24 hrs in rural areas
Content:
Coimbatore: Two murders were reported from the rural areas on Saturday.

A 21-year-old man strangulated his girlfriend at her house in Keeranatham on Friday. Police identified him as R Dinesh of Sanganoor Road at Ganapathy. “He was working as an interior designer and was in love with M Nandhini of Kallukuzhi in Keeranatham for the last six years. Nandhini was a final year BSc Mathematics student at the Government Arts College here. Her parents had told Dinesh that they would arrange their marriage after she completes her study. But he was not ready to wait and used to pester her,” a police officer said.

After a tiff, Nandhini stopped contacting Dinesh and did not talk to him for the last 20 days. “On Friday afternoon, when she was alone in her house, a dejected Dinesh, who had consumed cow dung powder a poisonous chemical came there and fought with her. He attacked her and also forced her to consume the poison. When she refused, Dinesh strangulated her using a shawl. He left for his grandmother’s house at Kurumbapalayam and later was admitted to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH),” the officer told TOI.

Nandhini’s mother, who reached the house after the incident, rushed her to CMCH. The girl died without responding to treatment on Saturday morning.

The Kovilpalayam police have registered a case. Police personnel have been deployed at CMCH to arrest Dinesh.

Though Nandhini’s family refused to receive the body after postmortem, they complied after police officers consoled them.

In another incident, a 40-year-old man was arrested on Saturday for murdering his younger brother at Amman Nagar at Therkkupalayam on the city outskirts. He was identified as S Selvakumar of Amman Nagar, a mason.

Selvakumar’s younger brother S Rajagopal, 35, was found dead on Saturday morning. He was working as a labourer in a local factory, the Periyanaickenpalayam police said. “Both the men were bachelors and were addicted to alcohol. Their mother Guruvammal had stopped talking to Rajagopal as he used to bunk work. Rajagopal used to pick up quarrels with Selvakumar,” an officer from the Periyanaickenpalayam police station said.

On Friday night, when Rajagopal had a fight with mother, Selvakumar intervened. “Rajagopal assaulted Selvakumar using his hands. Later, when Rajagopal was sleeping, Selvakumar strangulated his brother. He told their neighbours that Rajagopal had committed suicide by hanging,” the officer said.

But he confessed to the crime when police grilled him.

Title: Debris keeps piling on Rajaji hospital campus
Content:
Madurai: All sorts of debris continue to pile up on and around the campus of Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) amid the authorities’ apathy. Debris accumulated from demolition work, construction work and repair works are not cleared on time.

“The Public Works Department (PWD) is responsible for maintenance work. However, they do not remove the debris regularly. Only after a sizeable amount gathers do they take it away but even that is delayed sometimes,” said a source from the hospital. Nearby ward 51of the GRH, which houses the X-Ray and Scan departments, a huge pile of broken down bricks, stones and wood has been lying unattended for days. It is likely to attract rats and insects as attenders of some patients throw away food waste on top of it. “It causes foul smell and also so much dust is released from the brick pile,” said an attender of a patient.

In many spots around the GRH, the leftovers from many kinds of repair work-broken toilets, sinks, wooden furniture and boards- are left in piles. Near the department of respiratory medicine, a dilapidated jeep with sand, left over from construction work, has been left lying unattended for a long time. “At times even we forget when the debris was left behind as it is not a pressing issue for us,” said a hospital staff. Hospital authorities remained defensive and said that delays in clearing the debris were inevitable and as long as it does not get in the way of functioning of the hospital or cause disturbance to patients and doctors, it would not be an issue. “The PWD does periodical checks and makes a note of everything. It is understandable for delays to occur and you cannot expect them to come every other day to remove the debris,” said a source.

Title: Conduct inquiry into Delhi violence: CPI
Content:
Coimbatore: Union home minister Amit Shah is spreading unfounded lies that the opposition parties are responsible for the violence and arson in New Delhi that led to the death of more than 20 people, national secretary of Communist Party of India (CPI) D Raja said here on Saturday.

CPI seeks a fair and through inquiry into the violence, Raja told reporters. “More than half the people who died have died due to bullet wounds. Who instigated this mob violence and gun culture? The Delhi police, which is under the control of Amit Shah, did not take steps to control the violence or maintain peace in the capital. Why was the BJP leaders, who had made hate speeches, not arrested?”

The Centre should be open-minded on the issue and repeal the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), against which people across the country have been protesting, Raja said. “Leaders of 20 political parties, including the Congress and CPI, have written to the President to speak to the Centre and repeal CAA. CPI had opposed it when the bill was tabled in the Parliament.”

Speaking about the nod by the Aam Aadmi Party government in New Delhi to prosecute former Jawaharlal Nehru University Students’ Association (JNUSU) and CPI representative Kanhaiya Kumar and nine others in a sedition case for allegedly raising anti-India slogans during an event in the university campus in 2016, Raja said CPI would face the case politically and legally. “Who put pressure on the AAP government to allow the prosecution? Arvind Kejriwal himself had earlier said the videos against Kanhaiya Kumar and others were doctored. The case was false and made up.”

Speaking about US president Donald Trump’s recent visit to India, the CPI leader said the visit helped US and not India. “Trump has succeeded in boosting the US economy by acquiring huge markets in India. Subsequently, India has entered a comprehensive global strategic partnership. So far, India’s foreign policy was independent. Now, by entering the partnership, India has given up this independence and has bowed down willingly to US’s strategic interests,” he said.

The Centre has abdicated its responsibility from the country’s economy and is keen on privatising the public sector undertakings, Raja said. “Unemployment is high. People’s buying capacity and Rupee value are low,” he said.

Title: One more dies as Salem bus accident, toll rises to 10
Content:
Salem: The death toll in the bus accidentinvolving Nepalis has now risen to 10. One of the accident victims, who was getting treated ata private hospital in Coimbatore, passed away early Saturday morning.The deceased was Manju Roy Devi, 55, of Nepal. Her husband Beer Bahadur Roy also succumbed to injuries at the Salem government medical college hospital on February 20. The police are taking steps to airlift her body from Coimbatore to Nepal.

A total of 32 pilgrims including two drivers and a tour agent had came to India to visit various Hindu temples in the country. During this, an omni-bus that was headed to Kerala from Bengaluru, rammed into the mini-bus. A total of nine people succumbed to their injuries while 20 others were admitted.

Title: Ragpicker falls in nala, drowns
Content:
Hyderabad: A 45-year-old ragpicker drowned and died after he fell into a nala in Sanathnagar limits in the wee hours of Saturday.

The victim was identified as B Venu, from Fateh Nagar. “The victim, goes to the nala everyday at 5 am to collect waste . On Saturday , he fell into the nala and drowned,” said Sanathnagar Inspector, Chandra Sekhar Reddy. The locals saw the victim drowning and reached out for help. The body was recovered in an hour.

“He was declared brought dead at Gandhi Hospital,” the officer said . A case of accidental death was registered. TNN

Title: Indian gaur found dead in Mettupalayam forest range
Content:
Coimbatore: A female Indian gaur , aged around 10 years , died on Saturday in Irularpathi reserve forest near Kandiyur in Mettupalayam forest range. The gaur was found sitting in a water trough in the forest on Friday.

Officials said the water trough, meant to quench thirst of wild animals, was under repair. “We spotted the gaur on Friday afternoon. The wildlife veterinarian tried to revive it. We gave it green fodder, but to no avail,” said the official.

The official said the gaur had fractured its leg. “It could have been involved in a fight with another gaur and could have fallen through the trough,” he said. Despite efforts of reviving it, the gaur died around 11.30am on Saturday, said the official.

“We completed the postmortem in front of all stakeholders. As it had no diseases, we left its carcass in the forest as feed for carnivores in the range,” the official. tnn

Title: Married nan booked for molesting, stalking 19-year-old girl
Content:
Rajkot: A man was booked on Saturday for allegedly molesting a 19-year-old girl behind P D Malavia College on Gondal Road.

In her complaint, the girl alleged that the accused, Dharmesh Zaria, had grabbed her from behind and kissed her, a fortnight ago near her house.

“The girl said that she had come in contact with Zaria three months ago. Zaria had offered to help her in a property deal of her aunt. After some days, Zaria sent the girl a message of ‘hi’ on WhatsApp, and then sent her a message of ‘I love you’,” said an official from Rajkot mahila police station.

When the girl complained to her parents, they approached the police. However, Zaria asked for forgiveness, promising in front of the police that he would never contact the girl again.

However, when Zaria started stalking the woman again, telling her that he would marry her after divorcing his wife. Tired of stalking, the woman approached the police with a complaint against Zaria.

Title: Man gets 7 yrs in jail for molesting daughters
Content:
Rajkot: A Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) court in Bhavnagar on Saturday sentenced a man to seven years rigorous imprisonment (RI) for molesting his two minor daughters in 2015.

According to the details of the case, the accused had molested his daughters between July 2 and 10, 2015. When the survivors resisted his attempts, he threatened them of acid attack, beat them up and threw them out of his house.

After the survivors, with the help of their neighbours, lodged a complaint in this connection with Bor Talav police station, the cops arrested the accused and booked him under various sections of Indian Penal Code (IPC) and POCSO.

Title: Bareilly’s pilgrims stopped fromboarding flight to Saudi Arabia
Content:
Bareilly: Several Umrah pilgrims from UP’s Bareilly who were about to take flight to Saudi Arabia from Delhi on Thursday were turned back after Saudi Arabia imposed a temporary ban on entry of foreign pilgrims to the two holy cities of Mecca and Medina as a precautionary measure against the spread of novel coronavirus in the Kingdom.

Several pilgrims returned home dejected from the airport. Most of them were completely unaware and learnt about the Saudi decision only a few minutes before boarding. Notably, the Kingdom had made the announcement on Thursday.

Mohd Shah, a mason at Faridpur village of Bareilly, was one of them. “After saving money for years, I planned my Umrah pilgrimage and paid Rs 60,000 to travel agent. We learnt about the Saudi government’s decision just 10 minutes before boarding. I wept at the airport as it was my first Umrah pilgrimage. I have been dreaming about it for years. I don’t know if travel agent will return my food and lodging money.”

Elderly couple Chhote Abdul Gani and his wife Sadikan who were eagerly waiting for years for Umrah were “heartbroken”. Their son Mohd Raees, a zari artisan and resident of Juajawaharpur village of Bareilly, said, “My parents don’t know whether they would be able to go on a pilgrimage again.”

Convenor of Bareilly Haj Sewa Samiti, Pammi Warsi, said, “An Umrah visa is usually valid for 15 days and if the suspension order is not lifted, the pilgrims who were made to leave from airport will have to reapply. From Bareilly, more than 50 pilgrims go for Umrah daily.”

Managing director of a Bareilly based tours and travel company, Md Asim Hussain Qadri, said, “Tour operators will suffer huge losses as they will have to return money to the people. We have already done advance bookings for hotels.”

Title: 65% work under MGNREGA for water conservation done
Content:
Jaipur: With focus on water conservation in the desert state, around 65 per cent of work under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act ( MGNREGA ) is done to ensure conservation of water and plantation through natural resource management (NRM). At least 2,000-3,000 model ponds have already been built out of around 9,894 sanctioned under the scheme since last year.

Rajasthan accounts for 5% of the total geographical area in the country, but has just 1% of the total surface water in the country. Also, Rajasthan accounts for 18 per cent of the country's population of cows and buffaloes.

“The concept of model talaabs or ponds was introduced for water conservation. It is ensured that the edge of ponds doesn’t breach when there is an overflow of water. It is done by building concrete embankments and a passage for the flow of water. While this helps in protecting the model ponds from destroying by the animals roaming around, the ponds are also meant for ensuring drinking water for the animals. Plantation activities are also undertaken around the ponds,” said an official.

“Under the scheme, at least one model pond/talab was sanctioned in every gram panchayat,” the official added.

Last year, Prime Minister Narendra Modi had written a personal letter to gram pradhans (sarpanch) requesting them to conserve rainwater for monsoon. Special gram sabhas were conducted in all gram panchayats (9,892) of Rajasthan to sensitise them (sarpanch) about water conservation on June 21 and June 22.

Title: Large-scale hunting of spiny-tailed lizard suspected in Banni
Content:
Over 250 burrows found dug in the grasslands to hunt for the reptile

Rajkot: The Kutch forest department has ordered a probe into allegation of large-scale hunting of spiny-tailed lizard, a species found in the semi-arid plains of Banni region of the district.

The spiny-tailed lizard are listed under schedule II of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972. Popularly known as ‘Sandha/Sandho’ the reptile is known to occur in arid zones of northwestern India including Rajasthan, Gujarat and Uttar Pradesh.

The probe was ordered after a local researcher, associated with a voluntary organisation lodged a complaint with the forest department claiming that he had found over 250 burrows dug in Banni grassland region, allegedly for the purpose of hunting the lizards.

“We have received the complaint and we have begun investigation. We have got the video of empty burrows, but are yet to get proof of hunting,” said Pravinsinh Vihol, deputy conservator of forest, Kutch (east) forest division.

Sources suspect, a bigger poaching racket operating in the region.

The complainant in the case Ritesh Pokar of NGO Sahajeevan said that the spiny-tailed lizards were forced to come out from their burrow and hunted in Navlakha area of Banni in Bhuj taluka.

“This is the area where grassland ends and desert begins. The lizards are found in large numbers here,” said Pokar. “I came her for my research and found these borrows suggesting large-scale hunting of lizards. So I informed the forest department.”

According to forest officials, a major threat to these lizard species is illegal trade and killing to substitute protein through meat and oil extracted from its skin and tail. Locals also consider it to be an aphrodisiac and having other medicinal properties.

Title: NRI tests negative for coronavirus
Content: Coimbatore: A 30-year-old Tirupur resident , who had arrived in the city earlier this week from Malaysia and was placed in the novel coronavirus isolation ward in the ESI hospital, has tested negative for the virus The man, who has been working in Malaysia for the last six years, had landed in the Kochi airport on Monday and had reached the city by road on Tuesday. “He was suffering from symptoms of flu and had gone to the Kovai Medical Center Hospital (KMCH), where he was diagnosed with flu symptoms. A CT scan revealed pneumonic lesions in his lungs,” said Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH) dean Dr B Ashokan.The private hospital referred the man to CMCH, where he was isolated for a night. Doctors collected throat swab and sent it to the National Institute of Virology in Pune. “After a night here, we shifted him to the ESI Hospital’s coronavirus isolation ward. However, on Friday night, the test results came back negative,” said Ashokan. “ He is likely to be discharged by Saturday evening. We have advised him to remain in home quarantine as a precaution.”

Title: Spreading menstrual hygiene with home-made pads
Content:
Madurai: From raising her voice against food adulteration, Madurai’s ‘Paruthi Pen’ T Kannamma is now making home-made cotton sanitary napkins that are safer than commonly sold non-biodegradable pads that may have side effects.

“My husband runs a home-made food product business while I was involved with voluntary services during my free time. When I became interested in learning about herbs and natural elements to lead a healthier life, I was inspired to try making nature-based sanitary napkins as it is as important to a woman as food and water. I did some research and came up with this final product,” said Kannamma, a home-maker from Iyer Bungalow.

The 42-year-old homemaker’s ‘Paruthi Pen Mooligai Napkin’ is a fully cotton-based disposable sanitary napkin that lasts for 4-6 hours with surgical cotton used as the main absorbent.

A typical napkin has a top outer layer made of pure cotton cloth, a second additional layer of fine pure cotton cloth, a third surgical cotton absorbent layer with anti-biotic agents, a cloth canvas as the fourth layer and a final under layer made of paper canvas sheet to give stiffness, all stitched together.

“Everyone’s period is unique, so the main focus for me was to reach the customer directly with more of a service motive. I always give them a trial period to find out their needs. When I interacted with them, many had doubts and this initiated a dialogue. Especially, those with menstrual problems were looking for alternative and safer products,” said Kannamma. The homemaker is helped by her sister S Radha and Sumathi R to manufacture and package the napkins.

What makes these napkins more preferred is the inclusion of neem, aloe vera and thiruphala powder as antibiotic agents. Their presence alleviates the foul odour of menstrual blood. The powder is inside of the surgical cotton absorbent layer and does not leak.

“I soon started creating awareness about menstrual hygiene in schools because that is where change can happen. There, I learnt how children were struggling. Even now, many are unable to use regular pads because they are not able to handle the discomfort. Some children even used unhealthy practices of using cloths or took leave from school, completely not using napkins,” added Kannamma.

Now, with feedback from students, she is trying her best to make the napkins even more comfortable. The napkins are safely disposable by burning. The napkins with wings come in XL, XXL, and XXXL sizes, priced at Rs 150, Rs 160 and Rs 180 for six napkins respectively. The orders can be placed via calls or WhatsApp. Kannamma also delivers her products to customers’ homes via courier and has now found customers contacting her from even Bangalore and Mangalore.

“I felt cheated by a lot of so-called natural sanitary napkins. But I found these napkins safe and comfortable. I also know the entire process of making and there is no room for using chemicals or harmful products,” said Janani B, a customer. With help from her son, Kannamma also released a tutorial on YouTube on how to make these napkins, which has garnered around 4,500 views.

“My motive is not business. Many approached me about how to make these napkins at home. I have given training for a few but one should be careful to always use the best quality of materials,” added Kannamma.

Title: RSS orchestrated Delhi violence: Su Venkatesan
Content: Madurai: A public meeting organized in protest against the implementation of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC), and National Population Register (NPR) on Saturday saw participation of more than 4,000 people from across various religions. The meet organized by various Christian and democratic associations saw leaders from across different political parties and religious affiliations, including Madurai MP and CPM leader Su Venkatesan, addressing the gathering. “The Delhi violence is not a communal clash between Hindus and Muslims but rather an orchestrated violence by the RSS. We will not let RSS spread such violence to other parts of the country. We cannot be divided the country based on religion. We will stay strong united,” said Venkatesan at the meeting.TNN

Title: Karnataka: Budget could offer sops for industries, hints Jagadish Shettar
Content:
Jagadish Shettar

MANGALURU: Minister for major and medium industries Jagadish Shettar dropped hints that the soon-to-be-out state budget would be industry-friendly. A slew of policy initiatives, aimed at addressing issues that are hampering growth of industries, are likely to be announced in the budget. Such issues, having figured in pre-budget discussion with chief minister B S Yediyurappa, are significant during the three-day Global Investors’ Meet scheduled from November 3.

Interacting with industry representatives from Dakshina Kannada at an event held under aegis of department of industry here on Saturday, Shettar said a common thread of complaints have been highlighted while he interacted with the industry captains of the state. “There a few hurdles that urban development department have created with their rigidity on policy matters. They are hurting industries, and efforts are on to solve them, he said.

“We have mooted a middle-level taxation policy where layouts are neither considered commercial nor residential, a move that will give industries sufficient relief,” he said, adding that his department is ready to walk the talk in encouraging industries in Karnataka.

Plans are there to set up Industrial Township Authorities in 8-10 places in the state. They will be self-sustaining development models without taxation interference from ULBs or panchayat raj bodies. “We have mooted a revenue-sharing model where ULBs/ panchayati raj bodies get 30% of property tax and solid waste management revenue, and the rest goes to the authorities concerned that can use it internally to develop their areas,” Shettar said.

Other major concession mooted is to provide exemption under Section 109 of Karnataka Land Reforms Act for entrepreneurs who want to purchase agriculture land to set up their units, he said, adding permission for the same will be given within 30 days. “Likewise, investment permission and proposals of which are cleared by a high-powered committee chaired by the chief minister is not given within 30 days, then the same is deemed to have been given,” Shettar said.

With minimum wages in Karnataka being one of the highest figures, Shettar said his department is striving to strike a balance in ensuring that neither the interest of industries nor that of workers is hurt in implementing the same. The industries department has also taken note of the recent hike in tariffs for industrial use of natural water and will be pared to ensure that industries remain competitive. “We are committed to ease of doing business,” he noted.

Title: Mettur dam retains water above 100ft for 200 days
Content:
Salem: The Mettur dam has set a record by maintaining water level above 100ft mark for more than 200 days continuously for the first time in three decades. Even since the water level in the dam touched 100ft mark on August 13, last year, it hasn’t dipped and on Saturday evening the water level was recorded at 105ft. Meanwhile, the inflow has come down to 120 cubic feet per second (cusecs) from 400cusecs.

A senior Public Works Department (PWD) official said the water level had touched the full capacity of 120ft at least five times during the period. “The dam had reached its full capacity of 120ft on September 7, 2019. After that, it touched the full capacity four more times in the same year.”

While last year the dam was not opened on June 12 for kuruvai cultivation as the water level was not sufficient for the same, this time farmers are hopeful that the water would be released on the customary date itself.

M Kalianna Goundar, a member of Tamilaga Vivasayigal Sangam, said, “We hope that the state would this year release the Cauvery water for irrigation on June 12 itself.”

The dam is usually opened for irrigation on June 12 and closed on January 28. “Water will be released for around 230 days in a year. Nearly 330 thousand million cubic feet (tmc) water is required for samba and kuruvai crops,” the PWD officer said. It is to be noted that the quantum of water release would vary depending on the needs of delta districts.

However, last year, the dam was opened for irrigation needs only on August 13, when the water level touched 100ft mark. The water discharge to delta districts was stopped on January 28 as usual. At that time, the dam had 107ft water.

The reservoir is the main lifeline for Krishnagiri, Dharmapuri, Salem, Erode, Namakkal, Karur (partial), Trichy, Thanjavur, Tiruvarur, Nagapattinam, Ariyalur, Perambalur, Cuddalore and Pudukkottai districts. Nearly 16.05 lakh acres benefit from the dam.

At present, 750cusecs water is being released from the dam daily for drinking purposes in Salem region.

Title: MGNREGA: Rajasthan tops in mandays generation
Content: JAIPUR: Rajasthan has topped in the country in terms of generating persondays, having already recorded 30.04 crore (100.12%) of the total labour budget of 30 crore, under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act ( MGNREGA ). Uttar Pradesh is at a distant second having generated persondays of 22.59 crore, followed by Tamil Nadu at 22.32 crore (as on February 28).The state has also excelled in 'the number of families completing 100 days of work' at 5,72,561, followed by Chhattisgarh at 2,96,904 and Andhra Pradesh at 2,83,094 (as on February 28).Deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot said by paying wages to 99.6 percent unskilled laborers employed under the scheme within 15 days, the state has secured its place among the top three states in the country.Meanwhile, the centre has also cleared the payment of the workers amounting to Rs 800-900 crore up to February 17.The centre has also provided 3.34 crore more persondays (labour budget) for 2019-20, making it 33.34 crore persondays (labour budget) for this financial year, which would be the highest since the inception of the scheme. This would mean sanctioning an extra budget of around Rs 835 crore for the last two months of this financial year, i.e. up to March 31. So far, the state has spent over Rs 6,255 crore.
