The material component amounting to Rs 1,377 crore is still due to be released by the centre.The state’s MGNREGA department, having already crossed the target of generating 23 crore person days, achieving 24 crore mandays by December 2019, the centre had revised the labour budget to 30 crore person days for the financial year 2019-20, sanctioning an additional fund of nearly Rs 1,500 crore.

Title: Man who posed as police officer held
Content:
Dharmapuri: A 29-year-old man who went around claiming to be a cop was arrested by the Dharmapuri town police here on Friday night.

Police identified the accused as S Murali of Kundalahalli village near Matlampatty in the district.

Around 8pm on Friday, Murali, a truck driver, boarded a private bus to Pennagaram at the Dharmapuri bus stand. “Murali tried to occupy an empty seat, but the person sitting in the next seat told him that he had saved it for his friend. Disregarding it, Murali occupied the seat and started arguing with fellow passengers. At a point, he tried to scare them off by stating that he was a sub-inspector,” M Rathnakumar, inspector attached to the Dharmapuri town police station, said.

A fellow passenger, M Deepan, 31, an advocate, alerted police, who reached the spot and detained Murali.

Police found in Murali’s possession a fake police ID card. “The ID card has a real sub-inspector name, S Anbalagan, and his photo, who is currently working in Krishnagiri district. But there is no connection between the two. The card was a fake one,” the inspector said.

Claiming to be a sub-inspector, Murali extorted money from several people, including truck drivers and other vehicle drivers crossing toll plazas, the inspector said.

The Dharmapuri town police registered a case and arrested Murali. He was lodged at the Salem Central Prison under judicial custody the same night.

Title: Video of revellers drinking liquor at wedding goes viral
Content:
A grab of the video shows the booze party in full swing

Rajkot: A video of about a dozen men dancing and pouring liquor on each other during a marriage function in a village of Mundra taluka of Kutch district went viral on media on Saturday. As the video went viral, the local police ordered probe to ascertain its authenticity and where it was shot.

The video shows over a dozen men dancing with liquor bottles in their hands. One of them is seen pouring liquor on another man’s head, while he continues dancing to the music. Other members of the marriage party, including children are seen watching the act of the adult men. Some men are also seen drinking from the bottles.

Border range IG Subhash Trivedi told media persons, “A team headed by a Dy SP will investigate the incident. Stringent action will be taken those seen in the video and they will be booked under the Prohibition Act.” “We will inquire from where they got the liquor. Also, if any police personnel is found to be involved strict action will be taken against them too,” he added.

Title: Karnataka minister directs MSCL to shift abattoir
Content:
File photo of slaughter house at Kudroli in Mangaluru

MANGALURU: Urban development minister Byrathi Basavaraj directed the Mangaluru Smart City Limited (MSCL) to put on hold its proposal of redeveloping the abattoir in Kudroli in the city.

A proposal to redevelop the abattoir, which currently slaughters cattle for meat to be supplied in the city, was included in the Smart City project list by earlier urban development minister UT Khader. Accordingly, Rs 15 crore was reserved by MSCL to redevelop it. However, based on demands by Vishwa Hindu Parishad and Bajrang Dal, the minister on Saturday decided to put the proposal on hold.

At an official review meeting, he directed MSCL MD Mohammed Nazeer to hold the project till a suitable location was identified. The Sangh Parivar has been raising objections to the project, stating that the area has many temples and it’s close to the river. They also have been alleging illegal transportation of cows to the slaughter house.

In a memorandum to the minister, VHP and Bajrang Dal appealed that the abattoir under MSCL should not be built in the city. “Cows are being transported illegally to the abattoir and several cases have been registered in this connection. We have been worshipping cows as revered ‘Gaumata’ and slaughtering it is banned as per rules. While police fail to prevent illegal transportation, it also triggers conflicts if organisations try to stop it. The location identified by the MSCL is not suitable as it has no space for effluent treatment plant, pre-mortem, post-mortem facility, greenery and there are restrictions against setting up slaughter houses on river banks,” they said.

The minister, without mentioning VHP and Bajrang Dal, said, “A decision to hold the project was taken based on the public complaints. People have been complaining that the abattoir is close to the river and the place is not convenient. Hence, I directed MSCL officials to search an alternative location.”

Minister takes officials to task

Basavaraj took officials to task for not expediting development works at a review meeting on development works taken up by Mangaluru City Corporation and Mangaluru Smart City Limited here on Saturday.

While MCC is lagging behind in revenue collection, MSCL could complete only four of 47 projects taken up. It was brought to his notice that 40 development projects taken up in 2017-18 have not been completed. These include construction of a market complex in Surathkal. The minister fixed a deadline of March 31 for all projects to be completed. He also directed deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh to expedite all projects taken up by MSCL.

“Apart from works on roads, footpaths and drainages, there is a need to focus on other development works too under Smart City Mission,” Basavaraj said.

MSCL MD Nazeer said a detailed project report for waterfront development works has been prepared. The 2.1-km long waterfront project from Nethravathi bridge includes a cycle track, walking track, pedestrian path, kiosk and garden. The MSCL has earmarked Rs 150 crore, he said, adding that the DPR will be placed before the board for approval on March 2.

On sliding of waste from Pachanady dump yard which damaged 27 houses, arecanut and coconut farms due to heavy rain in August, 2019, the minister said the government has already sanctioned Rs 8 crore to construct a wall to prevent it from happening again.

Meanwhile, a proposal has been prepared to compensate residents who lost their property, crops and other valuables. It may require Rs 20 crore to compensate residents near Pachanady, he said, adding that the government will sanction the amount soon.

Title: Governor Lalji Tandon to supervise Madhya Pradesh universities online
Content:
Madhya Pradesh governor Lalji Tandon.

BHOPAL: Governor Lalji Tandon will now make a report card of all 21 government universities of Madhya Pradesh and rank them on performance. It’s said to be the first such system in the country where the Governor monitors universities at the click of a mouse.

Universities have been asked to upload every detail of administrative and academic activities — from exam calendar and student facilities to faculty strength, financial status, vacancies, sports achievements and researches — on a ‘monitoring system’ developed for the Governor to get information on his fingertips.

The software, developed by NIC, is undergoing trial runs. On Friday, vice-chancellors were called to Raj Bhavan and briefed on the details they have to send every month. “We were shown the mirror and asked to improve performance,” said a V-C who attended the meet.

Data of the past three years will have to be uploaded so that comparisons can be drawn, say sources. V-Cs have been given log-in IDs and asked to upload data in the given format under various heads.

On ‘strength’, for instance, universities have to submit data on number of professors, assistant professors, vacant posts, when appointments were last held, and number of students on the rolls. ‘Infrastructure’ includes creation or setting up of new departments or centres. Under ‘publication’, V-Cs need to mention innovations, articles and manuscripts.

Achievements cover patients, consultancies, start-ups, commercialization, technology transferred, awards receive state, national or international, sports achievements, conference, symposium, contribution towards nation building, smart campus initiatives, budget, university academic calendar and so on.

Raj Bhavan said that Governor Tandon wants universities to strictly follow the calendar, which is why he got a software developed that will help him access information and monitored at the click of a mouse. “Since universities have to fill all information in digital format, it will make them more accountable and help improve overall education standards and reduce grievances of students,” an official said.

Dr Jayant Sonwalkar , V-C of MP Bhoj (Open) University, called it a “welcome move”. “It will help prepare comparative charts of which university is doing better and which is lagging behind. Accountability of authorities will be fixed. I am happy that such system is being introduced in MP,” he said.

Title: Inquiry ordered into postmortem by mortuary staff
Content:
Dharmapuri: A video of two mortuary assistants performing postmortem at the Dharmapuri government medical college has been doing the rounds on social media since Thursday evening, raising many eyebrows.

While hospital dean Dr K Srinivasaraj has ordered a detailed internal probe, he plans to approach the cybercrime police to ascertain the authenticity of the video.

“I have deputed the medical superintendent and the resident medical officer to probe the issue,” he told TOI.

The government hospital has four forensic doctors, who work in shifts. “There is a technician and two other assistants to help them. It is the duty of the assistants to take the body to the postmortem table from freezer boxes,” a senior doctor in the hospital said.

He said the assistants would cut the bodies in the presence of doctor and take samples of vital organs for viscera test and other purposes as requested by police. “This is the standard procedure in all the mortuaries across the state.”

However, in the video that has gone viral the staff members are seen chopping the body and taking samples of vital organs in the absence of forensic doctors.

The hospital dean said he was yet to ascertain when the video was shot. “I want to know the date and time so that the probe team could inquire with the shift doctor to know what has transpired.”

Srinivasaraj said he was planning to approach the cybercrime police to verify the authenticity of the video. “I will write to the cybercrime police, seeking help.”

Title: Eco-friendly bags can make city plastic-free, says Kalshetti
Content:
Kolhapur: The only sustainable way to reduce the pollution caused by plastic is to carry the eco-friendly bags while stepping out of homes for shopping, said civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti.

Kalshetti was speaking at one of the corner meetings held at several places along the route of bicycle rally organised on Saturday. Reduce the pollution caused by plastic materials, especially carry bags and packaging materials, was the theme of the rally.

Mayor of KMC Nilofer Ajrekar inaugurated the rally at the starting point — Janata Bazaar Chowk at Rajarampuri. Hundreds of citizens, students, civic staff, and corporators participated in the bicycle rally. The rally passed through several major locations in the city and total distance covered was around 35 km.

Kalshetti said, “The KMC has initiated several campaigns to reduce the water pollution and air pollution. We are addressing the water pollution by treating the waste water. The air pollution is being reduced by initiating the no-vehicle day on the last day of every month and use of eco-friendly ways such as cycling to reach to the offices and use of the public buses.”

Further he said, “Since last two months we have taken the task to reduce the pollution caused by the plastic. Now I some trading areas such as Lakshmipuri and Mirajkar Tickti, the traders have stopped dispensing the plastic carry bags. They are using the eco-friendly bags made of cloth or paper. The strict measures are also being adopted, however if the citizens start to use the eco-friendly bags while stepping out of houses for shopping is the only sustainable way to make city plastic-free.”

The KMC has set March 31 deadline to make city plastic-free. If it happens, the city will be first to do so in the state. During the rally, the local leaders participated and assured that they will take the steps to make their locality plastic-free.

Title: Bubble tops in short supply as 1,700 firms continue strike in Chennai
Content:
As 1,700 packaged drinking water units shut down temporarily to push the state government to relax norms, bubb... Read More

CHENNAI: Bubble tops – a common sight in many households in the city – were either not available or were being sold at double the cost as supply dwindled. On Thursday, more than 1,700 drinking water packaging units across the state had begun a strike demanding clearer guidelines from the Centre and state government.

The strike was a repercussion of action based on the Madras high court order to the state to close borewells the units were extracting groundwater from without obtaining the mandatory no-objection certificate (NOC).

“More than 100 units in and around Chennai have closed down in protest. People in need are buying cans by bigger brands that cost nearly double, but we are running out of those cans too quickly,” said Manikumar, who supplies water cans in Vyasarpadi. Residents in Choolaimedu, who were paying Rs 35 a can had to pay Rs 70 on Saturday.

Velachery residents weren’t that lucky. “We were told there is no stock. Our supplier said he can get us a can only when the stock arrives,” said A Priya of VGP Selvanagar in Velachery. Fresh stock is expected only when the strike ends and manufacturers resume production.

It costs Rs 7 for manufacturers to pack a 20-litre can of water. The distributors, who bring the cans into cities, supply it to the retail stores for about Rs 20-30, who in turn sell the cans to customers for Rs 35 to Rs 40. Both distributors and retailers have now increased the price.

Manufacturers’ associations are vehement that they will not end the strike until the government holds talks with them. “We want government officials and ministers to give us a solution,” said A Shakespeare, founder of the Greater Tamil Nadu Packaged Drinking Water Manufacturers Association . “We will not open our shops until government relaxes rules and regularises us,” he said.

Although more than 1,710 units were set up with permission from the Bureau of India Standards and Food Safety and Standards Authority of India, only 600 have the NOC from the state. In 2014, the Central Ground Water Authority revised guidelines to regulate groundwater extraction in India. As Subsequently, the state was divided into four zones based on groundwater extraction– safe, semi-critical, critical and over-exploited zones.

“NOCs have been given to around 600 units that fall in the safe and semi-critical areas. Others don’t have the permission. Many of them were established before 2014 and we will not be able to move them to another zone. We have been asking the government to fix the upper limit for extraction in all zones and let us continue our trade,” Shakespeare said.

Title: Woman court staffer booked for Facebook post against PM Narendra Modi
Content:
P Parimala

SALEM: The cybercrime police have booked a woman staffer of Salem district combined court for posting derogatory messages against prime minister Narendra Modi on her Facebook page.

They registered a case against 39-year-old P Parimala, of Kannankurichi, based on a complaint lodged by BJP district president R P Gopinath.

In his complaint to city police commissioner T Senthil Kumar, Gopinath said the woman had in her Facebook post expressed her willingness to become a suicide bomber if anyone wanted to kill Modi. “She also said Modi would take the country back by 50 years if he were to remain PM for the next five years.”

The city police commissioner forwarded the complaint to the cybercrime police, who launched a probe into the issue.

Meanwhile, Parimala deleted the Facebook post after she came to know about the complaint against her. “I have faith in Indian sovereignty and PM Modi. I will not post such derogatory messages in future,” she said.

The cyber-crime cell police have booked her under Section 66 (a) (sending offensive messages through a computer or communication devices) of the Information Technology Act. Inspector Saroja said they would take any action on the woman only after detailed inquiry.

Title: No registration of BS-IV vehicles after March 31, says RTO
Content:
Bareilly: The regional transport office (RTO) on Saturday directed all vehicle dealers that the registration of Bharat Stage IV vehicles would be closed after March 31. This will also apply to those vehicles, said the office, which are purchased before March-end, if their papers are not processed.

In a letter issued to vehicle dealers, senior assistant regional transport officer (administration) RP Singh said, “In compliance with a Supreme Court order pronounced on October 24, 2018, no BS-IV vehicle would be sold after March 31.” The Bharat Stage VI emission norm would come into force from April 1 across the country.

Notably, the Bharat Stage emission standards are instituted by the Government of India to regulate the output of air pollutants from motor vehicles.

Meanwhile, local motor dealers are offering lucrative discounts to clear the stock as soon as possible.

Nimit Agrawal, a motorcycle dealer, told TOI, “We have around 150 two-wheelers of BS-IV norm left with us. The company has announced discounts ranging from Rs 8,000 to Rs 10,000 on some of the bikes and scooty. We are expecting that the company could increase the discount by Rs 2,000 to Rs 3,000 in the coming days.”

Another two-wheeler dealer, who wished not to be named, said his company was offering discounts up to Rs 5,000 on the vehicles which were in less demand, and there was no discount on the vehicles which were in high demand.

According to websites dealing in four-wheelers, heavy discounts ranging from Rs 75,000 to Rs 5 lakh are being offered on BS-IV cars.

On February 14, the SC rejected a plea filed by the Federation of Automobile Dealers Association (FADA), seeking an extension of the April 1 deadline by over a month to clear the stock of BS-IV vehicles.

Notably, in 2017, the Centre had announced that India would skip BS V norm and adopt BS-VI norm by 2020.

Title: ‘Using waste wisely is need of the hour’
Content:
Makarand Pandharipande speaks on ‘Management of plastic waste, e-waste and solid waste’ at Institution of Engi... Read More

Nagpur: The imbalance in the environment is primarily because of lack of concrete steps to tackle the problem head on.

To spread awareness to save the globe, a special lecture was organized by the Rotary Club of Nagpur Centre (RCNC) and Rotary Club of Nagpur Green city (RCNG) at the Institute of Engineers India (IEI) recently.

Expert Makarand Pandhripande spoke at length about how plastic waste , e-waste and solid waste are degrading the earth.

“Everyone should say no to plastic. Plastic that is not banned and allowed to use should be properly disposed of and given for recycling. Using alternatives to plastic like steel bottles, paper or cloth bags can bring about a change. Not using disposal items but biodegradable cutlery can be a huge helping hand as well,” said Makarand.

On growing e-waste, he said that it can be saved if everyone begins disposing it at the right location instead of the general dump yard. India is turning into a country with the maximum e-waste. ‘Service centres’ have been developed where only electronic material gets recycled without posing any harm to the environment. Scientific disposal of waste can improve the situation, said Makarand.

Prior to Makarand’s presentation, a welcome address was given by Rotarian Shyam Pandharipande. “This project of managing the increasing waste is highly vast and needs support from all the organizations, citizens and rotary clubs. To curb the increasing waste that is becoming a threat to the environment, it is every individual’s duty to take small steps to reach the desired destination.”

Anchor Ketki Salankar said, “Anything that cannot be reused, recycled or refurbished should be restricted from being redesigned.”

Speaking on the issues of plastic and solid waste, Makarand said, “Segregation of wet and dry waste should be finely taken care of. If every citizen starts this activity then over a period of times, a very big change can be seen.”

President of Vidarbha Plastic Industries’ Association, Rakesh Surana, stated the role of NGOs and varied organizations. “Awareness is the key and educating individuals is a must. Not littering roads, properly disposing garbage in bins and segregating waste can help bring about a change.”

The lecture was highly appreciated by the audience and all the dignitaries present on and off the dais.

Title: Tapping rainwater is need of hour
Content:
Times News Network

Jaipur: The decade-old Jaipur Development Authority (JDA)’s landmark provision for rainwater harvesting in houses awaits compliance. The civic body’s aim to tap rainwater in the state capital continues to be a distant dream with residents refusing to follow norms.

A senior town planner at JDA said it was mandatory to construct rainwater harvesting facilities in houses built on plot sizes of 300-sq m or above. Majority of residents have, however, still not constructed water harvesting structures at homes and rainwater is going down the drains without recharging the city’s groundwater.

The JDA was authorised to penalise house owners who fail to comply, but officials are turning a blind eye. The JDA enforcement wing had announced to impose a penalty of Rs 25,000 in 2011. In nine years, not a single inspection was carried out nor any notices issued to defaulters.

There was also a provision of seven days’ imprisonment. The punitive provisions, however, have remained on paper. “No notice has been issued to anybody for failing to set up a rainwater harvesting system during my tenure,” admitted a senior enforcement officer.

The town planning department approves layout plans for group housing societies and multi-storey buildings, after ensuring that these would have rainwater harvesting systems. However, no inspections have been made to ensure that the structure actually comply their undertaking.

The excess use of water in posh colonies, despite rules and regulations, and no serious measures being taken to recharge groundwater may pose a serious threat to the city in future. Areas such as Raja Park, Jawahar Nagar, Jhotwara, Adarsh Nagar and Janata Colony are already in the dark zone for overexploitation of groundwater.

Sources said, “Due to this, semi-critical blocks have turned into critical blocks. In Jaipur, out of 13 blocks, 12 fall under over-exploited category, while one comes under critical category.”

Residents claim that the high cost of construction of a rainwater harvesting system is one of the major reasons for the non-compliance. Shakti Singh, a resident of Jawahar Nagar said, “Spending Rs 35,000 on construction of such structures is a lot for the middle-income families. The government should give subsidiaries for these structures.”

Defiant citizens

JDA had made it mandatory to construct rainwater harvesting facilities in houses built on plot sizes of 300-sq m or above. But majority of residents have not constructed such structures.

In 2011, JDA had announced to impose a penalty of Rs 25,000 against people who flouted norms. In nine years, not a single inspection was carried out nor any notices issued to defaulters.

Title: Fake certificate racket busted in Ganjam, five arrested
Content:
Berhampur: A fake certificate racket was busted in Ganjam district on Saturday with the arrest of five persons, including a primary school teacher, who had secured a job by producing a forged B.Ed certificate in 2006. Police seized several fake B.Ed and other certificates of different universities, around 500 duplicate rubber stamps and computer sets from the accused.

The accused were identified as Gouri Shankar Jena, 42, who was working as an assistant teacher in Sunapallu UP School, Prakash Chandra Polai, 45, a teacher in UP School, Kaniar, Ranjit Kumar Palata, 48, from whose possession the rubber stamps were seized, K.Dhirendra Kumar Dora, 44, of Kodala, a computer shop owner, who allegedly made those fake certificates and Durga Prasad Mishra, 54, of Polsara, who acted as a middleman to sell the duplicate certificates for Rs 10,000 to Rs 50,000.

The racket was unearthed after the arrest of Jena, who sacked from his job recently after the district education office came to know that he got the job by producing a fake B.Ed certificate of Berhampur University, said Abhilash G., the probationary IPS officer at Aska police station.

Block education officer (BEO) Krutibash Barik lodged a complaint against him at Aska police station, said IIC of Aska police station P K Sahoo. During interrogation, he confessed to have produced the fake certificate and disclosed the place from where he obtained it.

Sahu said the hard disc seized from Dora’s computer kiosk at Polasara would be sent to the forensic laboratory for retrieval of data of fake certificates.

During certificate verification, the district administration found that 20 teachers have secured jobs by producing fake certificates. Criminal cases have also been registered against these teachers.

Title: Chandigarh civic body’s expenses rise, development works slide
Content:
Chandigarh municipal corporation

CHANDIGARH: The municipal corporation is spending less on developmental works while its expenses are going up in the last five years, according to data.

There has been a major increase in the liabilities, mainly salaries of employees, of the MC, a matter that was even discussed in the monthly general house meeting of the MC recently. “Employees have been hired through outsourcing agencies time and again in the past many years by different departments. In many wings or departments, employees were kept despite there being no demand and only to accommodate people due to various reasons. Employees were recruited in non-required wings and in many cases without any test or criteria. All these factors led to an increase in the financial burden,” said a senior officer of the MC. “Recently, orders were issued to sack employees kept in the MC or given jobs without tests,” he said.

The data of the MC has shown that it has been constantly preparing unrealistic budget to demand grant-in-aid from the UT administration, and ending up receiving less than half of its demand.

Title: Northeast Delhi schools not to open till March 7
Content:
A school building was attacked by a mob in a riot affected area following clashes between pro and anti-CAA pro... Read More

NEW DELHI: Delhi government on Saturday decided to keep the schools in the riot-hit northeast Delhi closed till March 7 . While the annual school examination has also been postponed in these areas, CBSE’s classes X and XII board exams will be held in all centres from March 2.

The government has written to Delhi police for deployment of adequate force in and around the CBSE centres “to ensure safety of students and teachers so that the board exams may be conducted smoothly without any further tension”.

In a letter to the station house officers of the police stations in northeast Delhi, the deputy director of education asked for adequate force as “the directorate of education (DoE) and Central Board of Secondary Education have decided to hold the board examinations from March 2 as per schedule”. A list of centres has been forwarded to police.

In another circular on Saturday, DoE postponed the annual school exam in northeast Delhi till March 7. These schools will also remain closed during this period, but the principals and the staff will come, it added.

“Realising the mental state of the students, and in order to help them come out of this traumatic situation, the competent authority has decided that all government, government-aided and private-recognised schools of Northeast district will remain closed for the students up to March 7,” the circular stated.

Title: Chennai: Now, get your chai, snacks at the nearest auto
Content:
The zero emission chai outlets will be driven by women to bus stops, IT parks and other crowded spots in the c... Read More

CHENNAI: You’ve seen the food trucks. Now get set for the food tuk-tuks as autorickshaws get retro-fitted into roving restaurants. On Saturday, city-based M-auto launched Gilli Chai , electric retrofit autorickshaws that will serve as mobile tea shops.

The chai autos will be completely managed and operated by women at various parts. “We are rolling out 50 autos this year and moving to other cities as well,” says managing director Mohamed Rahmathullah. “The idea is to have a zero emission chai outlet. The women will mainly drive to busy areas like bus stands, railway stations, parks, IT Parks and tourist spots and serve piping hot chai,” he says. Rahmathullah adds that they are also launching three conventional brick-and-mortar Gilli Chai outlets, which will double up as tea refill stations for the chai autos. The first chai auto is being driven by 33-year-old Mohanna Sundari, who says she has been an autorickshaw driver for a few years now. “I’m looking forward to hitting the roads because this feels like more fun than just ferrying passengers. I feel like I’m running a business,” says Sundari.

“Running a food tuk-tuk is cheaper than a food truck. Also, it is more convenient as it does not need to be stationed anywhere. It has no gears, so driving is easier. We’re hoping more women come on board to run the autos,” says Rahmathullah.

Other cities also have the autorickshaw restaurant concept, which seems to be popular among women as a viable business opportunity. As part of its Amma Ruchi Project for instance, the Kalamassery municipality in Kerala has set women up with e-auto mobile restaurants that serve up simple traditional food served on banana leaves. From her tuk-tuk stationed outside the Kalamassery metro station between 7pm and 2am, Priya Babu serves up tapioca and fish curry as well as dosas, parottas, and fish fry. “We are given bank loans to buy the autorickshaws and so it is a good business investment,” says Priya, who also heads the Amma Ruchi project. She adds that it costs around Rs 3.5 lakh to buy and retrofit the autos, way less than it would to run a brick-and-mortar restaurant.

Title: Gujarat: Principal accused of molesting girl student in school
Content:
Representative Image

PALANPUR: The principal of Kundol Primary School in Banaskantha district allegedly molested a girl student of Class VIII. Though the alleged crime occurred on Wednesday, the matter came to light only on Saturday when deputy primary education officer, Aravalli, inspected the school.

According to the case details, accused principal Kirit Patel had called the girl along with three to four other girls to his chamber. He asked the other girls to leave the room before allegedly outraging her modesty and demanded sex.

Deputy primary education officer, Aravalli, Samir Patel said, “I have taken statements of the survivor and the other students of the school and have sent my report to the director of Gujarat panchayati seva, Gandhinagar. If found guilty, the authorities will decide on further course of action against the principal.”

The parents of the survivor have not yet lodged a police complaint in this connection.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: 5k hawkers in draft list, 30 days to register objections
Content:
Kolhapur: After a six-month long survey and verification, the civic administration has finally published the draft list of eligible hawkers on its website, which has 5,000 hawkers.

The last survey of hawkers was conducted in 2012. Drafting a list of the eligible hawkers is the first step towards marking ‘hawking’ and ‘no-hawking’ zones.

A senior official from the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) said, “The new list has been drafted based on the state government’s notification about the rules to be followed to implement the Street Vendors Act. We have given 30 days to the hawkers to register their objections, request for changes, add or delete their names or make changes in the type of business they do. After clearing the doubts, the final list will be prepared.”

Once the final list is prepared, the civic body is going to constitute a committee, which will have representatives from the hawkers associations. The hawkers whose names feature in the final list will elect the representatives. The town vending committee will then take up the task to mark the ‘hawking’ and ‘no-hawking’ zones.

“Once the list is finalised, it will not change for the next five years. Hawkers approaching us later will be termed ‘illegal’ and not be considered for rehabilitation. We are studying the approaches of other civic bodies for rehabilitation and marking ‘hawking’ and ‘no-hawking’ zones. We expect the zones to be marked by the end of this year,” said the official.

KMC is going to issue biometric cards to the hawkers. The cards issued in 2014 will be invalid. Currently, the same card is used by relatives of the hawkers who make photocopies of the document.

“Hawkers will have to keep the original identity card with them to avoid the eviction during anti-encroachment drives,” said the official.

Title: Delhi Police rely on cyber tech to pursue rioters
Content:
Police commissioner S N Shrivastava asked the officers to focus on “confidence-building and peacekeeping measu... Read More

NEW DELHI: While no fresh incident of communal violence has been reported in northeast Delhi in the past four days, Delhi Police has apprehended 885 people and filed 167 FIRs till Saturday in connection with the riots.

Police commissioner S N Shrivastava, who took charge on Saturday, has asked the officers to focus on “confidence-building and peacekeeping measures” without going soft on deployment. “The force is maintaining a sharp vigil on the movement and activities of local people. Any attempt to disturb communal harmony will be dealt with strictly,” a police officer said.

Police have begun cracking down on social media propaganda and registered 13 FIRs against accounts operating from various platforms such as Twitter, Instagram and Facebook on charges of posting and sharing provocative content.

“Several accounts and web links circulating unlawful, offensive content have been suspended. Multiple advisories have been issued to sensitise people about responsible usage of online platforms. People have also been advised to maintain restraint while using these platforms,” said Delhi Police spokesperson Mandeep Randhawa . No PCR call was received about any violence on Saturday, he added.

The cyber cell is assisting the special investigation team set up to handle the probe. Police have collected and made an inventory of all videos shot by its personnel, mediapersons and the public, and are using the facial recognition technology to identify the rioters.

The cyber cell will also use a video enhancement software to improve the quality of images and utilise the information from social media. The videos will be verified through forensic tests.

The Special Cell and the Crime Branch have started pursuing the members of northeast Delhi’s gangs, most of whom are absconding. Late on Saturday, police reportedly got a location for Shahrukh , the gun-wielding man who was caught on camera threatening a policeman. Raids are being conducted across Delhi and in places like Amroha and Muzaffarnagar in UP, a source said.

The national human rights commissioner has asked its director general (investigation) to depute a fact-finding team for spot inquiries on of human rights violations.

Title: Two more child marriage bids foiled in Ganjam district
Content:
Berhampur: The Ganjam district administration on Saturday foiled two more child marriage bids at Sandhamula village in Beguniapada block. With this, it stopped 10 child marriage plans is the district.

After getting information from reliable sources that parents of minor girls plan to marry off their daughters, officials of the district administration, respective police officers and activists of Childline rushed to the villages.

While one marriage was scheduled for Sunday, the other was to take place on March 5, said Sai Prasad Samal, coordinator of the Childline. The marriage of one minor girl was fixed with a 20-year- old youth, which is not the permissible age for marriage for men, he said. The parents have given an undertaking not to marry off their daughters till the girls turn 18, he added.

On Friday, the team stopped a child marriage in Salabana village in Sandhamula panchayat. The marriage was scheduled on Saturday. “Some days ago, we convinced her parents but they changed their decision. After we spoke to the villagers, the girl’s parents agreed to marry her only after she turns 18,” said Samal.

Earlier, the district administration launched an initiative, “Nirvaya Kadhi”, to prevent child marriages. Under the programme, people and elected representatives at the the panchayat and block levels discuss about prevention of child marriage in their respective areas every week. Besides, “Mu Sachetan” (I aware) campaign was also launched in schools by the administration to prevent child marriages.

Title: Elephant kills cow near Mettur
Content:
Salem: A tusker killed a cow near Kolathur in Salem district early Saturday morning.

Forest officials said K Govindaraj, 45, a farmer, tied his cow behind his house at North Unjakkorai village. “Around 5am, he heard the cow moos in painful voice. When he went outside, he found a tusker attacking his cow. He tried to chase away the tusker. However, it carried the cow to nearby farmland and pierced the cow’s stomach using its tuskers,” a forest officer said, quoting residents of the village.

After being alerted, forest officials from Mettur reached the spot and performed autopsy. They later registered a case and are conducting an inquiry.

Govindaraj buried the cow’s carcass in his land.

Title: 90 cameras of Panchkula police not working for 20 days
Content:
Representative image

PANCHKULA: As many as 90 CCTV (closed-circuit television) cameras of Panchkula Police are lying non-functional after a private contractor working with Haryana Urban Development Authority (Huda) negligently cut the main wire going to the control room outside the Sector 14 police station while fixing a sewerage line on February 9.

Sarvjeet Singh, an engineer with Doorsanchar System Company , Industrial Area, Phase I, which technically helps the police at the control room on the first floor of the Sector 14 police station, had lodged a complaint against the contractor following which a case was registered against him for damaging public property. The contractor is, however, yet to carry out the repair work despite multiple requests.

Sarvjeet said the municipal corporation (MC) had installed the CCTV cameras to curb crime rate and help in issuing e-challans for traffic violations. On February 9, around 1.30 pm, Sandeep, the contractor, damaged the main wires of the CCTV control room while digging earth with a JCB to lay a drain pipe outside the Sector 14 police station. The damage stopped the working of 90 CCTV cameras installed throughout the district.

Sarvjeet said he called up the contractor, asking him to fix the problem as soon as possible. The contractor agreed to carry out the repair work but later started making excuses and stopped receiving calls, Sarvjeet said. “Due to the contractor’s negligence, 90 CCTV cameras are lying non-functional since February 9. Strict action should be taken against the contractor,” Sarvjeet said. He then moved a written complaint.

Police registered a case under Section 279 of Indian Penal Code (IPC) and Section 3 of the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act at the Sector 14 police station and started investigation. Inspector Naveen Saharan, station house officer, Sector 14 police station, said, “We have booked the contractor. The investigation is under progress.”

Title: If you see ‘illegal’ tree fellers, call NMC
Content:
Nagpur: Following TOI’s report on rampant chopping of trees by unauthorized tree fellers , the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has decided to join hands with city police to take action.

On Friday, TOI reported how these tree fellers are roaming freely in the city, especially the greener areas of West Nagpur. Not having the mandatory permission from NMC’s garden department, they offer services for trimming and cutting jobs from gullible citizens.

Now, civic officials have decided to initiate strict action against such gangs. NMC garden superintendent Amol Chorpagar informed that NMC would seek support from police officials to nab them. “People can call us on the helpline numbers to give information about such gangs. We will arrest and book them under relevant sections of Maharashtra (Urban Areas) Protection and Preservation of Trees Act,” he said.

NMC plans to initiate the action from Monday. “We will be circulating messages on social media to create mass awareness. We appeal to the citizens to contact us if they come across tree fellers,” added Chorpagar.

Earlier, the issue was raised by NGO Green Vigil Foudnation with the then municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar. “If such gangs are controlled, the cases of illegal tree felling in the city will reduce by 50%. The fellers make the job of illegal tree felling very easy,” said founder of the NGO Kaustav Chatterjee, adding that NMC should translate this decision into action.

As reported earlier, the cases of illegal tree felling, especially in residential areas, have been on a rise in the city. According to the study done by the Indian Space Research Organisation’s (ISRO) Regional Remote Sensing Centre (RRSC), Nagpur has lost 4,000 hectare of tree cover in 19 years. Between 1999-2018, the city’s green cover decreased by almost 30%.

Title: Delhi Violence: Man in viral clip who was asked to sing national anthem is dead
Content:
The spot in Maujpur where the five men were thrashed

NEW DELHI: A video that went viral during the violence in northeast Delhi showed five men being thrashed and forced to sing the national anthem by seven policemen in riot gear. TOI has identified three of the five victims. One died in hospital, while two are recovering from injuries.

Faizan, who ran a chicken shop, died while being treated in hospital. His younger brother, Naeem, identified Faizan as the man in the video lying unconscious. The family alleged that police kept him in custody for two days. “When we were finally summoned to take him home, Faizan couldn’t walk or speak and through signs indicated that he was in great pain,” said Naeem. “We took him to the hospital where he died. It has been four days since but the hospital authorities haven’t handed his body to us.”

At Faizan’s house in Kardampuri, a crowd awaited the return of the family with his body so the last rites could be conducted. Naeem told TOI, “On Monday (February 24), my brother reached home around 4pm but went out gain to check on our mother, who was at the protest site. My mother returned home, but my brother apparently stayed back to protect the women protesters when police resorted to firing teargas shells.”

The family accused police of picking Faizan from the protest site and thrashing him. “He was taken to hospital later and then brought back to Jyoti Nagar police station,” said Naeem. “Police did not permit us to meet him there. On February 26, they informed us to come and take him home. By then he was unable to speak. Faizan told me the cops had beaten him badly. We took him for medical aid, but he succumbed to his injuries.” Faizan was taken to GTB Hospital and discharged the same day. His family was informed. Two days later he returned to the hospital, where he died, said a police officer.

The second man in the video, painter Kaushar Ali, 45, lives two lanes from Faizan’s house. He was at work in Gandhi Nagar when police took him in and battered him. His son, Tahir, alleged, “My father was returning from work on Monday when the cops thrashed him and made him sing Jana Gana Mana. He fractured his hand and leg and has injuries on his head and abdomen.”

Tahir said his father was the one in the video with the head of another man on his chest. That other man is Rafiq, who lives in the same locality as Ali. Outside Rafiq’s residence, his brother, Aamir, stood with folded hands pleading with journalists to leave them alone. “We do not want anything, and I am glad my brother is alive. Yes, it is him in the video being made to sing the national anthem by the police officers,” said Aamir.

Aamir stated that his brother, a tailor, was picked up near his house and taken to the other side of the road where he was beaten with a stick. “We have been living here after coming to Delhi from Lucknow,” he said. He claimed not to be aware why Rafiq was picked up and assaulted by the cops. He said the family did not know the other men seen in the video.

Two videos of this incident went viral on social media. One was recorded at close range, and the other filmed by an area resident from his roof. In the close-up video, the police officers can be seen asking the five people to sing the national anthem properly. They also ask one of them what kind of drugs he took. An officer can be heard brusquely saying, “Sing the national anthem and Vande Matram. You have stayed in Hindustan but want azadi. You throw stones at the security forces.” The officers can also be heard constantly abusing the five men.

Title: Mohali: Fire breaks out at store basement
Content:
Smoke emanating from the basement of the store in Mohali’s Phase V

MOHALI: A fire broke out at a basement of a store in Phase V market in the early hours of Saturday. Employees of Vishal Mega Mart found smoke emanating from the store around 8am.

Jatinder, one of the employees, said, “We immediately shut down all the power outlets of our shop and informed the dire department.” Sub-divisional magistrate Jagdeep Saigal said, “Ten fire tenders from Mohali one from Chandigarh brought the blaze under control.” A short-circuit in the server room is suspected to have caused the fire. Employees said apparel and food items stored in the basement were gutted. The administration requisitioned additional manpower and machinery from the Indian Air Force and Chandigarh fire department. A quick rescue team from the NDRF was kept on standby.

Title: Pigeon spotted inside flight, plane delayed by 30mins
Content:
Jaipur: The incidents of bird hitting airplane are very common. However, in a bizarre incident, a Jaipur-bound Go Air flight from Ahmedabad got delayed by 30 minutes as passengers spotted a pigeon inside the plane on Friday.

After arriving at Jaipur airport , the passengers also complained on this matter to the officials.

According to one of the passengers who wished not to be named, the aircraft was brought at the apron at 4.30 pm on Friday. “Every one of us boarded the flight. When the flight gates were closed and one passenger opened the luggage shelf and was shocked to see a pigeon,” said the passenger.

The situation was though hilarious initially as passengers were laughing and also making video of the incident. However, passengers were unhappy with the response of cabin crew and others.

“It also caused a commotion inside the flight. However, the cabin crew also pacified us. The ground handling staff was intimated on this and after continuous efforts, the pigeon was ejected from the flight,” said another passenger.

The flight was supposed to land at Jaipur airport at 6.15 pm but it landed with a delay of half an hour at 6.45 pm.

Title: Water cuts in A, B and E wards on Monday
Content:
Kolhapur: The residents of wards A, B and E of the city are going to face water cuts on Monday.

The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has will be repairing the leakages in the pipelines of the Shingnapur water supply scheme.

A major leakage was reported in the pipeline at Khandsari, for which the repairs will be carried out on Monday. Last week, the leakage to the same pipeline was repaired. The leakages cause huge water loss leading to inadequate supply and at low pressure.

The officials said that there are more leakages in the pipes of Shinganapur and they are trying to repair the leakages before March 31.

The citizens face severe water cuts every year between April and May, mainly due to less water in the river. In such situations, reducing the losses is important for ensuring adequate water supply at least once a day.

A senior official of KMC, requesting anonymity said, “The pipeline will be repaired on Monday and the supply will resume normally from Tuesday. We are going to deploy water tankers to provide water to the affected areas. The leakages to the main pipelines will be repaired in March and we will ensure that the water cuts are planned so that the citizens face the least inconvenience.” The areas which will face water cuts are from wards A and B includes Salokhenagar, Kalamba, Aptenagar, Devkar Panand, Prathibanagar, Ware Vasahat. From E ward, the area are Rajarampuri, Kawala Naka, Kadamwadi, Lonar Vasahat, Shivaji Park and Udyamnagar.

Meanwhile, the residents of Rajendranagar and Jaragnagar approached civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti demanding regular water supply. Kalshetti has asked the water supply department staff to pay attention to the concerns of the residents. Accordingly, the officials visited the localities on Saturday and ensured that the areas that are not getting water for more than two days will immediately start receiving water.

Title: HMR to introduce shuttle buses on 12 new routes across all three lines
Content:
A shuttle bus picks up passengers near Marredpally in Secunderabad

Hyderabad: In its bid to improve last-mile connectivity and reduce traffic congestion in the city, the Hyderabad Metro Rail (HMR) will soon introduce shuttle services from 12 new routes. Each route is expected to employ three buses for picking up and dropping passengers across all three metro corridors. The buses are likely to come into operation in the next two months. The buses will be run by L&T Metro Rail Hyderabad Limited (L&TMRHL) in collaboration with Svida Mobility, an organisation that operates shuttle services.

“If people get a convenience of getting to the metro, then they will start riding the metro and that is exactly what we want to enable by introducing new services wherever required. Currently we have between 115 to 120 buses and we are doing 45 different routes in Hyderabad. All three lines put together, we are present on 24 stations plus at an average, we add about two routes a week,” founder and CEO of Svida, Siddharth Ravi told STOI.

For instance, on the Blue Line from Nagole to Raidurg, shuttle buses will run from Stadium metro station to Srinivasa Heights via Chilkanagar main road; Raidurg metro station to Platina near Kondapur, Raidurg station to Western Pearl; Raidurg station to Western Aqua and from Begumpet Metro Station to Panjagutta. Similarly, on the Red Line from Miyapur to LB Nagar, shuttle buses will be introduced from L B Nagar station to Meerpet, JNTU station to Bachupally, Balanagar to Chintal and from Irrum Manzil metro station to Raj Bhavan Road.

With the inauguration of green line last month from JBS Parade Ground to Mahatma Gandhi Bus Station, authorities have activated three new routes for shuttle services from JBS Parade ground to Alwal, Parade ground to ECIL Radhika and Parade ground to Anandbagh. “We try to introduce more buses on routes which have a high density of people. Currently, we are offering shuttle bus services to around 8,000 people per day,” said Svida CEO Ravi.

Title: Indian Oil ready to launch BS6 fuel in TN from April 1
Content:
Coimbatore: Indian Oil Corporation Limited is ready to launch BS6 fuel across the nation, especially in Tamil Nadu, from April 1, said chairman Sanjiv Singh.

Speaking to the media on the sidelines of the LPG conclave in the city, Singh allayed fears of the price hike expected during the launch of the less polluting fuel. While he did not specify the quantum of the hike, he said the hike would be marginal. “There will be an increase in retail prices of fuel from April 1. The price is expected it to increase by 1% to 1.5%,” he said.

Indian Oil officials said with the new infrastructure in place, the fuel being supplied in Tamil Nadu is already close to B6 standards itself. “However, we plan to officially declare it on April 1,” said an official.

Speaking about the benefits BS6 fuels, the chairman said it would have a Sulphur content of only 10 ppm (parts per million) compared to the existing fuels which contain 50 ppm of Sulphur. “The lower Sulphur content in the fuel will allow using advanced after-treatment devices to reduce harmful exhaust emissions like carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons, NOX and other carcinogenic emissions among others,” he said. State-run oil marketing companies have invested around Rs 35,000 crore to upgrade their refineries to produce this ultra clean fuel, off which IOCL alone has spent Rs 17,000 crore.

Meanwhile, Sanjiv Singh presented gifts to prison inmates and supervisors working at the ‘Freedom Fuel Station’ on Dr Nanjappa Road. Singh said the station was one of the retail outlets operated by Indian Oil Corporation without a business objective. Deputy inspector general, Coimbatore, Shanmuga Sundaram said the freedom station is serving as a rehabilitation platform for prison inmates.

Title: Telangana to get machines that can detect H1N1 in an hour: Chief secretary
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Telangana chief secretary Somesh Kumar on Saturday informed the high court that the state had brought in new testing machines to ascertain whether a person has swine flu . The TrueNAT-H1N1 is a chip-based machine which employs real-time micro polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing for H1N1 and gives the results in one hour. The machines are due to arrive in the first week of March accroding to the chief secretary.

“Testing equipment will be installed in government hospitals at King Koti and Barkas in Hyderabad. Similarly, various district hospitals and community centres all over the state will also be equipped with these machines,” the chief secretary said in his report to the court.

Earlier, a bench headed by Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan, while hearing petitions by Dr Karuna and advocate Rapolu Bhaskar, had sought a report from the chief secretary on how how the state was acting to arrest the spread of viral diseases. The report came as a result of this petitions.

“Asifabad, Karimnagar, Khammam, Nagarkurnool, Gadwal, Wanaparthy, Bhongir, Kamareddy, Rangareddy, Medchal, Sangareddy and Peddapalli hospitals which will get these test machines will be able to test people with symptoms of swine flu and ascertain whether they were affected with the virus,” the chief secretary said in his report to the bench.

The official also mentioned that they tested 253 samples in government hospitals out of which 26 samples tested positive for swine flu. “Of the 1,200 samples tested in private hospitals, 161 proved positive,” the report said. The chief secretary also said that isolation wards will be set up in Hyderabad’s government TB and Chest hospitals to treat swine flu patients. “Apart from sensitising government doctors and paramedical staff all over the state, we have also involved the private sector in the fight against virus,” the chief secretary said.

The bench acknowledged the efforts of the state in maintaining vigilance and dealing with them in an effective manner. “In addition to this, they have also undertaken a massive public awareness campaign asking people to do their bit and act as responsible citizens,” the bench said.

Title: Making the final journey, full of life
Content:
Death, is an uncomfortable realisation for everyone. It’s tougher for terminal-ill patients and their families. “In most cases, doctors don’t tell such patients there is no cure. They tell their families and that puts them in an uncomfortable position. How should we take care of someone who is bound to die soon is a question that troubles many,” says Dr Anjaneyulu Konda, chief medical officer at Sparsh Hospice .

The palliative care unit, founded in 2011, looks after patients suffering from terminal illnesses, free of cost. It was the brainchild of several doctors and philanthropists who wanted to give back to society in a way that was not common. “Orphanages, old age homes, donation centres are everywhere. We wanted to venture into a path not many would think of,” says B Mallikarjun, a trustee.

It is not just end-stage treatment and pain alleviation that the centre provides. It is a touch of humanity, a realisation that the final journey does not have to be uncomfortable. “Here, we counsel residents and their families. We put their inhibitions to rest,” says Sarada Lingaraju, head counsellor at Sparsh.

The centre provides entertainment, conducts cultural activities, trips and even gets jobs for its residents. “A 23-year-old resident got a job at a major multinational. But before he received his offer letter, he was diagnosed with last stage liver cancer. He told us that it was his wish to buy his parents something nice with his first salary. So, we made it happen. He bought his parents clothes with the first cheque,” Lingaraju said. Sadly, the 23-year-old passed away soon after.

The residents at Sparsh say the centre has made them free of their fear of death. “I was angry when I came in because one by one my family stopped visiting me. The staff and residents here have become my family. I don’t know what god has in store but I feel no anger. Naffrat nahi sirf mohabbat hai,” says Mohammad Iqbal, a resident with oral cancer.

Retired printing supervisor at the state assembly, Munnaiah from Dilsukhnagar says: “My wife’s cancer spread to her brain and I was not in a position to take care of her. The doctors told me about Sparsh. Ever since she has been here, it has been easier for her, me and my family.”

Title: Basic amenities sought for visitors to prison
Content:
Coimbatore: A petition was submitted to the chief minister’s special cell on Saturday seeking basic amenities for people visiting prisoners at the Coimbatore Central Prison.

The petitioner, Palani Kumar, of Tirupur, said people, including pregnant women, new mothers, elderly people and disabled are coming to the Central jail from 6am. However, they wait for hours, sometimes ranging between three to six hours to clear the security checks and submit their petition for visiting their relative or friend. “After all this, it becomes 2pm to 3.30pm, before they can actually visit the prisoner and come out,” said the petitioner.

The petitioner said that during these seven to eight hours of waiting, visitors are not provided seatings. “Many old, disabled people and pregnant women have no option but to sit on drainage tanks and covers,” he said. “There is also no dedicated space for women to breastfeed their children, and since women feel uncomfortable to breastfeed in public, many babies are deprived of milk for hours,” he added.

With visitors being forced to surrender their mobile phones during security checks, the petitioner said visitors don’t even have a public or pay phone facility to inform people outside that they were being delayed. The petition was forwarded to jail superintendent Krishnaraj and deputy inspector general of prisons Shanmuga Sundaram. DIG Sundaram said he was yet to receive the forwarded petition. However, he said it usually takes half an hour to 45 minutes for visitors to meet the inmates.

Title: A store powered by Goodwill
Content:
Hyderabad: When Manjula Pallipoyena saw Sasikala (name changed) leave empty-handed for the fifth time, the 42-year-old was curious. She asked the mother of two what she wanted. “A pressure cooker,” came the reply from Sasikala who worked as a domestic help. It would cut down cooking time and give her a few extra hours with her family, she shared.

“That day, I put up a post on Facebook and arranged for a pressure cooker… I can’t articulate the joy it brought the woman,” says Manjula, beaming at the recollection. Her Goodwill store in Mehdipatnam is a one-stop destination for the poor looking for essential commodities — clothes, utensils, blankets, shoes — all for free. The garage-turned-store bustles with activity on Thursdays and Saturdays -- the two days its doors are thrown open to all — with over 70 people turning up every week.

Everything in the store is donated. Though most of items are brought by people who have heard of Manjula’s initiative through word of mouth, she also has a Facebook page that has caught the attention of good Samaritans who have reached out to contribute.

“We get everything that we need here, not just in kind, but also in way of support,” says Balamma from Mahbubnagar. The 50-year-old who works as a security guard had come to take clothes for some migrant labourers when TOI caught up with her.

The journey began about five years ago, when, on hearing about a Class 8 girl being married off at a slum near Mehdipatnam, she rushed to her house. Though she convinced the girl's parents to call off the wedding, the abject poverty of slum dwellers shook her. “I decided I had to bridge the gap between the haves and have-nots of society. The store came up in October 2015,” says Manjula, who runs it with a little help from volunteers K Srilatha and Ravinder M.

Often, it doubles up as a health camp. “They provide free consultations and medicines for the poor,” she says, hoping that her small venture inspires more people. “Imagine how many lives that would change for better,” Manjula adds.

Title: Two assault cops & civic officials, held
Content:
Kolhapur: Juna Rajwada police have arrested two suspects for allegedly attacking police officers and civic officials attached with anti-encroachment department when they were trying to remove encroachments on the stretch from Bhavani Mandap to Bindu chowk in the city on Friday.

Ajit Pandurang Pawar (42) and Bharat Rajaram Bebitakatti (41)—both residents near Bindu chowk sub jail— were produced before a local court on Saturday, which remanded them in police custody for two days.

According to police, officials from the traffic department and the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) had launched a drive to remove encroachments that were impeding the traffic flow from Chhatrapati Pramila Raje civil hospital to Bhawani mandap and from Bhawani mandap to Bindu chowk. They were removing hawkers who had occupied the road and footpaths. They arrived at the shops of the two suspects near Bindu chowk sub jail on Friday afternoon. The suspects were operating snacks and tea stalls and had placed chairs and tables on the road.

Police asked them to remove the chairs and tables and keep it in their stalls. When they did not respond, the officials of the anti-encroachment department and police started seizing the tables and chairs. They obstructed police and misbehaved with the officials on duty.

“They also abused the police for their action.,” said an officer attached with Juna Rajwada police station.

Title: Coronavirus fears in T on the wane, 100 now out of isolation
Content: Hyderabad: With as many as 100 Coronavirus COVID-19 ) suspects leaving isolation on Saturday, fear of the virus in Telangana is on the wane. Currently, only 244 remain in isolation across the state down from the 345 who had been kept in isolation following their return from abroad. The hundred suspects have completed the 28-day quarantine period and are said to be safe. On the other hand, only one more suspected case was admitted to the Gandhi Hospital.Keeping a check on health of those suspected cases, health officials are maintaining strict vigil and making daily rounds of patient’s houses. “Out of the 345 passengers, 100 passenger (s) completed 28 days observation. One patient got a admitted to Gandhi Hospital and remaining 244 are under home quarantine...” the state health and family department said in a statement. “Till now, 108 samples have been taken from passengers and all found negative. The health status who are under observation at home and hospital are stable,” the health department statement adds.As per the state’s data, 16,274 passengers have been screened at the Shamshabad airport so far. The health department has decided to expand its universal screening to all passengers arriving by direct flights from other Coronavirus-affected countries such as Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam, Indonesia, Nepal, Iran and Italy.“The state has strengthened the surveillance measures against the disease. State helpline is functional, 568 calls received as on date (February 29),” the department said in its statement.

Title: Boy jumps to death after fight with his brother
Content:
Hyderabad: Upset with his elder brother, a 12-year-old boy jumped from the fifth floor of an apartment building in Miyapur on Saturday. Police said Bala Venkata Satya Prasad died on the spot.

Prasad was a class VI student in a Kondapur private school. According to police, Prasad was playing on a tablet with his brother Nanda Kishore. Soon, the siblings started fighting over who would use the tablet. Father Srinivas saw this and intervened. He handed over the tab to Kishore. “After Srinivas left home, Prasad climbed to the top of the terrace at 2.15 pm and jumped off. He did not leave any suicide note. The family suspects he was very upset,” said Miyapur SI K Lingya Naik. The family resides in the apartment on Manjeera pipeline road.

Prasad sustained hand and leg fractures apart from severe internal injuries and died on the spot. The body was shifted to a hospital and a case of suspicious death was registered.

Title: Delhi clashes: How cops lost the plot at the outset
Content:
Security personnel conduct flag march in north east Delhi (File photo)

NEW DELHI: It appears that erroneous judgements, inadequate deployment and absence of swift decisions on the part of police led to northeast Delhi spinning out of control and 42 people being killed in a span of 36 hours. TOI spoke to several police officers whose accounts seemed to suggest this was what happened when riots broke out last Sunday.

It was around 10pm on February 22 that the first seeds of the upheaval were sowed. Around 600 women were seen proceeding through the congested lanes of Jafrabad towards the Delhi Metro station there. However, police did not intervene immediately. Sources said the local police assumed the crowd was heading to an existing protest site only to realise they had squatted in protest at the metro station itself, 500 metres from the presumed spot.

There were very few women cops to handle the predominantly female crowd, and police could not use force to disperse them. They received no orders for their dispersal from the brass, which was apparently wary of how the courts would perceive such action.

The women were joined by around 400 male protesters. A senior police officer claimed that the core group comprised non-locals. By Sunday morning, the strength of the protesters had swelled to 3,000. “While we could not remove them physically, we did not permit the erection of a dais, tents or PA system at the site,” the officer said.

By noon, the police were in a catch 22 situation. Hindu groups announced they would block the entire road, arguing that if the other community was being allowed to sit on protest there, they too should be allowed to congregate. “We tried to reason with them but they didn’t listen,” the police officer added. Soon enough, the two groups began pelting stones at each other, and police managed to bring the situation under control only late in the evening.

There are allegations that the cops did not take the developments seriously as warranted, believing it would be peaceful like in Shaheen Bagh. A senior cop countered this. “We made adequate arrangements for February 24, when the US president arrived, though the eastern range officers had been exempted. It took time to mobilise the force, but we had sufficient officers on the ground,” he claimed.

By 9am that day, rioting had broken out. What began with stone pelting degenerated into arson and vandalism. Not much later, both groups resorted to shooting with country-made and semi-automatic pistols. “The antagonistic groups were not only attacking each other, but also police. In some places, cops were caught in the middle, and in others it was a three-sided combat. However, there was limited use of firearms,” attested a source.

DCP (Shahdara) Amit Sharma and his team accompanied by three companies were attacked around 11am near a mosque at Chand Bagh. While Sharma and ACP Anuj Kumar were beaten by rioters, head constable Ratan Lal was shot dead. “The challenge now was to send reinforcements to Chand Bagh,” another officer recalled. A joint commissioner was asked to rush there with more personnel. Rumours had sent large numbers on to the streets in 20 localities, so he wasn’t able to reach. A DCP was stuck near Maujpur, so another DCP from Crime Branch and a joint commissioner were summoned. Using the Usmanpur-Pushta route, they reached Chand Bagh, and by 4pm, we had reclaimed Wazirabad and the 66-Feet Road.”

However, it was only when national security advisor Ajit Doval and special commissioner S N Shrivastava stepped in that the situation was fully managed.

When asked why the force did not go all out against the rioters at the outset, an officer asserted, “With 80,000 people to every square kilometre, northeast Delhi is among the densest areas in the country. The groups very easily mobilised 25,000 people from Jafrabad and Kardampuri in a few minutes. On December 22 last year, over 40,000 had gathered on the Jafrabad road, though things passed off peacefully then.”

The officer added, “Every step had to be calculated. Not one officer retreated. We didn’t allow any lynching on the main road. If police had been reckless, the toll would have been much higher.”

Title: Asaduddin Owaisi: Why no march in other parts of city?
Content:
Why only at CHARMINAR ,why not in front of Secunderabad Railway Station or at Hi Tec City maybe in front of a US So… https://t.co/BFA54vcYDm — Asaduddin Owaisi (@asadowaisi) 1582948351000

HYDERABAD: Following a tweet and picture by Hyderabad City Police showing Rapid Action Force personnel carrying out a flag march near Charminar, All India Majlis-e-Ittehad-ul-Muslimeen ( AIMIM ) president and Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi questioned as to why the flag march was conducted only near Charminar and not other parts of the city.“Why only at CHARMINAR ,why not in front of Secunderabad Railway Station or at Hi Tec City maybe in front of a US Software company?” Owaisi tweeted.The tweet garnered mixed responses with many lauding the Hyderabad MP while many opposing his words. “Kindly enlighten the world how many times curfew was imposed around Charminar and how many times in front of Secbad station,” tweeted one user. Some users alleged that this was a tactic being enforced by the Centre.Earlier, Maulana Husamuddin Sani, a speaker at an anti-CAA, NPR and NRC protest held on February 24 had criticised Telangana home minister Mohammad Mahmood Ali and Hyderabad police commissioner Anjani Kumar.“Is home minister powerful or is police commissioner powerful? The police commissioner who himself claims to be secular suddenly says that Shaheen Bagh-like protests will not be allowed. What happened to him? Let us all send bouquets to him,” Sani had said.

Title: Delhi riots: ‘Seeing DCP hurt, we felt hopeless for a second’
Content:
Anuj Kumar also sustained injuries in the violence

NEW DELHI: “Blood was oozing from the mouth of deputy commissioner of police(Shahdara) Amit Sharma, and he was not responding. Police were outnumbered by the mob 1:50 and the divider behind us acted as a wall. With the help of two others, we picked up Sharma and crossed three fences to take him to the hospital,” recounted Anuj Kumar , ACP (Gokulpuri) on Saturday. Kumar also sustained injuries in the violence.

Sitting on the bed at his residence, Kumar with a collar on his neck and a bandage on his forehead told TOI that stones rained on them and his helmet broke leading to an injury at the back of his head.

On Monday, Kumar, Sharma, head constable Ratan Lal and two company force personnel were deployed near a religious place at Chand Bagh on the Wazirabad road.

“It all happened between 11.30am and 12.30pm. We were instructed to ensure that the road was not blocked as it was one of the main connecting roads. However, men and women started gathering on the service road, and they gradually spilled over to the main road. Some construction work was being carried out on the service road and a lot of construction material was available there. At least 30,000 people were there till the Brijpuri T-point,” recalled Kumar.

Kumar stated that the force tried to push the crowd back. “ But people started firing and pelting stones. We were heavily outnumbered and the situation worsened in no time. Stones were flying from all over. I saw Sharma lying near the divider with blood oozing from his mouth. For a moment a sense of hopelessness went through my mind when seeing an officer in such a state, but then we had to make a way to reach him to the hospital,” said Kumar.

Injured Ratan Lal was, meanwhile, taken to the hospital from the other side of the road which heads towards Yamuna Vihar.

“I thought of firing to disperse the crowd, but then there were women. With the help of two other officers, we picked Sharma up. We climbed over three fences with Sharma in my arms and people pelting stones from all sides. A stone hit my head and my helmet broke, but we continued to move,” said Kumar, adding that they stopped a random car later to take the DCP to the hospital.

Title: Cellphone number leads Delhi police to missing girl
Content:
File photo

NEW DELHI: Amid the violence in northeast Delhi , Delhi Police was tasked to find a 13-year-old girl who went missing from her house in Sonia Vihar on Monday afternoon. Police swung into action fearing she could have been picked up by some rioter. Apprehending an untoward incident in a tense situation, a team of officers from Kahjoori Khas police station was immediately formed. However, they later found the girl staying at a friend’s place without informing her parents.

A police officer said that the girl went “missing” while she was on her way back from school. After she did not return home on Monday, her parents thought that she must have taken shelter at a relative/friend’s house due to the prevailing situation. When she did not reach home till Tuesday morning, the parents filed a complaint. A case of kidnapping was subsequently registered and a team under the leadership of SHO Khajoori Khas, Pawan Kumar began searching for the girl.

Investigating officials said they too initially thought she could have gone missing during the riots. But while scanning her notebooks they came across a mobile number. Police called up the number but the girl from the other side revealed her name as someone else’s. When the parents heard the recording, they identified it as their daughter’s voice. Further probe revealed that the girl had an affair.

The girl, however, later told the cops that she went to her friend’s house as she was scared of the prevailing situation.

Title: Newly-laid hockey turf faulty, to be replaced
Content:
Panaji: The state government has ended up with an egg on its face after the hockey turf laid at the Peddem sports complex in Mapusa was found to be faulty and dangerous.

An agency approved by FIH, world’s governing body for hockey, inspected the turf in Mapusa last week and refused to provide the mandatory certification that was needed to host competitions, which includes the National Games later this year.

Left with no other option, the state government has now told the contractor and supplier to ensure that a new turf is in place.

“The turf is being replaced. There were wrinkles and creases on the turf. We tried to make things work but it’s not happening. We have jointly discovered that there was some error in the fixing of the turf. The company has now ordered for a new turf,” V M Prabhu Desai, executive director of the Sports Authority of Goa (SAG), told TOI.

Creases were discovered immediately after the artificial turf was laid at Peddem. Sources said high-ranking officials from SAG were told that the “creases are normal” and would disappear once it has been put to use.

Even before its inauguration, the SAG allowed locals to use the artificial turf ground, hoping the creases would go away. But despite several days of using the turf, the creases didn’t even out.

In fact, many of the players found the turf dangerous to use as there was increased risk of injuries.

“It will take another two months for the new turf to be laid. This will not have any impact on the National Games and will have zero financial implication (to the government). We are laying a new turf essentially for the National Games, so we will ensure that everything is in place when India’s top athletes come here,” said Prabhu Desai. The SAG executive director said there were “technical issues” that led to a faulty turf being laid.

“The contractor and supplier have both accepted the blame. It’s a technical issue,” he said.

Sources said the creases could have developed because the contractor left the rolled-turf outside for too long before getting the go ahead to lay it. There was a delay in payments by the state government that had brought work to a standstill. The turf was transported to Peddem but without the necessary payments being made, sources said, work could not progress.

Work on the construction of the hockey ground has been entrusted to M/s. Syncotts International for Rs 8.6 crore.

For 20 years now, the state government has been promising Goa’s hockey players and coach – now retired, Alexandre Remedious – that a synthetic turf would be laid in the state. For 20 years, that has remained an empty promise with the team that will now take part in the National Games left with no choice but train on outdated grass turfs.

Despite the lack of infrastructure, Goan hockey has punched above its weight. A Goa-India team lost to Portugal 3-5 in Lisbon in 2009. Fr Agnel HS, Pilar, won the Consolation Trophy at the Nehru Cup in 1995 and two teams made it as far as the quarterfinals of the National School Games.

At the Senior National Hockey Championship in Tamil Nadu, Goa scored five goals in five games; all from build-up play, took the lead in two matches, and even scored from a penalty corner. Goa’s opponents were mighty teams like All India Police, Madhya Bharat, Sports Authority of India, Hockey Coorg and Steel Plant.
