More recently, Goan women defeated Uttarakhand 1-0 to qualify for the pre-quarters for the first time.

Title: Rs 78,000 crore allotted by CM Edappadi K Palaniswami for welfare of women
Content:
Edappadi K Palaniswami

ERODE: School education minister K A Sengottaiyan distributed welfare assistance to the tune of Rs 2 crore to 223 beneficiaries at a function that was held in Gobichettipalayam here on Saturday.

Addressing the gathering, he said the state government was providing financial assistance to parents with girl children under the Sivagami Ammaiyar Memorial Girl Child Protection Scheme. Under the scheme, the government would provide a fixed deposit (FD) of Rs 22,200 in the case of a single girl child and an FD of Rs 15,200 each if there are two girl children.

Lauding the state government and its achievements, Sengottaiyan said chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami had allotted Rs 78,000 crore for the welfare of women.

He said steps were being taken to set up playgrounds across the state to promote cricket, kabaddi and hand ball games. “So far, we have procured and distributed sports materials worth Rs76 crore to 12,524 panchayats and 528 town panchayats in the state.”

Environment minister K C Karupannan, district collector C Kathiravan and other officials participated in the event.

Title: Pvt moneylending: 10 booked for harassing businessman
Content:
Kolhapur: Ten suspected private moneylenders were booked by the Shahupuri police for allegedly harassing a businessman as part of attempts to recover interest on a Rs 30 lakh loan the victim had borrowed from the three of them.

The businessman had borrowed money in February, 2018. He had also returned the amount, with interest, to the lender. However, the gang is suspected to have harassed him for not paying the principal amount. The police have now launched an investigation.

Authorities said the victim had approached three of the suspects in February 2018 after he suffered losses in business. The businessman was given a loan of Rs 30 lakh — an amount he was able to clear along with interest. But the gang continued to harass him, claiming that he had only cleared the interest amount, and not the principal.

The 10 suspects, including the three from whom the businessman had borrowed the money, had barged into his home and threatened him with violence if he failed to clear the loan. The victim was also warned against going to the police. Two other individuals — a mediator and his wife — were also threatened. Police said the gang later forced the businessman to hand over his chequebook, with his signature on blank cheques.

“After the incident, the mediator’s wife lodged a police complaint against the suspects. We have booked them under relevant sections of the IPC, including sections 509 (word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman), 452 (house-trespass after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint), 323 (punishment for voluntarily causing hurt), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace), 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation), 143 (punishment), 147 (punishment for rioting) and 149 (every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object) and sections 33, 39 and 45 of the Maharashtra Moneylending Act,” a police officer said.

The police officer added: “We are gathering information about how much money the businessman had paid so far and the rate of interest the suspects charged. We will make arrests soon.”

Title: Suburban train between twin cities from today
Content:
Bhubaneswar: The railways will run the Jan Sadharan Express special train between Bhubaneswar and Cuttack from Sunday till March 31 on a trial basis. “If we get good response, we will continue the service. It is an additional mode of transportation to ease the traffic congestion in the two cities,” said ECoR chief spokesperson J P Mishra.

This train will not only accommodate commuters from Bhubaneswar and Cuttack but also be helpful for passengers within 25 km radius of Cuttack. The Bhubaneswar-Cuttack Jan Sadharan special train (08460) will originate from Bhubaneswar at 1.30 pm and arrive in Cuttack in 2.30 pm via Barang and Gopalpur Balikuda.

In the return direction, the train (08459) will leave Cuttack at 2.40 pm and arrive in Bhubaneswar at 5.20pm via Nergundi, Gurudijhatia, Radhakishorepur and Naraj Marthapur.

This special train will stop at Vani Vihar, Mancheswar, Patia, Bhubaneswar New, Barang, Gopalpur Balikuda and Kathajodi passenger halt. In the return direction, it will have stoppages at Kendrapara Road, Manguli Choudwar, Nergundi, Salagaon, Charbatia, Badapadagaon, Gurudijhatia, Machhapur, Radhakishorepur, Ghantikhal Nidhipur, Sarpeshwar, Naraj Marthapur, Barang, Bhubaneswar New, Patia, Mancheswar and Vani Vihar.

Besides people from the two cities, passengers from Choudwar, Athgarh, Badamba, Narasinghpur and some parts of Dhenkanal can board the train. It will run till March 31 on a trial basis.

ECoR official sources said it will be a mainline electric multiple unit (MEMU) train that the railways run in suburban and rural areas. Unlike conventional mainline trains, MEMU trains take comparatively less time to halt and leave the station because of their technology. These trains have a potential for average speed increment up to 20 km/hour compared to conventional ones.

Though Mo Bus service caters to the need of commuters in the two cities, it is not available for people staying within the 25 km radius of Cuttack. The suburban train will help people connect with cities. In 2018, chief minister Naveen Patnaik urged the Centre for metro railway but there has been no discussion on this issue so far.

Title: Marathi-medium college to be set up at Maha-K’taka border
Content:
Kolhapur: The state government is planning to set up a Marathi-medium college in the Maharashtra-Karnataka border area to help the Marathi-speaking people of the area get education in their mother tongue, said Uday Samant, the higher and technical education minister, on Saturday.

He was speaking to reporters at the circuit house in the city after reviewing the work of educational institutes in Kolhapur.

Minister Samant directed district collector Daulat Desai to identify the land in the border area so that the government can initiate the process to set up the college.

“We are working on filling up the vacant professor posts in the colleges across the state. We will soon fill 2,900 vacant posts,” he added.

Later, addressing the students at a convocation ceremony of the D Y Patil group of institutions, Samant said that students should learn to be humble even after they achieve success in their respective fields.

Devanand Shinde, the vice-chancellor of Shivaji University, who was the guest of honour for the programme, said, “High-quality professionals are needed in all sectors for the society’s development. There are several opportunities in the solar energy and pharmaceutical sectors and students should grab these opportunities.”

At the convocation ceremony, 866 students from the D Y Patil College of Engineering and Technology, Kasaba Bawada; D Y Patil Technical Campus, Talsande; and D Y Patil College of Engineering, Salokhenagar, Kolhapur, were awarded their degrees.

Title: School suspends teacher arrested for culpable homicide
Content:
Kolhapur: Initiating disciplinary action against Nilesh Balu Pradhane — the teacher who was arrested after a Class X student died due to poisoning — the school authorities have suspended him.

Pradhane was arrested under various charges, including culpable homicide not amounting to murder, after a Class X student of a private school in the Shirti village of Shirol taluka, died due to poisoning at a hospital on Tuesday.

Police have recovered the CCTV footage from the shop that Pradhane had purchased the pesticide from. Pradhane is in police custody and is being interrogated.

An official of the educational institute, which runs the school in the Shirti village, told reporters that the institute has taken action against Pradhane and has suspended him following his arrest. The institute will take necessary actions against him as per the rules set by the government.

Meanwhile, the police officials investigating the case have stated that they took Pradhane to the shop from where he had bought the pesticide and also the place where he handed the poisonous substance to the deceased student.

“The accused has said that he had divided the pesticide into two bottles. While he gave one bottle to the victim, he threw the other bottle somewhere. We are looking for that bottle as it may help us to find the content of the pesticide,” said a police officer investigating the case.

A delegation of villagers met officials at Shirol Tehsil and demanded that the police should speed up the investigation and the guilty should be punished immediately. They also demanded that the government make provision to try the case in a fast-track court.

Title: Timely action could have foiled Delhi riots: Former top cop Ajay Raj Sharma
Content:
Ajay Raj Sharma

NEW DELHI: Former top cop Ajay Raj Sharma has accused Delhi Police of allowing the situation in northeast Delhi to snowball and turn into a riot. According to Sharma, the riot could have been prevented had the police force acted in time.

In an interview with journalist Karan Thapar for The Wire, Sharma said the first mistake made by Delhi Police was to allow the gathering at Shaheen Bagh to take place. “The gathering was clearly a violation of the law. It occurred on public property and no one had a right to block roads and create inconvenience. If cops had acted on the very first day the Shaheen Bagh gathering began, a lot that followed thereafter could have been prevented,” he said.

Apprehending that the force may have become communal, Sharma said that he would have arrested BJP leaders like Anurag Thakur, Parvesh Verma and Kapil Mishra had he been the commissioner of the force.

Terming communal riots as the second most important challenge for a country after an enemy attack, the ex-top cop, who was in charge of the capital’s police force from 1999 to 2002, said police commissioner Amulya Patnaik was thrown a challenge, which he failed.

The former cop said that the force’s failure in controlling the violence suggested they were under political influence.

Title: 14 held for pelting cinema theatre with stones
Content:
Dharmapuri: Fourteen people were arrested for pelting a cinema theatre with stones at Bommidi in Dharamapuri district on Friday evening.

The Boomidi police made the arrest after filing a case based on a complaint lodged by Mallapuram village administrative officer (VAO) K Tamilarasan. The complaint said about 200 people gathered in front of the cinema theatre, in which ‘Draupadi’, a recently released movie that deals on caste issues, and pelted it with stones around 3pm.

The VAO said people protested against the release of the movie from the morning. Due to the protest, the movie was screened at 12.30pm, instead of the planned release at 8.30am. “Roof of the theatre as well as banners and tube lights on the theatre premises were damaged in the incident,” the VAO added.

A case was registered under various sections, including sections of the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984.

“We have arrested 14 people in the case. More arrest will be made after checking footage from CCTV cameras near the threatre,” a police officer said.

(photos: A M Shudhagar, Salem)

Title: Pune: One more SUV worth Rs 86 lakh of jailed developer DSK seized from ex-minister’s former PA
Content:
The seized SUV is among the two missing vehicles that the police were trying to locate for quite some time.

PUNE: The economic offences wing of the city police on Friday seized a high-end SUV, worth Rs 86 lakh, belonging to the arrested builder DS Kulkarni alias DSK from an authorized vehicle service station at Mazgaon in Mumbai.

The vehicle, a Toyota Land Cruiser, was found in the possession of Manik Nimbalkar . He was working as a personal assistance of a former state minister, police said.

A team headed by assistant commissioner of police (crime) Shivaji Pawar and assistant inspector Sunil Gavali seized the vehicle from Mumbai, following which it was brought to the city.

Pawar said, “Once the seized SUV reached a Mazgaon service centre, its authorities immediately informed us about it, following which we seized the vehicle. We also took the statement of the person, Nimbalkar, who had sent it for servicing. Nimbalkar was working as PA to a former minister,” Pawar said.

Vijay Shivtare, former MLA from the Purandar assembly constituency and former minister of state for water resources and water conservation, confirmed that Nimbalkar used to work for him. “Yes, Nimbalkar used to work for me, though he is not associated with me right now. I don’t know much about the vehicle,” he told TOI.

The economic offences wing (EOW) has already seized 13 vehicles, including a Porsche, two BMW cars and an MV Agusta Motorcycle, from DSK in 2018 during the course of investigation in the alleged Rs 2,091-crore economic fraud by the developer and his firm. The vehicles were worth Rs 5 crore. Police have auctioned six cars of DSK so far.

Assistant commissioner of police (crime) Pawar said as the police had invoked provisions of the Maharashtra Protection of Interest of Depositors (MPID) Act against the developer and others in the case, police wanted to seize all the vehicles and properties belonging to DSK.

“During the course of investigation, we realized that two of the vehicles belonging to the developer were missing, following which a search was initiated to trace them. We found a high-end SUV (sport utility vehicle) in Mumbai, while the search for another is going on,” he said.

A senior police officer told TOI, “Since it was an SUV, we believed it would not be serviced at a roadside garage. Thus, we sent letters to different service stations across Maharashtra and requested them to inform us if any of the two vehicles was with them for servicing.”

Title: Pune: After Elgar case transfer, district govt pleader relinquishes charge
Content:
Senior lawyer Ujjwala Pawar, who led the state in the Elgar Parishad case proceedings before the Pune court, o... Read More

PUNE: Senior lawyer Ujjwala Pawar , who led the state in the Elgar Parishad case proceedings before the Pune court, on Saturday relinquished charge as the district government pleader and public prosecutor.

The move comes little over a month after the Union home ministry transferred the Elgar case probe to the National Investigation Agency (NIA) and a subsequent order of the Pune court on February 14, directing all the case records and seized properties to be sent to the special NIA court in Mumbai.

When contacted, Pawar told TOI, “I have relinquished my responsibility by handing over the charge to the government. I have conveyed my decision in an email to the principal secretary for law and judiciary, stating that since the term of my appointment (on a post-retirement extension) was until further orders, I am handing over the charge to the government.”

The government is now expected to appoint an officiating district government pleader and public prosecutor till the time a full-time replacement is in place.

Pawar, who specialises in criminal matters, holds the record of being the longest serving woman district government pleader in the state after she was appointed to the post here in 2011. “I am content with whatever service I have been able to render to the state in an honest manner. I shall now look forward to opportunities for conducting criminal trials as a special public prosecutor,” she said.

It was Pawar’s no-nonsense and studious approach that ensured none of the nine activists arrested so far in the Elgar case for their alleged links with the banned CPI (Maoist) organisation could get any relief — bail or otherwise. Her work stood validated in the form of various orders in relation to the case passed at different points in time by the Bombay high court and the Supreme Court.

Apart from the Elgar case, she has to her credit convictions that resulted in death penalties in many sensational cases. Those include the January 2012 rampage by state transport bus driver Santosh Mane that left nine persons dead and 27 others injured; death penalties to BT Kawade Road resident Vishwajeet Masalkar for killing his mother, wife and two-and-a-half-year-old daughter over his extra marital affair, and the mother-daughter duo of Leena and Dipti Deosthali , who were convicted for kidnapping and murdering a Pune doctor.

Mane later got reprieve from the Supreme Court, which commuted his death sentence to life imprisonment. The high court acquitted the Deosthalis of the murder charge but sentenced them to life in jail for kidnapping. The high court upheld the death sentence to Masalkar.

I have relinquished my responsibility by handing over the charge to the government. I have conveyed my decision in an email to the principal secretary for law and judiciary, stating that since the term of my appointment (on a post-retirement extension) was until further orders, I am handing over the charge to the government.

Title: Delhi Riots: They kept rioters out, preserved amity
Content:
Social life in Babarpur has been marked by communal amity

NEW DELHI: While communal tension gripped Maujpur, less than a kilometre away, Babarpur village kept hostility at bay, with the Hindu and Muslim residents living as neighbours deciding not to be provoked into senseless violence.

“On Monday, when news of stone pelting emanated from Maujpur, senior citizens immediately called a meeting and asked the residents here not to allow outsiders entry into the village,” disclosed area resident Ajay Sharma. “We also decided to nab any suspicious people and hand them over to the residents’ welfare association or the local police.”

Sharma’s neighbour and childhood friend Waseem Khan joined the conversation to add, “Some people claimed that Muslim houses were being targeted elsewhere in northeast Delhi and that we should join the protests. But we didn’t give heed to such talk, opting instead to say at home.”

While the cops began patrolling the area, the residents took it upon themselves to take the rounds of the village in batches, especially at night. “Our only objective was to keep goons or anti-socials away from our area. We were worried that the harmony shared by the people here would be affected by the presence of such people,” said Desh Raj.

Social life in Babarpur has been marked by communal amity. Mohammad Imran shared how all Muslims keenly wait to partake of the bhandara organised every year at the local temple and how dishes prepared during the Eid celebration are distributed to all Hindu houses. Mangu Singh affirmed that his Muslim landlord was very protective about his family. “I saw a few tenants in my neighbourhood collecting stones to deal with any unforeseen incident, but I convinced them that no violence would take place here,” said Singh.

In Mustafabad, amid the hatred, chaos and violence, this spirit of amity was in evidence at the Mankameshwar Mandir. Muslims sacrificed sleep the whole night to protect the Shiva temple from attacks by rioters. They also assisted Hindus employees of a sweet shop to leave the area when rioting broke out.

The mandir is surrounded by Muslim residences. As soon as reports of vandalism at a mosque in Ashok Vihar started being circulated, the residents became angry, “But we didn’t let anyone attack the temple,” claimed carpenter Mohammad Khalid. “Most of those indulging in violence were people from outside our localities. It was our responsibility to make sure our Hindu brothers and sisters did not face hostility.”

Harikant Sharma, the son of temple priest Indradev Shastri, commended the act of the local Muslims. “It was the Muslims who ensured our safety and protected the temple,” he corroborated. “Policemen were nowhere to be seen during all this, and if not for the locals we don’t know what could have happened.”

Mukesh Kumar, who runs a sweet shop in Mustafabad, expressed gratefulness at how the local Muslims alerted him to the violence in the nearby areas on Monday and helped him reach his home in Nand Nagri. “I have never seen anything like this before. I can’t even imagine how it all began,” said Mukesh, who returned to Mustafabad on Saturday to open his shop and meet with the locals.

Title: Savitribai Phule Pune University to launch solar panel walled building
Content:
'Experience Centre' will be inaugurated by Sharad Pawar on Sunday.

PUNE: The Savitribai Phule Pune University is set to inaugurate what it claims to be the first solar panel walled building in the country, with its glass facade mounted with panels made of cadmium telluride photovoltaic cells instead of the silicon-based cells.

The facility, being pegged as “Experience Centre” by the university’s energy studies department, will be inaugurated by Nationalist Congress Party chief Sharad Pawar at 9am on Sunday.

The panels would be mounted on the glass facade of the building covering an area of 200 sqft, the department officials said.

“Unlike the silicon solar panels, the Cadmium Telluride (CdTe) photovoltaic cells are transparent and bring in natural light. Because the walls are made of glass, the building would also give the people inside the structure a feeling of being in an open space,” director of School of Energy Studies at SPPU Sandesh Jadkar said.

He said the walls would generate 19 units of electricity per day. “We consume this much energy to run a four-tonne air conditioner, TV, projector, induction stove light and computers, among others,” Jadkar said. The building is a prototype model funded by SolarScape Enterprises .

“The building would be used to research on improving the efficiency of CdTe. In Pune, we have many structures with a glass façade. Hopefully, this model would give them an idea of how to use these CdTe imprinted glasses. If done right, dependability on clean energy could be improved,” Jadkar said.

He, however, said the cost factor and comparatively less efficiency of CdTe could hamper the popularity of such structures.

Title: Cong worried over crimes against Dalits: Pilot
Content:
Jodhpur: Deputy chief minister and PCC president Sachin Pilot on Friday said his party was rattled with the series of crimes against Dalits in the state and stressed the need to address the shortcomings in the system leading to such incidents.

“We have taken the crime and atrocities against the Dalits seriously and would act in these matters. If there was any shortcomings in the administration and the home department, they would be addressed. After all, it is a matter of reputation of the state,” said Pilot.

Pilot had arrived here to attend the wedding of party leader Karan Singh Uchiyarda straight from Delhi after submitting a report to party chief Sonia Gandhi.

He said all the aspects of the incidents have been mentioned in the report and the government was doing its duty.

“I have given the report to the party president and the government has also been doing is duty. But apart from transfer or other action, we needed to give a political message that in our government, we would exercise zero-tolerance towards such incidents against Dalits,” said Pilot.

“It was our duty to control these crimes and instill confidence among them that it would not happen again,” Pilot said while sharing the concern of the party for atrocities against Dalits.

Emphasising repeatedly on fixing of responsibilities, Pilot said until responsibilities for such incidents are not fixed, the fear of recurrence of such incidents would always be looming.

“For this, we would have to further strengthen the home department”, he said.

Referring to corruption in the system specially in the context of bajri mining, Pilot said harsh action, irrespective of the status, stature and influence of the corrupt, would have to be taken to root out corruption.

Talking about the violence in Delhi, he said investigation will find out the reason of riots and who were responsible.

“There was lacunae on the part of both central and Delhi government. Whosoever is responsible will have to be punished,” he said.

Title: Panchayat president lendS a hand in keeping villages clean
Content:
Dharmapuri: The panchayat president of Thadangam panchayat here did not shy away from wielding a broom stick and a mop when she came upon accumulated garbage in her panchayat.

Kavitha Murugan, along with her husband, who was visiting villages in her panchayat in Nallampalli union, spotted garbage accumulating in several places. “The panchayat comprises 22 villages with about 10,000 families living in it. Nearly five tonnes of garbage are produced in the panchayat every day. But there are only 19 sanitary workers to handle waste,” Kavitha Murugan said.

She said until the government sanctions more sanitary workers to the panchayat, she would lend a hand in keeping the villages clean. She appealed to the residents of the panchayat to keep their houses and surroundings clean.

Title: Adamapur, a village thronged by devotees from across the state
Content:
Adamapur, a tiny village located on the Maharashtra-Karnataka border has its name registered in the bucket list of devotees from across Maharashtra, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh. It hosts the famous Balumama temple. Adamapur has the Samadhi (tomb) of the famous 19th century saint Sadguru Balumama which makes it one of the frequently visited destinations by devotees from across the state borders.

How to reach

Located in Bhudargad tehsil of the district, one has to cover a distance of 45 km to reach Adamapur from the city. Travellers can take the Kolhapur-Gargoti route until they reach the Mudhal Titta village. From there, one has to take a left deviation and head further for another 2 km to reach Adamapur.

Legend has it

The Balumama temple at Adamapur is built using white marble and has intricate and beautifully carved walls. Ashok Patil, manager of the Balumama Devasthan Trust, said, “Shri Balumama was a shepherd from the Dhangar community. While sheep-herding, he performed several miracles and helped a lot of poor and downtrodden people and solved their problems. Thus, he attained sainthood. He was believed to be an incarnation of Lord Shiva. Balumama was born in a village called Akkol in Chikkodi tehsil of Belgavi district. He spent most of his time in Adamapur in Kolhapur district which is also the place where he took his last breath. Today, the temple trust runs a multi-speciality hospital, Bhakt Niwas and Annachhatra on a charity basis. Also, a museum is set to be opened soon where devotees could witness the clothes, things and utensils used by the saint during his days. There is a Peepal tree in front of the temple with three major sub-branches to it which is a rare thing. Devotees offer coins near the tree while offering prayers.”

Surroundings

Visiting this place on a weekend can prove to be an amazing experience, especially for nature lovers. This place has the perfect combination of nature and spirituality. Yashwant Patil, a resident of Adamapur, said, “Along with pleasant and cool atmosphere, one can find farmlands on either side of road leading to the village where sugarcane, paddy, marigold, cashew and tamarind is produced on a large scale”.

Title: Tractor driver has fits, rams vehicle
Content:
Hyderbad: Commuters at Chaitanyapuri had a narrow escape after a tractor rammed into four parked vehicles on Saturday. The tractor driver suffered fits while he was driving through Ganesh Nagar, causing him to lose control of the vehicle. The tractor ran into vehicles that were parked in the colony lane. Only the tractor driver sustained injuries .

In another incident at Pet Basheerabad, a motorist was hit by a car that was allegedly speeding. The motorist was badly injured and was shifted to a hospital. A case was registered. TNN

Title: Pune: Two developers booked for construction worker’s death
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Kondhwa police on Friday booked two developers on the charges of causing the death of a construction worker due to negligence, days after he fell from the first floor of a building coming up at Bhagyodayanagar on February 13.

The police said Sohail Ahmed Siddique (35) Siddique died due to multiple head injuries around 12.30pm the same day. The police had registered a complaint of accidental death.

“Investigations revealed that the building at lane number 24 was illegal, as the developers had not obtained permission from the civic body that had issued a stop-work notice. But the developers went ahead with the work,” an officer said

“The probe also revealed that Siddique died in the absence of safety measures at the site. The FIR was lodged under section 304 (a) of the Indian Penal Code,” the officer said.

Title: Pune: ‘Thirsty’ man robs woman of ornaments
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A woman (80) was found bleeding in the bed of her Narayan Peth home on Saturday afternoon after a man entered her house in the morning seeking water to drink and robbed her gold bangles as well as finger ring.

Senior inspector Dadasaheb Chudappa of Vishrambaug police said in the evening, “We have recorded her statement and filed a case against the man.”

The woman’s home is a few metres away from the crowded Modi Ganapati Chowk, off Laxmi Road. Chudappa said she had returned home from a temple around 11.30am. “When she opened the door, the man walked inside her house,” he said.

“The man drank water and charged at the woman. He pressed her mouth, forcibly removed four gold bangles and a finger ring, and fled bolting the door from outside,” he said, adding that the woman’s hands and finger were bleeding.

Her son and daughter-in-law had gone to their workplaces when the incident occurred.

Title: Pune: Slum Rehabilitation Authority schemes may go vertical to build more on less space
Content:
TimesView SRA officials have decided to opt for ‘vertical development’ model by enhancing the Floor Space Index limit to attract more developers. High-rises put enormous pressure on the existing infrastructure, including water supply. There is a need to assess the possible impact of such buildings on the existing infrastructure. A plan should be readied and executed to augment the service lines and avoid traffic congestion before the skyscrapers are allowed to come up.

Maintenance A Task In Tall Buildings

PUNE: Sky scrappers are expected to come up as Slum Rehabilitation Authority ( SRA ) projects after the state government removes height restrictions and frees up Floor Space Index. The move aims at accommodating more slum dwellers in these schemes using limited available space.The urban development and housing ministry recently decided that the construction of SRA schemes in Pune will be done on the lines of Mumbai.Developers are not coming forward as building ‘free sale houses’ under the SRA is not economically viabl, and many said steps are needed to make such projects feasible.“The construction of SRA schemes has become tough, and lack of land is our biggest hurdle in rehabilitation. Vertical development is the only option available as of now,” chief executive officer of SRA Rajendra Nimbalkar told TOI.A TOI report on SRA schemes in Mumbai in November 2019 said they were solely driven by offering high floor space index (FSI) to builders as a sop. But, over the years, housing activists have complained that while slum families are put up in narrow buildings with little light and ventilation in a small portion of the plot, the larger area is used to build spacious apartments in towers, and sold at a high profit.Nimbalkar said development control rules will be adhered to while granting such permissions in Pune. The Pune Municipal Corporation ’s data indicate that the rates of TDR per sq ft have gone down from Rs 3,000 to Rs 800 due lack of demand.“The lull in demand for Transfer of Development Rights (TDR) in the market is adding to the problems. Developers don’t want to build SRA schemes against TDR. They want some free sale properties in the scheme so that the funds for the SRA scheme can be generated through such sales,” Nimbalkar said.“If a private builder builds a high-rise for buyers, the same type of load is generated on the infrastructure like roads and water. When solutions for big societies are found, then they can be found for the SRAs too. We will find answers for rehabilitation projects too. The idea is to move to a slum free city which can be achieved only through vertical development of buildings,” he added.Activists are concerned about the stress on infrastructure and the maintenance of the slum rehabilitation buildings if sky scrapers are allowed as slum rehabilitation authority (SRA) projects. Current SRA projects are already facing problems due to improper management, they added.Maintaining cleanliness, garbage disposal and upkeep of elevators have become headaches in these buildings. Residents not familiar with elevators do not know how to operate them leading to frequent break downs. Once the elevators become non operational, nobody takes the initiative to repair them and residents have to take the stairs.Sadanand Shetty, a developer of SRA schemes, said residents find it difficult to look after the buildings once they are handed over. Occupants will have to make the effort to maintain their houses and amenities, he added.“Sensitisation of residents has to be taken up on priority before they shift to SRA schemes as there is a change in lifestyle while living in high-rises. Otherwise, SRA projects won’t prove successful,” he said.Shetty said sanitation and solid waste management are not easy in such societies. Lack of funds for maintenance creates hurdles in regular upkeep.Open spaces are often treated as garbage dumps. Door-to-door garbage collection and segregation at source need to be implemented rigorously, he added.Vijay Kumbhar of Surajya Sangharsha Samiti, a citizens’ group, said the PMC had shown its inability to provide infrastructure to high-rises some years ago. “If vertical development is being promoted and rehabilitation of the slums is done, then it can be a good solution. But, the civic administration should make sure civic infrastructure is provided.”Nimbalkar said the authority was working on steps. Collecting a one-time maintenance charge and creating a corpus is one solution, he added.“The corpus will be monitored by the authority, and instead of handling over these funds to the residents, SRA will take up the maintenance,” he said.

Title: Higher minimums for the next two weeks, forecast IMD
Content:
Pune: The minimum temperature in the city will continue to be on the higher side for the next two weeks, India Meteorological Department said.

On Saturday, the minimum temperature in Shivajinagar and Lohegaon was 15.9°C and 18.7°C, respectively, about 3-4 degrees notches above normal in both the locations.

The Met department officials stated that the next few days would record a further rise in the minimum temperature. The mercury would climb to 16-17°C in Shivajinagar. In Lohegaon, the minimum temperature is likely to rise to 19°C during the next few days.

The minimum temperatures have shot up across Madhya Maharashtra, with 1-6°C positive departures. This has translated into significantly above-normal temperatures, a Met department official said.

The minimum temperatures on Saturday were above normal at many places across Madhya Maharashtra. Sangli recorded the highest minimum temperature, with the mercury rising to 22.3°C — almost 6 degrees above normal.

Ahmednagar was the only district in Madhya Maharashtra where the observatory recorded a below-normal minimum temperature of 11.9°C. This was also the lowest minimum temperature in India over the plains on Saturday, according to the Met department.

The day temperatures recorded on Saturday were near-normal or marginally above normal. The Shivajinagar observatory recorded a maximum temperature of 33.8°C, while the day temperature in Lohegaon was 34.3°C.

Title: No toll at Khed-Shivapur for Pune and PCMC vehicles until issues resolved
Content:
PUNE: Commuters from Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad driving to and from Satara via Khed-Shivapur will not have to pay toll until the issues inconveniencing them were resolved, stated the district administration and the authority managing the toll booth.

An official from Reliance Infrastructure , which is managing the toll booth, said MP Supriya Sule and Union minister for transport Nitin Gadkari’s meeting was scheduled this week, to discuss the issues pertaining to the stretch. Until they were resolved, the toll for vehicles plying from Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad would be free. They will just have to show their ID cards, the official added.

The toll removal action committee was demanding the Khed-Shivapur toll plaza to be relocated outside the limits of the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA). However, the decision would be taken by the higher authorities, the Pune district collector Naval Kishore Ram said.

In January, the collector had directed the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) to build additional toll booths and lanes at the Khed-Shivapur toll plaza to ease traffic flow. “Under first phase of the work, there are five lanes at the Khed-Shivapur toll plaza, work for which has commenced. Of them, two lanes are dedicated to local commuters,” he said.

MP Supriya Sule on Saturday told TOI that she would hold discussions with Gadkari to resolve the issues.

A state government official said the Khed-Shivapur toll plaza was under the NHAI and to shift it to another location would not be easy as the distance between two toll plazas should be at least 60km.

Another official from Reliance Infrastructure said at present, additional booths of five lanes were ready towards Pune. “The trial was conducted on Friday. These lanes will be operated depending on the traffic flow on Sunday. They will be fully equipped in about 10 days. The booths are ready for operation in temporary-mode and rest of the plans would be completed as per the proposed timeline,” Amit Bhatia, the regional head of the west region of Reliance Infrastructure, said.

Title: FIR junked as rape survivor ties knot with the accused
Content:
Jaipur: A single bench of Rajasthan High Court quashed the rape FIR lodged at the Chandwaji police station after the accused married to the rape survivor .

The FIR was quashed after the accused filed an application in the court stating that he got married with the rape survivor and both have entered into a compromise in this regard and wish not to take up the matter further. The rape survivor also said that she does not want to continue the case against the accused she got married to her. “Both are married and the woman does not want to take the matter further,” said Deepak Chauhan, counsel for the petitioner accused told TOI on Friday.

Chauhan also presented the marriage certificate of the accused and pleaded to quash the FIR against him.

As per the case the rape survivor had lodged an FIR against the accused at the Chandwaji police station. She had alleged that while studying in a private university, she got acquainted with the accused Vishal. Meanwhile, on 19 January 2019, the accused brought her to Jaipur in pretext of shopping. The rape survivor in her complaint later stated that the accused took her to his friend's house in Jaipur and raped him in a drunken state.

Title: Officials ignoring court matters to be pulled up for neglect
Content:
Panaji: Officials of departments, corporations or autonomous bodies not taking court matters seriously will be taken to task. A circular in this respect has been issued after the Supreme Court imposed heavy fines on the state government for not filing a counter affidavit in one matter.

“All government departments, corporations and autonomous bodies are informed that whenever a response is not filed within time before the Supreme Court, National Green Tribunals or any other courts, or the matter/s are not attended on priority, the same will be viewed seriously,” law secretary Chokhan Ram Garg said in the circular.

Garg said some instances have come to their notice where, despite being served a notice by the apex count, no file or proposal has been moved by the departments for appointment of a standing counsel in the matter. As a result, the matter remains unattended on behalf of the state and the court imposes heavy fines for not filing out a counter affidavit/response in the matter.

“This issue is a clear sign of negligence on the part of departments,” Garg said.

He said that whenever departments or offices receive notices from any courts, authorities or tribunals, they should immediately submit their proposal for appointment of a standing counsel/advocates in the matter to defend the state’s interest. Simultaneously, a copy of the notice, summons or writs, along with the copy of the petition, must be marked and submitted to the law secretary within 24 hours of the receipt of the same.

The standing counsels before the apex court have also said that on instances, when they have tried to contact department officials, even on an urgent basis, they have failed to respond.

“The head of the department should ensure that a nodal officer is appointed for every matter pending before the Supreme Court,” he said.

Title: Yamuna water to help resolve water crisis in Mussoorie
Content:
Mussoorie: The “bhoomi poojan” ceremony for a new pumping project was initiated on Saturday in which water from Yamuna river would be extracted to meet the water demands of Mussoorie town.

The ceremony took place at Yamuna Bridge, about 30 kilometres from Mussoorie and was attended among other by Tehri MP Mala Rajya Lakshmi Shah and Mussoorie legislator Ganesh Joshi.

The pumping project has an outlay of Rs 144 crore and can supply up to 12 million litres per day (mld) from Yamuna river – which flows to the north of Mussoorie.

Joshi alleged that the scheme, once operational, would resolve the water crisis in Musoorie.

“Mussoorie faces a huge water crisis, especially during the summer months. Through this pumping scheme, the town’s water demand will be fulfilled at least for the next 30 years,” the MLA claimed.

Funded by the Centre, the water pumping scheme is expected to be completed in the next two years.

Sharing the technical details of the project, executive engineer of Peyjal Nigam, Subhash Chandra told TOI that under the scheme, water would be pumped from the Yamuna river to Radha Bhawan in Mussoorie.

“Water will be pumped in four stages and will be lifted from a height of 1,500 metres from Yamuna to Mussoorie. The total length of the pipeline, from the river to the town, would be around 17 km,” Chandra said.

Officials further said that a reservoir of 4,000 kilo-litre capacity would be constructed at Mussoorie from where the Yamuna water would be distributed across the town through the existing pipelines and also through additional pipelines that would be laid in the upcoming days.

“Starting from 2022, around 6 mld would be supplied to fulfill the current shortfall. The quantity would be increased in the later years based on increasing demand. It is expected that this project would fulfill the water demand at least up to 2052,” Chandra said.

Notably, Mussoorie draws its water from 20-odd springs and brooks that are currently supplying 7.69 mld water per day while the peak demand is over 13.5 mld.

Meanwhile, on Saturday, some villagers from nearby Bhidiyana village also reached the site and accused the officials of not informing them about the programme while also demanding compensation for land to be acquired for the project.

Peyjal Nigam officials told the villagers that compensation proceedings were underway.

Title: Pune: Zilla Parishad promises land for trash treatment plant
Content:
PUNE: The Zilla Parishad authorities on Saturday said gram panchayats in Hinjewadi, Maan and Marunji would be provided 2-3 acres of land to set up a garbage treatment plant.

At present, waste is picked up by private contractors as well as unregulated vendors who dump and burn the garbage, which pollutes the environment in the IT hub, said members and office bearers of registered cooperative housing societies in Hinjewadi, Maan, Marunji.

A town hall meeting, held under the chairmanship of the Pune Zilla Parishad CEO Ayush Prasad, was attended by villagers and members of housing societies from the IT hub. Issues related to garbage burning and disposal, water, sewage treatment plant and property tax were discussed at the meeting.

An alternative land would be sought by the Zilla Parishad from the Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation (MIDC) or the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA) to process and treat garbage for a cluster of four villages in the Hinjewadi area, said Prasad, who had conducted the first round of hearing with the villagers and residents of the IT hub.

He said he had already held a round of talks with the PMRDA and the gram panchayats could buy land on ready reckoner rate from the authority.

With the three gram panchayat areas largely dependent on tankers, Zilla Parishad authorities said water will be brought from the Kasarsai dam through a pipeline for the water scheme cleared by the government. For that, only an NOC from the MIDC and PMRDA will be required, he said. “I am told that 0.15 TMC water will be required. We will plan the water scheme within eight to nine months.” he said.

At present, there is no piped water supply to over 50 large complexes in Hinjewadi and Maan, while only a few societies in Maan get limited piped water supply. Overall, the entire area is heavily dependent on private water tankers, which has crippled the financial health of the societies, the residents pointed out.

The residents also stated that the Hinjewadi water supply scheme was approved by the government in 2014 and was to be implemented by ZP, Maharashtra Jeevan Pradhikaran and gram panchayat for lifting water from Kasarsai dam. The budget of Rs 17.86 crore was approved, but work was held up due to protests by local farmers in Kasarsai.

The ZP has since proposed a water supply scheme for the villages in Hinjewadi, Maan, Sus, Nande, Chande, Mahalunge and are in the process of taking the necessary approval from the irrigation department and district administration. The ZP CEO assured residents that the matter would be expedited.

Over 100 representatives from societies and townships attended the town hall meeting. “We have been pressing for better garbage and water management issues for the last three years,’’ said Ravindra Sinha, a member of Hinjewadi Industrial Residents.

Title: Pune: Burglar caught by society residents after hot chase
Content:
The burglary occurred at Vidyaniketan Housing Society in Undri on Thursday.

PUNE: Minutes after a gang of burglars broke into a flat at Vidyaniketan housing society at Undri on Thursday and stole cash and ornaments worth Rs 8.66 lakh, residents caught one of them after a hot chase.

Nazim Ansari, a criminal-on-record, was caught with a part of the loot worth Rs2.25 lakh and handed over to the police by the residents. Kondhwa police are on the lookout for Ansari’s two accomplices who are on the run.

The flat owner, Sameer Shaikh (43), has lodged an FIR under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code.

Shaikh told TOI, “I was in my garage at Bhavani Peth . My wife had gone out to fetch my son from school at Sayyednagar. Most resident of the society had gone to a neighbouring building to attend a meeting on water scarcity. The burglars took advantage of the situation and struck at my flat on the first floor after finding the door locked.”

He said that burglars broke into his flat after breaking open the door lock with a sharp weapon. “They stole gold and silver ornaments and cash worth Rs Rs8.66 lakh from the cupboard safe and took to heels,” Shaikh said.

“My neighbour Vijay Chavan heard noise of locks being broken from inside the flat and then spotted the burglars leaving the flat. Chavan alerted his friend Ganesh Raut who rushed to the society. On seeing them, the panicked burglars ran helter-skelter, but my neighbours chased and nabbed Ansari with a bag at Undri Chowk and handed him over to the police,” he said.

Ganesh Raut told TOI, “I was riding a motorcycle when I entered the society and saw Chavan raising an alarm and chasing the burglars. I too gave them a chase and pelted stones at them, but they escaped in a waiting autorickshaw. I chased the rickshaw and intercepted it at Undri Chowk. Though two burglars manage to flee, we caught Ansari and handed him over to the police.”

“Ansari has revealed the names of his accomplices to the police. I have requested our building residents to form a society, appoint trained security guards and install CCTV cameras,” Shaikh said.

Sub-inspector Santosh Shinde from Kondhwa police said, “Ansari is a criminal-on-record. We have recovered part of the stolen loot and some weapons from him. He will remain in police custody till March 2. We are working on certain clues and hope to arrest his two aides at the earliest.”

Title: After SC rap, lawyers of Doon district court work on Saturday, call off 35-yr-old strike
Content:
DEHRADUN: Ending the over three-decade-old practice of striking work in the district court of Dehradun every Saturday — in support of their demand to have a bench of the Nainital high court in the region — lawyers of the court worked on Saturday, the first time in 35 years.

The Supreme Court on Friday had held the strike called by lawyers of the district courts of Dehradun as well as some parts of Haridwar and Udham Singh Nagar districts every Saturday as “illegal” and had asked the advocates to end their strike as it amounted to “obstruction of access to justice.”

Reacting to the SC ruling, Manmohan Kandwal, president of the Dehradun Bar Association , told TOI, “We respect the Supreme Court guidelines and from now on, will work on Saturday as well. Our protest was essentially linked to the common man and was being held to highlight the problems that litigants were having while travelling to Nainital for their cases.”

He added that the lawyers’ association still felt that there was a need for a high court bench in Dehradun as well. “Nainital is a tourist city and litigants have no other option but to stay in expensive hotels, which adds to their financial burden. It would therefore be good if a bench is set up in the state capital as well.”

Significantly, before the formation of Uttarakhand, lawyers had been demanding for a western Uttar Pradesh bench of Allahabad high court . After Uttarakhand was formed in 2000, lawyers continued to observe strike on every Saturday, but now to press for their demand of a bench of the high court in Dehradun or Haridwar.

In September last year, the Uttarakhand high court had ruled that strikes and boycott of court work by lawyers was illegal, as it “violates fundamental right of speedy trial and delays justice.” While hearing a Public Interest Litigation (PIL), the double bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Verma had held that “strike or boycott of court work is a misconduct for which disciplinary action can be taken by the state bar council and its disciplinary committee.”

The HC had directed that district judges should ensure that the court functions on all working Saturdays and senior superintendents of police should provide police protection to ensure smooth functioning of the courts. Subsequently, an appeal had been filed against the high court’s verdict in the apex court which came up for hearing this week in the bench of Justices Arun Mishra and MR

Title: Online frauds siphon off Rs 11.22L from elderly man’s account
Content:
Pune: Fraudsters siphoned off Rs11.22 lakh of an elderly man from Pashan through 15 transactions using the UPI system between October 11 and November 6 after he downloaded a link following an interaction with a telecaller and shared a number with the latter.

Senior inspector Anil Shewale of the Chatushrungi police said, “The elderly man is a retired employee of India Meteorological Department (IMD). The man’s account linked to a UPI-based application had the money he had received from the central government after retirement.”

He said, “On October 11 last year, the man wanted to send a small amount to someone. But the UPI application continuously showed him the ‘server down’ message.”

Shewale said, “After the man failed to transfer the money, he decided to run an online search for the UPI (Unified Payments Interface) application’s helpline number.”

He said, “After finding a number, he made a call on it. A telecaller asked him to download a link, which he would receive on his cellphone in a text message.”

After downloading the link, the elderly man shared a number with the telecaller. “The suspects then siphoned off the money effecting as many as 15 transactions,” Shewale said.

“The elderly man realized that someone was siphoning off money from his UPI and contacted the branch concerned. But it was too late,” he said.

According to police, the man had downloaded a remote access software application on his cellphone and gave access of his device to the suspects unknowingly. “Once the suspects got the password of the UPI application, they made the transactions,” he said.

The police have booked the suspects.

Title: Calcutta University colleges can apply for skill-focused courses
Content: KOLKATA: Colleges affiliated to Calcutta University can apply for new subjects and streams at the undergraduate level to impart courses in subjects sought after by students and adopt a curriculum focused on skill orientation.The university has invited applications from its affiliated general degree colleges to apply for affiliation to new subjects/streams to keep pace with the changing landscape of higher education. It is also trying to address the issue of huge vacancies in many subjects at the UG level. In 2018 and 2019, the university had to postpone the last day of admission multiple times so that maximum seats could be filled up.University authorities said they have received applications for subjects like sociology, zoology, computer science, electronics, economics and journalism and mass communication from several colleges. In 2012, many colleges were given affiliation for new courses and subjects. Subsequently, several colleges applied to upgrade their pass courses to electives and elective courses to the honours category.“This is an attempt to provide the colleges an opportunity to focus on courses that help in skill enhancement of students. Several subjects fail to find many takers, as a result of which seats remain vacant. The college suffers as the infrastructure remains unutilized. Hence, we decided to invite applications from the colleges for affiliation to new subjects or streams that are in demand,” an official said.The colleges seeking affiliation to new subjects and streams will have to apply to the Calcutta University and the higher education department. The deadline for receiving the compliance report from colleges is April 30. After that, a university team headed by the inspector of colleges will evaluate the colleges. The colleges that make the cut can commence teaching the new courses or subjects from the 2020-2021 academic session.Several principals TOI spoke to said there was a need to revamp the assortment of subjects that had become obsolete in the current times.0 Students now scout for skill-oriented courses or which are in demand in the competitive examinations for government jobs right after their Plus II. This is why many colleges have started skill-enhancement courses as they are not affiliated to the university.“While many students still opt for core subjects like physics honours, chemistry honours or English honours, several choose new-age courses keeping the job requirements in mind,” said Tapan Kumar Poddar, vice-president of All Bengal Principals’ Council.

Title: Coronavirus in Vijayawada: Public shun chicken to keep coronavirus, bird flu at bay
Content: VIJAYAWADA: While the World Health Organisation has cautioned people against consuming raw or undercooked animal products as part of its list of basic protective measures against the new coronavirus , it has had a considerable impact on the diet of people of Vijayawada . While demand for chicken has crashed by almost 65%, demand for fish has skyrocketed.Besides the fear of coronavirus, the reported outbreak of Very Virulent Newcastle Disease (VVND) in a poultry farm in the Godavari districts have further fuelled fears.Data revealed that cost of chicken fell by 50% in the last three weeks and there has been a simultaneous rise in the cost of mutton. Consequently, sale of fishes has risen, being the only cheaper alternative available.Nowadays it is not out of ordinary to see long queues at fish markets. Speaking to TOI, Ramesh who runs a retail live fish unit at Patamata Lanka fish market, said “We usually see a huge demand on Sundays. But we are witnessing sales throughout the week. Buyers are showing interest in freshwater fish and we have arranged for small tanks to promote sales. Meanwhile, aquafarmers have increased their prices by Rs 40 per kilogram. Consumers are happy as they are able to buy a big fish for the cost of 1 kilo mutton.”Fisheries authorities have confirmed to TOI that the average consumption of fish has increased in recent times. “Aquafarmers of Kalidhindi, Kaikaluru, Gudivada are happy with the rise in demand. Domestic consumption in the district has increased by 50%. The government is encouraging farmers to cultivate fishes in a healthy atmosphere and helping them earn profits,” said SK Lal Mohammed, joint director at the fisheries department.Meanwhile, physicians have swung into action and are trying to debunk claims that coronavirus can spread through the consumption of meat. “ Fish is a good source of protein and it is healthy for all age groups. But it should be preserved in a healthy atmosphere. There is no chance of the spread of coronavirus from meat,” said Dr Vattipalli Bhagyaraj, a city-based physician.

Title: Research, strategic thinking key to use combat power: Air Marshal Amit Dev
Content:
(Second from left) Air Marshal Amit Dev after signing the MoU

PUNE: Air Marshal Amit Dev, Air Officer-in-Charge (personnel) of the Indian Air Force (IAF), said on Saturday that research and strategic thinking were the key elements for utilisation of combat powers in the current security scenario.

He was speaking to reporters after signing an MoU with the department of defence and strategic studies of the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) for establishing a chair of excellence in the name of IAF Marshal Arjan Singh for the resident scholar programme (RSP) for IAF officers.

Air Marshal SS Soman (retired), who commanded the Western Air Command , will be the first head of the chair. “Some people from the force can take leave and study and conduct research on strategic subjects. This move will certainly bring a positive difference to the service. We are looking for scholar warriors. As technology is advancing rapidly, we need strategic thinking to utilise elements of various combat powers that are with the force,” Dev said.

This is the first time that the IAF has collaborated with any university in the country.

“There are very few universities in the country which run courses related to defence strategic studies. The SPPU has been conducting this course since 1963. In fact, it has adequate resources, conducive environment and enough experience in the field. This is the reason why the IAF chose SPPU,” said Dev, a fighter pilot of the IAF.

“About eight to ten IAF officers will do research on national security subjects at the department,” said Vijay Khare, head of the department.

Vice-chancellor Nitin Karmalkar described it as a historic moment for the university. “The chair will bridge the gap between the armed forces and academia,” he said.

Title: DRDO’s explosive detection device impresses Maharashtra ATS
Content:
PUNE: The Anti-Terrorism Squad ( ATS ) of the Maharashtra and Telangana police have evinced interest in procuring a device called ‘OPX Revilator’, which can detect more than 25 pure explosives as well as trace explosives in mixtures of mud, sand, sugar, salt and diesel.

The device was developed by the city-based High Energy Materials Research Laboratory (HEMRL) of the Defence Research and Development Organisation ( DRDO ) in 2018.

“Several security agencies, including Maharashtra ATS and Telangana police have tested the device in the last few months. They have informed us that their field results were positive. They had put forth some additional requirements, which will be added in the device,” HEMRL director KPS Murthy told TOI on Friday.

Mass production of the device will be done through transfer of technology (ToT), he said. “Currently, two private firms are bidding for the ToT,” added Murthy.

This device is useful for homeland security and civil security operations at airports, railway stations, shopping malls, multiplexes, schools, colleges, universities and all strategic locations. This device can also play a crucial role in post-blast analysis.

The HEMRL and the Indian Institute of Science Bangalore have developed new explosive detection device called ‘Raider X’. It will be launched during the second national workshop on explosive detection to be held on March 1 at the HEMRL Pashan.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Fixed charges back; petrol, diesel become dearer again
Content:
Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The government on Saturday increased the fixed charge component in value added tax ( VAT ) on petrol and diesel in the state. The hike will see petrol become dearer by 76 paise, while diesel will cost Rs 1.07 extra per litre. The new rates will come into force from the first hour on Sunday.

The government had, on January 29, made changes to the VAT tariffs by removing the earlier fixed charge on petrol and diesel. The tariffs were revised from 31% on petrol to 35.2%, and from 22.25% to 27% on diesel. By increasing the tariff, the government removed the fixed charge of Rs 2 per litre being collected on both petrol and diesel. Now, the tariffs have been reverted to the previous 31% and 22.25% on petrol and diesel respectively, but the fixed charge component has been reintroduced. In place of Rs 2 per litre, the fixed charges have now become Rs 2.76 on petrol and Rs 3.07 on diesel per litre.

The fall in prices of crude oil in the international market and the removal of fixed charge component had an adverse affect on the government’s coffers. Earlier, the government used to get fixed revenue from the sale of petrol and diesel despite the fluctuation in prices. But the recent fall in fuel prices has resulted in fall in revenues. The move to reintroduce the fixed charge is being seen as an attempt to bridge that gap.

AP has been collecting the highest VAT on petrol and diesel when compared to its southern counterparts. Photos of fuel stations putting up huge banners comparing local fuel prices to that in AP in the border areas of Karnataka and Tamil Nadu to attract consumers have gone viral on social media many times before.

Title: Maharashtra: 4 leopard cubs spotted on sugar cane fields at 2 villages in Junnar
Content:
The three cubs found in Rajuri village

PIMPRI CHINCHWAS: Four leopard cubs were spotted at two villages — three at Rajuri and one at Gunjalwadi — of Junnar taluka , around 17km from Otur and 123km from the city, on Saturday morning during sugar cane harvesting.

Sugar cane is cultivated on a large scale in these villages. Round forest officer SK Salunke of Ale said, “Labourers were harvesting sugar cane on farmer Shivaji Gatkal’s field at Rajuri when they spotted three leopard cubs around 11.30am.”

He said the forest department had left the cubs at the same spot on the field in anticipation that the mother leopard would come searching for them.

Gatkal said, “The labourers called me when they saw the cubs sitting at a small cleared space on the field. The harvesting activity was stopped immediately as the labourers were afraid of the mother leopard coming back. We notified the forest department.”

Gatkal said a tractor driver coming to his field to collect sugar cane spotted a big leopard, from a distance, in the morning.

Another cub was found at Gunjalwadi village, around 4km away from Narayangaon. Round forest officer Manisha Kale of Narayangaon said, “Farmer Arvind Dongare has a field in the village near Meena river. Three cubs wandered out when sugar cane was being cut on the field around 11am. Two of them scampered back into the thicket of uncut sugar cane, leaving behind the 25-day-old female cub. The forest team reached the spot after villagers informed us about it.”

Kale said the forest officials left the cub in the field hoping that its mother would take her away at night.

Title: Developed economies pulling the ladder from developing peers: India’s WTO envoy
Content:
Former RBI governor at the Asia Economic Dialogue on Saturday.

PUNE: India’s ambassador to the World Trade Organisation JS Deepak on Saturday said developed economies, especially the United States, were imposing unfair terms and trying to dilute reforms at the WTO to the detriment of the developing nations.

“The agenda of the US is basically a reaction of them losing many cases at the appellate body of the WTO (World TRade Organisation), and many of their laws are being successfully challenged. In the name of national security or otherwise, they want to get out of commitments they had made in terms of tariffs,” he said, while speaking as a part of a panel chaired by former RBI governor Urjit Patel at the Asia Economic Dialogue organised by the Pune International Centre.

Deepak alleged that the US was trying to remove statutes from the WTO rules that they took advantage of, including removal of flexibilities for developing countries, so as to return to the era of bilateral trade deals.

He largely praised the WTO’s role in maintaining multilateral trade all over the world and underlined the effect of free trade, bringing millions of people all over the world out of poverty, besides offering consumer choice. He also offered a word of caution.

“Free trade has had both good and bad effects. There is of course a backlash against free trade these days because it had disruptive effects too. The steel industry in the US and the electronics industry in India have been wiped out by free trade,” Deepak said.

He said the US was funding thinktanks and other measures to implement its own WTO reforms agenda, which was centred on the fear of “the rise of the rest, including China, India and South Africa, among others”.

Deepak also cited examples of politicians who professed free trade, but went on to impose tariffs. “We had President Donald Trump going to Davos and affirming his commitment to free trade. But after return to the US, he imposed tariffs on hundreds of goods and services. Similarly, we had Prime Minister (Narendra) Modi speak at Davos and say that the country would be open without protectionism, but in the budget, we had tariffs going up. So, good economics of liberalisation does not seem to be good politics, as far as trade is concerned,” he added.

Title: SIT starts probe, searches conducted at several places
Content:
Vijayawada: A team from the SIT , constituted to probe the alleged irregularities, which took place during the TDP regime, conducted searches in the house and offices of former minister Prathipati Pulla Rao’s relative Basavaiah on Friday. They inquired into his land transactions in the last five years in and around Amaravati.

Similar searches were conducted at the residence and offices of a builder from Vijayawada on the suspicion that he was acting as a Benami for Pulla Rao. They searched his house for documents related to land transactions, which may have taken place through his firm in the capital region.

Another SIT team conducted searches in the house of one Subhani, who works as a carpenter. He purchased a piece of land in the capital region, according to sources.

He is also suspected to be a benami to another person accused in the case. Houses of suspected benamis who made land purchases in capital region without proper source of income were also searched.

The SIT, which was given a wide-ranging powers to investigate the irregularities, has focussed on suspected benami land transactions, which took place in the capital region.

Meanwhile, on Saturday, the SIT also searched the residence of senior TDP leader and former chairman of Kanchikacherla Agriculture Market committee in Krishna district, Nannapaneni Lakshminarayana.

Officials had served search notices to Lakshminarayana on Friday. But, since his residence at Kanchikacherla was locked and his family members were unavailable, the officials pasted the search notices to the walls of his house and posted police personnel outside the house to prevent any outsider from entering the house. Lakshminarayana and his family members, who had gone to the hospital on Friday, returned home on Saturday.

Sources said SIT searched the residence for more than three hours and seized a few documents. Lakshminarayana’s son-in-law D Srinivasa Rao served as a government advocate general during the previous TDP government and Lakshminarayana’s son N Sitharamaraju is a real-estate business and he was also one of the sub-contractors of the Polavaram project in the TDP regime.

SIT officials suspect that Lakshminarayana and his family members might have been involved in the alleged insider trading (land purchase) in the Amaravati region.

As a cabinet sub-committee and CID prima facie identified the transactions pertaining to more than 4,000 acres of land in the capital region as part of the insider trading and benami transactions, the SIT is now digging deep into each transaction. It was also identified that some of the land were purchased by white ration cards holders, which are all suspected as benami transactions.

Title: Hooghly water unfit for bathing, Dakshineswar worst: Study
Content:
TimesView A concerted approach involving upstream states, where many of bigger river systems originate, is necessary. Many of our rivers are still used as sewerage systems and this must stop.

KOLKATA: Water in the 17 rivers monitored by the state pollution control board (PCB) do not meet the bathing standard, putting several lakh who live along the rivers and bathe there at risk. The worst-hit area is Dakshineswar that attracts 50,000 devotees daily. Of the 44 locations where water quality was tested, Dakshineswar has the worst biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) level, implying that the pollution load is so high that it is difficult for even fish to breathe in the water here.None of 14 monitoring locations along the Ganga, five in the Himalaya and north, 19 in the west, including 10 locations at Damodar and six in the upper and lower Ganga delta rivers currently meet the bathing standard (5mg/litre dissolved oxygen; 3ml/litre biochemical oxygen demand and 500MPN/100ml coliform bacteria) revealed a report prepared by NGO Legal Initiative for Forest and Environment (LIFE) after analysing the water quality data compiled by PCB.Admitting that the rivers were choking and needed a break from the untreated sewage flowing into them, PCB chairman Kalyan Rudra said the watchdog agency’s target was to ensure that water in rivers improves to achieve the bathing standard.The report has also pointed out discrepancies in activities recorded by the watchdog agency and classification of rivers. “Designating the right use-based classification is a prerequisite for curbing pollution as the permissible limit of separate parameters is different for each class. For example, the level of total coliform (TC) needs to be brought down to 500 MPN (most probable number)/100ml if the water has to be made suitable for ‘Class B’(outdoor bathing). For ‘Class C’, or water that can be made fit for drinking with conventional treatment, the TC can remain at 5,000MPN/100ml. A higher level of TC indicates the presence of disease-causing organisms (pathogens),” said LIFE analyst Kankana Das.Rudra said water in the rivers are now a lot more polluted than when the classifications were done a couple of decades ago. “The ecological flow of the rivers, or their ability to flush the sediment load and dilute pollutants has since reduced. We have to stop flow of further drainage into rivers,” he said.

Title: Volunteers, locals join hands to help riot-hit pick up the pieces
Content:
Releif work at Mustafad after Section 144 was removed for few hours in North East Delhi on Friday at Chand Bag... Read More

New Delhi: Relief poured in for the riot-hit people on Sunday as volunteers from diverse spectrums documented losses, distributed food and provided legal help. At GTB Hospital , independent lawyers were seen providing monetary as well as legal help.

Senior advocate HS Phulka and spiritual guru Sri Sri Ravishankar were among those who visited the riot-affected areas. Police officers could be seen making note of the damage. They approached owners and recorded videos of them narrating their ordeal.

Sri Sri said people should take lessons from those who saved lives. “We should punish the anti-social elements. It is so disturbing to see so many people affected. We need to bring the lives back on track,” he said.

Naresh Aggarwal, owner of a sweets shop in Khajuri Khas, said: “My shop was locked when it was vandalized by goons. Last year, I had sold my wife’s jewellery to renovate it.” Phulka, accompanied by Khalsa Aid volunteers, spoke to shop owners. He said: “High court lawyers are voluntarily coming out to help the victims. We are working in coordination with Khalsa Aid as they have experience in this field. Our first priority is to ensure that people get their means of livelihood back.”

A delegation arrived from Nizamuddin Dargah in Babu Nagar to provide food to the refugees. Md Abdullah, the local Imam, said there were hundreds of people who had arrived in the colony to take shelter. Karan Pal (22) and his family had brought food for the security personnel on duty. “We are taking care of our fauji brothers who are helping everyone,” Pal said.

Right outside the morgue at GTB Hospital in Dilshad Garden , volunteers could be seen offering food, water and tea to the family of the victims. The group is working in shifts, from 9am to 9.30pm. “We are locals. We came here and saw people facing problems. We decided to pitch in,” Gulzar Ahmed (46) said. Teachers of a government school in Tukhmirpur in northeast Delhi also got together and distributed rations at Shiv Vihar. Dinesh Kumar, a political science teacher, said: “Motivated by other teachers, I came forward to help.”

Title: DRDO’s explosive detection device impresses Maharashtra ATS
Content:
PUNE: The Anti-Terrorism Squad ( ATS ) of the Maharashtra and Telangana police have evinced interest in procuring a device called ‘OPX Revilator’, which can detect more than 25 pure explosives as well as trace explosives in mixtures of mud, sand, sugar, salt and diesel.

The device was developed by the city-based High Energy Materials Research Laboratory (HEMRL) of the Defence Research and Development Organisation ( DRDO ) in 2018.

“Several security agencies, including Maharashtra ATS and Telangana police have tested the device in the last few months. They have informed us that their field results were positive. They had put forth some additional requirements, which will be added in the device,” HEMRL director KPS Murthy told TOI on Friday.

Mass production of the device will be done through transfer of technology (ToT), he said. “Currently, two private firms are bidding for the ToT,” added Murthy.

This device is useful for homeland security and civil security operations at airports, railway stations, shopping malls, multiplexes, schools, colleges, universities and all strategic locations. This device can also play a crucial role in post-blast analysis.

The HEMRL and the Indian Institute of Science Bangalore have developed new explosive detection device called ‘Raider X’. It will be launched during the second national workshop on explosive detection to be held on March 1 at the HEMRL Pashan.

Title: Pune: Shirdi airport key works face delay
Content:
PUNE: The work of extending the runway of the Shirdi airport and setting up a night landing facility has been delayed yet again, officials of the Maharashtra Airport Development Company Limited (MADC) said.

“While the runway extension is expected to take another six months, the technicalities and equipment for night landing facility at the airport is expected to be ready in the next three months. The Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) officials will inspect the work before approving it. We are hoping to commission the both in August or September this year,” said an official.

MADC vice-chairman and managing director said, “We have had to go for a re-tendering to finalise a new contractor to execute the project. The previous contractor couldn’t do the job properly, resulting in both the projects getting delayed.”

Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray , who presided over the MADC board meeting on Tuesday, asked the officials to ensure that projects related to the Shirdi airport were completed on time.

Title: Maharashtra: 4 leopard cubs spotted on sugar cane fields at 2 villages in Junnar
Content:
The three cubs found in Rajuri village

PIMPRI CHINCHWAS: Four leopard cubs were spotted at two villages — three at Rajuri and one at Gunjalwadi — of Junnar taluka , around 17km from Otur and 123km from the city, on Saturday morning during sugar cane harvesting.

Sugar cane is cultivated on a large scale in these villages. Round forest officer SK Salunke of Ale said, “Labourers were harvesting sugar cane on farmer Shivaji Gatkal’s field at Rajuri when they spotted three leopard cubs around 11.30am.”

He said the forest department had left the cubs at the same spot on the field in anticipation that the mother leopard would come searching for them.

Gatkal said, “The labourers called me when they saw the cubs sitting at a small cleared space on the field. The harvesting activity was stopped immediately as the labourers were afraid of the mother leopard coming back. We notified the forest department.”

Gatkal said a tractor driver coming to his field to collect sugar cane spotted a big leopard, from a distance, in the morning.

Another cub was found at Gunjalwadi village, around 4km away from Narayangaon. Round forest officer Manisha Kale of Narayangaon said, “Farmer Arvind Dongare has a field in the village near Meena river. Three cubs wandered out when sugar cane was being cut on the field around 11am. Two of them scampered back into the thicket of uncut sugar cane, leaving behind the 25-day-old female cub. The forest team reached the spot after villagers informed us about it.”

Kale said the forest officials left the cub in the field hoping that its mother would take her away at night.

Title: Man damages parked vehicles
Content:
Pune: A man damaged four vehicles parked on a road at Sutardara in Kothrud around 1.30am on Saturday after a group of youths teased and hurled abuses at him.
