The man damaged the three cars and a school van with an iron rod and stones lying on the road, police said.

Senior inspector Pratibha Joshi of the Kothrud police said, “A group of youths from the Sutardara area were sitting on the rooftop of their houses when they spotted a drunken man and started teasing and hurling abuses at him. This enraged the man, who picked up an iron rod and also stones from the roadside and smashed windscreens and headlamps of the four vehicles.”

“A search has been launched to trace the man as well as the youths,” she said.

Title: Nagpur: Airforce employee under scanner for leaking information
Content:
NAGPUR: A clerical staffer with the Indian Airforce (IAF), identified as Radheshyam Pandey, was rounded up during a joint action by the intelligence wings of IAF and city police from Narmada Colony on Friday. Four mobile phones were seized from him.

Pandey is learnt to be under the scanner for leaking information. The IAF sleuths are now scanning the contents of the mobile phones and contact details in them. The deleted messages, images and other contents are being recovered by cyber experts. He is learnt to be working at the administrative office of the IAF at Vayusena Nagar. Pandey had access to some crucial information which the intelligence wing feels he may have passed on to some handlers.

It’s learnt that Pandey was whisked away from his rented apartment following a sweeping search. He is learnt to be under the scanner for espionage.

Intelligence agencies have started probing Pandey’s contacts and network. He is still being grilled by the IAF.

Title: Economies will come out stronger after coronavirus challenge: Chinese consul general
Content:
Pune: China’s Consul General in Mumbai Tang Guocai on Saturday said his country as well as the regional and the world economies would come out stronger after the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) challenge.

“We are fighting coronavirus with great capability and responsibility. We are setting an example for the world in facing future challenges,” he said during a session on ‘Global Value Chains’ at the ongoing Asian Economic Dialogue in the city.

“We are confident that with the kind of cooperation and concerted effort, we shall win this war against coronavirus. With this, we shall fight against other challenges the humanity will face in the future,” Guocai said.

As of now, the Chinese government at all levels was making a tremendous effort focused on fighting the contagion and containing its spread, he said. At the same time, the other challenge remained in revitalizing China’s economy, which was nothing short of another battle, Guocai said.

He said, “A megacity like Wuhan has been placed under scientific quarantine. Adequate focus, in terms of precautionary measures, is being put on the manufacturing hubs in China’s coastal provinces, including Shanghai and Guangdong. The manufacturing industries in the coastal provinces, too, have responded positively to the crisis and cooperation from neighbouring countries has increased.”

According to latest reports, China reported at least 44 new coronavirus deaths on Friday, taking the total number of fatalities there to 2,788 so far. Coronavirus has killed more than 2,800 people and infected more than 83,000 worldwide.

“The spirit of global village chain must precede the global value chain concept. We have to move towards a global community of shared future that is free of divisions caused by politics, caste, race and religion, among others,” Guocai said.

Zhang Xiangchen, the Chinese ambassador to the World Trade Organisation (WTO), said reforms were required at WTO to ensure that more developing nations had a voice, in the face of more protectionism and tariffs from economies like the US.

Title: Delhi government’s special cell to tackle online rumours
Content:
Security personnel walk past a riot hit area in Delhi

NEW DELHI: Delhi government is going to set up a special cell to fight the menace of rumours and fake and misleading content being shared on WhatsApp and other social media platforms . During the riots, which left nearly 42 dead, rumours were used to fan violence in different parts of northeast Delhi .

The government will soon issue a mobile number on which the public can forward suspicious messages. All such messages, which are in violation of the IT Act and various sections of the IPC, will be forwarded to the police for action. A public advisory will also be issued for people to refrain from taking the fake WhatsApp forwards at their face value, and from falling prey to the misleading information on social media.

An official said forwarding sensitive fake and misleading content could land any person in jail for up to five years. “The law has enough provisions to punish those who engage in spreading rumours which promote hatred in the society on the grounds of religion, race and other factors. But despite the presence of strong laws, such rumours are common during riots. The government wants to use the existing laws to check the spread of rumours to ensure peace and harmony in the society,” an official said.

“The elected government of Delhi does not have control over Delhi Police. It stops the government from taking direct measures in improving law and order. But it faces a share of the blame when law and order condition deteriorates as many of the common people do not understand the nitty-gritty of jurisdiction. The special cell will work in coordination with Delhi Police to control the fake content factory,” the official added.

Title: Dist administration completes preps for Inter exam in Krishna
Content:
Vijayawada: Krishna district administration has completed arrangements for the Intermediate examinations, scheduled to begin from March 4. The intermediate board has introduced a few reforms, which include downloading hall tickets directly from the official website of the Board of Intermediate Education (BIE).

Around 70,000 students from the city are likely to appear for the examination this year. Officials are focused on providing necessary amenities to the students at examination centers.

Krishna district administration had formed co-ordination committees to arrange transportation, drinking water, continuous power supply at examination centers. Authorities has completed installing CCTV cameras in examination halls for the first time, which would help control mass copying. Departmental officers, chief supervisors will monitor the examination process along with invigilators. The board has decided to utilise the services of ward volunteers as invigilators in required locations. High power committee under the leadership of district collector Mohammed Imtiaz will inspect the examination centers.

Regional inspection officer P Ravi Kumar said they have arranged multiple helpline centers at Machilipatnam, Pedana, Pamarru, Korukollu and other locations to help students. “Students can download hall tickets from the board’s website and this will reduce the burden on colleges, he said.

We have directed the chief superintendents of all exam centers to acquire necessary furniture and will initiate stringent action if we find any student writing the examination on the floor, Ravi Kumar said.

Collector Imtiaz on Saturday urged officials to make the exams a success. He asked parents to use the mobile application to locate examination center and seating to prevent last-minute confusion. Officials at the centres will scan the special QR code printed on the hall tickets to prevent malpractices, he said. The collector also directed the students not refrain from cheating.

Police have been directed to deploy special security at exam centers and close all photocopy centers located close to exam centers.

Title: Pune: DPR for waste management in all villages in district
Content:
PUNE: The Zilla Parishad is set to roll out a detailed project report ( DPR ) on solid waste management after several villages raised concerns about garbage burning in their areas.

The plan would be applicable to all 1,405 villages in Pune district .

Burning of untreated garbage along highways in the proximity of these villages is a common concern among villagers.

Officials from the Zilla Parishad said they would be drawing out the plan for the bigger gram panchayats first, followed by the smaller ones. “The entire plan should be ready within a year for all the villages. Once it is readied, the villages would have to follow the plan diligently. A panel would be appointed to monitor strict implementation of the plan,” said an official of the Zilla Parishad.

In a first, the detailed plan would ensure that garbage disposal and treatment were done at the village-level itself. Setting up sewage treatment plants (STPs) in these villages would be a part of the DPR that should be ready soon, said Pune ZP CEO Ayush Prasad .

He said only 100 villages have a rough draft at present. But soon the others would be covered to ensure streamlined waste disposal.

The plan would include activities such as collection, removal and safe disposal of waste with the participation of every member of the village community.

Village panchayats having the potential of generating the maximum volume of waste, those with a population of more than 10,000 peri-urban panchayats, those having association with tourist, pilgrim and industrial activities and the ones abutting national highways would be covered on a priority basis, another Zilla Parishad official said.

Title: India’s integration into global value chains a collective task: PMEAC head Bibek Debroy
Content:
Pune: Chairman of Prime Minister’s Economic Advisory Council (PMEAC) Bibek Debroy on Saturday said the broader ecosystem, including industry and manufacturing, needed to react to the competitive pressures of international trade before the country was seen as doing much better in terms of integration into the global value chains (GVCs).

“Government is just an island in the broad ecosystem. It cannot become excellent in isolation and needs to do some things hitherto denied and to reduce some things that are malign with intent. But the broader ecosystem must react to the competitive pressures,” he said at a session on GVCs at the ongoing Asia Economic Dialogue organized by the Pune International Centre.

The GVCs refer to coordinated activities across geographies for production and post-production supply and distribution of goods and services. It has led to a redistribution of economic activity towards emerging countries, offering economic development opportunities to large and small firms.

“When we talk about GVCs, what we probably really mean is manufacturing and not services. The manufacturing share in India’s gross domestic product (GDP) has been virtually flat for several years. Liberalisation, whether multilateral, bilateral or unilateral, means competition and to benefit from it. To integrate oneself and one’s economy into that competitive framework, we require indigenous domestic changes,” Debroy said.

He said, “For decades, we have had a litany of woes that plague manufacturing. Be it in the form of physical infrastructure like road and electricity, taxation regime (tax rates and procedure), cost and availability of credit, and labour and skills problems. Many reforms we have in mind also relate to the judiciary and legislature. Many reforms that are required need changes in areas such as the Concurrent List and the 7th Schedule in the Indian Constitution.”

Debroy said there were various measures for judging India’s integration into GVCs. “While India has not performed badly on backward integration, it is the forward integration that remains a challenge. Much of this has to do with the fact that the country has historically been much more centralised for colonial or planning reasons. There is a long list of things that government has to do, but government is just an island in the broad ecosystem.”

World Bank’s former lead economist Jayanta Roy, while presenting a theme paper on the GVCs and what India needs to do, observed that India had been hesitant in global supply chains. “We have to make our industries competitive,” he said.

Sanjay Gandhi, chief financial officer of New Delhi-based Pearl Global Industries, gave an industries’ perspective on the GVCs and expectations from the government.

Title: Nagpur: SMSN to oppose 5% religion-based reservation
Content:
NAGPUR: The save merit save nation ( SMSN ) forum that has been opposing more than 50% reservation in education and jobs is now up in arms against the proposal of 5% reservation to Muslims.

“Though it’s still a proposal given by one of the ministers in the state cabinet, there are differences within the state government. We don’t want to take any chances for 5% more reservation,” said Dr Anup Marar, secretary of SMSN forum.

A meeting of SMSN office bearers was held in Nagpur on Saturday to decide the further course of action. Members will oppose the very idea of religion-based reservation on all platforms.

“Religion-based reservation is unconstitutional and we will oppose it. SMSN is already fighting against the alarming situation in Maharashtra due to increase in the percentage of reservation to 74% after SEBC and EWS. This reservation escalates to 85% with further lateral reservations. What will remain for meritorious students of the open unreserved category if 5% religion-based reservation gets added?,” said working president Shreekrishna Buty.

SMSN is planning to hold an awareness programme in Nagpur in March to mobilize masses against the proposal of 5% religion-based reservation.

SMSN activists recently met chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray in Mumbai and they were quite optimistic about the meeting. They are now saddened by the government’s response to their demands.

“Unfortunately, the very next day after our meeting with the CM, one of the ministers in his cabinet came up with the proposal of 5% religion based reservation ,” said Buty.

SMSN Office bearers said that the additional reservation should be opposed right at the beginning, before it takes the form of a bill or ordinance.

“Religion specific reservation will further divide our nation and lead to caste hatred and civil unrest. We will demand that reservation should never be religion specific and should be limited to 50 % for the non-creamy layers in all reserved categories. The balance 50% as per the Supreme Court judgement should be left for the open category so that merit is also recognized,” said Adv Rahul Pande.

Title: 7-yr-old boy dies in freak accident
Content:
Jaipur: A seven-year-old boy died while playing with a rope in Kardhani police station area on Thursday evening. The child was killed accidentally when the rope which he was playing with got wrapped around his neck and he got strangulated.

The deceased child was identified as Kamlesh Kumar.

Ramkishan, SHO, Kardhani police station said, “The child was playing with the rope when he accidentally got his neck trapped in it. The neck broke because of which the child died.”

Police have not found anything suspicious about the death and they are calling it accidental.

“We have no reason to believe that there was any foul play in the incident and it was an accident though extremely unfortunate. Since the child was very young, he did not realise when the rope formed a noose and he got strangulated. As the neck broke, nothing could have been done to save him,” added the official.

Title: NMC begins to make aiwajdars permanent
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has started giving permanent jobs to daily wage sanitary workers (aiwajdars) from Monday. Around 347 aiwajdars were inducted on a permanent basis in the civic body on the eve of NMC’s foundation day.

Mayor Sandip Joshi handed over letters to 50 aiwajdars, five each from ten zones, in a programme held at NMC head office situated at Civil Lines. “2,206, including 347 aiwajdars will get permanent jobs in the NMC. Aiwajdars play a major role in city’s sanitation. Aiwajdars put their health at risk to keep city neat and clean. They deserve permanent induction in the NMC. Therefore, leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis had approved it during his tenure as chief minister,” he said.

The state government on September 21, 2019, had issued a notification allowing the NMC to give permanent jobs to aiwajdars. The government had also relaxed the criteria of establishment cost for this particular subject. The government had also created new posts of 4,407 permanent sanitary workers.

The NMC has 4,407 aiwajdars. But the aiwajdars who completed 20 years of service in the NMC will get permanent jobs. Therefore, 2,206 will get the benefit immediately on completion of 20 years. The rest will be given the benefits whenever they attain 20 years in service.

While approving the plan, the government also imposed a condition that the NMC will not recruit anymore aiwajdars. Already, the NMC had started to give compensatory jobs to the kin of aiwajdars in case of their deaths.

The cash-strapped NMC is likely to incur a financial burden of Rs18 crore per annum if it gives permanent jobs to all aiwajdars. The number of posts of sanitary workers will increase to 8,346 in the NMC after permanent induction of all aiwajdars. The number of approved posts in the NMC will rise to 16,300.

The NMC had also transferred a few aiwajdars to the other departments like fire, administrative office and property tax.

Title: Reducing gap between TTD income and outgo should worry temple body
Content:
The TTD might have approved its highest-ever budgetary estimate of Rs 3,309.89 crore for the 2020-21 fiscal, but the sharp rise in salary payments in the last five years coupled with a decrease in its revenues from interest receipts from banks and a decline in its corpus investments is a matter of concern for the richest temple body in the country.

TTD is expecting an income of Rs 1,351 crore through hundi collections, which is its major source of revenue . However, a comparison between the hundi income and its major outgo, which mostly comprise employee wages, presents a dangerous picture for the temple administration which definitely needs to have a closer look at the salaries and other monetary benefits extended to its employees.

In the last five years (2016-17 to 2020-21), while TTD’s hundi revenues rose from Rs 1,010 crore to Rs 1,351 crore — a rise of Rs 341 crore — its employees’ salaries and other benefits, which stood at Rs 500 crore in 2016-17, has jumped to Rs 1,385 crore in the 2020-21 budget, which is a raise of Rs 885.09 crore. Interestingly, in addition to the Rs 1385.09 crore towards human resources payments, TTD has to allocate Rs 75 crore towards employees’ pension fund.

Now, while the temple’s hundi revenues rising only by Rs 341 crore, the human resources related payments has gone up sharply by Rs 885.09 crore, which is almost triple within a five-year span.

Another policy decision which cost the temple administration dear was not to park funds in private banks but put everything only in nationalized banks. This particular decision has resulted in a dip in its revenues through interest receipts from Rs 857.28 crore in 2019-20 to Rs 706.01 crore in 2020-21. This is another area of concern for the TTD which maintains that temple funds are safe only with nationalised banks and not with private banks, despite the stringent RBI guidelines in place today.

With all these financial constraints adding up to TTD’s woes, the temple administration has trimmed its corpus and other investments to Rs 105.98 crore for 2020-21, down from Rs 165.41 crore in 2019-20.

Title: ‘Anhad garje’, a fusion of Indo-Western music enthrals all
Content:
Chitnavis Centre and Vidarbha Gaurav Pratishthan organized an Indo-western fusion programme titled ‘Anhad Garj... Read More

Nagpur: Music lovers cherished their time listening to a fusion of Indo-Western music at a programme titled ‘ Anhad garje ’. The event, jointly organized by Chitnavis Centre and Vidarbha Gaurav Pratishthan, was staged at the Banyan Hall on Friday.

The unique concept of presenting Indo-Western music was put forth by various promising artistes of the city, who are national level awardees associated with the All India Radio.

The melodious tunes commenced with classical music and then moved to the western genre. The music was composed by Ram Khadse, who was on the tabla.

Nikhil Khadse won the hearts of the audience by melodiously playing the shehnai. Rishikesh Karmar’s performance was the highlight of the show. He amazed the audience by skilfully playing the dilruba.

Yashwant Humpiholi set the audiences’ feet tapping as he played the mrugadum. Kaustubh Tambuskar added his personal touch and turned the music magical by playing the keyboard.

Western music blended pleasingly with Indian classical with Chinmay Pittule on the drums. Rajdeep Ghagde complemented the beats by strumming the guitar.

The music part of the show was partially in solo and group form. The jugalbandi of the audience amazed the audience which responded with a round of applause.

The audience not only enjoyed the beats of tabla but also grooved to the beats of drums when western music was in motion.

The music was composed by Ram Khadse and the programme was conceptualized by Ravindra Durugkar.

Mitesh Lokhande, who was among the audience, said, “I feel privileged to have attended this event. The artistes were amazing and this programme was truly unique. I’m looking forward to many more programmes featuring these artists.”

Another music enthusiast, Amit Mehta, said, “I absolutely enjoyed the programme right from the start. All the instruments are wonderfully well-tuned. The composition of the music was noteworthy. I will definitely attend many more musical programmes like this one.”

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: Gadchiroli collector kick-starts financial awareness campaign in Maoist-affected district
Content:
Nagpur: Gadchiroli District collector Dipak Singla has formulated a policy to conduct a financial awareness campaign in the Maoist-affected tribal district. The move aims to take banking facilities to the masses, especially farmers, who have stayed away due to lack of knowledge.

Singla chaired a meeting of the district level coordination committee to review the preparedness of the district administration and modalities framed by them to implement the innovative project. The administration now aims to conduct such awareness camps at different places in the district on March 14 and 28 between 11am and 3pm.

Block developmental officers (BDO), tehsildars and bank managers participated in the district level meeting. It’s learnt that Singla also issued instructions to committees at the taluka level to engage in mobilizing maximum number of tribals, who are living in impoverished conditions, to attend the camps. The existing bank customers, too, would be invited to the camps to train them to use the facilities in a positive and benefiting manner. Awareness would be created regarding banking facilities, loans, government schemes and benefits for tribals residing in the interiors of the district.

It’s learnt that bankers and the district administration staffers exchanged their views and also discussed the possible hardships that may come their way. Singla, who promised to look into the issues, motivated the staffers and bank managers to take up the awareness camps in right earnest.

Title: At ‘peace’ march in Connaught Place, family of Delhi riot victims narrate ordeal
Content:
People gathered in large numbers at Jantar Mantar, holding the Tricolour

NEW DELHI: Even as residents of north-east Delhi are trying to pick up the pieces after the riots which left 42 dead amid widespread destruction, a “march against jihadi terrorism” was taken out at Connaught Place on Saturday.

BJP leader Kapil Mishra, who has been accused of making provocative statements before the riots broke out, was present along with families of some of the victims. He, however, didn’t shout any slogans or address the gathering during what was touted as a ‘peace march’ organised by NGO Delhi Peace Forum from Jantar Mantar to Parliament Street police station.

People had gathered at the march in large numbers, holding the tricolour, at Jantar Mantar and raised slogans of ‘Jai Shri Ram’ and ‘Bharat Mata ki Jai’.

Mishra had earlier posted a tweet asking people to join the protest. He later posted videos of the march, saying: “No matter how much falsehood you spread, people know the truth”.

Even as the Opposition and a section of civil society has been demanding an FIR against Mishra, the BJP leader has maintained that he did nothing wrong and had only demanded that the roads be cleared of anti-CAA protesters.

The organisers paid tributes to Ratan Lal of Delhi Police and Ankit Sharma of IB, who were killed during the violence.

One of the participants was Suresh Kumar, who said his brother Dinesh Kumar Khatik was shot when he had gone to see whether shops were open on February 25. “He was shot near the Shiv Vihar puliya where petrol bombs were also used. I found him at GTB Hospital where he was on ventilator support. The next day he died of his injuries. He is survived by two children, a one-year-old and a seven-year-old,” he said.

Alok Tiwari was shot in the head while he was returning home on Tuesday from a Karawal Nagar factory where he worked, said his brother-in-law Sumit. “His fault was that he had stopped to see whether he could buy fruits for children. My sister got to know that he had been attacked and with the help of neighbours he was taken to hospital where he died of his injuries the next day. “He leaves behind a four-year-old son and a nine-year-old daughter,” he said.

Title: ‘Time Muslims mingled with fellow countrymen’
Content:
English professor Mohammed Ayyub Khan

Mohammed Ayub Khan is an English professor at the Women’s College of Arts and Commerce. He has been a teacher in more ways than one. He has dedicated his life towards ‘Mission Education for Slums’.

Khan has been working with Jamaat-e-Islami Hind (JIH) for the past 12 years. As an office bearer of the organization, Khan has been attempting to integrate the larger part of the Muslim community into the mainstream. With the message of the Quran, Khan is also putting in efforts to initiate an interaction with other communities.

In an interview with TOI, he talks about the ‘We the Citizens’ concept which is now gaining a lot of ground due to the prevailing situation in the country.

Excerpts...

Q. Why have Muslims remained aloof from society for so long?

A. You can’t say that more or less all Muslims have been aloof from the society. Having said that, there is a section which was not enlightened enough to understand the social engineering of the Holy Quran. The Quran encourages every Muslim to develop peaceful, amicable and compassionate relations with other communities. Moreover, it persuades them to serve all communities without any inhibitions. The Holy Quran is the divine message of the omnipotent, the omnipresent and the omniscient Allah (SWT), who loves everyone on this planet and the scripture is the message for the entire humanity.

Q. Do you agree that this section has now realized its shortcomings in terms of not interacting with other communities?

A. With the advent of divide and rule politics, they have realized that it’s high time they mingled with their fellow countrymen. Due to vested interest, these so-called politicians have misused the communication gap by spreading many misconceptions about other communities.

Q. What are the initiatives being taken and since how long?

A. We reach out to our fellow countrymen in various ways. We invite them on Eid. We organize Eid Milan programmes even at temples. We share the dais with them and interact with them on a regular basis. We conduct medical camps for our fellow countrymen. We also run coaching centres where socially marginalized students are taught English and Maths. For women, we have a skill-based training programme. The JIH has been conducting these activities for almost 50 years. In Nagpur district alone, we have eight units which are backed by a workforce of 110 dedicated members and 1,000 associates. We have a big team at the national level. Our projects like social service, women’s wing, education department and movement for peace and justice are meant for people of all communities.

Q. In what way will creating awareness about other communities help?

A. The main mission is to create peace and communal harmony. Ultimately, it will lead to the country’s progress. For example, we want to inform the Muslim masses about the correct history of the Marathas. Warrior king Shivaji was never hostile to Muslims. His commanders, Ibrahim Gardi and Siddhilal, personal secretary Bande Ali and counsel Hyder Ali were all Muslims. Madari Mehtar was his very loyal servant who risked his life to free Shivaji from the Agra Fort. In addition to this, apart from Ramdas, Baba Yakub Shah was Shivaji’s spiritual guru. We are creating awareness among Muslims that Shivaji Maharaj was the only Hindu king who issued a government resolution which stated that the Holy Quran should not be dishonoured. Over 600 Pathans served in Shivaji’s army.

Q. How is ‘We the People’ gaining momentum?

A. Our community has now realized that it’s high time we researched real history to bridge the gap with other communities. JIH has been running four educational guidance centres for slum dwellers in Zingabai Takli, Petasur and Godavari. Free English and Marathi classes for all have been running at the centres since five years. We want to root out all misconceptions about Islam. The lord has sent a divine message for the entire human race. It is the only scripture which motivates the reader to reason and meditate on the signs of the lord before believing in Him.

Q. Were Muslims reluctant to sing the National Anthem , hold the Tricolour and chant Bharat zindabad?

A. Never. Since childhood we have been taught to sing the anthem, respect the tricolour and say Bharat zindabad. But people of other communities have been misinformed by vested interest. There should be no doubt in anybody’s mind regarding our commitment to patriotism. To prove this point, even madrasas, which are run by religious groups, have started hoisting the tricolour on Independence Day and Republic Day as well.

Q. How did Muslim women come to the forefront now, compared to the earlier times when they were sidelined?

A. Women are doing national service with the dignity and grace of Islam. JIH’s women’s wings became operational 70 years ago. The Quran has given the best status to women which makes men lower their gaze and not stare at women or stalk them. A woman is given respect of the highest order. She also has the freedom to pursue education, start a business or go shopping. You can find many examples in the history of India.

Q. Will women get entry into mosques ?

A. Women were never barred from entering mosques. They were unable to go for prayers five times a day due to personal reasons. For Ramzan and Juma, special arrangements are made for women to offer prayers.

Title: Kolkata: Majerhat bridge looks at July completion
Content: KOLKATA: With the Commissioner of Railway Safety (CRS) nod, the new Majerhat bridge could be commissioned by July this year.The state public works department (PWD), implementing the Majerhat bridge reconstruction project, had set a deadline of five months from the date of the CRS approval. It is now racing against time to meet the July 2020 deadline. The Majerhat structure will be a road overbridge (ROB).A span of the ROB, that comes within the ambit of Eastern Railway (ER), collapsed on September 4, 2018. The new bridge, being built since January last year, has already missed its September 27 and December 31, 2019 deadlines. The Bengal government has held the railways responsible for the delay. On November 25 last year, CM Mamata Banerjee had written to railway minister Piyush Goyal, urging him to intervene in the matter to expedite the construction of the superstructure and in getting the CRS sanction. On Friday, she broached the issue with Union home minister Amit Shah as well. Hours later, Md Latief Khan, CRS, eastern circle, Kolkata, wrote to the general manger of Eastern Railway (ER) in charge of the ROB, that “sanction is accorded”. ER forwarded the letter to the PWD soon after.“The CRS wants that a quality assurance plan be rigidly implemented and any deviations brought to the notice of the approving authority. This means the conditions laid down by the CRS must be strictly adhered to. So, it will take at least five months to complete the bridge,” a state official said.The CRS, when it had turned down the approval in a letter to the general manager, ER, had asked PWD to adhere to 31 stipulations. In its approval letter on Friday, the number of stipulations were reduced to 22. Some important aspects — like using the right bearings and wind tunnel test — remain to be addressed.As things stand now, PWD has written to ER that the old ROB’s piers will be used as a temporary launching pad for building the superstructure. PWD is using temporary bearings. Permanent ones, as per the specifications of the CRS, will be installed once the superstructure is launched.Since November, PWD had been lobbying for the CRS nod to start building the superstructure. The superstructure will be a continuous girder system, built using high-capacity cranes. “We have asked ER for a railway block. As soon as we get it, the superstructure launching work will start,” a state official said.After the launch, there is the very complex job of fixing the pylons. Pylon construction has started and should end by March 10, engineers said. This will be followed by the deck construction. It will be a time-consuming phase because the casting must be done as per specifications of the Indian Road Congress (IRC).

Title: Complete bio-digester in time: AAI to waste corp
Content:
Panaji: The Airports Authority of India (AAI) on Friday informed Goa Waste Management Corporation (GWMC) that Rs 14.96 crore has been sanctioned under the Corporate Social Responsibility ( CSR ) by the AAI board to fund a 10-tonne bio-digester plant in the vicinity of Chicalim .

In a letter to GWMC managing director Levinson Martins, AAI’s general manager for CSR O P Chugh said that as per AAI’s CSR policy, Goa airport director is the implementing and monitoring officer for the project.

The bio-digester plant will consist of two reinforced concrete cement tanks which will each be able to treat 5 tonne wet waste per day. Around 3,000 sqm of land has been demarcated for waste management purpose.

As part of the project, four materials recovery facility (MRF) sheds will be set up along with a baling machine, forklifts and dustbins to help curb the garbage menace around Goa International Airport at Dabolim.

“Accordingly, action for signing of memorandum of agreement, release of payments, progress monitoring and collection of completion certificates, utilisation certificates may please be carried out at your end. Itis also requested to get this project implemented and completed as per the timelines,” said Chugh.

GWMC issued an expression of interest on February 19 seeking qualified agencies to setup and operate the bio-digestor plant for a five year period.

The biodigester plant will treat garbage generated from Chicalim panchayat, Chicolna - Bogmalo panchayat, Sancoale panchayat, part of Hollant and from AAI , and will help generate electricity.

AAI took the decision to sanction the funds at the Corporate Social Responsibility Committee meeting held on January 6.

Title: Two foreigners held for overstaying in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Two Ugandan nationals were arrested on Friday for overstaying in the city without valid documents.

The Airport police identified the women as Nakijoba Euie (28) and Nadagire Yudaya Tasha (24). The duo were arrested following a special drive to identify those overstaying after the expiry of their visas.

“We had received a tip-off about three Ugandan nationals, a man and two women, overstaying without valid travel documents in a house in Kalwad Vasthi of Lohegaon. While the man had valid documents, the women failed furnish them,” assistant inspector Hanmant Giri of the Airport police said.

“The duo were arrested under the relevant sections of the Foreigners Act, 1946. Probe revealed that business visas of Euie and Tasha had expired in 2016 and 2018, respectively,” he added.

Title: Delhi: Life returning to normal with shops open and traffic stalling
Content:
Security personnel patrol on a street following clashes at Mustafabad in northeast Delhi

NEW DELHI: Life in violence-affected areas of northeast Delhi limped back to normalcy on Saturday with several shops and establishments resuming their businesses and people coming back to work. Locals came out of their homes to buy groceries, fruits and other items of daily needs.

After several days of the stretch remaining deserted, traffic jam was reported on the main road leading to Maujpur, Kardampur and Yamuna Vihar.

Meanwhile, police and paramilitary personnel maintained strict vigil in the northeast Delhi areas. They were deputed at every nook and corner to avoid any confrontation. Minority commission teams visited Maujpur and Jafrabad.

Jahangir Ali, resident of Moonga Nagar in Chand Bagh, accompanied his daughter, Iqra, who was returning from her school in Tis Hazari. “I didn’t let her go to school for six days because the situation was not suitable. Life is more important than anything else. On Saturday I decided to accompany her. I pray for things to get normal as riots have never served anyone’s purpose,” said Ali, with worry writ large on his face.

Sultan Singh, another resident of Chand Bagh, opened his confectionery shop for the first time after Monday. “All hell had broken loose in the area during the violence. People were mindlessly pelting stones at each other. Fearing my shop also getting targeted, I had decided to down the shutters,” said Singh.

In Mustafabad also, things are back to normal. Anshul Jain, running a general store in Mustafabad area, cannot stop thanking god for saving his shop from rioters. “Like others, I had also locked my shop on Sunday evening. The rioters burnt all shops in this lane, but failed to unlock my shop so it was saved from getting burnt. On Saturday, I decided to re-open it after assessing the situation in the area,” said Jain.

A team from SDM office reached Shiv Vihar, Kardampuri and other areas for property damage assessment. “We are also distributing forms to the affected people so that instant relief of Rs 25,000 can be given,” said an official.

Delhi government had earlier promised cash incentive to people who lost their houses in violence.

At Kardampuri, government staff were found approaching people in internal lanes to know their requirement for food and water.

Compared with Friday, the areas looked much cleaner. “For past six days, garbage was not being lifted as sanitation staff were not visiting the areas out of fear. On Saturday, debris and other materials were removed from the main road and garbage was lifted at some colonies. However, the situation in internal lanes is still bad,” claimed Kardampuri resident Shaukat Ali.

A few minor incidents have, however, come to fore and police are probing them. In Kardampuri, one Naeem alleged that he was thrashed on Friday night while he was returning from his factory.

(With inputs from Mohammad Ibrar, Sakshi Chand)

Title: Delhi: Woman got past rioters, rescued 40 trapped relatives via rooftops
Content:
I knew that the mob would not see us if we moved from terrace to terrace, says Mushtari Khatoon

NEW DELHI: Mushtari Khatoon mostly stays at home, doing stitching jobs to supplement her husband’s income. The 42-year-old doesn’t often venture out.

On Tuesday (February 25), when her family members needed help, Mushtari walked a kilometre through roads that had fallen to the mobs, managed to dodge stones and petrol bombs, and got past rioting groups to get to trapped members of her extended family in Khajuri Khas . There were 40 of them and Mushtari managed to get everyone out safely, showing great presence of mind to move the group along terraces of houses till they reached a police team that gave them safe passage.

In Chandu Nagar , where she and her husband, Hakeem, live, Mushtari has since become a household name. Neighbours call her “a hero”.

“I knew if someone didn’t go to them, they would lose their lives,” Mushatri said on Saturday, back home, relieved that her young nieces and nephews are unhurt. The worst clashes of the riots in north-east Delhi were reported on Monday and Tuesday and one of the most-affected areas was Khajuri Khas, where arsonists have left many houses burnt beyond recognition.

“I waited for the whole of Monday. On Tuesday, I left early in the morning,” said Mushtari. Khajuri Khas is on the main Karawal road — where mobs had gathered — from Chandu Nagar.

When she reached the house where her relatives were, Mushtari realised there was no way out through the streets. The mobs were everywhere, attacking each other and setting cars, bikes and houses on fire.

“We were trapped. The next four hours were tense because mobs were going berserk around us,” Mushtari said. While they waited, the family members coordinated to ensure everyone gathered at one place.

“When the mob grew closer, I asked them to jump from the terrace of one building to the other. The possibility of the mob seeing us was less if we moved along the terraces (the houses here are cheek by jowl and the terraces sometimes continuous). I had called people from our neighbourhood for help to get us out. The women who were with me were scared and someone had to guide them,” said Mushtari, who managed to hold her nerve through the escape till they met a police team, which gave them a passage across the main road so that they could reach Chandu Nagar. Along with police were over 100 people from Chandu Nagar who escorted Mushtari and the others back.

Mushtari saved eight families, all related, that day. Mohammad Minhaj , a nephew of Hakeem, was in that group. “The families have lived in Khajuri Khas for many years. The situation became tense on Sunday evening but we stayed back. Now, we are not sure if we will be able to go back there,” he said.

Mushtari said she wasn’t scared; all she was focused on getting her family members out. “We were getting no help despite our pleas. There were men with lathis and petrol bombs and police were nowhere to be seen for over a day. If I hadn’t take the decision, many lives would have been lost,” she said.

“There are so many children in our family, and most of them are girls. My wife insisted she wants to go and help them out. It is something to be proud of,” said Hakeem, who works as a labourer.

Title: Avian aviation: Flyers joined by two pigeons before take-off
Content:
Flyers try to shoo the bird out of the cabin

AHMEDABAD: Irked by pigeons annexing balconies? Now two were found in an aircraft flying from Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport in Ahmedabad! Passengers aboard the Jaipur-bound G8-702 flight were confronted by the bizarre sight of two pigeons in the aircraft as it was about to depart from SVPI airport on Friday evening.

Confirming the incident, the airline issued a statement stating, “Two pigeons found their way inside GoAir Ahmedabad Jaipur flight G8-702 while passengers were on-boarding.” The statement went on to say: “The crew immediately got the birds shooed away outside. The flight took off as per its scheduled time of 1700 hours.”

The menace of birds has been a worry for airline crews using SVPI airport. Ahead of the visit of US President Donald Trump to Ahmedabad, another flight suffered a bird-hit while taxiing for take-off.

The airline said that it has requested the airport authorities to get rid of the menace. Sources said that birds, monkeys, and stray dogs are frequently sneaking into the city airport.

SVPI airport director Manoj Gangal could not be reached for comment.

In 2019, 37 bird-hits were reported at SVPI airport and three have been recorded so far in 2020. SVPI airport authorities have taken several measures to keep the birds away, including the deployment of avian-chasers. Just ahead of the US president’s visit, the authorities had written to the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation to maintain cleanliness in areas surrounding the city airport.

Title: Hyd woman accused of child labour
Content:
Vijayawada: Nuzvid rural police are set to register a case against a Hyderabad-based private television channel employee for engaging two minor girls as domestic help in her house. A complaint has been filed against the woman by officials of Child Welfare Committee (CWC) of Krishna district, who have asked the police to investigate the matter and file a case under the Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986.

Child Welfare Committee chairman BVS Kumar said the two siblings, aged 12 years and 11 years respectively, were studying at a child care institute in a village under Nuzvid mandal of Krishna district. “Their mother took them to their village during the Sankranti holidays, but the girls did not return to the school even after the end of the vacation. The child care centre authorities tried to contact their mother and after failing to reach her, lodged a missing complaint with the Nuzvid rural police,” Kumar said.

The police traced the missing girls to Hyderabad and sent them back to the child care centre, who then informed the CWC. During their interaction with CWC officials, the girls said they were engaged for domestic work. Based on the siblings’ written statement, CWC directed Nuzvid rural cops to probe the matter and book the woman under the Child Labour Act. Nuzvid police station sub-inspector Ranjith Kumar said they will register a case against the TV channel staff after investigating the matter.

Title: Ahmedabad: Another killed by illegally dumped hot sand
Content:
TimesView The government should not wait for more innocent people to die to crackdown on this criminal dumping of hazardous materials in the city. These incidents raise concerns not only about citizens’ safety but is also reflective of inaction and sloth on the part of authorities, giving the impression that criminals can get away with taking away other people’s lives. This has to stop. PASA should be imposed on such criminals, a policy governing disposal of flyash should be framed, and a squad comprising officials of the police, GPCB and AMC, dedicated to detecting and monitoring of illegal waste dumping must be formed. What matters now is action.

AHMEDABAD: Thirty-five-year-old Parvati Sarkar on Friday night succumbed to burns suffered when she accidentally stepped into superhot sand illegally dumped by the roadside in Ganeshnagar. For one month, she battled for her life in LG Hospital. Her son 20-year-old son Raja is shocked and inconsolable. Parvati collected metal scrap from waste for a living, and is the second casualty of illegal dumping that continues around Ganeshnagar in the Pirana area.A multi-department special task force — with representatives of the police, Gujarat Pollution Control Board (GPCB) and the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) — was formed to identify the culprits. Except for a report on the nature of the substance that caused the death, there has been no arrest. A senior GPCB official admitted that the report confirms that there was 40 tonnes of superhot flyash and 100 metric tonnes of burning garbage underneath when Parvati stepped into a pit to find metal scrap. Several heaps of dumped flysash and sand can be seen in the area. Narol police inspector S A Gohil told TOI, “We registered a case of accidental death in Parvati’s case. We are yet to nab the culprits and have no pertinent CCTV footage as yet. We are now relying on informers.”The loss for the Sarkar family is massive. “I lost my mother. I did not go to work for a month because she was in pain and I was by her side. My father and my sister are yet to come to terms with the loss,” said Raja. Parvati had already lost one lung to an infection. Doctors knew that though she suffered only 23% third degree burns, her body would not be able to fight if an infection got severe.In July 2018, 52-year-old Salma Nizamuddin succumbed to 57% third degree burns suffered after the motorcycle she was pillion riding on slipped and she fell on to a heap of hot sand. The accident had taken place on June 22 that year. “Salma’s case is also unsolved. She was in LG Hospital for a month. Police and the GPCB are yet to identify the culprit and the illegal dumping continues,” says her husband Nizamuddin.Environmental activist Mahesh Pandya of Paryavaran Mitra says, “This is a clear case of human rights violation and not just an environmental pollution case. We have already lost two lives to such illegal dumping and this should not be tolerated any longer.”

Title: Citing HC order, Congress asks CM Pramod Sawant to sack Mauvin Godinho
Content:
Congress said that Mauvin Godinho and Kamla Prasad Yadav were involved in illegal construction within the airp... Read More

PANAJI: Congress on Saturday demanded that panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho and Chicalim deputy sarpanch Kamla Prasad Yadav , should be sacked from the cabinet and as member of Mormugao Planning and Development Authority ( MPDA ) respectively for violating construction norms around Goa International Airport .

Addressing the press, Congress media convener Trajano D’Mello urged chief minister Pramod Sawant to take action based on the high court of Bombay at Goa’s judgement regarding construction around the airport.

“The sacking of the panchayat minister is necessary, failing which I would caution the chief minister that Godinho has succeeded in using his position under more experienced chief ministers and managed to hoodwink them,” said D’Mello.

Congress said that Yadav is a “close aide of the notorious panchayat minister” and both were involved in illegal construction within the airport’s funnel zone.

“We demand that Yadav be immediately removed as member of MPDA as his conflict of interest with duty is a serious offence and being the deputy sarpanch he has knowledge of the law and still violates it with criminal intention,” D’Mello said.

D’Mello said that “interference of the minister of panchayat” prompted MPDA to pass a resolution on November 18, 2019 rejecting the Colour Coded Zoning Map prepared under the provisions of the Aircraft Act, 1994 Rules and Notification GSR 751(E).

“This has exposed the minister’s arrogance. He is paying scant respect to the judiciary when the writ petitions were heard. The motive was to try and abort judicial power,” said D’Mello.

Title: VHP, Bajrang Dal warn Thackeray govt of backlash on Muslim reservation
Content:
NAGPUR: In what could be termed as signs of troubles for chief minister Uddhav Thackeray-led Maha Vikas Agadi (MVA) government, the Vishwa Hindu Parishad ( VHP ) and Bajrang Dal on Saturday warned him against granting 5% reservation to Muslims as announced by minority affairs minister Nawab Malik.

Speaking at the joint convention of VHP and Bajrang Dal at Chitnis Park in Mahal, VHP national coordinator Surendra Jain in his speech, that was full of vitriolic attack, said they will fight against the government’s move from roads to judiciary.

“Their minister (Malik) said the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government would grant 5% reservation in education to Muslims. Next day, the Shiv Sena minister said no such decision was taken. We’ve already given them Pakistan and Bangladesh. Why do they need reservation? It wasn’t expected from Uddhav, who’s son of Hindu Hridaysamrat Balasaheb Thackeray . He has unexpectedly stooped to such a low level for the lust of power and in the process shattered the dreams of Shivaji Maharaj , his father and even Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar,” said Jain.

Further targeting Uddhav, Jain challenged him to remove all illegal Bangladeshi migrants from the state and VHP and Bajrang Dal would support him.

Flaying AIMIM’s ex-MLA Warris Pathan for his warning, Jain reminded him that the VHP and BD activists had thrashed his master (Asduddin Owaisi) in Hyderabad. “You threaten us with 15 crore numbers, but just think of the repercussions if we decided to reply. We will no longer tolerate such warnings. This is not the 1947 India, but a changed one after 1992, which is ready to give a befitting reply to any attack,” said Jain.

Supporting the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), he said that when the entire country was celebrating the enactment, those who were not in favour of India had resorted to riots, arson, burning of shops, buses and the police were also attacked. “The coordinated attacks took place when US President Donald Trump was in Delhi. In Shaheen Bagh, they took shelter behind women, who were paid money. This amount is coming from the neighbouring country. I don’t know why the Supreme Court is entertaining them by sending a panel to hold talks. There can’t be any talks with traitors and terrorists as they don’t have any religion or gender. Leave the situation to the police to tackle it,” said Jain.

Attacking the Tukde-Tukde and Khan Market gang along with the secular mafia, Jain said all of them were hell bent on destroying the country, which was rapidly progressing in all sectors.

“Currently, India is a fourth in terms of armed forces and will soon occupy the third position. Once a land of beggars is now the fifth economic power and fourth in space. On the other hand, China is suffering due to Coronavirus. When all countries failed to take their nationals out of China, it was India which had taken the lead,” said Jain.

Applauding prime minister Narendra Modi, the VHP’s senior member said miracles were happening ever since he took over. “Article 370 and 35 A was abrogated, triple talaq was abolished and now, the way has been cleared for the Ram temple. Ram Janmbhoomi was in fact an ‘Andolan’ that was under way since the last 500 years, where lakhs sacrificed their lives. Over 16 crore participated in this movement which is akin to the world’s biggest freedom struggle,” he said while calling all activists to visit Ayodhya.

Earlier, a big rally containing floats was organized as a show of strength. It started from Reshimbag and culminated at Chitnis Park in Mahal with hundreds of activists waiving saffron flags and shouting ‘Jai Shree Ram’ and ‘Har Har Mahadev’ slogans. Children from Bhumiputra Akhada with swords and sticks demonstrated traditional warfare skills used by Marathas.

The dignitaries, including Govind Shende, Devesh Mishra, Navin Jain, Rajesh Murkute, Hemant Jambhekar and Amol Andhare shared the dais.

Title: Peace my first priority: Delhi Police commissioner S N Shrivastava
Content:
Delhi Police special commissioner S N Shrivastava takes charge as the new police commissioner from outgoing to... Read More

NEW DELHI: IPS officer S N Shrivastava took over as Delhi Police commissioner on Saturday evening from Amulya Patnaik . Shrivastava is currently awaiting formal orders and will hold the police chief’s post as an additional charge apart from being the chief of law and order in Delhi.

“My priority is to restore peace in the national capital and ensure communal harmony,” the 1985-batch officer told reporters. He said they had taken many steps in the last few days but a lot was left to be done. He pointed out it the city has a tradition of people of every section and religion living together in harmony and helping each other in good as well as bad times.

Shrivasatava said Delhi Police has started a massive outreach programme and senior officers have been meeting with people in order to build confidence among them. “The area (north-east) will soon return to normal and I am committed to doing this,” he said. “To avoid such incidents in future, cases will be registered in crimes that were committed and we will try to arrest the accused involved, so that legal proceedings can be initiated at the earliest,” he added.

Shrivastava was serving in CRPF as special director general since 2015. After Delhi Police came under fire for being unable to quell the riots, he was handpicked by home minister Amit Shah and National Security Advisor Ajit Doval to control the situation which is now fast returning to normalcy.

Known to be an honest officer with a no-nonsense attitude, Shrivastava was the anti-terror chief in Delhi Police till 2015. He headed several departments before going on deputation to CRPF. It was during his tenure that the special cell wiped out the Indian Mujahideen and Lashkar-e-Toiba network in the capital. Brought to the special cell in the aftermath of the high court blasts in 2011, he played a crucial role in strengthening the cell. While preventing any terror attack in the capital for over three years, the cell went on to arrest 37 terrorists, including 22 from IM and seven from LeT.

Title: After Naidu stopped at airport, TDP meets guv
Content:
Vijayawada: After moving the high court over police detaining former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu at Visakhapatnam airport, the TDP took up the issue with governor Biswa Bhushan Harichandan on Saturday. A delegation of TDP functionaries submitted a memorandum to the governor alleging that the state government used brute force to suppress rightful dissent.

The delegation, led by former ministers Nakka Anand Babu, Alapati Rajendra Prasad, MLCs Ashok Babu, Bachula Arjunudu, former MLAs Tenali Sravan Kumar and Bode Prasad among others met the governor. They accused YSRC of being paranoid and resorting to revenge.

They alleged that if such callous acts of the government go unhindered, there would be anarchy. The police are pursuing their personal agenda by conniving with the ruling party, the TDP said in a statement after meeting the governor.

The TDP leaders also told the governor that the Visakhapatnam incident was not a lone example of the government’s attempt to stifle the voice of dissent. They alleged that in the past few months, police have denied the opposition parties their right of expression in the guise of imposing prohibitory orders. In Visakhapatnam, the police allowed the YSRC cadre to disrupt the programme of Naidu. Instead of controlling the mob, they arrested Naidu by serving him 151 CrPC notice, they alleged.

The TDP delegation also expressed concerns about the safety of Naidu in the representation submitted to the governor. They have raised the issue of moving Naidu from the assembly in a regular vehicle instead of a bullet-proof vehicle on the night of January 20. Although Naidu is under Z+ security cover, the state government often puts him in dangerous situation and compromises his security, they alleged. tnn

Title: No bail for driver who didn’t stop for traffic cop
Content:
Ahmedabad: A city sessions court refused to grant protection against possible arrest to one Faisal Malik, who allegedly did not stop his car on a traffic policeman’s instruction and drove the vehicle away in a rash manner.

The alleged incident took place on February 14 on Gujarat University Road. Malik was asked to stop because he was not using the seatbelt. He did not stop and the traffic constable chased the car to LD Engineering College, where the car had to stop. The constable told Malik to move the to the side of the road but the driver tried to drive away. The constable grabbed hold of the car’s wipers and lay on the bonnet, but fell down near a speed breaker.

Malik was charged with rash driving and attempt to commit culpable homicide under Section 308 of IPC the apart from violations of the Motor Vehicles Act. In his anticipatory bail plea, Malik said that he insisted on CCTV footage because the case against him was false.

After hearing the case, the court said that if traffic police ask a driver to stop vehicle, it is his duty to follow instructions.

Title: Riot probe: Congress seeks SC supervision
Content:
AICC spokesman Anand Sharma

NEW DELHI: Alleging that Delhi Police was lodging false cases against bonafide protesters after letting the rioters to burn the capital for four days, Congress Saturday urged the Supreme Court to supervise riots cases even as it underlined that the entire world was watching the happenings in India.

AICC spokesman Anand Sharma said that protesters were being booked for attempt to murder for merely saying that they will not leave the protest site even if they had to die with cases even lodged against an organisation called “united against hate”. He said the police action mirrors the earlier lodging of sedition cases against protesters who flouted Section 144. In contrast, he said BJP leaders who gave incendiary speeches had not yet been booked for hate speeches.

“We urge the Supreme Court to take cognisance of all these cases. Let the SC appoint an amicus curiae, let them scrutinise all such cases which are being registered. People are being framed and put in jails,” Sharma said.

“The SC is the custodian of the Constitution. The delays don’t help. The entire world is watching this country. It is time the SC intervened effectively to protect the rights of citizens guaranteed by the Indian Constitution,” he added.

Sharma alleged the police “which allowed Delhi to burn for four days” was carrying out a “one-sided” investigation. “As per the cases registered, if made by BJP leaders, they are not hate speeches, and protests by citizens are a threat to the society,” he said.

Title: Coop polls: TRS bags chairman, vice-chief posts
Content:
Hyderabad: TRS candidates bagged chairman and vice-chairman posts of District Cooperative Central Bank (DCCB) and District Cooperative Marketing Society (DCMS), for which elections were held on Saturday.

In all the nine districts, the elections were unanimous as TRS enjoyed a clear majority. Telangana State Cooperative Bank (TSCOB) chairman Konduri Ravinder Rao was elected chairman of Karimnagar DCCB, while Yellala Srikanth Reddy bagged DCMS chairman post. Pingili Ramesh and Fakruddin were elected vice-chairmen of DCCB and DCMS respectively.

In Khammam, K Naga Bushaiah was elected DCCB chairman and Seshagiri Rao as DCMS chairman. Nizam Pasha bagged DCCB chairman post and Prabhakar Reddy became DCMS chairman of Mahbubnagar. Namdev Kamble as DCCB chairman and T Lingaiah as DCMS chairman of Adilabad, Pocharam Bhaskar Reddy as DCCB chairman and N Mohan as DCMS chairman of Nizamabad.

In Nizamabad, two TRS leaders G Ganga Reddy and Srinivas Goud, who aspired for chairman posts of DCCB and DCCB expressed displeasure as their names were not considered.

Title: Sternest test yet: School in race to be ready for exams
Content:
New Delhi: As rioters wreaked havoc in northeast Delhi, even schools were not spared. With life limping back to normal now, there are signs of activity there too. DRP Convent School in Mustafabad, for one, has started rebuilding on a war-footing to host students for the upcoming exams. On Sunday, teachers joined the management in its effort to restore the school to its original state. That won’t be easy though, with several floors damaged and the furniture charred.

Sandeep Verma, a mathematics teacher, lent a helping hand to the carpenters. Others assisted with painting the gates and the walls. Verma said the school community would ensure that the exams, which were scheduled to start from March 13, were not postponed. “We have another branch in Johripur , but we are committed to holding the exams here. Everyone will come together for this purpose,” he said. The school, located along the main Brijpuri Road, caters to some 1,200 students who come from a mix of communities from Shiv Vihar as well as Mustafabad.

Most of the rooms on the ground floor have been reduced to ashes. Books have gone too. Caretaker Roop Singh said the school was vandalised over two days by a mob of over 1,000 people. Sunil Sharma, another teacher, said: “We will give our best shot to starting the exams on time —even if that means camping here.”

Having remained holed up in their homes for several days due to the imposition of Section 144, several parents, too, arrived at the school to not only check its condition but also help out. Teena Yadav, whose son is an LKG student, said the children were scared. “It has been a week since they last came to school. They want to go back and meet their friends,” she said. Others say that while it won’t be easy for them to send their wards to school, they have no other option. Lalita Devi said she didn’t want her two kids to lose out on a year after studying so hard.

Title: ‘Understanding’ on cards between Cong, MGP, says Chodankar
Content:
Panaji: Congress has decided to shun a formal alliance with MGP and other political parties for the zilla panchayat ( ZP ) elections . They said the party will have an “understanding” with other like-minded parties which want to take on BJP.

State Congress president Girish Chodankar said the party has already started preliminary seat sharing discussions with MGP as well as some independent MLAs.

“Where MGP feels they are strong, we will support them and where we feel we are strong, they will support us,” Chodankar said.

Congress also demanded the resignations of chief minister Pramod Sawant and Union minister of state for defence and AYUSH Shripad Naik, accusing both of serving Karnataka’s interests, instead of Goa’s, in the tri-state Mhadei water sharing dispute.

Chodankar was speaking before inducting Mandrem sarpanch Serafina Fernandes, former sarpanch Mahesh Konadekar, pancha Priya Konadekar and ex-pancha Domingo Fernandes into the party .

Interestingly, Konadekar, along with the others, had strongly backed and worked for BJP MLA Dayanand Sopte in the 2019 byelection.

Title: Delhi: Amulya Patnaik didn’t lead from front, his image makeover for the force was non-starter
Content:
Amulya Patnaik

NEW DELHI: It was December 15, 2019. Violence had erupted in southeast Delhi’s New Friends Colony around 3.30pm with rioters setting buses on fire and pelting stones at policemen. Even as an area of the city burnt, police commissioner Amulya Patnaik was in Dwarka, cutting the ribbon at the inauguration ceremony of a public facilitation desk. This pretty much sums up Patnaik’s tenure as police chief — indifferent.

After then police chief Alok Verma was posted as director, CBI, in January 2017, 1984 batch officers Dharmendra Kumar and Deepak Mishra were the front-runners for the post of police commissioner, being the seniormost officers of the cadre. Taking them and the force by surprise, Patnaik managed to beat them to the chair.

Patnaik, who always preferred the backseat in his career, had his own plans for the force. One of the first things he did after taking charge was to ask women cops to shed their uniform, wear colourful sarees and sit at a desk at the entrance of police stations. Though it was apparently aimed at an “image makeover” wherein people were to be greeted with a smile upon entering a police station and not by frowning, old duty officers, many in the department — particularly senior women cops — criticised the move as ‘sexist’.

As far as decisions regarding welfare of the force is concerned, Patnaik’s intentions, people close to him say, were good. “It was just that he did not have a good plan or planners in place. Look at his supposed revamp of the crime branch..While he meant to do good, he ended up making teams with nomenclature like STARS & IGIS. He wanted to have a reformed cyber cell but ended up getting embroiled in inter-departmental politics and sidelining able people. The result was visible in their performance,” said a senior cop.

While Patnaik struggled to prove his mettle by working on the image of the force, law and order began to take a beating. His first big challenge was the major violence which broke out at Ramjas College in May 2017. Neither he, nor his deputy, chief of law and order, visited the spot. The college, meanwhile, turned into a battlefield, leaving dozens, including journalists, injured.

Throughout his tenure, Patnaik was seldom seen at any law and order situation. Those who have worked with him say he had individuals, and never a team of officers, in his close circle. “More than IPS officers, he trusted a few DANIPS cadre officers,” said another officer. For about a year, 1990-batch IPS officer R P Upadhyay was Patnaik’s troubleshooter as he took control of law and order.

After the Ramjas violence, two major challenges thrown at him were the farmers’ agitation at NH-24 and Vishwa Hindu Parishad’s rally at Ramlila Maidan. Thanks to Upadhyay and joint commissioners on the ground, Patnaik sailed through unscathed.

“Under Patnaik, police functioning focused on inauguration of initiatives, applications, buildings and cultural programmes. The core concepts of policing i.e. investigation, detection and prevention of crime were never given due importance. It was always done as a damage control measure,” said another top officer, who is currently serving out of Delhi.

The real test for Patnaik began in 2019, when he started losing his troubleshooters who got posted out of Delhi. Brazen shooting incidents and gang wars were staged in the city. While the police appeared helpless in controlling the organized gangs, the street crime situation hit rock bottom.

The last round of tremors began in November last year. In the aftermath of the Tis Hazari violence, a large section of force revolted and staged a protest demanding that the police chief should stand up for them. This unprecedented event was seen as a result of a build-up of a series of incidents where Patnaik did not side with the force.

As the anti-CAA protests broke out, the police came under fire in their conduct at Jamia and JNU. His tenure would have come to an end on January 31 but he was given a month’s extension in the wake of elections. The north-east Delhi riots proved to be the last nail in his coffin. As he hangs up his boot after three long years, his successor has his work cut out.

Title: CBSE cracks whip as schools violate board exam norms
Content: NEW DELHI: Cracking down on lax compliance of examination guidelines , the Central Board of Secondary Education has issued notices to over 200 schools that are part of the 5,300 examination centres for the classes X and XII board exams currently under way. After violations were detected through the board's confidential material tracking monitoring (CMTM) mobile application, CBSE issued 1,242 notices, each carrying a fine of Rs 50,000, to the schools.Anurag Tripathi, secretary, CBSE, disclosed that the majority of the notices were issued during the first 10 days of the examinations, which started on February 15, though none of the cases involved tampering of question papers. The violations, he said, were related to timelines associated with the exam process, handling of confidential materials and delegation of scheduled responsibilities.It is for the first time that CBSE is taking a disciplinary step of this sort and imposing financial penalties. The schools facing action include Kendriya Vidyalayas, Navodaya Vidyalayas and government and private schools. The notices were sent not only to the school principals, but also the school education departments in the states concerned, school managements and official authorised to enforce compliance. The schools have been cautioned that repeat violation could attract a fine of up to Rs 5 lakh and even disaffiliation.“Following this, 99% of the schools are complying with the guidelines,” said Tripathi. “CBSE is cracking the whip not to harass a school, but to ensure safety of the students, preserve the sanctity of the exam process, sustain the trust of the people and offer a full-proof examination. If the schools respond to the notices with genuine reasons, for instance that internet access was not available, then the fines will be waived.”According to a senior CBSE official, the board is enforcing a “zero-tolerance policy” on any breach of the examination guidelines for 2020 and affiliation bylaws. For the safe collection and delivery of exam materials such as question papers, the guidelines require photo tagging of the custodian and centre superintendent with the image of the material meant for that particular centre. The superintendents, who are generally school principals, have also been instructed to be personally involved in the handling of the confidential materials and not to delegate their responsibilities to others. “If emergency cases require the superintendents to delegate work to others, they have to take written permission from CBSE regional offices,” said Tripathi.Over 5,000 centre superintendents were directed to personally use the CMTM app at each step of the exam process. The app captures images, time and location of activities like receiving of sensitive materials, opening of question paper packets and completion of the exam. Timelines were given for each part of the process.According to sources in the board, sensitive exam centres were identified, and principals of other institutions were deputed as superintendents at such centres. CBSE also nominated external observers at the centres.

Title: Swearing-in of Simhachalam trust board postponed
Content:
Simhachalam temple in Visakhapatnam

Visakhapatnam: The swearing-in ceremony of Simhachalam Trust Board , which was supposed to take place on Sunday, has been postponed. The postponement of the event has led to discussions and speculations on social media. Some of these comments made on social media have even questioned the legitimacy of some of the nominees.

However, sources in the endowments department said that this is only a temporary delay and that there would be no changes made to the list of nominated members.

In a government order issued on February 20, the state government appointed 16 members to the Simhachalam Trust Board. Constituted after a gap of 15 years, the nominations reportedly raised many eyebrows. Although hereditary trustee P Ashok Gajapathi Raju who became the chairman of the board had welcomed the move.

Speculations were rife on social media about the merit and eligibility of sone of the nominated members. However, the endowments department is tight-lipped about whether it is those speculations on social media that led to the postponement of the swearing-in ceremony.

Sources are of the opinion that disagreement over the appointed members might be responsible for the delay. According to them, people from BJP, TDP and even some members of YSRC are unhappy with the list of nominated candidates. Some changes to the list could be in the offing, they said.

Title: AJAC to intensify agitation
Content:
Vijayawada: Amaravati Parirakshana Joint Action Committee (JAC) has decided to intensify agitations against the proposed three capital Bill by spreading its programmes to other districts. The JAC held a round table meet here on Saturday with representatives of all political parties. The round table has passed some resolutions about the future course of action.

The resolution adopted by the JAC with the consent of all political parties except the ruling YSRC, includes spreading of the the movement to all 13 districts to garner support for continuation of Amaravati as single capital for the state.

The JAC has also adopted a resolution demanding the state government to pay compensation to the farmers who died during the agitations for Amaravati. The JAC is set to conduct programmes in Hyderabad and has decided to send a delegation to Delhi to meet Union ministers and other political parties at national level.

It has demanded that the government withdraw all cases lodged against farmers, especially women, in the capital region. The police should stop surveillance by drones. The SC/ST Act is also being misused against the farmers in the capital region and the police should refrain from booking cases.

As part of the continuing agitations, the JAC will conduct a cycle rally in Vijayawada on Sunday. To garner support from all sections, a doctors’ meet is also scheduled to be held in Vijayawada. CPI national secretary Narayana, CPM state secretary P Madhu, Varla Ramaiah from TDP, Vangaveeti Radha, Tulasi Reddy from Congress and Potina Mahesh from Jana Sena attended the round table meet. tnn

Title: Lift schemes: Irrigation department, discoms in ‘power’ struggle
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Telangana power distribution companies (discoms) and the irrigation department are at loggerheads with each other over power requirement for lift irrigation schemes. So much so, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao had to step in to resolve the differences, highly-placed sources said.

Owing to the differences on power indents, the discoms have even deferred the date of filings of annual aggregate requirement (ARR) to the Telangana State Electricity Regulatory Commission (TSERC).

The Telangana State Southern Power Distribution Company Ltd and the Telangana State Northern Power Distribution Company Ltd were supposed to file ARRs to TSERC on Saturday, but sought a month’s time to file ARRs as the lift irrigation scheme indents were not finalised. With the budget session beginning on March 6, the delay looks inevitable. Sources said the discoms and the irrigation wing were also warring over the per unit cost at which power need to be supplied.

“The irrigation department has submitted a proposal that it requires 5,290 MW a day to run the lift irrigation schemes such as Kaleshwaram, Devadula, Sitarama, Palamuru-Rangareddy and the existing schemes like Kalwakurthy, Nettampadu, Bheema and Alimineti Madhava Reddy. But, the energy department assesses that the irrigation schemes will need only 3,000-3,200 MW going by the previous consumption,” a senior official of TSTransco said.

Last year too, the irrigation department had placed an indent for 4,000 MW, but only 2,100 MW was granted. “The Yellampally project under Kaleshwaram was filled following rains in Maharashtra and Chhattisgarh and pumps were not fully operated,” officials said.

Irrigation experts say that projected figures are submitted to the discoms to get them ready for providing power. “If all pumps under Kaleshwaram project are operated, the single project itself will need about 5,000 MW. Similarly, Palamuru Rangareddy project (phase I) will require 2,000 MW and Sitarama 650 MW. Another 1,500 MW will be needed for existing lift schemes . Since all the pumps are not operated at a time, the demand comes down,” a chief engineer of irrigation department said.

Meanwhile, the irrigation department is planning to procure power under open access method where it would get electricity at a cheaper rate. While the discoms have been charging Rs 4.80 per unit, the charges will come down to Rs 2.30 in the new method.

Title: Delhi: BSF steps forward to help jawan rebuild his house
Content:
BSF DIG Pushpendra Singh Rathore visited Anees’ house and assured his parents of all possible help from the pa... Read More

NEW DELHI: Border Security Force (BSF) will help its jawan, Mohammad Anees, rebuild his house in Khajuri Khas which was burnt during the riots that engulfed northeast Delhi recently. On Saturday, BSF DIG Pushpendra Singh Rathore visited Anees’ house and assured his parents of all possible help from the paramilitary force. BSF engineers, who will assess the extent of the damage, accompanied him.
