It is estimated that exports of IT special economic zones (SEZs) in Telangana is worth Rs 70,000 crore.

The growth rate recorded by Visakhapatnam SEZ, consisting of SEZs of all merchandise and services in Telangana, AP and Chhattisgarh, is 37% — which is highest in the country. VSEZ has already overtaken SEZs in Kolkata, Chennai, Kochi and Mumbai. In what could gladden the industry experts, the SEZ authorities have scotched rumours that IT units were moving out of AP. “In fact, Telangana has shown the way ahead with some of the ITES units from Bengaluru shifting to Hyderabad,” the authorities said.

Telangana has 33 SEZs, AP has 21 and Chhattisgarh has one SEZ.

VSEZ development commissioner A Ram Mohan Reddy told STOI that they achieved the highest growth rate despite the economic recession. “When compared to Rs 63,924 crore exports in the last financial year, our overall exports of Rs 89,748 crore till February 27 this financial year tells you the story,” he said.

Ram Mohan ruled out any unit from Andhra, Telangana and Chhattisgarh moving out of SEZs. “We do not know about other SEZs. But, there is no migration of units from AP to Telangana. In the last 10 months, we have 86 new units making an entry. They are investing Rs 7,935 crore in the next five years in three states,” he said.

Telangana has 292 units currently. “Hyderabad is adding four units every month. On February 19, approval for 10 units was accorded by VSEZ Hyderabad sub-office,” he said. The units are coming up in private SEZs like Phoenix Infocity Private Ltd, Divija Commercial Properties, BSR Builders, Sundew Properties, Laxmi Infobahn Private Limited and NSL.

Title: Waste dumping at corpn’s yard to delay bio-mining
Content:
Trichy: Waste is still being dumped at Trichy City Corporation’s dump yard at Ariyamangalam, where the bio-mining process to reclaim the land is under way. According to people involved in the land reclamation project, this is delaying the bio-mining process. They have urged the civic body to take steps to prevent waste from entering the dump yard to avoid the delay in the reclamation of the land.

The scientific land reclamation process at the 47.70-acre dump yard has been initiated under the smart cities mission at an estimated cost of Rs 49 crore. Segregation and recycling of waste, which accounts to 7-11 lakh cubic metres, is being done using machinery. But, fresh batch of waste from the city is still ferried to the yard, adding to the mounds of waste there. “Every fresh set of waste entering the dump yard is adding to our burden. We have stabilized the garbage mounds and started recycling a portion, but fresh waste dumping continues in other portions,” a source involved in the bio-mining project said. Fresh addition of waste to the existing mounds means that the agency, which has been engaged to undertake the work, will have to spend more time and resources in stabilizing, processing and recycling waste.

Corporation sources acknowledged that new batch of waste is entering the dump yard as they have no other choice. Around 50 MT of waste is being ferried to the yard, sources said. As a solution to prevent this, a proposal to set up an alternative temporary dump site was mooted. However, the civic body seems to be reluctant in implementing the proposal. “We have restricted the quantity of waste entering the dump yard. Further, new decentralized compost centres are planned in the city. Soon, waste dumping in Ariyamangalam yard will be completely stopped,” a corporation official said.

Title: Kolkata: Resale property owners have to pay limited tax dues
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Owners of apartments purchased through resale will no longer have to cough up property tax dues that date back several years, and at times, over a decade. Kolkata mayor Firhad Hakim on Saturday asked the assessment department to ensure that KMC did not demand dues exceeding one general revision (GR) from new owners, who have either bought a property or had been gifted one.

A GR or general revision of property tax is carried out every six years. Usually, the rate of hike is 10%.

The issue came to light when the mayor received two calls from property owners in the Garia-Patuli belt during the ‘Talk to Mayor’ session on Saturday. Both said they bought apartments on resale and that they were burdened with huge tax dues for no fault of theirs. Hearing them out, Hakim made it known to KMC assessment department team that the civic authority could not demand unreasonable amount of money from a recent owner and fixed the limit of liability to one GR period. “It is your duty to give relief to owners of transferred property,” Hakim told civic staff.

Sources in the KMC assessment department said the new rules would offer relief to buyers of properties on resale but at the same, dent the civic coffers. A senior KMC official said the civic body would automatically switch all new flats to unit area assessment (UAA) method once the owners applied for mutation and instructions would be given to assessor collectors in the borough offices to give relief to buyers of resold properties or gifted properties.

Title: Two arrested in sex racket at Calangute
Content:
Representative image

SALIGAO: Calangute police on Saturday arrested Mukesh Chaurasiya, 21, of Daman and Laxmi Prasad Jaiswal of Uttar Pradesh, for their involvement in a prostitution racket .

Three women who were rescued by the police were produced before the Mapusa sub-divisional magistrate and lodged in the state protective home.

Chaurasiya and Jaiswal were booked under provisions of the Indian Penal Code and Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act, 1956. They were then produced before the Mapusa JMFC and were remanded in 3 days police custody.

Title: No entry-parking fee at Veerappur temple
Content:
Trichy: Bringing cheers to the pilgrims coming to Veerappur Periyakaandiyamman temple near Manapparai for the annual festival, the district administration has banned collecting entry-cum-parking fee from the visitors.

Periyakaandiyamman temple at Veppur, about 13 km away from Manapparai, attracts lakhs of people, mostly from the western districts. During the Tamil month of Masi, the temple celebrates Masi Perunthiruvizha (grand festival), which will be observed for more than 10 days. In the past, to go to the temple in Nallampillai panchayat and park their vehicles, the devotees had to pay fees (minimum Rs 50), which was collected by private agencies or people entrusted by the panchayat body.

The annual festival started on February 21 will continue till March 4 and at least 5 lakh people are expected to visit the temple in the next four days. Based on the grievances received from the public, Trichy district administration has asked the local body and temple management not to collect fee from devotees. District collector S Sivarasu has warned of stern actions against those involved in collecting fee near the temple.

Title: Where politicians live without privileges
Content:
BENGALURU: In 2019, India ranked #80 in the Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI), an index that is published annually by Transparency International. The index ranks countries based on their ‘perceived levels of public sector corruption’. Per CPI, the definition of corruption stands for ‘the misuse of public power for private benefit’. In the last five years, India’s ranking has hovered in the 80s. Next, if you just did a cursory search on ‘political corruption in India’, you will be presented, in alphabetical order, with a range of scams that have and continue to shock us regular citizens for the sheer scale of impunity of the political class and bureaucracy that is involved in them. While the money involved can give the strongest amongst us a heartburn, the snail’s pace at which the scams are investigated and solved have only worked to numb us to corruption, we as a country have gotten used to shrug and look the other way. It is just the way it is. “The most infamous corruption scandal in Sweden happened in the ’90s when the then deputy prime minister Mona Sahlin used her official credit card to buy bars of Toblerone and some other personal items. The scandal was so huge that she had to resign and it has since been referred to as the Toblerone Affair,” laughs journalist and writer Claudia Wallin who was in Bengaluru to attend the Times Litfest. Set against India's state of affairs, Wallin’s comment about Sweden and its corruption-free politics sounds a little fantastic. Wallin gets your bewilderment.

As a Brazilian who grew up during a military dictatorship, Wallin is familiar with corrupt governance. “Brazil is violently corrupt and very high on social inequalities as well. And because I grew up during a military dictatorship, I didn’t know what democracywas for a long time,” she says. So when Wallin landed in Stockholm sometime in the 2000s after marrying her Swedish husband – “I am what they call a love refugee” she jokes – she found herself in a strange country.

“My first shock happened in a supermarket in Stockholm because I was there doing my shopping when I suddenly saw former Swedish PM Carl Bildt there pushing his own shopping trolley and choosing his own vegetables! He was the minister of foreign relations at the time, and for a Brazilian like me that was nearly like an extra-terrestrial experience because in Brazil, politicians don’t buy their own vegetables. They have servants and private assistants to do that,” Wallin jokes. “After that, I saw the speaker of the Swedish parliament–the highest political office in the country, even higher than the PM–in a subway train. I discovered that he went to work by train. Another time, I saw the mayor of Stockholm waiting in line at a bus stop with grocery bags in hand, just like any other regular citizen. All these incidents made me wonder what this was about,” Wallin recalls. That curiosity eventually led Wallin to write a book about Sweden’s politicians. Called Sweden: The Untold Story the book, first published in the Brazilian language in 2014, became a bestseller. Translated into English in 2019, Wallin has since then been travelling the world to spread the word about Sweden’s political system. “It is important for people to know that there is another way of doing politics. Sweden can become an inspiration to so many countries,” she says.

For cynics, Wallin may seem like an enamoured outsider but Sweden’s uncorrupt governance is the reason why the country ranked #4 on the CPI in 2019. Prod Wallin to share more details of the ‘normal’ lives Swedish politicians lead and the former BBC journalist says, “In Sweden, politicians including MPs go to work by bus, they live in state apartments as small as 16 square meters, they work in parliamentary offices which are as tiny as seven square meters, they even wash their clothes in shared laundry facilities. Even inside the Swedish parliament (the Riksdag), there is a laundry facility where they wash their own clothes because Sweden is a society that does not offer luxury or privileges to its politicians. At all.” The only privilege Swedish politicians have is a card that allows them to use public transport, she adds.

In Brazil, Wallin says that her book and TV specials she has done on the subject have inspired youngsters to demand for change. “What I wanted to show was that if Sweden can do it, we can too. Today, people are realizing that if they want to change the system, they have to enter politics themselves or be more active in terms of citizen participation and demand their MPs to do more. The Swedish model of politics is achievable, but we all need to work together to make it happen,” Wallin says.

Title: Anandwan to create gene pool of 1 million native forest trees
Content:
Nagpur: Philanthropist Baba Amte’s Anandwan in Warora will create a gene pool of 1 million rare endangered native forest trees of 200 species.

Dr Sheetal Amte-Karajgi, social entrepreneur and CEO of Maharogi Sewa Samiti (MSS), Anandwan, said that less than 1% native forest tree species are remaining. “So, even in case of they get extinct, we will be able to restore them,” she said.

In view of the United Nations General Assembly declaring 2020 as International Year of Plant Health (IYPH), Anandwan is geared up to expedite the project.

Amte said, “Of these 1 million trees, 5 lakh will be created at our project at Somnath in Mul, while another 5 lakh through distribution by tying up with various universities, educational institutes and National Service Scheme (NSS) volunteers.”

The MSS has been organizing national-level youth camps at Somnath (Chandrapur) since last 52 years to inculcate values of national integration, peace, harmony and voluntary labour. Over 40,000 youth have drawn inspiration from it.

“We are thinking of redesigning the camp and coming out with a model where an army of youth can create long-term sustainable impact for mother earth with a single vision. We will train youth by holding year-long camps for this constructive work. Registration will start from March 10,” said Amte.

In the last 10 months, the project was implemented at Anandwan by planting 43,000 trees of 85 species from southern tropical dry deciduous forest region. At least 18,000 have been done under Miyawaki model of dense forest plantations.

On one of the small plots in Anandwan, 420 trees were planted on February 25 last year. This patch has turned into a dense forest in a year. 45 of the trees are native ones. Amte and her staff celebrated first birthday of these plantations on February 25.

Akira Miyawaki is a Japanese botanist and expert in plant ecology. In a bid to boost 33 crore plantations in 2019, the then BJP government, under the ‘Green Maharashtra Mission’, had launched Anandwan model in MIDC and civil corporations.

The social entrepreneur said, “In conventional forestry, you cannot plant more than 400 trees in 1 acre of land, but 12,000 trees can be grown under Miyawaki. The expenditure per sapling for three years was Rs242.”

Dr Amte said there are many advantages of these multilayered Miyawaki plantations. There is no soil erosion and groundwater recharge is good. These plantations act as good carbon sinks and reduce temperatures. This technology gives 10 times faster growth, 30 times density, and trees are 100 times biodiverse.

The Samiti will plant over 5 lakh trees by 2025 and remaining in the next five years. These 200 tree species are going extinct due to forest fires and indiscriminate felling for various development works.

Native trees play an important part as they are the spine of food chain in the forest. These trees create food, fertilizer, fodder and fresh air, besides cleansing the water streams and revitalizing soil.

As native tree species have dwindled in core areas of forests, it has disturbed the food chain, thus causing man-animal conflict. Wild animals are coming to human habitat in search of food resulting in conflict.

“Our team aims to create micro forests from 1,200 trees to mega forests of 5 lakh trees and conserve them. Attempt is to bring back food chain to barren lands,” Amte said and added, “A leopard recently visited our 7-month-old forest besides blue bulls, porcupines and several bird species.”

The mother plants at Anandwan will act as a bank of genetic material so that even if these trees go extinct from forests, they would have the genetic material in the form of trees and seeds to bring those species back.

Title: Giant croc captured from canal, released into Kollidam river
Content:
Trichy: A 10-foot long crocodile , which has triggered panic along the banks of Uyyakondan canal for a few days, was finally captured by the fire and rescue department officials here on Saturday. The scaly reptile was later released into the Kollidam river at Grand Anaicut.

The crocodile reportedly crawled to the banks of the canal near the shrubs at Thirumalai Kallangadu, near Kuzhumayi Amman Temple after the water Cauvery, Uyyakondan, receded. Sources said that the residents had noticed the crocodile in the shrubs a few days ago and were scary of venturing into the canal.

Visiting the banks on Saturday morning, a few devotees saw the hulking creature and alerted the rescue service officials in Cantonment. A team headed by station officer Melchiah Raj arrived at the scene and launched a hunt. The team captured the crocodile after in two hours.

Following the capture, the forest department officials reached the spot and took possession of the reptile. The forest department later released it into the Kollidam River at Grand Anaicut.

Hundreds of devotees converge at Kuzumayi Amman Temple as the annual festival is nearing.

“Had the reptile was not captured, it might have scared the devotees gathering around the temple on the banks of Uyyanodan canal,” residents said.

Fire service station officer Melchiah Raj warned the public that chances of crocodiles crawling out of rivers or canals is high as there is no flow in waterbodies. He asked them to be cautious.

Title: CM for jt inspection of Mhadei project to expose Karnataka
Content:
Panaji: Two days before the Supreme Court hears the state’s application seeking relief in the Mhadei water dispute on March 2, chief minister Pramod Sawant on Saturday said that Goa would push for joint inspection of the Kalasa-Bhandura project to expose illegalities committed by Karnataka. He also said that the government would seek a stay so that Karnataka can’t start work on the project.

Sawant said that he would seek a direction from the apex court to Karnataka that it should not approach any authorities for permission till the matter is heard in court. He also said that we would appeal to the court to stop the diversion of water, which is being done “illegally” by Karnataka.

The state government wants a joint inspection of the Kalasa-Bhandura site, and that it should be headed by the chief engineer of the central water commission or assessor of the Mhadei Water Disputes Tribunal, Sawant told reporters.

On Tuesday, the state government filed an application before the Supreme Court seeking interim relief to restrain Karnataka from carrying out construction or any other activity on the Mhadei. The chief minister’s office said after senior advocate Mukul Rohatgi pleaded before the bench presided by justice D Y Chandrachud for an urgent hearing, the court posted the matter for March 2.

Sawant also said that the state government is opposing the transfer of 3.9 tmc water from the Mhadei basin to the Malaprabha basin as per the award of the tribunal. “We oppose this because one cannot allow the transfer of water from one basin to another,” Sawant said. He also said that under the garb of water for drinking, they want to use it for irrigation. “Hence, we are opposed to it,” he said.

Sawant said that the state of Goa would challenge the finding of the tribunal that there is 188 tmc yield in the Mhadei basin. He said that as per the state government, the yield of the Mhadei basin is around 113.5 tmc.

In August 2018, the three-decade-old dispute between three states — Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Goa — over sharing of the Mhadei waters ended with the tribunal rejecting Karnataka’s demand for 36.5 tmc, and allotted it only 13.4 tmc, including 3.9 tmc for drinking purposes through diversions, against its demand for 7.5 tmc.

Sawant said that as per Mhadei tribunal interim order dated April 17, 2014, Karnataka cannot divert water till the revised detailed project report is prepared, as well as wildlife and forest clearances are issued.

Title: Kolkata: Showers likely next week, to check rising temperature, says Met
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The city can expect showers next week that would check the mercury from rising.

The Met office is keeping an eye on two weather systems: a high-pressure zone over the Bay of Bengal and a trough extending from Bihar and Chhattisgarh. Once the two systems form, they are expected to bring rain to the city. “We are expecting rain on Monday as well as on Wednesday and Thursday. While the chance for rain on Monday is 30%-40%, that for other two days is 60%,” said director at Regional Meteorological Centre Kolkata G K Das.

The Met office said the intensity of rain could be light to moderate, but there could be thundershowers. “These shower will prevent the mercury from jumping up abruptly,” Das said.

Title: Fake ED officer held for extortion in Kolkata
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: An Ekbalpore resident, impersonating an ED officer, was arrested on Saturday for robbing a cellphone dealer , who had gone to Burrabazar to collect payment from a client.

Police said Sitaram Pareek, a resident of Howrah, was returning after collecting Rs 14 lakh from a client when he was intercepted by the accused, Md Pappu alias Abu Bashir (25), who claimed to be an ED officer. He told Pareek to get into an SUV, in which four others were seated. They accused Pareek of laundering money and took the entire amount from him as well as a few mobiles. They drove him around for 15 minutes and dropped him off on the road. Pareek later lodged a complaint at Hastings PS.

Title: Dempo look to make I-League comeback with Academy lads
Content:
Panaji: Dempo Sports Club are keen to make a comeback in the I-League but not with the big budgets that they had in the past.

Dempo won a record five national league titles before opting out of the top-tier. They were protesting the roadmap from All India Football Federation (AIFF) that proposed to make Indian Super League (ISL) the top league and reduced I-League to second tier. Salgaocar FC and Sporting Clube de Goa also withdrew in 2016.

Now, Dempo could take another shot at the top-tier – through I-League – with help from their academy graduates.

“Our eventual pathway is we want to become a factory of players. We want every single ISL and I-League club to come and tell us that they want our players. The same set of team, they have to be capable enough to go through the competitive league system and at least through the I-League, we can see whether we can come and play,” club chairman Shrinivas Dempo told TOI on Saturday, while felicitating their junior squads, all of whom have topped in Goa and made it to the national leagues.

When at its peak, Dempo had the highest budget with a reported Rs 15 crore being spent in 2012, the year they won their last I-League title.

“Today, low budget teams have done well. You no longer have to spend Rs 15 crore which Dempo spent 10 years ago. Things are changing. There’s hope for us,” said Dempo.

Since opting out, Dempo has chosen to invest in the academy at Ella in Old Goa, a decision that is now starting to bear fruits. Since October 2019, Dempo have won 44 of the 46 matches, kept 33 clean sheets and averaged four goals a game.

“Our journey has just begun. I would have been disappointed if success wasn’t there. What’s the point of having a team for three years, detailed planning if you cannot get results (at the state level). The challenge is now to do well in AIFF leagues,” said Dempo.

Title: Trichy: 9 child labourers rescued from shops in two days
Content:
Representative Image

TRICHY: An interdepartmental raid conducted for the past two days has led to the rescue of nine child labourers in Trichy.

Initiated by the Bachpan Bachao Andolan (BBA) project, a team comprising sub-judge R Nandhini, secretary of district legal services authority (DLSA), volunteers of One Stop Crisis team, Child Labour Elimination and Effective Rehabilitation Society (CHEERS), labour department, Child Line, anti-child trafficking unit (ACTU) and District Child Protection Unit (DCPU) carried out a massive raid on shops at the central bus stand, Chathiram bus stand, Teppakulam and Somarasampettai area on Friday.

The raid brought to light employment of children below 14 years and adolescent child labourers under 18 working in mechanic shops, tea shops, bakeries and grocery shops in the areas. The rescued children include a girl who was working in a book shop. Almost all of them were school dropouts. The children said poverty has pushed their parents to send their kids for jobs. Project manager of CHEERS, Trichy, S Gowthaman was also part of the rescue team. He said that the team reprimanded the employers for employing the children and warned of legal action against them. “They are paid a paltry daily wage of Rs 100 to 150 for which they have to toil for nearly 12 hours at the workplace. The situation is worse in some places in the rural areas,” said Gowthaman.

Acting on the information from the labour department, a 14-year-old boy was rescued from a two-wheeler mechanic shop by the ACTU police in Thuraiyur in Trichy on Saturday. The children were produced before the Child Welfare Committee (CWC), which ordered to keep them in government reception homes until further orders.

Title: Gujarat high court relief for financiers in Rs 1,300 crore gold smuggling case
Content:
Court relief for financiers in ₹1,300cr gold smuggling case

AHMEDABAD: The central government’s action at a belated stage against financiers in the Rs 1,300-crore gold smuggling racket at the Ahmedabad international airport has been nixed by the courts, which found no nexus between financing the alleged illegal activity and the present detention orders. On Thursday, Jitendra Rokad was released from the Sabarmati Central Jail after the Gujarat high court quashed a detention order passed by the customs department under the Conservation of Foreign Exchange and Prevention of Smuggling Activities Act (COFEPOSA). The order to detain Rokad was passed on August 2, 2019 after the Customs authority came to know about his financing the smuggling activity in 2014-15. He along with others were accused of financing Rutugna Trivedi — the alleged kingpin of the gold smuggling racket with as much as 4,242kg gold being smuggled between 2014 and 2019 — Rs 52.35 crore to get 185kg gold smuggled into India between January 2014 and July 2015. Similarly, a detention order was passed against Mehul Bhimani for financing Trivedi during 2014-15. One Pramodgiri Goswami too was detained by the agency for allegedly financing Trivedi Rs 204 crore to bring in 731.7kg gold without duty in India through Ahmedabad airport. All three persons had challenged their detention orders before different courts. Goswami had moved the Supreme Court, which quashed his detention order on January 27. The SC order was placed in his submissions by Bhimani in proceedings before the Delhi high court, which quashed on February 25 the detention order passed against him. Rokad had challenged his detention before the Gujarat HC and placed the orders passed by the apex court and Delhi HC relieving the co-accused in the smuggling racket. Justice S H Vora said that the court noticed that there is “no nexus or live link between alleged illegal activity and purported claim of detaining authority, as the activity had been committed between January 2014 and July 2015 while the detention order was passed in August 2019”. The high court also said that the authority could not give reasonable explanation for the delay in taking action against Rokad and no offence was registered against him either by the customs or central department about “prejudicial activities”.

Title: From the darkened halls, a peep into global culture
Content:
BENGALURU: If you’re among those watching the Andrei Tarkovsky retrospective at the on-going film festival in Bengaluru, you surely wouldn’t have had to scrounge for information about the Russian film director and theorist before walking into the movie hall. There are numerous online blogs, analytical notes, documentaries and scholarly video lectures, apart from DVD collections of his cinema for further viewing.

It wasn’t so in the decades before this millennium; nothing came off the shelf or at a click of a button. Why, even a film festival in the city wasn’t regular. Before the 35th edition of the International Film Festival of India (IFFI) became competitive and pitched tent in Goa in 2004, Bengaluru hosted the event only twice: the Filmotsav in 1980 and the IFFI in 1992.

Both those events were widely celebrated by the media, students of cinema and professionals. Viewers lapped up special coverage in the papers, stood in queues for season tickets and strode in and out of theatres in Majestic –then, with about 20-plus movie halls in the vicinity and seen as an ideal location for a film festival. Critics not too familiar with world cinema, had begun to contact film societies for material on trends and seek old copies of “Sight and Sound”. First-hand experience meant taking down notes in the darkened halls – perhaps of Miklos Jancso’s expansive use of open fields and trademark long-takes.

They had to change the structure and language of their reviews too. All year long, they had been used to writing about popular cinema in a set format: opening lines that set the mood followed by a summary of the plot invariably beginning with “The film revolves around…” and a concluding paragraph that judged the performances of the cast and the cinematographer with one or two adjectives for each. Assessment of quality cinema needed a more rigorous approach – of not only understanding the socio-cultural and political context of the theme, but also unique narrative styles and technique. Why does Robert Bresson “flatten” his images? Or why does Chantal Akerman use the kitchen as central space in her films?

And even if it didn’t interest most readers, there was a mandatory article on the market. Looking at the film bazaar in 1992, one report said there was hardly any buzz “as far as imports were concerned owing to certain curbs and censorship code, but organisers believed enquiries for exports were encouraging”.

The coverage ended with comments that art cinema was still in the grip of “neo-Rayalism”, with no sincere attempt to break the mould. At least a dozen films in the Indian Panorama package were set in the countryside. As a cinematographer put it, “The village has become an ideal setting for projecting universal values, even if simplistic. Can you recollect how many calendar shots of sunrise and sunset you have seen, or how often you have heard the suprabhatam on the soundtrack in the morning sequences of Indian art cinema?” There were exceptions that year, though, and pick of the Panorama included Satyajit Ray’s “Agantuk”, G Aravindan’s “Vastuhara”, Mrinal Sen’s “Mahaprathibhi”, MT Vasudevan Nair’s “Kadavu” , Jahnu Barua’s “Firingoti” and TS Nagabharana’s “Mysuru Mallige”.

Many festivals in India have left us with a tinge of displeasure about the absence of big names and the best cinema. If there was a memorable one, it was in Delhi in 1977, attended by maestros Satyajit Ray, Michaelangelo Antonioni and Akira Kurosawa. A photograph of their visit to the Taj Mahal was splashed across newspapers and magazines. BIFFes (Bengaluru International Film Festival), now in its 11th edition, is grappling with the task of establishing its own identity.

Finally, it’s all about access to films and avenues for film appreciation. The city wasn’t short of independent film clubs, among them the most active were Bangalore film society and Suchitra. They brought out newsletters and journals, apart from hosting their own festivals. One club, Manthan, had a distinctive process of understanding a film. I remember attending a screening of Ingmar Bergman’s “Wild Strawberries” sometime in the early 1980s on a Saturday. Soon after the movie, we were given some notes to read for a second screening that happened the next morning. On the second day, finer points – specific shots and sequences – were discussed threadbare, after halting the projection for a veritable “rewind” of the reels. At a time when film was still physical and the digital evolution was nowhere on the horizon, this took some doing.

Over the years, the experience hasn’t changed drastically, though. Cinephiles continue to search for newer works of true art. They spend hours for the living experience, for that matchless joy of watching directors sculpt a “lump of time”. When the lights fade out, they would have grasped a bit of Tarkovsky. And agree with him that the power of cinema hasn’t to do only with stars, story-lines and entertainment.

— Jayanth Kodkani

Title: Farmers urge CM to expedite work on Kollidam barrage
Content:
Thanjavur: Farmers from Nagapattinam and Cuddalore have appealed to chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami to take steps to speed up the work on a barrage across the Kollidam. The farmers also urged the chief minister visit the worksite during his scheduled visit to Tiruvarur to participate in a felicitation function organized for him by farmers.

Based on the announcement made by former chief minister J Jayalalithaa in the assembly, Rs 428 crore was allocated by the government in November, 2018 for constructing a barrage across the Kollidam with head sluices on the downstream of the Lower Anaicut connecting Kumaramangalam village in Nagapattinam district and Adhanur village in Cuddalore district.

The chief minister laid the foundation stone for the barrage in February 2019, to minimize surplus flow of water in the river and for creating additional infrastructure to control excess flow in the Cauvery and Kollidam during monsoons. The barrage will be built at 1,300 meter length and three meter height. The state government has allotted Rs 23 lakh to conduct a study and prepare a project report. Now the work has been going on at a snail’s pace, farmers said.

The secretary of Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association, Swamimalai S Vimalnathan, said that construction of a barrage was a long pending demand by the farmers to save water. “The work, going on at a snail’s pace, has to be expedited. The chief minister had inspected Mukkombu barrage and reviewed the work. He should also come and visit the sites, when he visits Tiruvarur on March 7,” he said.

Title: TNTJ leads anti-CAA protest at 82 places in central Tamil Nadu
Content:
Trichy: Tamil Nadu Thowheed Jamath (TNTJ) organized protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR) at 82 places in eight central districts on Saturday.

Trichy city witnessed protests at eight places since morning with people crossing the Palakkarai area having a tough time as the protesters camped on the Palakkarai road. The group staged its protest under a large shamiana forcing the city police to divert traffic through sub-jail road and other roads. However, traffic moved at a snail’s pace for many hours. A pandhal also came up outside Jamal Mohammed College (JMC) with members of the Muslim community blocking one side of the road as they sat in protest.

Protests were organized at Edamalaipatti Pudhur, airport, Ariyamangalam, Singarathoppu, Palakkarai and Woraiyur. Police said the protesters numbered about 3,000 in the city. Meanwhile, the ongoing protest at Uzhavar Sandhai grounds in Thennur for the past two weeks continued. Wearing masks of leaders like Mahatma Gandhi, Subash Chandra Bose and E V R Periyar, the protesters tore a sheet of paper intended to be a copy of the CAA to register their protest against the central government.

Trichy rural witnessed protests at five places whereas Pudukottai, Karur, Perambalur, Ariyalur, Thanjavur, Tiruvarur and Nagappattinam districts saw protests at 69 places. Police have been deployed at all the places to keep a watch on the protests and ensure law and order in the area. The protesters, except in Thennur Uzhavar Sandhai grounds, dispersed in the evening.

Title: Gujarat reported five atrocity cases a day in 2019
Content: AHMEDABAD: Dalits seem to bear the brunt of caste-based violence in the state with 1,500 cases of atrocities reported in 2019. These include 32 murder cases, 81 assault and 97 rape cases. This indicates that on an average nearly five cases of atrocities were reported last year.Figures between 2001 and 2019 suggest a rise in cases till 2018. In 2019, there was a nominal decrease of 45 cases than 2018, however, in 2019 the state saw three Dalit youths being stopped from riding horses in marriage processions in Arvalli, Sabarkantha and Mehsana districts by upper caste people. Recently, a Dalit youth was beaten for riding horse in his marriage in Palanpur town of Banaskantha.In 2019, Ahmedabad reported the highest 164 cases followed by Junagadh where 102 cases were reported. Ahmedabad city also reported six murders, 16 rape cases of Dalit women and 10 cases of grievous injuries.Police committed a goof-up in invoking the atrocities act in 2019 against the director of the national award winning film ‘Hellaro’ who is himself a Dalit.These figures have been obtained from an RTI plea filed in Gujarat DGP office by a civil rights activist Kaushik Parmar.Parmar said that the cases have increased as Dalits are still not being given equal treatment in society.

Title: Man shoots wife after being confronted for illicit affair
Content:
Agra: Agra police arrested a man who shot his wife, after she confronted him about an illicit affair with another woman. To avoid suspicion, the accused made a distress call to the police, feeding them a fake narrative of been robbed by dacoits, who also allegedly killed his wife.

The apprehended accused was identified as Netrapal Singh, 30, of Parmal village under Kagraul police jurisdiction. He was married to Rakhi (28) since 2011. The duo had three children. The victim hailed from Sahrai village of Bharatpur district.

SP, rural west, Ravi Kumar said, “Prima facie it looks to be a pre-planned murder . After returning from a wedding ceremony, around 9.30pm, the accused whipped out his country-made pistol and shot his wife. In order to avoid police suspicion, the accused shared a false narrative, that group of dacoits attacked the couple and took away Rs 1.25 lakh and shot the woman.”

“His lie was caught, after he was confronted by his children, who told police a totally different story,” said SP.

SP added, “Later during interrogation, the accused broke down and claimed, that he was having an affair with another woman and wanted to marry her. His wife Rakhi came to know about his affair and reprimanded him. Infuriated over Rakhi, the accused shot her dead.”

Title: Kolkata: Charge sheet for Gariahat murder case
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Police have submitted charge sheet in the Gariahat case, in which a 65-year-old woman was murdered allegedly by her daughter-in-law, her lover, and granddaughter.

Urmila Jund was found beheaded at her Gariahat home in December, following which daughter-in-law Dimple, her lover, Saurabh Puri, and daughter Kanika were held. Cops suspect Dimple hatched the plot as Urmila had refused to give her her share of property.

Title: Valuables worth Rs 17 lakh stolen
Content:
Ahmedabad: Three burglaries took place on Friday in Satellite, Sola and Vadaj with total Rs 16.65 lakh worth of cash and valuables stolen. Concerned police stations have registered FIRs and begun inquiries.

In the FIR in the Satellite case, the complainant Kalpesh Purohit stated that on Friday morning, Purohit saw the lock on the main door of his bungalow broken and jewellery and cash worth Rs 8.24 lakh stolen.

In the burglary in Sola, the complainant Indrajeet Sinha, resident of Harihar Ashray-1, said thieves had broken the terrace door of his bungalow on Friday night and fled with jewellery, valuables, clothes and cash worth Rs 8.11 lakh.

In the Vadaj burglary, which took place at Sohrabji Compound, thieves broke into the house of one Hardik Parmar and fled with jewellery worth Rs 30,000.

Title: 77 people complete 28-day quarantine for coronavirus
Content:
Jaipur: As many as 77 people who returned from China, the epicentre of novel coronavirus outbreak, have completed the 28-day tenure of isolation on Saturday.

They were worried when they reached Jaipur a few weeks ago. Since they have now completed 28 days of surveillance, they have heaved a sigh of relief.

Varun (name changed) told STOI that they returned from China on January 13. They were the first who were kept in isolation. “We were asked to remain at home (home quarantine) for at least 28 days. I was kept in the isolation ward at Sawai Man Singh hospital for six days. They took my samples twice and both times, I was tested negative for nCoV. My 28-day ordeal has ended now,” he said. However, 261 people are still under surveillance. According to the health department figures, till date, a total 73 suspected patients had been admitted in isolation since the scare of nCoV gripped the state in mid-January. The health department has conducted 100 tests of nCoV, all of them tested negative, a health department official said.

WHO has declared the recent nCoV epidemic as public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC). In India, so far only three confirmed cases of nCoV have been reported, all from Kerala.

Keeping a close eye on nCoV, the health department is conducting nCoV screening at Sanganer airport, Jaipur. They are conducting screening of all passengers arriving from the eight international flights daily since January 28, 2020. For the purpose, five doctors and five paramedical staff have been deputed at the airport. Passengers are screened using non-contact thermal scanner. “Till today, 22,437 passengers of 152 flights have been screened,” said the official.

The official said those who have travelled recently from the corona-affected countries must inform the national/state/district helpline number and remain under strict home isolation for 28 days from the date of arrival in India, irrespective of whether they are symptomatic or asymptomatic. Those who have travelled Wuhan-China since January 15, 2020 onwards must get themselves tested for nCoV at the government-designated centres.

Title: Woman protests with ailing hubby before registrar office
Content:
Karur: A woman staged a protest with her husband on a stretcher in front of the registrar office in Karur after she was denied transfer of property from her husband to her. As the man was bedridden due to a nervous problem, the woman wanted to sell their property to remit fees for her daughter’s final year BDS course.

R Manjula, 52, a native of Vanjiyamman Temple street, is working as staff nurse at a government hospital in Karur. Her husband K V Rajaram, 60, was running an automobile spare parts shop. He became bed-ridden and could not even speak after being diagnosed with motor neuron disease (MND) four years ago, sources said. Manjula had spent several lakhs of rupees for her husband’s treatment at various hospitals. Meanwhile, their only daughter who is now in her final year of BDS at Puducherry had to remit Rs 7 lakh as fee.

“Only one in a lakh people get affected by this neural disease. Despite spending lakhs of rupees at hospitals across the country, he was not cured”, she told TOI. With their money drying up, they decided to sell two plots of land in Rajaram’s name. “I explained our situation to the sub-registrar of Mela Karur, BalaSenthil Murugan, and appealed to him to help change the property’s ownership to my name so as to sell it easily. He too promised to help us. We went to the sub-registrar office in an ambulance and took my husband on a stretcher to his room. The sub registrar did whatever procedure was required to be fulfilled. However, when he asked my husband to say his name and also asked a few questions, he could not speak and started to cry. Suddenly, the sub-registrar went out without completing the procedure and also without telling us anything”, she said.

Confused by his act, Manjula staged a dharna in front of the office demanding the name change. Soon, Karur town police arrived there, pacified her and got a complaint from her to take further action. Manjula also sought help from the district legal services authority to settle the issue. When contacted by TOI, sub-registrar Balasenthil Murugan refused to divulge anything in tune with the government rule. “I have no option but to seek the help of legal authorities. I hope I will get legal aid for my problem”, Manjula added.

Title: 3.5L benefit from Palanhar scheme so far this year
Content:
Jaipur: Over 3.5 lakh people have already benefitted under Palanhar scheme of the social justice and empowerment department, that provides financial assistance to orphan children, this year (2019-20) as against 3.1 lakh beneficiaries last year (2018-19).

With this, already 40,000 more beneficiaries have been benefitted this year under the scheme over last year.

Of the allotted budget of Rs 260 crore, Rs 257 crore has already been utilised under the scheme (up to December 2019). Last year (2018-19), the proposed budget was Rs 228 crore. An additional fund was allotted last year to benefit the extra beneficiaries under the scheme, taking the total expenditure to Rs 259 crore.

Under the chief minister pension schemes (old age/widow/disability), till December 2019, 64.47 lakh people have been benefitted at an expenditure of Rs 4,776.39 crore (as on December).

Title: CU researchers decode stickiness of mussels
Content:
Kozhikode: Researchers from Calicut University have uncovered physico-chemical and structural properties that make marine mussels stick onto underwater rocks withstanding constant pounding of waves and extreme under water conditions.

Dr Y Shibu Vardhanan, associate professor of the department of zoology, along with researcher Anand P P at the department have completed the physio-chemical structural and functional characterisation of mussel foot proteins (Mfps) responsible for the moisture-resistant biological glue which helps mussels cling to under water surfaces.

They have also revealed the specific physio-chemical structural and functional characters of each of the 78 Mfps belonging to nine mussel species which are available in the protein bank of National Centre for Biotechnology Information, USA. The study holds potential for developing super-strong water-resistant synthetic bio-mimetic adhesives in the future. While most conventional engineered polymer-based adhesives cannot be applied onto wet environments, marine mussels have mastered the ability to anchor to foreign surfaces under the seawater. The foot of mussels contains glands which release glue-like materials known as byssus thread made up of an array of proteins. The byssus threads cure rapidly to form adhesive plaques with high interfacial binding strength, durability, and toughness. They are engineered to withstand elevated mechanical loads applied by waves and currents.

The moisture-resistant adhesive property of Mfps has inspired development of a wide variety of functional materials. Understanding the specific physio-chemical and functional property of each Mfps is vital for designing mussel-mimetic adhesive materials. The 3,4 dihydroxy phenylalanine (DOPA) is the main constituent in mussel foot proteins which can form various types of chemical interactions and cross linking which imparts foot proteins the ability to solidify in situ and bind tightly to various types of surfaces.

Vardhanan said that the remarkable wet-adhesive properties of these proteins have potential in a range of biomedical applications including developing super-strong synthetic bio-mimetic adhesives, which can be used for biomedical purposes like post-surgery wound closing adhesives.

A major industrial application of mussel protein is for the preparation of anti-fouling surfaces, especially for ships. The work has been published in international journal ‘Nature – Scientific Report, Springer Nature Ltd’. They are also invited as speakers at International Conference on Material Science and Nanotechnology to be held at Osaka in Japan in 2021.

Title: SUV hits woman, then runs her over in Kolkata
Content:
The spot at Kalighat, where the accident took place

KOLKATA: A 44-year-old schoolteacher died when an SUV dashed into her at a breakneck speed and flung her into the air. As she landed on the bonnet, the driver took a sharp turn, throwing her to the ground and then, ran her over while speeding away. Police have got the vehicle’s registration number but are yet to track down the driver.

The incident took place early on Saturday at Kalighat , barely 50m from the victim’s home.

Subhalaxmi Banerjee, a resident of Syama Prasad Mukherjee Road who taught English at Arya Kanya Vidyalay in central Kolkata, had gone out around 6 in the morning to buy flowers for puja at home. After buying flowers from shops near the Kalighat temple, she was on her way back home, when she stopped at a traffic signal, waiting for the light to turn red so that she could walk across the road. When she reached the middle of the road, the SUV reportedly sped at her and hit her before she could react. The impact was such that Subhalaxmi was flung in the air and she fell on the bonnet of the same vehicle. In his attempt to flee the spot and apparently to shake her off, the driver took a sharp turn towards right, and Subhalaxmi flee on to the road. The fleeing driver did not stop but reportedly ran her over as he sped away.

As the SUV driver sped towards Rashbehari Avenue, he tried to jump a signal, rammed into a car waiting at the signal and nearly hit a traffic cop who tried to flag him down.

Cops on the road imm-ediately took Subhalaxmi first to M R Bangur Hospital and then, to SSKM Hospital, where she was declared brought dead.

“I was selling tea at my stall. I had seen the woman about to cross the road. Suddenly, the vehicle appeared from nowhere and dashed into her. Before we could react, the vehicle took a turn and again ran her over and left at an equally high speed. But I managed to note down the SUV’s registration number,” said Pratap Pailan, owner of a nearby tea stall.

It was the Banerjees’ domestic help, who first learnt about the death, when she went out looking for Subhalaxmi. “Boudi always offered puja before leaving for her school. Like every day, she had gone to buy flowers. Worried that she was taking way too long to return, I went out, looking for her. The flowersellers in front of the Kali temple know us and they said she left long ago. When I was asking some shop owners on the opposite pavement, a traffic police approached me and showed me her photograph. Her head was completely smashed,” said Bratabala Biswas, the help.

Subhalaxmi’s husband, Mrinal Banerjee, is a wildlife photographer and was in Siliguri when the incident took place. After his family informed him of the tragedy, he managed to buy a flight ticket and reached Kolkata by afternoon. “Our house is nearly a century old and we have a temple inside. A special puja is offered on Tuesdays and Saturdays and she went out to buy flowers for that,” was all that he could manage to say.

“We have checked the CCTV footage and got the number of the vehicle. We are trying to track it down,” said an officer at Lalbazar.

Though Subhalaxmi started walking across the road only when the traffic light had turned red, residents of the area said the non-functional timer at the signal leads to uncertainty among pedestrians as they are never sure when the traffic light will again turn green and till when it is safe to cross the road.

Title: 100 Anganwadis in Gadchiroli to be developed on lines of urban play schools
Content:
A Mumbai-based NGO is likely to be roped in for training the Anganwadi teachers, volunteers and other support ... Read More

Nagpur: Gadchiroli administration has decided to develop 100 Anganwadis in two blocks of the tribal district, on the lines of play schools in the cities with a budget allocation of around Rs30 lakh.

A Mumbai-based NGO, already engaged in similar projects in Jharkhand and elsewhere, is likely to be roped in for training the Anganwadi teachers, volunteers and other support staffers.

The Anganwadis, which had been so far catering to only nutritional aspect, will now be elevated a notch higher with the attendants and teachers also imparting basic elementary education to the students emulating a similar kind of practices in the pre and play schools in the urban centres. The decision was taken by the district administration to improve the standard of primary education and help students prepare better at the pre-entry level.

With Maoist-related problems, education had been one of the most adversely affected sectors with high absenteeism of teachers in schools and anganwadis in the backdrop of uncertainty and insecurity.

District collector Deepak Singla, who is planning to implement the project, said the anganwadis with maximum attendance have been earmarked in the first phase. “The idea is to impart and empower the students at the pre-school level with motor and cognitive skills like basic counting, identifying colours, some reading skills, learning alphabets, names of animals and so on,” Singla said.

“Right now, the anganwadis just ensure that the mid-day meal is properly served and try to shrug off the rest of their responsibilities at that point. We are now aiming to ensure that the anganwadis go beyond just providing the mid-day meal and teach some basic skills to the students too,” he said.

Singla said the students face hardship in the first couple of years in the schools after walking out of the anganwadis as they are not learning much at this stage in today’s scenario.

Singla said the trainings would include the aspects of using the materials available at the spots, like stones, sticks and such things, as tools for learning. “The cost of training per student is around Rs1,000 per annum, which is negligible. We are trying to arrange the funds from certain channels, or else shall use the budget allocated for the district under various heads,” he said.

Title: Mulberries, cherries, and chillies for some zing, their summer wine is made from all these things
Content: BENGALURU: The Kodava people are known for their love for nature and its products. One member proudly said that they can make a fine wine out of anything and everything. The community in Bengaluru is also a witnessing a wine-making renaissance and new inventions of wine crop up time and again here, with recipes shared by word-of-mouth.But the wine making in Kodava culture isn’t something that was passed on from generations. “This wine creating frenzy is relatively new among us. I don’t remember my grandmother making any wine at home,” says Ponnamma Barianda, a microbiologist who hails from Murnad in Coorg.According to this Victoria Layout resident, the wine making and serving didn’t really exist among the community this the 90s. “In functions or family get-togethers, men used to be served hard alcohol and women used to stick to fruit juices. But it gradually changed from the late 90s when women started to enjoy some wine in gatherings. Then slowly some ladies started to make their own and serve it in events much to the appreciation of those attending,” Barianda recalls.A healthy contestWhat was just traditional grape-based wines gradually started to evolve into wines fermented out of pineapple, gooseberries, mulberries, starfruit, cherry and even the betel leaf and rose petals. The women of Kodava community in Bengaluru began to experiment in their kitchens and came out with new and unique varieties of wines. Soon, people from outside the community started showing interest. Kodava women started competing with their wine-making skills in meetings and the commercial value of these drinks started to mount.Anitha Ben Kariappa had to quit her marketing job involving real estate to concentrate on a restaurant business. It also allows her to indulge in her favourite hobby, wine making. On any given day her kitchen in Indiranagar has a dozen unique wines she had made over the years. He oldest bottle is seven years and interestingly, its base is the red rose petal. “I like to experiment with new flavours and ingredients. Our community comprises of people who are nature-lovers and we cherish what it has to offer to us. Therefore, making wines from local ingredients is where some Kodava women are excelling,” proudly adds Kariappa as she shows her bottle of rose petal wine.Right now, she has a set of nine wines she has fermented including flavours like mint, betel leaf, grape, passionfruit, ginger and chilly. Her son’s wedding in November turned a platform to showcase her wine-making skills as she served a variety of flavours much to the delight of the attendees.Kariappa doesn’t plan to market or sell her wines but is keen on serving it to her family and friends who can appreciate her skill and of course give feedback be it positive or negative.No expiry date, commercial value“A real Kodagu wine and honey doesn’t have an expiry date,” says Ponnachanna Madhu, a winemaker and dealer from Madikeri who acquired his mother’s skills in making using local flavours for wine, namely hibiscus, jackfruit, jamun and even the honey. Madhu asserts there are 32 varieties of wines which can be called Kodagu’s own and they are best in the country in terms of natural ingredients and traditional fermenting procedures.“Today what was made in homes started to attract tremendous commercial attention. Some wine makers from Kodagu have made it big for their unique flavour. People personally preserve wines at home that are decades-old and serve it with pride. But the wine boom among tourists began from early 2012 and has been a rage ever since,” adds Madhu. Interestingly, the wine trade has boosted the prices not just of the drink but also the bottles it comes in. Few years ago an empty bottle for packaging cost Rs 2, but today it is Rs 12.According to Anil HT, tourism promoter and businessman from Madikeri, there are over 32 varieties of pure Kodagu wine, with and without alcohol and are unique in flavour and taste which the Karnataka state can be proud of. “Unfortunately, fakes have been pumped into the market with fraudsters sensing the demand,” Anil adds.

Title: Drive launched for saving kids from HIV, syphilis
Content:
Jaipur: Aiming to eliminate mother-to-child transmission of HIV and syphilis, Rajasthan State AIDS Control Society (RSACS) along with social organisations have launched a statewide campaign to sensitise private hospitals for scaling up of screening of pregnant women for HIV.

It is estimated that 23% of babies are born in private hospitals in the state. For the purpose of sensitising private hospitals on HIV screening among pregnant women, RSACS, Federation of Obstetric and gynaecological society of India, Rajasthan and NGO SAATHII organised a state level training of trainers for the elimination of mother to child transmission of HIV and syphilis.

“At present there is coverage gap of almost 32% from estimated pregnant women in private sector. The private health facilities who provide services to pregnant women are requested to engage with government under public private partnership and support in the elimination of mother to child transmission of HIV and Syphilis by 2020,” said Dr Anju Soni, chairperson, FOGSI.

For eliminating mother to child transmission of HIV, it is required that all pregnant women should be screened for HIV and Syphilis preferably in the first trimester, once detected reactive, they should be linked to the Integrated Counselling and Testing Centres (ICTC) for confirmation of HIV. Those tested positive for HIV are linked to Anti-Retroviral Treatment (ART) services.

“There are 33% chances of transmission of HIV from infected mother to her baby at the time of the birth. But, the chances are reduced to 2%, if the woman gets ART on time. ART helps in preventing the vertical transmission of HIV from mother to new-born,” said RSACS official.

Also, HIV testing data from all private hospitals should be reported to HIVPULSE portal.

“At present there is coverage gap of almost 32% from estimated pregnant women in private sector. The private health facilities who provide services to pregnant women are requested to engage with government under public private partnership and support in the elimination of mother to child transmission of HIV and Syphilis by 2020,” said Dr Soni.

Title: E-challan system formally starts in Uttrakhand
Content:
DEHRADUN: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Saturday announced the formal start of E-challan system in Dehradun at a function in Police Lines area. E-challans will now be implemented in the entire state. A total of 1,200 machines have been provided to the traffic department for this purpose.

In the presence of the CM, an MoU was signed between the traffic directorate and the State Bank of India for the E-challan service. The documents were signed by director of traffic Kewal Khurana and SBI DGM B L Saini. On the occasion, Rawat also flagged off interceptors for all districts of the state.

The e-challan will also reveal how many times an offender has been challaned before. A driver's licence can be revoked if its holder is challanned thrice.

Speaking at the event, the CM said, “It is everyone's responsibility to follow the rules of traffic. Continuous awareness programs are necessary for road safety. The number of accidents has come down in the last one year due to strict police action against traffic violators.”

“The purpose of police is not to cut challans but to protect people’s lives. Action should be taken against those who violate the rules. Challans and punishments can be helpful in following the rules but discipline is the only way to avoid accidents,” Rawat added.

The state government has sanctioned 20 new vehicles to the police for traffic arrangements in Dehradun. DGP Anil Kumar Raturi said that “it is the responsibility of the police to ensure public safety and they have to deal with difficult situations and challenges with discipline.”

Title: Govt to file offences against 70 insts named by SIT in scholarship scam
Content:
Nagpur: The Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) would be registering offences in the multi-crore scholarship scam against 70 educational institutions named by the Special Investigation Team (SIT) after the probe by the Enforcement Directorate (ED) is completed.

Relief and Rehabilitation minister Vijay Wadettiwar, who informed this to media recently, said that the SIT report would be tabled in the cabinet to decide future course of action.

The ED probe was set up by previous state government led by then chief minister Devendra Fadnavis. According to officers who were part of SIT, the previous BJP government failed to initiate any action despite assurances by the former CM.

The SIT had confirmed the scam, which was exposed by TOI in 2013, after inspecting audit reports of just around 14% — about 1,704 — of state’s colleges availing scholarships. Based on this, it had arrived at misappropriation of Rs2,174 crore in scholarship distribution in these colleges. TOI had first published the SIT report on August 20, 2017.

About 24 offences were lodged against colleges, including two from Nagpur, and students before formation of the SIT on January 15, 2016.

The SIT strongly recommended probe by Criminal Investigation Department (CID) and Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB). The panel adopted the audit method and was able to inspect only 13.43% colleges coming under tribal development department and 15.11% of social welfare department in 35 districts of Maharashtra. The audit reports are based on documents received from the colleges.

The scope of the scam could be massive as SIT so far has managed to audit only about 14.21% institutions while 85.79% is yet to be inspected, the officers said.

The SIT directly named about 70 institutions, mostly belonging to Congress, NCP and some BJP leaders, and recommended criminal offences against their chairmen/directors. The government had directed officials from social welfare and tribal development departments to register FIR against the culprits, but no action was taken till date.

The SIT mentioned that in all the cases it was found that all students who received scholarship grants were fake.

The SIT had actually recommended probe using three methods — physical verification of students getting scholarships, inquiry through police in various districts and towns, and audit. But due to stay from the court, the panel managed to collect information through audit method only, the officers said.

Irregularities found by SIT

* Students granted admissions on duplicate transfer certificates

* Amount distributed even as courses were not recognized

* Scholarships granted to more no. of students than sanctioned intake

* Even for short-term courses, scholarships were illegally distributed

* Same students were shown taking scholarships from different institutes

* Scholarships taken on names of bogus students who didn’t exist

* Even management quota students offered scholarships without eligibility

* Students were distributed grants without verifying caste validity certificates

* Non-existent colleges granted amount on bogus documents

* Even failure students were awarded funds without authentic documents

Title: Cantt board cuts water supply of 85 consumers for defaulting tax
Content:
Nashik: Cantonment Board, Deolali (CBD) has disconnected water connections of 85 consumers in the area as they had failed to pay the water tax.

“These defaulters have not been clearing water tax dues for several years despite our constant follow-ups. Now, we have decided to disconnect their supply, which will only be restored after the dues are cleared. Our action against will continue,” said CBD officials.

There are nearly 6,500 water supply connections from the board. The consumers have to pay water taxes every six months.

In the last six months, the board has collected nearly Rs 68 lakh from the consumers.

“But during that period, the total amount that was supposed to be collected as water tax amounted to more than Rs 73.54 lakh. A large number of consumers have failed to clear the tax dues,” said board officials.

According to CBD vice president, Bhagwan Katariya, the board had to take this harsh step as the board needs money to provide proper services to the residents.

The current rate of water charges in the cantonment area is Rs 4.21 per litre which was last revised in June 2018.

Apparently facing problems in collecting water tax from a section of the residents, CBD has now planned to take an advance amount for new water connections.

The civic administration has placed a proposal before the board to seek its approval on this issue.

At present, CBD takes a deposit of Rs 2,120 as advance payment from applicants seeking water connections. The applicants have to produce documents like rent receipts, no objection certificates from property owners, ownership titles recorded in 7/12 extract.

“The move to increase the advance is a wise thing to do. If they fail to pay the tax, the board can use the advance money paid to adjust the pending dues,” added the board vice president.

The cantonment board has a water tank of 10 lakh litre that supplies water to the whole cantonment area with the help of four overhead tanks.

The water is supplied for one-and-a-half-hours in the eight wards of the area.

Title: Gujrat: PIL filed against mining mafia
Content:
Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: An NGO, Lion Nature Foundation , has filed a PIL in the Gujarat high court seeking directions to concerned authorities to stop illegal mining in the 10km buffer zone around the Gir National Park and Wildlife Sanctuary for protection of environment and wildlife. The petitioner demanded that the government be asked to repair, restore and re-vegetate the area in accordance with established forestry practices. The power company should be asked to cut electricity supply to all offenders involved in illegal mining. The government should also be ordered to recover wealth amassed illegally by the mining mafia.

The PIL has requested the HC to ask authorities to take immediate steps to terminate all leases in the buffer zone, which are found to be involved in illegal mining and in violation of the Forest Conservation Act and other laws. The PIL has demanded that the authorities be asked to submit a list of quarry leases granted within the 10km buffer zone and submit a report of steps undertaken to implement the December 15, 2011 resolution, which prohibited mining in the area.

The PIL has urged the HC to appoint an expert committee to ascertain the damage already caused due to illegal mining. It has also sought action against officials who are found complicit in the illegalities.

The petitioner said that for any project, including mining, in the 470.5 sq km area of buffer zone around Gir sanctuary, prior environment clearance and recommendation of standing committee of National Board for Wildlife is required.

Title: Climate activists take up signature campaign
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Deepri Palla — a school student from the city who has been campaigning for the last 14 weeks as part of the ‘school strike for climate ’ campaign — has now found support in Extinction Rebellion (XR), Vizag and Fridays For Future (FFF), Visakhapatnam. The groups, along with Palla, have initiated a signature campaign titled ‘Signature for Future’.

The objective of the campaign is to spread awareness about the significant issues about climate change.

The green organisations staged a demonstration at YMCA, RK Beach on Saturday with members holding placards like ‘If you breath air, you should care’ and ‘One Earth, One Chance’.

The petition that they are carrying around states, “Environmental protection is the responsibility of the government that can be achieved along with individual efforts. We would like to remind the people of the present deteriorating condition of the environment, the impact of which is grave.”

Title: Ayodhya readies for mandir construction
Content:
Chairman of the Ram Temple Construction Committee Nripendra Mishra (2nd from right) and senior VHP functionary... Read More

AYODHYA: Heavy earthmoving machines rolled into the Ramjanmabhoomi premises in Ayodhya on Saturday afternoon, marking the beginning of construction of the Ram Mandir.

The chief priest of the makeshift temple, Acharya Satyendra Das , said, “Machines have begun levelling land and clearing bushes and heavy thickets… It’s a joyous moment for Hindus in India and abroad as we are now free from 500 years of slavery.”

The 67.7-acre compound also houses more than 12 ancient temples, including the Ram Janamsthan and the Sita Rasoi , which are in ruins. No rituals have been performed here since 1993, when land was acquired by the Centre. There’s still no word from the Ram Mandir Trust — it will lay out the blueprint of the Ram Mandir — on whether these temples would be renovated or annexed into the greater temple design. Dr Anil Mishra , a trustee, said, “The Trust will decide the fate of these structures and on restarting worship.”

As was first reported by TOI, Ram Lalla idols will be shifted 150m from the sanctum sanctorium towards the north-east during nine days Ram Navami to make way for construction of the temple. Highly placed sources in the office of Ayodhya royal Bimlendra Mohan Pratap Mishra confirmed this to TOI.

The Vishwa Hindu Parishad has also finalised moving carved and uncarved marble to the Ramjanambhoomi premises.

The shifting of stones will take place from the rear of Ayodhya town at night to avoid traffic snarls.

Title: Shatabdi crushes two on Ludhiana crossing
Content:
Smashed vehicles on the tracks after the accident in Ludhiana

LUDHIANA: Two people were crushed under a train and two were injured when they were negotiating the "closed" Giaspura railway crossing in Ludhiana at 8.15pm on Saturday.

Government Railway Police officials confirmed the death of Ratanjit Singh, 63, and Gurpreet Kaur, 26. Two other commuters - Sunny (21) and Arjun Kumar - were injured in the accident. Two scooters, two motorcycles and one cycle were smashed in the accident.

Northern Railway officials claimed that the accident occurred as the commuters tried to pass the crossing that had been closed ahead of the trains' arrival. Sunny, one of the injured, however blamed the accident on the confusion caused by gates opening for a short while. He said some of commuters were at the crossing when a train went towards Ambala, after which the gate opened and then shut, all within a few seconds, followed by the Shatabdi's arrival on other track, and running over those trying to cross over.

Railway officials rule out technical error

However, chief area manager, Ludhiana railway station, Parminder Singh, said the crash was not caused by any technical error.

He said, “As the people were crossing the tracks, two trains reached there on different tracks. First the Chandigarh-Amritsar Intercity going toward Am ritsar passed through. Then the Amritsar-bound Shatabdi Express arrived and hit the two-wheeler riders on the second track. After we received a message in the control room, a team was sent to the spot. We also deploy the Railway protection Force (RPF) during the peak hours, but people still cross the closed gates, risking their lives,” he said.

PRO, Northern Railway, Deepak Kumar said all the gates were closed and there was no error.

(With inputs from Saurav Arora)

Title: Dadar hotelier kills himself, son in native Udupi
Content:
Gopalkrishna Rai with his son & wife

MUMBAI: Gopalkrishna Rai, a 52-year-old hotelier from Dadar, committed suicide with his six-year-old son Aneesh in his native town near Udupi, Karnataka. The bodies of the father-son duo who went missing from Nethravati Bridge on February 16 washed ashore on Friday at Mattu beach in Udupi district .

Rai ran the popular orchestra bar, Leena Restaurant and Bar in Dadar. He lived in Mira Road and had business interests in Dombivli. A native of Bantwal, Dakshina Kannada district, Rai had gone to attend a function at his wife's house with his family a fortnight ago. He left with his son while the function was under way on the morning of February 16. Rai's wife Ashwini did not accompany them.

Their car was found abandoned near Nethravati Bridge and a suicide note was recovered from the car, which said they were jumping into the river. Police had conducted search operations in the river for five days.

Their decomposed remains were identified by Ashwini and Rai's brother Harish. On Saturday the autopsies were completed and the bodies were handed over to the family for last rites. Harish, who works in Mumbai, said, "We cannot fathom why he became so depressed. He had no trouble within the family."

Title: Thane: Insect kills one at station on Matheran line
Content:
Representative image

THANE: A 35-year-old man from Neral died after he was bitten by an unidentified poisonous insect close to Jummapati railway station near Neral on Saturday morning.

The railway police from Karjat said initial investigations revealed Dinesh Temare (33), who was found unconscious along the tracks near the platform of the narrow gauge Neral-Matheran railway line, might have been bitten by a venomous insect.

"The man was found on Saturday morning, following which he was rushed to the nearest hospital, where he was declared dead," a police official said. "We are awaiting an autopsy report."

The railway police lodged an accidental death case.

Title: Rs 111-crore terminal for Nerul-south Mumbai boat service by May
Content: NAVI MUMBAI: The Rs 111-crore Nerul passenger water terminal , funded by Cidco, will be ready around May, and Maharashtra Maritime Board (MMB) will operate speed boats and catamarans to Ferry Wharf, Gateway of India and Elephanta.Cidco MD Lokesh Chandra told TOI, "The terminal, behind DPS and NRI colony, should be ready in May. MMB is selecting an operator. Sailing time will be 30-35 minutes. There will be catamarans with capacity of 100-150 passengers and smaller boats. The vessels will be AC and non-AC.'' The catamarans will be AC.The project has two phases. Phase II will have a RoRo service and a direct trip to Mandwa. A survey will be undertaken to study phase II. There's no need for dredging in the first phase, as the water depth of 3-4 metres is available, while the requirement is a two-metre depth for operating passenger boats in the first phase. The second phase will require dredging for bigger vessels.The waterway transportation project, for which tenders were to be floated in 2016, took time because of green clearance over CRZ and a small mangrove patch. The project had envisaged six months for clearances, but it took nearly 17 months. The project was scheduled to be flagged off in May 2019. Boat travel will save time compared to road travel and reduce air pollution besides offering a scenic coastal view.The project is under revenue sharing model with Cidco, a major stakeholder, MMB and an operator the maritime board will select. Around 25 years back, a hovercraft service was available from Vashi and Belapur to SoBo.

Title: Forces to stay longer in J&K as Syed Ali Shah Geelani health sparks unrest fears
Content:
File photo of Syed Ali Shah Geelani

SRINAGAR: Withdrawal of additional forces from Kashmir has come to a halt in the wake of rumours that 90-year-old separatist Syed Ali Shah Geelani ’s health is fast deteriorating, a J&K administration official said on Saturday.

At least 400 additional companies of CRPF , BSF, ITBP and SSB were brought into Kashmir the day before August 5 last year. In December, on the directions of the ministry of home affairs, 72 companies of additional forces were withdrawn from Kashmir.

Now, J&K authorities apprehend law-and-order problem in the Valley in case Geelani passes away, which may trigger violence, the official said.

A CRPF official, requesting anonymity, said there were thorough deliberations of the security grid, both in New Delhi and Kashmir, in the wake of strong rumours about Geelani’s deteriorating health.

“Earlier in February, rumours about Geelani’s fast-deteriorating health had raised serious concerns on law-and-order front. Keeping this is in view, the MHA took a decision that further withdrawal of forces should be halted immediately,” the officer said.

Another reason why additional forces are not being withdrawn could be the impending by-elections to nearly 12,000 vacant panchayat seats and the upcoming tourist season, he said.

Title: Confident India can ensure return of peace: Indonesia
Content:
NEW DELHI: The Indonesian government called in Indian ambassador in Jakarta Pradeep Rawat and raised concerns over the Delhi riots which have until now claimed 42 lives.

It said in a statement later that the government of Indonesia had complete confidence that the government of India will be able to manage the situation and ensure “harmonious relations among its religious communities”. “Moreover, both countries share similar characteristics as pluralistic countries that uphold democratic values and tolerance,” it said. In a separate statement, the Indonesian religious affairs ministry described the riots as “inhuman” and contrary to religious values.

There was no official reaction from India. Rawat was quoted as having said in his response by the Indonesian media that the situation was now under control and that everything was peaceful. “What I will convey to you, is a press release from our home minister for your reference,” Rawat said following a meeting with Indonesia’s coordinating minister for political, legal and security affairs Mahfud MD in Jakarta. “We advise our friends to not believe false news that is being brought out by personal interests to mislead and by those trying to disrupt our country’s diversity.
