As Indonesia has the spirit of unity in diversity, India also believes in the same principles,” he added, according to a report in Antara news agency.

Title: Violence may lead to radicalisation: Imran Khan
Content:
Pak PM Imran Khan (File Photo)

In the aftermath of communal violence in Delhi, Pakistan PM Imran Khan on Saturday warned that "state-sponsored" terror through police may lead to radicalisation of Indian Muslims, reports Omer Farooq Khan ."In Delhi carnage of Muslims, state-sponsored terror through police & RSS gangs is going to lead to radicalisation of the 200 mn Indian Muslims just as the Kashmiri youth has been radicalised through the oppression of Indian Occupation forces & deaths of almost 100,000 Kashmiris (sic)," he tweeted along with photographs of a burnt mosque and Muslim families in distress.

Title: Monkey menace bites Mohali, 26 cases in two months
Content:
In 2019, 231 cases were reported.

MOHALI: Be careful when you visit prime sectors of the city beautiful on foot. Handle your belongings carefully as monkey menace is on the rise and can attack you anytime.

The fear of monkeys has taken a toll in the city and surprisingly, most of the cases are being reported from the prime sectors.

According to the data provided by the officials of the Sector 19 dispensary, which is the closest sectors and where 70% of the monkey attack cases are reported, a total of 26 cases have been reported till Thursday this year.

Mandeep, a resident of Sector 7, said, "The municipal corporation (MC) should pull up their socks and not leave a single spot of garbage. As monkeys come here and find fruits for themselves in garbage bins."

"In 2019, 231 cases were reported and most of them were from Sector 7 and Sector 8," said Narinder, one of the officials at the Sector 19 dispensary.

Harkirat Singh Saini, a resident of the Sector 8, said, "Monkey menace is a common sight in our sector. Monkeys come on the top floor of our house and open the doors themselves. It has been many times that they have taken fruits kept inside, but now we keep our doors locked as it is risky for all of us."

Meanwhile, experts claim that monkeys are scared of snakes and one should keep looking for snakes within their surroundings or at rooftops or boundary wall of your house.

Debendra Dalai, chief conservator of forests, UT administration, said, "Many cases are being received from Sector 8. In the past three years, if one goes by the data, approximately 690 monkeys were caught by our officials in the city and were released in the forest area."

The official further said one should not feed monkeys and if anyone was found doing the same, legal action would be taken.

According to health officials, monkey-bite cases are treated at six places in the city, including civil dispensaries in Sector 19 as well as one is in Sector 38. For emergency cases, officials claimed that one could visit Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), Sector 16, civil hospitals in Sectors 22 and 45 as well as Manimajra any time.

Title: Mumbai: RPF man dies trying to save a life 2 days after becoming dad
Content:
Ranveer Gurjar

Mumbai: A Railway Protection Force (RPF) constable, whose wife delivered a baby boy two days back, was killed after a fast Virar-Churchgate local hit him between Bandra-Mahim stations on Friday. Ranveer Gurjar was on patrol duty at 10.45pm, to check for fatka gangs along tracks, Bandra railway police said.

Gurjar who was with his colleague, constable Rahul Pawar (29), spotted a man walking along the tracks at a distance. Pawar told railway police, "We rushed to help him, on spotting a fast train coming from Bandra. The train hit Gurjar as he failed to duck and move one side." Gurjar had reported to work around 8pm.

The accident was witnessed by Pawar, who had little time to react, before the train heading towards Dadar hit Gurjar. Bandra police senior inspector Vilas Chougule said Gurjar, from Thakurli RPF headquarters, was posted with Bandra Barack RPF. "Pawar said they feared the train would hit the man. The 55-year-old physically challenged man, from Mahim , had gone to answer nature's call," said Chougule.

A case of accidental death report has been registered.

Gurjar, who hailed from Pancholi village in Rajasthan, was survived by his wife, a daughter and the baby and his parents.

Police said RPF HQ informed Gurjar's family about the incident. His cousin brother reached Mumbai on Saturday around 4pm and took his body from Nair Hospital. Gurjar's cousin Rajeshyam (35) told Bandra police that his wife and parents were shattered. An RPF battalion accompanied Gurjar's brother in Golden Temple Mail for the final salute in this village.

Title: Mantri’s fresh salvo against ‘anti-nationals’
Content:
SHIVAMOGGA: Karnataka agriculture minister B C Patil on Saturday repeated his controversial comment that those raising slogans against India should be shot dead.

“People who raise slogans like ‘Pakistan Zindabad ’ are anti-nationals. Anyone who dares to say ‘Hindustan Zindabad’ in Pakistan will be beheaded in five minutes. Aren’t people residing in India and shouting ‘Pakistan Zindabad’ traitors?” he asked. This is a repeat of the comment that Patil, a former police officer, made last Sunday at Chitradurga that anti-nationals should be shot dead. When asked about it, he defended his statement and said he “will repeat it anywhere in India”.

He also urged the Centre to frame laws “to tackle such anti-national elements”. Two weeks ago, Karnataka tourism minister C T Ravi had tweeted in support of Union minister Anurag Thakur , who led a crowd into chanting “shoot the traitor” slogan at a poll rally in Delhi. “Anti-nationals should get bullet and not biryani,” he had tweeted. Revenue minister R Ashoka had said “anyone indulging in anti-national activities” should be shot dead.

Title: Watch out! BMC to renew its plastic ban drive from Sunday
Content:
Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation

MUMBAI: After state environment minister Aaditya Thackeray 's statement on making Maharashtra single-use plastic free by May 1, BMC has decided to renew its plastic ban drive from Sunday, by going the extra mile to make it a success with the help of a squad sporting navy blue jackets.

BMC has decided to take an undertaking from marriage hall managements, institutions and schools that they will not allow single-use plastic material on their premises, like spoons, plates and glasses. The squad will also check act against visitors using plastic at gardens.

Environmentalist D Stalin said, "BMC should penalize people with plastic in public places, but after imposing a nominal penalty. They should act against big institutions by imposing heavy penalties. BMC must also conduct drives at night to act against hawkers using plastic. These are few things that can make the drive successful, instead of making it complicated by exploring multiple options that are not workable."

The ban is Shiv Sena's pet theme and Thackeray was pushing for, during the previous state government, a ban on single-use plastic in 2018. BMC started its drive in June 2018, and till date has seized 86,000kg plastic material and recovered Rs 4.6 crore as fines after examining around 16 lakh premises.

Most of this took place during the initial days, when it started acting against big shops, malls and fast-food chains.

There was no political will and the drive slowed down gradually, said officials. Now, Thackeray is environment minister, and his party is ruling the state, so officials are taking keen interest.

An official admitted the drive slowed down due to lack of clarity, non-availability of alternatives and inadequate awareness campaigns. Civic officials stated that they will continue acting against shops, malls and food chains, apart from trying to include other stakeholders in the drive. They said they will create awareness at BMC schools, asking students to collect plastic at home and deposit it at school for recycling. Most BMC school students come from slums. BMC will then encourage private schools to adopt similar measures.

A civic official said, "Plastic was coming into the city from neighbouring states after the ban. Since last October, single-use plastic is banned across the country, so we do not expect plastic to come in. But extended producer responsibility (EPR) are a matter of concern. It was decided that plastic water bottle manufactures would develop a mechanism to collect used plastic bottles for recycling, but it has not happened."

Title: Ambala: Man throws acid on pregnant wife, held
Content:
Representative image

AMBALA: The Ambala police on Saturday arrested a man, who had reportedly attacked his four-month pregnant wife with acid on Friday evening.

The victim had suffered around 40% burn injuries in the attack that took place in Alawalpur village of Ambala district. "The accused was arrested on Saturday evening. He has been identified as Anil of Ravidas Pura in Karnal. He will be presented before the duty magistrate on Sunday,' Ambala superintendent of police (SP) Abhishek Jorwal said.

The woman was out for an evening walk along with her brother's wife when she was allegedly attacked with acid by her husband, Jorwal added.

As per sources, the woman had come to her parents' house in Alawalpur village from Karnal and on Friday evening; she was out for an evening stroll with her sister-in-law when a motorcycle-borne man attacked them with acid, resulting in injuries to both of them. Sources added that the main target was the pregnant woman.

"We received information about an acid attack on two women in Alawalpur village from the MMU Hospital in Mullana. After the attack, both women were rushed to the hospital by their family members and villagers. A case has been registered on the complaint of the victim's sister-in-law against the accused under Section 326-A (voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and further investigation is being done," said Barara police station house officer (SHO) inspector Hamir Singh.

"The pregnant woman has received around 40% burn injuries on her face and stomach. She has been kept on ventilator and the next 72 hours are critical for her. Her sister-in-law has suffered 18-20% burns in the attack. Both of them are undergoing treatment at MMU Hospital in Mullana," said Jorwal.

He added, "It was the husband of the pregnant woman who attacked her with acid. As she was accompanied by her sister-in-law, some acid splashed on her as well. We have rounded the accused up and further investigation is being done. So far, the exact reason behind this crime is yet to be ascertained."

Title: Sharon Stone shares 'samosa packet' pic showcased by CAA protesters
Content:
KOLKATA: Days after Pink Flyod co-founder Roger Waters read an English translation of Aamir Aziz 's "Sab yaad rakha jayega", Hollywood actor Sharon Stone has shared an image of a samosa packet that is being used by "a joint artists' protest in solidarity with mass protests in India". In her Insta story post Stone has commented: "These are so interesting."

Titled #turbinebagh, this "samosa packet movement" will exhibit its works at the Turbine Hall at London's Tate Modern on March 28; the exhibits will include a samosa packet made out of a photograph taken at an anti-CAA/NRC/NPR rally in Kolkata. A screenshot of Stone's post was shared on the Instagram handle of this movement.

Title: Property tax: BMC acts tough, nets Rs 350 crore in week
Content:
Sumer builder’s site furniture and computers were seized on Saturday

MUMBAI: BMC received Rs 350 crore as property tax in the last week after it started taking strong action against defaulters by attaching their properties, including movable assets.

The civic authority's property collection target for the current financial year is Rs 5,400 crore, of which it has collected Rs 3,500 crore till February. In March, it hopes to collect the remaining Rs 1,900 crore, after exerting pressure on defaulters to clear dues.

Ward officers, who have been told to act against defaulters by seizing their movable assets, last week seized two helicopters. BMC has already attached 3,179 properties and disconnected water supply of 213 for non-payment of Rs 1,645 crore property tax dues.

Civic official also started shaming defaulters by making loudspeaker announcements on pending dues where such properties are situated or where owners of these properties live. BMC had published a list of defaulters in newspapers whose property they have attached for non-payment of taxes and initiated the process of seizing their movable assets for auction to recover the dues.

Despite that, civic officials are struggling to increase collections. An official stated that most of the major defaulters are builders or land-owners. He said, "Due to a slowdown in construction market, they are not clearing pending property taxes, as it is last on their priority list. Through the action, we are sending a message to defaulters to clear dues."

BMC seized Sumer builder's site office furniture and computers at Reay Road for defaulting on Rs 22 crore property tax on Saturday. It also sent notices to three partners to clear payments at the earliest to avoid further action.

BMC's property tax collection has been dropping over the last few years, and is expected to drop further as the government, as part of election promises, has decided to exempt flats measuring below 500 sq ft. Property tax is the biggest revenue source for BMC ever since octroi was abolished.

Title: Minor held for raping seven-year-old in Mohali's Dhakoli
Content:
Representative image

MOHALI: The Mohali police have arrested a juvenile for allegedly raping a seven-year-old girl in Dhakoli around 12 days ago.

According to the police officials, the juvenile used to work as a labourer in Peer Muchalla.

A case has been registered after the girl's mother lodged a police complaint. "In her complaint, she alleged that her 7-year-old daughter had gone out to play where some unknown miscreant lured and fled after raping her," said a cop.

He added that the girl's mother told them that at around 10pm, she found her daughter at the back of their residence.

A case under sections 376 (punishment for rape) and 377 (unnatural offenses) of the IPC and the Pocso Act has been registered against the accused at Dhakoli police station.

Dhakoli station head officer sub inspector Sumit Mor said, "The accused was arrested on Friday night. He was produced in juvenile court that sent him to juvenile home on Saturday."

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Param Bir Singh new Mumbai police chief
Content:
MUMBAI: After two names were shortlisted for the post of Mumbai police commissioner, DGP of the Anti-Corruption Bureau Param Bir Singh was chosen over Pune police chief K Venkatesham. It was NCP which tilted the scales in Singh's favour, if a IPS officer is to be believed.

"Our information is that while Shiv Sena was in favour of K Venkatasham, he missed the bus following reservations expressed by the NCP," the IPS officer said. It was under Venkatasham's leadership that the Pune police registered offences in the Elgar Parishad case.

Title: Hyderabad: Man arrested for raping daughter
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 45-year-old man was arrested by police on Saturday for allegedly making a bid to rape his younger daughter at his Dundigal home. The accused was caught by his wife while he was trying to sexually assault their daughter on Friday night.

More shocking details tumbled out on Saturday when his elder daughter broke her silence and revealed that her father had been raping her for almost a year now.

Dundigal police arrested and booked a rape case against him.

Wife caught him in the act as he tried to abuse younger daughter

Police said the accused had made attempts to sexually assault the younger daughter (12) in January also. “Both girls, along with their parents, sleep in the same room. After midnight, the accused would sexually assault his elder daughter when his wife was asleep. On Friday, the woman woke up and saw her husband trying to abuse their younger kid,” Dundigal inspector A Venkatesham said.

The girls are in Class VI and V. Police said the elder daughter is mentally unstable. “When he was confronted by his wife, his 14-year-old elder daughter revealed that she had been sexually assaulted multiple times in the past one year. He had threatened to kill her and her sister if they speak about their ordeal,” the inspector said.

It was only after he was caught red-handed, the elder daughter mustered courage to speak about her abuse, the inspector said. In fact, the accused had even threatened to kill his wife when she confronted him. Following a complaint by his wife, the accused was arrested on Saturday and booked under Pocso Act.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Lok Janshakti Party to release manifesto 6 months before Bihar polls
Content:
Lok Janshakti Party Chief and MP Chirag Paswan ( Picture credit: ANI )

NEW DELHI: In a bid to break the convention when it comes to election strategies, Lok Janshakti Party will release its manifesto or vision document on April 12, nearly six months before assembly polls are scheduled in Bihar.

LJP chief Chirag Paswan , who is trying to invoke Bihari pride by launching a ‘Bihar First Bihari First’ campaign in the state, told TOI that manifestos should be the centre of a campaign, not caste or religion.

“Political parties should come out with their manifesto quickly so that elections are fought on developmental issues rather than caste and religion. We saw in Delhi how the entire campaign centred around religion and caste. We can’t blame people as they don’t come to know about the manifesto. How can they weigh options when parties release manifestos just days before polling? In some cases, manifestos are released after one round of nominations are filed,” the LJP supremo said.

The second time MP from Jamui claimed that the main intention behind his new campaign is to revive the pride of the state and its people against the present bad perception of ‘Bihari’ as a derogatory remark. Though sources said LJP is targeting a bigger role for its young chief by 2025 and the ground work has begun with this campaign, Chirag said the main aim of this initiative is to bring the development agenda to the forefront during the election.

Claiming that the campaign is not merely for elections, he said, “It’s our aim to push development in the state. Since Independence several states have grown, but we have been lagging behind. This has been a matter of concern for us. The CM has done a lot by building a solid base. But we need to make it number one. We will come out with a complete road map; we need work across all sectors — health, education, law and order and infrastructure.”

He added the campaign will reach out to all sections of the society and put greater focus on students and professionals such as doctors, lawyers, middle class, service class and farmers.

Title: Civic body banks on BPS as town planning revenue dips
Content:
Visakhapatnam: At a time when the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) is struggling to reach its target revenue , the civic body’s building penalisation scheme (BPS) has come as a blessing in disguise.

While the city’s civic body has been able to realise just around Rs 90 crore through the town planning wing by giving permissions for construction as of Friday, the building penalisation scheme has fetched GVMC around Rs 50 crore.

Revenue from town planning wing permissions has come down significantly. In the 2018-19 fiscal, GVMC had earned Rs 163 crore and in 2017-18, the civic body had earned Rs 146 crore by giving permissions for construction plans of housing and commercial complexes.

GVMC officials attribute this drop in revenue to increased issuance of TDRs (transferable development rights) as compensation to landowners over the last two years and the consequent utilisation of TDRs. Thus, it is the BPS scheme that is helping GVMC’s town planning wing to compensate for the decreased revenue in building plans.

According to GVMC, the civic body received 6,166 applications under BPS when the scheme made a comeback in 2019. GVMC had disposed 3,800 applications till 6pm Saturday— the last day to process BPS applications— to generate revenue of nearly Rs 50 crore. The municipal corporation has sent intimation letters for payment of balance amounts in documents to around 1,400 applicants.

Now, if the state government does not extend the deadline again as it has done in the past, the processing of applications may end on Saturday midnight.

Through BPS, GVMC regularised constructed buildings that had deviations from the sanctioned plan or completely unauthorised structures. Building owners whose applications have been processed and approved will be issued occupancy certificates.The scheme however is not applicable for buildings constructed on government land or on prohibited areas under CRZ (coastal regulation zone) norms.

Title: Gold biscuits worth over Rs 50 lakh seized at Visakhapatnam airport
Content:
10 gold biscuits seized at Visakhapatnam airport on Saturday

VISAKHAPATNAM: In a major haul, customs officials of the Visakhapatnam international airport seized 10 gold biscuits weighing 1,166 grams worth Rs 51.5 lakh on Saturday.

According to reports, the gold was seized from two passengers who had arrived in Visakhapatnam from Dubai via Hyderabad.

The passengers, identified as Noorul Huda and Rafaqat Ali, have been arrested.

Sources informed that the passengers are from Uttar Pradesh. While one of the passengers boarded the flight in Dubai, another boarded in Hyderabad. The gold was exchanged in the flight on the way to Visakhapatnam.

Title: District gets ready to host Inter exams
Content:
Visakhapatnam: With the Intermediate examinations set to commence from March 4, education officials of the district are busy finishing arrangements.

This year, a total of 109 examination centres are being set up. The question paper set for the first exam has already been dispatched to concerned centres.

Speaking to TOI, B Sujatha, regional inspection officer of the board of intermediate education said, “I request students to check their examination centres a day before the examination so as to avoid last minute confusion. I further request students to turn up at examination centres by 08:30am.”

Sujatha further said that the examination centres should display the route map at two to three places on the way to centres. “Once the exam has started, non-teaching staff should immediately leave the centre. We conducted a meeting with concerned district officials on the examinations at Dr LB Bullayya College yesterday (Friday),” added Sujatha.

Around 56,369 students (including those enrolled in vocational courses) will appear for the first-year examinations. For the second-year examinations, nearly 53,929 students are slated to appear. Examinations will be conducted under CCTV surveillance at all centres.

The district administration has identified 12 problematic centres in the district. Additionally, the Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (APSRTC) will run special buses for the convenience of examinees.

56,369 students (including those enrolled in vocational courses) will appear for the first-year examinations, while 53. 929 will appear for second-year exams

Title: 1 held for fracas during Naidu visit, Pendurthi MLA under house arrest
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The city police have begun to issue section 41 notices to the people involved in the airport melee on February 27. Meanwhile, a person was taken into custody by the airport police on Saturday.

TDP president Nara Chandrababu Naidu’s convoy was allegedly obstructed by YSRC cadre on Thursday for almost four hours and the leader was forced to go to Hyderabad following a section 151 notice issued against him by the city police.

In this connection, West Zone police have begun taking action against the persons involved in the incident. They have been trawling CCTV footage and photographs to identify the people. “We are trying to identify the persons who staged protests and blocked the road on that particular day. We also arrested a person, JT Rama Rao, who tried to immolate himself by dousing himself in petrol after climbing on the roof of a vehicle,” West Zone ACP Swaroopa Rani said.

She further said cops issued section 151 notices to both TDP and YSRC leaders on the particular day. They even put Pendurthi MLA Adeep Raj, leaders Saragadam Chinna Appalanaidu and Demudu under house arrest . “We brought in a lady who hit a sub-inspector. We issued a notice to her and sent her home. We are identifying the persons and issuing section 41 notices,” she said.

Meanwhile, Telugu Shakpresident BV Ram said TDP president Nara Chandrababu Naidu will resume his Praja Chaitanya Yatra in Visakhapatnam next week. He claimed that Naidu will return to Visakhapatnam on March 4 or 5.

Title: Students highlight health, social issues through plays
Content:
Nagpur: The academy of paediatricians of India (API) Nagpur chapter organized ‘Jagar’ (awakening) a street play contest for school students in city on Saturday.

As the contest was organized by doctors, the subjects of the plays were about health awareness, gender discrimination, and environment.

Over 25 schools in city participated in this contest and highlighted themes like cleanliness, fitness, public health, traffic safety, drugs, and addition to mobile phones. Social issues like save girl child, sensitize boys, and gender discrimination etc were also highlighted.

API Nagpur President Dr Shubhada Khirwadkar said that the event was organized as part of the youth connect initiative.

“Children and adolescents need to be educated about personal hygiene, healthy lifestyles, fitness, gender respect and many other issues important for their health in all its dimensions. If these messages are given in the usual didactic way, they hardly make an impact. API Nagpur has come up with a novel way to reach out to children through this contest,” she said.

API joined hands with the South Centre zone cultural centre (SCZCC) to organize this event in their premises. Siddhivinayak Academy of Performing Arts, Tarang Foundation and Inner Wheel Club of Nagpur supported this maiden initiative of API. Paediatricians have decided to connect with school students and spread awareness about prevention of non-communicable diseases and providing CPR training during this year.

“Street play is the most effective and popular medium of giving social messages. Children conveyed appropriate health messages in an interesting and effective manner today. Some of the actors were very talented and I have offered them to join theatre movement with me,” said senior theatre activist Sanjay Bhakre, who was one of the judges of the contest. Adolescence health specialist Dr Nishikant Kotwal, physician Dr Smita Desai, and veteran journalist Barkha Mathur were among the jury.

Dr Avinash Gawande, Medical Superintendent of Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) was the chief guest. “Street plays are simple, effective and low-cost way to share social messages impactfully. Students who presented these plays must have learnt a lot about these important themes,” he said.

It was a novel experience for doctors to coordinate a theatrical event, said API Nagpur secretary Dr Mustafa Ali.

Title: City girl to represent India in talent contest
Content:
Visakhapatnam: 6-year-old girl from the city, L Dhruvika Aaryana has been selected to represent India at Little Miss Galaxy— an international-level talent show to be held in Bulgaria from March 26 to April 2.

Speaking on the occasion, Dhruvika, a student of Ralla Bella School said, “I feel blessed to represent my motherland at an international platform. This is an amazing opportunity for me to meet my peer group from around the globe.”

Dhruvika’s mother Shimpy Kumari said, “We (the parents) ensure that she balances her academics and her extra-curricular activities. While she attends dance classes regularly, she spends her weekends by participating in science workshops, storytelling sessions and other competitions.”

Previously, Dhruvika had won the ‘Best Talent’ award for her dance performance in ‘Smart Kid Andhra Pradesh’— a state-level contest for school students.

Title: Delhi violence disturbing, govt must remain secular: Amartya
Content:
Santiniketan: Nobel Laureate Amartya Sen is “deeply concerned” and “disturbed” with the violence in Delhi and wants peace to return to the country’s capital. The government should govern by allowing free public interaction instead of slapping “sedition” charges on dissidents, Sen said on Saturday.

“I am deeply concerned with what happened in Delhi. Delhi is the country’s capital and centrally-governed territory. Now, there are incidents of torture on minorities because most of the victims are Muslims. We have to find out why it is so. Were the police unable to tackle the situation? Or was there any shortcoming in the government’s initiative? Our country has a secular name. We can’t distinguish between Hindus and Muslims. But if that happens, there is a reason to worry. I am proud that I am an Indian citizen. I feel disturbed,” he said after speaking at a Pratichi Trust programme in Santiniketan.

The senior philosopher and economist, however, refrained from making any comment with finality. He said he was asking certain questions on the recent developments in Delhi out of concern.

Sen didn’t see any contradiction between restoring peace in the capital and the different views aired by political parties to attain peace. “Peace is important. But that doesn’t mean that the discourse over why it happened or ways to bring peace will hamper the peace process. There is no reason to believe that there is a contradiction between the two,” he said.

Sen also raised the transfer of Delhi High Court judge S Muralidhar, who was hearing the Delhi violence cases. “It is a big question. I know him personally. His transfer came at a time when he was trying to help out people. But I don’t know why he was transferred. The government must have an answer,” he said.

The Nobel Laureate reserved his comment on the government’s decision to serve a notice to the Visva Bharati student from Bangladesh to leave India after she uploaded a photograph of an anti-CAA demonstration on her Facebook wall.

“I have read it in the newspaper. The government must have reasons to take such action. We need to know from the government what the reasons are,” he said.

Sen reiterated the need for the government to remove opaqueness in decision-making. “Democracy is a government by discussion,” Sen said quoting John Stuart Mill and held that the government should allow free public interaction. “If government decisions are taken after public deliberations, then their opaqueness disappears. On the contrary, efforts to silence critics by slapping sedition charges do not help democracy,” Sen said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Chinese yuan offtake comes to a halt in Kolkata
Content: KOLKATA: For the first time in recent memory, foreign exchange units in Kolkata have stopped transactions in Chinese yuan , a currency that was being bought and sold in impressive volumes till the novel coronavirus outbreak brought an abrupt end to trading around 10 days ago.With both business and leisure travel to China coming to a halt, forex units are refusing to buy yuan. “We are not purchasing yuan now as there is no possibility of trading in it under the current circumstances. Once travel to China resumes, trading in yuan will restart,” said A K Dutt, director of RN Dutt & Sons that has been in the currency exchange business since 1887.The only two currencies to witness suspension in trade in recent years were the Qatar riyal and Kuwaiti dinar after both countries faced external conspiracy and aggression. But neither currency traded in high volumes.The Chinese yuan , on the other hand, has emerged as one of the most popular currencies in the past decade following a sharp rise in business and leisure travel to the country and introduction of direct flights to Kunming and Guangzhou apart from Hong Kong.Till January, around 4,000 people from Kolkata — businessmen and holidayers — were travelling to China every month. That has dramatically changed since the news of outbreak hit headlines. There were very few travellers in the first week of February. And, no one has travelled to any Chinese city from Kolkata in over a fortnight now, leading to a crash in the demand for yuan.Kirshore Majumdar of Lakshmi Narayan Air Travels that also deals in forex said purchase of the Chinese currency was unofficially suspended by most forex traders in Kolkata around a week ago. At the time, yuan was being purchased for Rs 9.20 and sold for Rs 10.50.“All money changers are holding some Chinese currency but there are no takers. Similarly, many businessmen who regularly travelled to China and a few holidayers who were about to depart for the country but were forced to cancel their trip are saddled with yuan that they cannot sell,” said Travel Agents’ Federation of India chairman (east) Anil Punjabi.Dutt explained that holding the Chinese currency at a time like this entails risks as one doesn’t really know the kind of volatility it may encounter if the country remains isolated for a prolonged period due to the nCoV outbreak. It has already had a ripple effect on China’s economy — and the global economy — as many factories remain closed, disrupting supply chains and impacting revenue.Also with nCoV spreading to other countries, travel to the entire region has dropped drastically. This has led to a dip in all forex trading in the past week.While the US dollar is by far the most traded foreign currency in terms of value in the city, euro, Japanese yen, UK pound, Thai baht, Singapore dollar and Arab Emirate dirham are the other major currencies traded in Kolkata. The currency that is traded in the highest volume in Kolkata is, however, the Bangladeshi taka.

Title: NCP nixed Shiv Sena’s choice, leaned on ally to pick Param Bir Singh as Mumbai police commissioner
Content: MUMBAI: After two names were shortlisted by the Maha Vikas Aghadi for the post of Mumbai police commissioner , DGP of the Anti-Corruption Bureau Param Bir Singh was chosen over the other contender, Pune police chief K Venkatesham. It was the NCP which tilted the scales in Singh’s favour, if a senior IPS officer is to be believed.“Our information is that while the Shiv Sena was in favour of K Venkatasham, he missed the bus following reservations expressed by the NCP,” the IPS officer said-.The state home ministry is with the NCP.Though Singh had held a press meet on the Elgar Parishad case in his capacity as additional DGP (law and order) to show “proof” against the accused, it was under Venkatasham’s leadership that the Pune police registered offences in the case against activists. NCP chief Sharad Pawar has claimed that the activists have been framed and that the role of Pune police must be probed and has pushed for an Special Investigation Team.Singh, on the other hand, had been directly handling, as DGP of the ACB, the multicrore irrigation scam case involving NCP leaders Ajit Pawar and Sunil Tatkare. In his affidavit filed before the Nagpur bench of the Bombay high court in December last year, Singh had granted a clean chit to Ajit Pawar, who is now deputy CM.Though in political circles, there was speculation over whether the NCP had favoured him for this reason, a senior ACB official claimed that the clean chit had been granted to Ajit Pawar during BJP rule. “It was in July 2018, when the BJP was in power in the state, that the water resources department wrote to the ACB saying all proposals were cleared at the level of the water resources department secretary and as per rules of business, the cabinet member is not responsible for decisions taken by the department,” the official said.Significantly, Singh’s affidavit granting Pawar a clean chit was filed a year after Barve’s affidavit on the scam, in which Barve – who was then heading the ACB -- had obliquely blamed the political leadership, saying the scam needed in-depth investigation.Sources said the search for Barve’s successor as city top cop began a week ago after the Sena-led government took a decision not to grant further extension to him following objections raised by the NCP. In fact, NCP had objected also to the way CMdesignate Uddhav Thackeray had granted him a second extension on November 27, a day before he was sworn in.When deliberations began, there were more than a half-a-dozen senior IPS officers in the zone of consideration, among them MD of police housing corporation Bipin Bihari, state security corporation MD D Kanakratnam, DG (legal) Hemant Nagrale, DG (ACB) Singh, SID commissioner Rashmi Shukla, ADG (law and order) Rajneesh Seth, Pune top cop Venkatesham and Thane police commissioner Vivek Phansalkar.The senior IPS officer said that there was a long discussion on whether the Mumbai police commissioner should be of DG or additional DG rank. “There was a vertical split in the Maha Vikas Aghadi government as one section felt the CP should be of DG rank, while the other section said that he should be of additional DG rank. Even as these discussions were in progress at the political level, the names of Param Bir Singh and Venkatesham were shortlisted,” he said.

Title: Chennai: 8-month-old girl abducted from Elliot's rescued
Content:
Joy Of Reunion: Dcp (Adyar) P Pakalavan With The Rescued Baby And Her Parents At Adyar Police Station On Satur... Read More

CHENNAI: Scanning footage from as many as 150 CCTV cameras from Besant Nagar to Jafferkhanpet, police on Saturday rescued an eight-month-old girl, less than 36 hours after she was kidnapped from her mother's side on the Elliot's beach, and arrested five people including a juvenile. While K Manikandan, 26, of Jafferkhanpet, A Thirupathi Ammal, 42, of Saidapet, and S Mary, 35, and her son S Ruben, 19, of Saidapet were sent to jail, the minor, daughter of Thirupathiammal, was admitted to the correctional facility in Kelly's.

Police said Manikandan's elder sister Pandi Meena, who worked as a maid, didn't have children and was desperate for one. Through a common friend she came to know of Thirupathiammal, who allegedly made a living as a surrogate mother, and Mary. Pandi Meena then told Manikandan, 26, who offered the two women 2 lakh for a child, an officer said.

After trying to get some narikurava women in Besant Nagar to sell a baby, Mary and Thirupathiammal decided to steal one when the women refused, he added.

On Thursday night, Mary, Ruben, Thirupathiammal and her daughter went to the Elliot's beach. Around 2am on Friday, they went to the skating rink. One woman sat close to Rajeshwari and her mother Sneha, narikuravas from Kumbakonam. Around 4am, Selvi woke up and found her daughter missing. She rushed to the nearest police station with her niece. A case was registered but police found no CCTV camera at the spot. About 100 metres away, a camera caught four people including two women boarding an autorickshaw.

Police questioned an auto driver who confirmed the four had boarded his vehicle and that one woman carried a child. Police checked footage from CCTV cameras at Chinnamalai near Saidapet and at Jafferkhanpet. One showed the gang handing over the child to Manikandan, a second showed him walking home with the girl and a third had him handing her over to Pandi Meena.

On Saturday afternoon, a police team landed at Manikandan's house and later rescued the girl from Pandi Meena's house. She was reunited with her parents in the evening.

Adyar assistant commissioner Vinoth Shantharam who formed the special team and its members sub-inspectors Jai Ganesh and Karthikeyan and constables Thirumurugan, Pushparaj, Damodharan, Senthilkumar, Venkateshwaran and Vinod won praise from commissioner A K Viswanathan.

Title: A strongroom door that won’t open is at the heart of 47-yr-old royal dispute
Content:
The attempts to open the strongroom are part of the evaluation exercise of royal treasures so it could be divi... Read More

RAMPUR: It was a bit of an anticlimax when the family of the erstwhile nawab of Rampur (UP) gathered at the sprawling lawns of Khasbagh Palace this week to witness the opening of a strongroom — now at the heart of a decades-old inheritance dispute — and its six-tonne door refused to give away. Despite several hours of drilling, five expert welders armed with an array of tools — gas cutter, pulling machines and grinders — managed to chip through only one of the multiple layers of iron on the eightfeet-tall door on Wednesday.

This was the sixth in a series of futile bids to open the strongroom which was built in the 1930s by Nawab Raza Ali Khan . In fact, the only time the room was breached was during a break-in back in 1980 when thieves had entered through the roof and made away with valuables. Today, no one really knows what’s behind the sealed door. The reason: Very few royals have actually seen the inside of the strongroom since its keys were lost decades ago. Speculations have been rife about the riches it could hold.

The attempts to open the strongroom are part of the evaluation exercise of royal treasures so it could be divided among family members of Nawab Raza Ali Khan. Raza Ali Khan — who had acceded to India in 1949 — was survived by three wives, three sons and six daughters. The government recognised the eldest of his three sons—Murtaza — as the sole inheritor as per the customary law. But this was challenged by his siblings, spawning a 47-year-long legal battle. In 2019, the Supreme court ruled that the property would be divided among all family members according to Muslim law .

The property assessment is now being done by the Rampur district court following apex court’s orders. As part of the exercise, the locks of an armoury in the 450-acre palace were opened to reveal carved guns, gem-studded swords and knives while a garage was hiding vintage cars imported from the US and Europe, among them a Plymouth (1957), Dodge convertible (1954), Austin convertible (1956), Buick (1939) and Jeep Willys (1956). Other properties to be divided among 18 claimants include the 200-acre Benazir Bagh Palace, Sarhari Kunda, Shahbad Bagh Palace and a private railway station, all in Rampur.

On March 24, another attempt will be made to open the strongroom. Court-appointed commissioner Saurabh Saxena said he was hopeful they would be able to get through this time.

Some family members said they have little expectations about what the room would yield. Nawab Kazim Ali Khan, son of former Congress MP Begum Noor Bano, wife of Murtaza’s younger brother, told TOI, “The strongroom used to house Basra pearls, trays filled with diamonds, emeralds, sapphires and rubies. It also contained a crown, carpets with stone-work, heirlooms and sword scabbards. But I believe little is left now.”

Nawab Muhammed Ali Khan, Murtaza’s son, whose mother had the keys to the strongroom insists they were never found. “My mother was a cancer patient but she passed away suddenly during treatment in Mumbai in 1993. The keys were never found,” said Khan, who lives in Goa and was in Rampur with sister Shehzadi Naghat Abedi for the evaluation.

“The family opened the strongroom ahead of Muharram every year. Gold alams (plates) and silver tables were taken out for rituals. I don’t know what’s inside because I lived abroad until my mother’s death and there was a theft as well. We were told that thieves had entered through the roof and stolen valuables from the strongroom. The theft was discovered after a child found a part of a gold plate in the palace premises,” he said. Rampurbased historian Nafis Siddiqi said very few people were even aware of a strongroom in the palace until the evaluation started. “This is the first time, many have heard of a strongroom full of treasure in Khasbagh. It has evoked a lot of curiosity here,” he said.
